Description: large stone with hollowed out trough at top and inscription "1666 / Plague".  Until about 1910 the stone stood by the side of the Chapeltown road on the site of the lower end of Reginald Terrace.  It is believed that the basin was filled with a mixture of
WebDescription: large stone with hollowed out trough at top and inscription "1666 / Plague".  Until about 1910 the stone stood by the side of the Chapeltown road on the site of the lower end of Reginald Terrace.  It is believed that the basin was filled with a mixture of vinegar and water, and that the inhabitants of the city in purchasing produce brought in from the neighbouring countryside dropped their coin into the water, whence it was extracted by the farmer, without direct contact of the coin from hand to hand.

Description: toby jug in the form of an 18th century man
WebDescription:
This Toby jug  shows a man with his bottle of beer.  Unfortunately his pipe is missing!

It is part of the Stephen Cliff bequest left to Leeds Museums in 1928.

Description: white porcelain tea cup with black lines round  border and black transfer print of "BRIGGATE  LEEDS", engraving dated 1870; unmarked
WebDescription:
White porcelain souvenir tea cup with a black transfer print of "BRIGGATE  LEEDS". The engraving is dated 1870.
This view of Briggate shows the site of the Moot Hall after it had been demolished for road widening.  The 1829 Corn Exchange seen in the distance was demolished in 1869 to make way for New Briggate, which proves that the view was already out of date when the cup and saucer were made.

Description: sausage making machine, wood with brass fittings
WebDescription: A sausage making machine, made of wood with brass fittings.  This was an early exhibit at Abbey House Museum and was displayed in the "Old English Room" in 1943.

Description: large dolls house, model of Tudor-style timber  framed house, black and white, with date "18 MC  83" over door; 2 storeys; known as "Abbey Grange"
WebDescription: This house is known as Abbey Grange

Description: large dolls house, model of Tudor-style timber  framed house, black and white, with date "18 MC  83" over door; 2 storeys; known as "Abbey Grange"
WebDescription:
This mock Tudor style house was donated to the museum in 1948 by Miss Maude Cooper.  In the 1880's Miss Cooper spent her childhood with her family living in Abbey House, Kirkstall and the dolls house belonged to her as a child.  The initials in the inscription '18 MC 83' over the door are thought to be those of Miss Cooper.  Known as Abbey Grange, this style of mock Tudor house can be found in other dolls houses of the period.  Access to some of the rooms is via the front but others are accessed from the back.  On some of the internal doors there are detailed pictures of characters. When the house was donated it was fully furnished with nineteenth and twentieth century furniture and at some stage it was installed with electrical lighting.
The Cooper family rented Abbey House from 1883 to 1890.  Leonard Cooper was an industrialist who owned the Airedale Hematite Company in Hunslet, which manufactured pig iron for Kirkstall Forge.

Description: penny farthing bicycle, 1870s
WebDescription: Penny farthing bicycle, 1870s.  The popular nick-name "penny farthing" is based on the discrepancy in size between the larger penny and smaller farthing in pre-decimal coinage.

Medium/Materials: metal, iron; metal, steel; wood; leather
Description: bone shaker bicycle, leather saddle, carrier  affixed to front, large front wheel, small rear  wheel
WebDescription: A "bone shaker" bicycle with a leather saddle and a carrier fixed to the front.  It has a larger front wheel and small rear wheel, but the size difference is not as marked as with the penny-farthing.  The nick-name "bone shaker" relates to the fact that there is no suspension and the tyres are solid.

Description: small animal trap, wooden block with four holes all set with wire sprung traps
WebDescription: Small animal trap, designed as awooden block with four holes all set with wire sprung traps, probably to catch mice or other rodents.  This was part of the private museum collection amassed by Miss Emily Wardman of Wetherby who died in 1939.

Description: serpent, wood and brass, in two halves, bound with  cloth or leather and painted; 5 silvered keys on  metal saddles; metal stays across the coils and  ferrules at 2 ends; bone mouthpiece; wide end  turned slightly outwards (suggestion of George  III); ivo
WebDescription:
A serpent (a bass wind instrument descended from the cornett), made of wood and brass, bound with cloth or leather and painted.  It has five silvered keys on metal saddles, metal stays across the coils and ferrules at two end.  It has a bone mouthpiece and a wide end  turned slightly outwards.  There are ivory or bone liners in all tone holes and it is marked H. Cockroft, Haslingden.
H. Cocroft of Haslingden seems to have been a bookseller.  In 1836 he published a book called "The duel, the Batlle of Waterloo and other poems" by L. O. Shaw - which might fit as someone who also owned a serpent horn.

Description: meerschaum pipe or cheroot holder carved in shape of horse with case (pipe stem missing)
WebDescription: Meerschaum cheroot (or cigar) holder carved with a surmounted running horse, in its original case.  "Meerschaum" is the German for "foam of the sea" and refers to a soft white mineral (magnesium silicate) which was often found floating in the Black Sea and was often used to make pipes.

Description: blue and white (Delft-type) glazed ceramic  jar, with brass lid; marked "STOKVIS" (meaning  "dried cod" in Dutch)
WebDescription: A blue and white (Delft-type) glazed earthenware storage jar, with a brass lid. It marked "STOKVIS"  whic means "dried cod" in Dutch.

Description: coloured print on silk, framed and glazed; "Mr.  T.P. Cooke as WILLIAM (in Black Eyed Susan)",  printed, J. Fairburn, Minories, London; picture of  man in sailor suit
WebDescription: coloured print on silk, with the title "Mr. T.P. Cooke as WILLIAM (in Black Eyed Susan)",  printed by J. Fairburn, Minories, London. "Black Eyed Susan" was a nautical melodrama by Douglas Jerrold which was performed at the Surrey Theatre, London in 1829.

Description: model theatre, Pollocks, c.1880; with scenes,  characters and scripts for "Aladdin", "Sleeping  Beauty", "Robinson Crusoe", etc. (showing "Jack  and the Beanstalk" in display)
WebDescription: A model theatre, printed by Pollocks, about 1880.  It is complete with scenes, characters and scripts for "Aladdin", "Sleeping  Beauty", "Robinson Crusoe" among others and the show currently on display is "Jack  and the Beanstalk" .  Pollocks famously published toy theatre sheets that were "penny plain" and "tuppence coloured".  This is a coloured version.

WebDescription: A moustache cup and saucer, white glazed earthenware with gilt dusted rims and coloured brown transfer print of floral sprigs.  It is made for a left-handed user.  There are no marks on the underside except "Made in England".

WebDescription: A wooden chair with and advertisement  for "Watson's Matchless Cleanser" soap set into the back. The chair made in Scotland, and is marked "Registered design, F  East, Dundee".  Joseph Watson and Sons Ltd was a Leeds based soap manufacturer, affectionately known as "Soapy Joe's".

WebDescription: A large blue grocer's canister with a painted picture of  an industrial scene.  This would have been used for storing dry goods, such as tea.

Description: wooden doll's cradle, covered with cut-out  coloured scraps, including motto "Continue Ye in  My Love"
WebDescription: A wooden doll's cradle, covered with cut-out  coloured scraps, including motto "Continue Ye in  My Love". This is an example of the Victorian love of decoupage, decorating objects with cut-out printed images which were produced for the purpose.

Description: clear glass bottle or flask, with label "Ess: Kiss Me  Quick", in black letters on a gold bordered white  ground. It contains a yellow liquid
WebDescription: This clear chemist's bottle is labelled "Ess: Kiss Me Quick", in black letters on a white label with a gold border. It contains the remnants of a yellow perfume or eau de toilette.  "Kiss Me Quick" was one of perfumes created by Jean-Baptiste Rigaud, a French perfumer of the 19th century, who marketed many of his scents with an English name (which was fashionable in Paris in the 1850s).

WebDescription: A cast iron matchbox holder, in the shape of mule or donkey carrying a pack.  It is stamped R.22410, indicating that the design was officially registered.

WebDescription: A travelling inkwell in the form of a black tin top hat. The umbrella attached beneath the crown contains a pen.

Description: glass fly trap, hand blown with three feet
WebDescription: A hand-blown glass fly trap bottle.  The cavity ring would have been filled with beer or a sugar solution to attract the flies who would then be unable to escape and eventually drown.

Description: toy duck, with green velvet head and neck, yellow  leather beak, and green painted tin feet; wearing  green coat, pink waistcoat, white shirt, blue tie  and brown trousers; manipulated by metal rod  fitted into back
WebDescription: A toy duck, with a velvet head and neck,  leather beak and painted tin feet.  He is wearing a green coat, pink waistcoat, white shirt, blue tie and brown trousers.  The toy can be manipulated by a metal rod  fitted into the back.

Description: board game, "THE PATHS OF LIFE"  board only; coloured lithograph, mounted in 20  sections on linen; a map with numbered routes from  "Parental Care Hall" to either "The Peaceful Ocean"  or "The Bottomless Pit".
WebDescription: board game, "THE PATHS OF LIFE" , coloured lithograph, mounted in twenty sections on linen.  It consists of a a map with numbered routes from  "Parental Care Hall" to either "The Peaceful Ocean"  or "The Bottomless Pit".

Description: opaque greenish glass bottle, moulded base,  "Clarksons Leeds Melbourne", Registered Trade Mark  - a horse, pat. 28th August 1871
WebDescription: Glass mineral water bottle marked "Clarksons Leeds Melbourne", including a Registered Trade Mark  of a horse, patented 28th August 1871.  The rounded base meant that it would have to be stored on its side, which would keep the cork moist and stop the carbonated water going flat.  Thomas Clarkson had his mineral water premises on Melbourne Street, Leeds from about 1863.

Description: toy wooden aeroplane, green, with swastika on tail
WebDescription: Wooden model aeroplane made by Mr L. H. Fuller of Roundhay, as part of an set of model aeroplanes (British, American and German) originally bought by the museum in 1947.  The green livery and swastika on the tail indicate that this one represents the German Luftwaffe.

Description: clear glass soda syphon, raffata covering, metal  tap on top, "Made Soley by / the British Syphon  MFG. Co. / London England"
WebDescription:
This  glass soda syphon with raffata covering is marked "Made Soley by / the British Syphon  MFG. Co. / London England". 

These devices were also known as "gasogenes".  The lower contained water or other drink to be made sparkling, the upper a mixture of tartaric acid and sodium bicarbonate that reacted to produce carbon dioxide.

Description: one of pair of vases, circular body, on bridge base; painted dark green, with a bird in flight;  impressed on base BF (monogram) / 298; plus  signature RB 933 (& RB 936); RB = Robert Bond, Burmantofts Faience
WebDescription: One of a pair of Burmantoft vases with a circular body painted dark green with illustration of a bird in flight. The base has been impressed with the monogram BF plus  signature RB 933 (& RB 936). Made by Robert Bond, Burmantofts Faience

Description: glass Hamilton bottle (pointed base), embossed  HARSTON & CO / TRADE MARK / LEEDS
WebDescription:
This is an example of a "Hamilton" bottle, designed to lie on its side.  Made for carbonated drinks such as lemonade, the idea was that the cork would thus remain moist and not let the contents go flat.  
The bottle is embossed  HARSTON & CO / TRADE MARK / LEEDS.

A 1924 advertisement for Harston & Co. says "Ask for Hartson's Table Waters - specialities Stone Ginger Beer, Dry Ginger Ale, Lemonade, Soda Water, Fosferzone, Hop Ale".

Description: enamelled metal ashtray for "Leeds Daily News",  ALL NEWS 1/2 HOUR IN ADVANCE OF ANY RIVAL only  paper with exclusive private wire London to Leeds.
WebDescription: enamelled metal ashtray for "Leeds Daily News",  ALL NEWS 1/2 HOUR IN ADVANCE OF ANY RIVAL only  paper with exclusive private wire London to Leeds.

Description: Burmantofts jardiniere, globular, moulded with  Viking ships (or oriental?) against a sunset  picked out in dark blue, brown, green and yellow;  impressed "BURMANTOFTS / FAIENCE / 2218 C /  ENGLAND"
WebDescription: Burmantofts jardiniere, moulded with  images of  Viking longshipsagainst a sunset  picked out in dark blue, brown, green and yellow.  It is  impressed "BURMANTOFTS / FAIENCE / 2218 C /  ENGLAND" on the base.

Description: ornamental vase, globular lower section  and tall flared neck; entwined with heavily  modelled fierce reptile with monkey clinging to  side; liberally applied with foliage and branches  and naturalistically painted with coloured slips  on a graduated blue
WebDescription: A ornamental hall vase, entwined with a heavily modelled fierce reptile chasing a monkey clinging to the rim.  It is marked on the base with the BF monogram (for "Burmantofts Faience") and has the signature of E. Hammond, plus the incised date 1882.  Edward Hammond was one of several artists who worked on designs for Wilcock & Co. at Burmantofts in Leeds which raised the profile of the company's venture into art pottery in the 1880s.

Description: ornamental vase, globular lower section  and tall flared neck; entwined with heavily  modelled snake looking up at bird sat on rim;  liberally applied with foliage and branches  and naturalistically painted with coloured slips  on a graduated blue ground;
WebDescription: This ornamental hall vase is entwined with a heavily modelled snake looking up at bird sat on the rim.  It is marked with the "BF [monogram]" (Burmantofts Faience) and the painted initials "RB" (probably relating to Robert Bond),  plus the incised signature "V. Kremer 1881".   Victor Kremer was one of several artists who worked with Wilcock & Co. to produce designs for their art pottery range in the 1880s.

Description: large bulbous vase, cream and pale blue ground  with entwined winged dragon in green, brown etc.;  impressed on base "BF [monogram] / 170";  Burmantofts
WebDescription: This large hall vase with its modelled design of an entwined winged dragon does not have an artists signature, but is typical of the flamboyant designs produced for Wilcock and Co. in the 1880s. It  impressed on the base "BF [monogram] / 170";  standing for Burmantofts Faience.

Description: hall vase in shades of blue, three dimensional  sculpted crocodile entwined around vase, monkey on  branch of tree; blossom pink  marked "BF [monogram]"; side marked "E.HAMMOND  1882"
WebDescription: This hall vase has a sculpted crocodile entwined around the body of the vase, eyeing up a monkey perched on the branch of a tree.  It is marked with  the "BF [monogram]" (standing for Burmantofts Faience) and  is signed  "E.HAMMOND  1882". Edward Hammond was one of several artists who worked on designs for Wilcock & Co. at Burmantofts in Leeds which raised the profile of the company's venture into art pottery in the 1880s.

Description: green glass poison bottle with stopper, l19thc, label LIN: BELLADON:
WebDescription: A green ribbed glass poison bottle from a chemist or pharmacey.  It has the label "LIN: BELLADON:"  which stands for Belladonna Liniment. This was a very concentrated tincture of Belladonna (commonly known as deadly nightshade) intended for external use only.  It was intended as a pain relief in particular to relieve rheumatism.

Description: metal gyroscopic toy; Japanese man sitting  cross-legged holding fan in left hand and parasol  in right; string is wound round top of parasol,  and pulled; parasol spins round and is pulled  upwards operating interior mechanism causing fan  to be moved up
WebDescription: This is a small metal gyroscopic toy, representing a Japanese man sitting  cross-legged holding fan in his left hand and a parasol  in right.  A string is wound round top of parasol and when pulled the parasol spins round and is pulled upwards operating an interior mechanism causing the fan  to be moved up and down.

Description: green glass bottle, "John Parfitt / Trade Mark /  Woodhouse / Leeds", with marble stopper, man. by  Redfearn Bros / Bottle Makers/ Barnsley
WebDescription: This is an example of a Codd bottle, designed by Hiram Codd in the 1870s to solve the problem of keeping soft drinks carbonated.  The specially shaped neck held a marble which would seal against a rubber ring at the neck .  When opened the marble was pushed down into the neck.    This bottle was made for John Parfitt of  Christopher Road, Woodhouse, Leeds who was first listed as a Mineral Water Manufacturer in 1897.  The bottle was made by  Redfearn Bros. of Barnsley.

Description: pressed sheet steel coffin plate or plaque, child praying "OF SUCH IS THE KINGDOM OF HEAVEN"
WebDescription: This coffin plate has the image of  child praying and the motto "OF SUCH IS THE KINGDOM OF HEAVEN".  It was probably for use on child's coffin, reflecting the high levels of infant mortality in the Victorian era.   It is made of pressed steel with details picked out in black enamel.

Description: Rotary knife cleaner by Geo Kent, 199 High Holborn  London, c1880; circular wooden drum mounted on  cast iron support, contains 2 cleaning plates  turned by a crank on the side; holes for inserting  4 knives and larger grip for carving knives; label  show
WebDescription: This rotary knife cleaner is designed by Geo. Kent, 199 High Holborn  London.  It consists of a circular wooden drum mounted on cast iron supporst, and contains two cleaning plates turned by a crank on the side.  There are holes for inserting up to four knives and larger grip for carving knives.  The label on the front shows the correct mode of use.  It is marked "size no.7 No.10933".  Before the advent of stainless steel, steel cutlery had to be frequently cleaned of rust and tarnish.

Description: cast iron toy elephant, with moving legs and  trunk; will walk down inclined slope; stamped  "PATENT / 1873" on one side
WebDescription: This cast iron toy elephant, with moving legs and  trunk, is designed to walk down inclined slope.  It is stamped  "PATENT / 1873" on one side.

object width (base): 325mm
object depth (base): 325mm
Description: chimney pot, with square base, round collar with serrated lip; known as "bishop" from resemblance to chess piece; originally from donor's house built in 1870
WebDescription: This style of chimney pot was known as the "bishop" from its resemblance to a chess piece.  It came originally from the donor's (Mr J H Lapping) house in Shadwell, Leeds, which was built in 1870.

Description: paper roll organ, "THE REED-PIPE / CLARIONA", man.  Merill-Gally, New York USA, last patent 1883
WebDescription: This paper roll organ is named "THE REED-PIPE CLARIONA", and was designed by Merill-Gally, New York USA.  It has a list of patent datees between 1866 and 1883.  Merill Gally claimed to have invented the organette (although others also claimed the same).  His designs seem to haev been sold by mail order.  The "reed pipes" were wooden channels which sat above the reeds to help resonate the sound, but had to be removed and replaced every time the paper roll was changed.

Description: vesta case, rectangular, silver, with picture of owl embossed on one side
WebDescription: This silver vesta case is embossed with the picture of an owl on one side. It was made to hold an early type of match known as a wax vesta (Vesta was the Roman goddess of the hearth).  There is a ribbed groove on the underside of the case to strike the match.

Description: white glazed feeding cup with side handle and  spout, blue underglaze transfer printed floral  decoration (incl. wild roses), blue printed mark  "13 / Copeland / Late Spode"
WebDescription: This is a feeding cup with side handle and spout, designed for use by bed-ridden invalids.  Because the spout was difficult to clean properly they were not very hygienic and may sometimes have helped to spread infections rather than cure the sick.  It is made of earthenware with a blue underglaze transfer printed floral decoration including wild roses.  There is a  blue printed mark on the underside:  "13 / Copeland / Late Spode".

Description: bull frog vase, moulded in the form of a Japanese  bull frog on 3 feet; orange yellow glaze;  impressed "583 / BF (monogram) / ENGLAND"
WebDescription: This is one of the quirkier designs of Burmantofts vase and is moulded in the form of a Japanese bull frog  with three feet.  The orange yellow glaze is one of the standard glaze colours used in Burmantofts art pottery.  It is impressed "583 / BF (monogram) / ENGLAND" on the underside. BF stands for Burmantofs Faience.

Description: earthenware dragon figure, green glaze, glass  eyes; Burmantofts; impressed "BF (monogram) /  ENGLAND / 1004"
WebDescription: This earthenware figure of a dragon was made by the Leeds Fireclay Company at  Burmantofts.  It is impressed "BF (monogram) /  ENGLAND / 1004" (BF stands for Burmantofs Faience).

Description: white porcelain mug, over painted in Burgundy red  with white oval inscribed in gold "A Present /  from / Leeds"; unmarked
WebDescription: This white porcelain mug is over painted in red with a white oval inscribed in gold "A Present  from Leeds".  It does not have any manufacturers mark on the base, but was probably made in Staffordshire.

Description: pill roller or pilll making machine (brass ribbed roller and base)
WebDescription: This device is pill making machine which consists of a brass ribbed roller and base.  Pills were made from pliable dough containing the prescribed medical ingredients.  This would be rolled and cut into uniform-sized pellets by this pill cutter.  They could then be rolled into balls and coated with sugar or silver using a separate device.

WebDescription: This pale green glass bottle was used for port and is labelled "Geo. W. Blackburn,  Fine Old Port, Duke of York, Beeston Hill, Leeds.

Description: hexagonal concertina in wooden box; instrument (register says label on instrument reads "Lachenal & Co. / Patent  Concertina Manufacturers / London")
WebDescription: This hexagonal concertina in its original wooden box.  The label on the instrument reads "Lachenal & Co., Patent  Concertina Manufacturers, London".

Description: clockwork toy pig, dressed in felt clothes,  carrying suitcase (containing clockwork  mechanism); man. Schuco Patent, Germany
WebDescription: This clockwork toy pig, dressed in felt clothes and carrying suitcase (which contains the clockwork mechanism) was made and patented by Schuco of Germany.

Description: school abacus, square wooden frame on wooden  stand, painted green; in frame mounted 10 iron  bars (2 missing) horizontally, each with ten  wooden balls on them (originally each row painted  a different colour)
WebDescription: This wooden school abacus came from St Matthew's School in Chapel Allerton, Leeds.  It will have been painted a standard Leeds School Board green sometime during the early 20th century.

Description: prosthetic or artificial hand, wood, with  adjustable fingers and joints, made by donor's great grandfather Charles Fozard (with a penknife) for his wife Ann Fozard
WebDescription: This prosthetic or artificial hand, wood, with adjustable fingers and joints, was made by the donor's great grandfather Charles Fozard (with a penknife) for his wife Ann Fozard.

Description: iron model of town crier (or clock seller), with  small pendulum clock attached to front of his  chest; model painted, wearing to hat and carrying  bell in one hand, stick in other
WebDescription: This iron model of town crier (or clock seller), with a small pendulum clock attached to front of his chest does not have a visible manufacturers mark, but was probably made in either the Black Forest (Germany) or Vienna (Austria).

Description: pear shaped pottery ashtray, brown glaze with  relief moulded picture of early steam engine or  locomotive "AD 1811"; impressed "MIDDLETON /  LEEDS"
WebDescription: This ashtray was made by the Middleton Fireclay Works, Leeds to commemorate the centenary of the first commercially successful steam locomotive (the "Salamanca") which was patented by Matthew Murray in 1811 and commissioned by John Blenkinsop to run on the Middleton Railway.

Description: egg beater, cylindrical with  hand turned gear mechanism with works whisks,  wooden handle; with brass plaques on front marked  GRIFFITHS' PATENT / 1 5417 / (royal coat of arms)  / SIZE NO. / KENT / SOLE MANUFACTURER / 199 HIGH  HOLBORN LONDON // T. BRIGG
WebDescription:
This devise was probably an egg beater and has a  hand turned gear mechanism which works the whisks. It has also been previously suggested to have been an ice-cream maker, but this does not seem to match the patent information.   The brass plaques on the front are marked  "GRIFFITHS' PATENT 1 5417  (royal coat of arms)  / SIZE NO. / KENT / SOLE MANUFACTURER / 199 HIGH  HOLBORN LONDON // T. BRIGGS & SONS. / LEEDS / TOP  OF ALBION ST."  
T. Briggs and Sons were ironmongers who were in business from 1848 to at least 1910.

Description: white porcelain mug with black transfer print of  "KIRKSTALL ABBEY"; marked "H. FOGGITT / RD. NO.  92391 / KIRKSTALL"
WebDescription: This mug and other souvenirs like it were sold by Mr H. Foggitt from his shop on commercial road in Kirkstall at the turn of the century. This particular design was registered in 1888, the year that the abbey was sold to Colonel North and probably appeared on all kinds of Kirkstall Abbey memorabilia.

Description: black glazed earthenware teapot; double spout;  with detachable lid; green band with flowers  around top, gold patterning elsewhere
WebDescription: This black glazed earthenware teapot has a double spout in order to be able to pour two cups at once.

Description: copper tea urn with lid, copper body stands on  four legs, elaborate brass fittings (Napoleonic  eagles), bone handles; late Georgian
WebDescription: This highly decorated tea urn stands on four legs protruding from a base. Six eagles are incorporated into the design and the spout is made of brass.  It is typical of late Georgian style.

Description: white glazed pot marked "The Improved Rational  Plate Washer", Rd. No. 261705, GRANITINE.  For use in photography.
WebDescription: This ceramic vessel is marked  "The Improved Rational  Plate Washer", Rd. No. 261705, GRANITINE and was designed for use in developing photographs from glass quarter-plate negatives. Granitine was a trade name for a range of darkroom products produced by Taylor, Tunnicliff & Co. of Hanley, Staffordshire, from about 1887.

Description: cream stoneware jar with waxed paper lid, 'Moorhouse's  Fig Jam,
WebDescription:
This cream stoneware jar with waxed paper lid is labelled for  'Moorhouse's  Fig Jam".  This was made at  William Moorhouse & Sons'
of Leeds.  The figure of a baker was later replaced by the more child-like advertising mascot figure known as "Sonny Sunglow".

Description: large food storage tin with picture of dog holding a duck on side; grocer's
WebDescription: This storage tin or canister would have been used to keep dried goods in a grocer's shop.  It is illustrated with picture of hunting dog holding a duck in its mouth, but probably had no direct relation to the contents of the tin, unless it was possibly intended for dog biscuits!

Description: brown glass bottle, "Kirkstall Brewery / Co. Ltd.  / Kirkstall", writing on lid says "John Smiths  Ltd. / 1912 / BB / Tadcaster"
WebDescription:
This beer bottle is embossed "Kirkstall Brewery Co. Ltd.  Kirkstall".

The Kirkstall Brewery Co Ltd was registered in 1871, and by 1898 the brewery was producing around 72,000 barrels of beer a year. The beer was sold in Leeds, Yorkshire and beyond.

Description: oak infant's high chair, collapsible to low chair by means of hand operated metal ratchet device, complete with tray, presently lined with blue green and blacks lined on white "fablon"
WebDescription: This infant's high chair which is collapsible to make a low chair by means of a hand operated metal ratchet device.  Chairs very similar to this were advertised by the Leeds ironmonger's firm T. Briggs & Sons in 1888.

Title Sort: Grand Bazaar in the Albert Hall, Mechanics Institute, Leeds
Description: G Bownas, Grand Bazaar in the Albert Hall, Mechanics Institute, Leeds, signed and dated June 26 1867,  watercolour heightened with white, in an arched  mount, framed, slightly faded
WebDescription:
This watercolour shows the "Grand Bazaar in the Albert Hall, Mechanics Institute, Leeds".  It is signed by the artist G. Bownas and dated June 26 1867.  This event would have been a privileged preview event for the new Mechanics Institute which had been newly built by the architect Cuthbert Brodrick and was officially opened in 1868.

The Leeds Institute now houses the Leeds City Museum, opened in 2008. This space is now called the arena.

Description: green glass bottle, "The / Armley / Brewery /  Ltd."
WebDescription: This beer bottle is embossed "The Armley Brewery Ltd."  Armley Brewery Limited were based in Marquis Street, Cross Kiln Street & Beeston Hill with offices in Armley Road.  There core business was supplying malt to other breweries.

Description: French ornate gilt chiming clock; depicts small  birds in coloured beads, butterflies and flowers;  pendulum action, chimes only when hand is moved  manually; movement has "AB" stamped on the back  plate and is numbered "2265" with a matching  pendulum; t
WebDescription: This French ornate gilt chiming clock is decorated with images of small birds, butterflies and flowers made in coloured beads.  It has a  pendulum action, and chimes .  The movement has "AB" stamped on the back  plate and is numbered "2265" with a matching  pendulum; The mark may refer to Achille Brocot  (1817-1874). The clock case is cast either in  brass or bronze with AB 527 cast into it. The dial and decorative panels are porcelain. The clock forms part of a garniture set with two matching vases.

Description: wooden opener for Codd bottle
WebDescription: This simple wooden device is designed as an opener for a Codd bottle and serves to push the marble down from the rubber seal in the bottle's neck.

Description: Tool for making Bee Skeps.  In making Bee Skeps the straw is pushed through a hollow bone so as to bind it together. Made from a sheep shank bone, shaped like a claw, coloured and gilded.
WebDescription: This strange object is an apple corer.  These were often made from sheep shank bone so that they didn't rust, bend or discolour the fruit.  This example has been shaped like claw, coloured and gilded.

Description: Bone apple corer.  Usually made from sheep shank  bone as didn't rust, bend or discolour the fruit.;  shaped like claw, gilded
WebDescription: Bone apple corer.  These were usually made from sheep shank bone as didn't rust, bend or discolour the fruit.. It is shaped like claw and gilded.

Description: lead tobacco jar and lid, oval shaped, embossed shields with Leeds fleece emblem, Bishop Blaize (patron saint of woolcombers) and sailing ships; lid inside jar  for pressing down tobacco
WebDescription: This lead tobacco jar and lid is moulded with symbolic decoration including with Leeds fleece emblem, the figure of Bishop Blaize (who was the patron saint of woolcombers) and sailing ships.  It has an inner lid inside jar  for pressing down the  tobacco.

Description: catalogue, 1892, Simpson, Fawcett & Co.'s  Perambulators, Royal Mail Carts, Tubs, Pails etc., printed by  J. Green lith. Leeds
WebDescription: This is the 1892 catalogue for the Leeds firm of  Simpson, Fawcett & Co.'s and contains "Perambulators, Royal Mail Carts, Tubs, Pails etc.".  It was printed by  J. Green lith. Leeds.

Description: large mustard pot, white pottery, on front in black design of "Genuine Abbey Mustard Warranted Prepared from the Finest Seed at Richard Gay & Co. Mustard & Spice Mills Kirkstall near Leeds" Patterned border surround in border "Manufactured Middlesbro' Pot
WebDescription: This earthenware mustard jar was manufactured by Middlesbrough Pottery for Richard Gay & Co producers of Abbey Mustard. The jar is decorated with a romanticised view of Kirkstall Abbey church. For centuries local businesses have associated themselves with the abbey as a local landmark and as a mark of distinction.

object width (frame): 1145mm
Description: Philip Naviasky, Portrait of Soloman Wolfson Esq.  3/4 length, seated holding a pamphlet, signed and  dated 1927, oil on canvas, framed, presentation  plaque on frame inscribed "presented to Soloman  Wolfson Esq. as a mark of esteem for services  rendered
WebDescription:
This portrait of Solomon Wolfson was painted by Philip Naviasky.  The presentation plaque on the frame is inscribed 'presented to Solomon Wolfson Esq. as a mark of esteem for services rendered 1879-1927 by the members of the Old Hebrew  congregation, Leeds June 1927'.
Solomon Wolfson was listed in the 1881 census as living at 28 Belgrave St, Leeds, aged 19, son, traveller together with Jay Wolfson, lodger, 35, hawker, Henrietta Wolfson, head, 56 and Reuben Wolfson, son, 21, watchmaker.  His father was from Kurland in Latvia and had settled in Leeds about 1846.  His mother was from Amsterdam.  Theirs was the seventeenth Jewish marriage in Leeds and Solomon was born in Leeds.  The family firm was Wolfson's furniture store on Merrion Street, which was founded in 1878.
Solomon Wolfson was President of the Belgrave Street Synagogue, Leeds  from 1923-1927.

Description:
wooden stethoscope (wrongly identified as an ear trumpet (hearing aid))
doctor's wooden stethoscope, mahogany wooden tube in two interfitting sections
(Laennec's wooden stethoscope according to register)
WebDescription:
This is a wooden stethoscope to allow a doctor to listen to a patient's chest and breathing without having to get too intimate and close to the patient.
The stethoscope was invented in 1816 by French physician Rene Laennec.

Description: vase, turquoise green with pale blue, cobalt blue  fluted rim, with tulip type yellow flower; brown  stem and green leaves; marked "BURMANTOFTS FAIENCE  2244 / ENGLAND" and "Col. no. 164"
WebDescription: This Burmantofts vase is glazed with a turquoise green with pale blue, and a cobalt blue fluted rim, with yellow tulip type yellow .  It is  marked "BURMANTOFTS FAIENCE  2244 / ENGLAND" and  "Col. no. 164".

Description: Burmantofts vase - dimpled ovoid body with dimpled  ovoid neck; impressed sunburst pattern; sang de  boeuf glaze; marked on base "BF (monogram) /  ENGLAND / 3"
WebDescription: This Burmantofts vase has a dimpled shape decorated with an impressed sunburst pattern.  This deep red glaze was known as "sang de boeuf" (beef's blood) and was one of the disctinctive colours used by the Leeds Fireclay Co.  It is marked on the base "BF (monogram) /  ENGLAND / 3" (BF standing for "Burmantofts Faience").

Description: pale green glass Codd bottle, with marble,  embossed B. CHAPMAN / GOLD MEDAL /.. / MINERAL  WATERS / ACERADE WORKS / LEEDS  man Redfearn Brothers, Barnsley
WebDescription: This glass Codd bottle, complete with its marble,  is embossed "B. CHAPMAN / GOLD MEDAL /.. / MINERAL  WATERS / ACERADE WORKS / LEEDS".  Benjamin Chapman was a mineral water manufacturer based in Holbeck. The bottle itself was made by the  Redfearn Brothers of Barnsley.

Description: German manufactured bacon slicer;  cast iron base with 4 legs; handle with "Westfalia"  cast into side; removable white enamelled tray  underneath blades, white enamelled circular plate  and oblong plate with design of blue chequers;  circular iron blade
WebDescription: This German manufactured bacon slicer has a cast iron base.  The handle has the name "Westfalia"  cast into the side. There is a removable white enamelled tray underneath the blades and a white enamelled circular plate and oblong plate with design of blue chequers.

Description:
Wilfred Jenkins, Street Scene with figures and trams  at night by Gas Light, signed and dated 1884, oil on  canvas, this view may  be Upper Briggate from just below its junction with  Boar Lane, Duncan St. seen on right 
The horse drawn tram is advertisi
WebDescription:
This painting by Wilfred Jenkins shows upper Briggate from just below the junction with Boar Lane and Duncan Street (which can be seen on the right).  The horse-drawn tram is advertising "Willey's Lion Suits, Kirkgate" and there is a sign for Bean & Son on a building on the right.  J. W. Bean & Son were booksellers based at 149 Briggate.  
This genre of gas-lit night time cityscape became popular after it was pioneered by John Atkinson Grimshaw and his success spawned many lesser imitations including this one.

Description: cast iron garden roller, c1900, manufactured by T.  Green & Co., Leeds; maker's name cast into handle
WebDescription:
This cast iron garden roller wasmanufactured by T.  Green & Co., Leeds.  The maker's name is cast into the handle.

Thomas Green & Son Ltd. were famous for their lawn mowers and made a wide variety of products including wheelbarrows, pub tables, steam rollers, steam trams and vehicles for road sweeping and locomotives.

Description: oil painting, view of  Park Row, Leeds, view northwards from Philosophical Hall, signed  Walter Pinder '90 (or'00), black wooden frame
WebDescription:
This oil painting shows a view of  Park Row, Leeds, view northwards from Philosophical Hall (old Leeds City Museum). It is signed Walter Pinder. 

Donated by the Thoresby Society, the Leeds historical society

Description: card advert depicting soldier on horse for Yorkshire Relish, by Goodall, Backhouse & Co, Leeds
WebDescription: card advertisement for Yorkshire Reslish, depicting a soldier on a horse.  Yorkshire Relish was made by Goodall, Backhouse & Co, Leeds

Description: painted wooden train set; locomotive, goods wagon, 8 carriages, and sloping  wooden track (4 sections), c1845
WebDescription: This painted wooden train set, including a locomotive, goods wagon and eight carriages may date from as early as 1845 which would date it to the the early boom in railway building in England.  It is part of the Sanderson Collection of Costume, Toys and Dolls.

Description: large doll's house, 3 storeys, 13 rooms, stair  cases in centre, 2 chimneys, balustrade around  roof; 6 black painted steps at front; wrongly  known as "Abbey Grange" (see notes below);  probably matches the following "dolls house, time  and style of Will
WebDescription: This is a large and imposing dolls house donated to the museum service in 1948.  It is thought to be mid to late nineteenth century.  This is partly due to the exterior design of the house.  It's sash windows are made with two panes of glass which was more common after the 1840's when technological developments produced glass in larger sheets. In addition the stained glass used in the larger arched window above the entrance is perhaps more in keeping with the later part of the century.  During the nineteenth century there was a revival in the use of stained glass especially in Gothic design and later in the Art Nouveau style. Finally, the interior of the house is very similar to the Amy Miles House of 1890 in the Bethnal Green Museum of Childhood.  They both have thirteen rooms that vary only slightly in their configuration and social function.  At some stage the house was fitted with electric lighting possibly reflecting this technological development in real homes.  The interior has some fitted furniture with fireplaces in five rooms, a range and dresser in the kitchen and another dresser in the Butlers room.  In the Drawing room there is some intricate and impressive oak panelling.  Grand dolls houses such as this one were often commissioned for a family and whilst in earlier periods they were often for the pleasure of the lady of the house by the end of the nineteenth century they were made predominantly for children.

Dimensions:
object height: 360mm
object width: 235mm
object depth: 210mm
Description: block of wood with mounting tabs and metal plate -  'Knarl from the Old Shire Oak Headingley'
WebDescription: This odd looking souvenir has a plaque reading "'Knarl from the Old Shire Oak Headingley".  This venerable oak tree stood in Headingley and was reputed to have marked the centre of the Viking wapentake of Skyrack (or "Shire Oak") where legal disputes were settles and armies raised.  It was finally cut down in 1841 having been dead for many years before that.  This knarl was probably collected earlier than that as the branches had been gradually trimmed back when they became dangerous and many pieces were turned into souvenirs.

Description:
framed notice, "Bramley and Leeds... The public are respectfully informed that a NEAT COACH will commence on the First of Nov... from Bramley to Leeds.."; Isaac Morley, Proprietor - with  illustration; printed H. Cullingworth & Son, Boar  Lane, Leeds.
A
WebDescription:
This poster reads "Bramley and Leeds... The public are respectfully informed that a NEAT COACH will commence on the First of Nov... from Bramley to Leeds.."; Isaac Morley, Proprietor. It was printed by H. Cullingworth & Son, Boar  Lane, Leeds.
A new westerly turnpike road was constructed from Wellington Road through Armley and Bramley to Stanningley during 1835 and 1836 and, on 1st November of the latter year, Isaac Morley, innkeeper of the Cardigan Arms, Bramley, introduced a market coach making four journeys on Tuesdays and Saturdays from the Griffin Inn, West Bar, to his establishment at Bramley.  The coach also made one journey on Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays.  The fare was said to be 9d each way, but this coach too was short lived.

Title Sort: The Rev'd Richard Hale M.A. Vicar of Harewood
Dimensions:
object height (frame): 457mm
object width (frame): 330mm
object: 285 x 430mm
Description: lithograph, "The Rev'd Richard Hale M.A. Vicar of Harewood"  Portrait of man with wooden leg. Holds a stick in  right hand and clerics hat in left hand
WebDescription:
This lithograph shows "The Rev'd Richard Hale M.A. Vicar of Harewood", who was appointed vicar of Harewood in 1801.
In 1849 he was reported to have been charged before the Ecclesiastical Court, with irreverent and unseemly conduct in the pulpit, and also with quarrelling, chiding, and brawling, in the parish church of Harewood.  He published his own version of the case in a book published in Leeds in 1849 titled "The Bishop of Ripon Versus the Vicar of Harewood."

Description: wax head doll, stuffed body, red leather hands;  dressed in straw bonnet, black flannel cape, green dress etc.; box says "in costume of scholar of  Harrison Free School, Leeds"
WebDescription:
This wax head doll, with a stuffed body and leather hands is dressed  "in the costume of a scholar of the Harrison Free School, Leeds". 
The Harrison Free School had originally been set up as a charity school in Lady Lane in 1705 but was later moved to Mark Lane when the original building became the workhouse. In 1815 it was rebuilt for the purpose of "the clothing and education of poor girls, who should already have been instructed in the first elements of reading and writing".  It was what was known as a Blue Coat School and the disctinctive blue uniform marked pupils out as being the subject of charity.

Dimensions:
object height (frame): 610mm
object width (frame): 457mm
object: 440 x 365mm
Description: mezzotint, 3/4 length portrait of Richard Oastler. On table to  his right are two volumes titled "White Slavery" & "Marcus"
WebDescription:
This mezzotint print shows a portrait of Richard Oastler. On table to  his right are two volumes titled "White Slavery" & "Marcus". 
Richard Oastler became known as the Factory King with his fight against cruelty to children in the factories and mills. He was born in St Peter's Square, Leeds, and started his career as a cloth dealer and when his father died in 1820 he managed an estate near Huddersfield. About ten years later Richard Oastler started his campaign against children working in the mills. His main object was a ten hour day, which he achieved in 1847 before retiring from public life. He died in Harrogate on August 22nd 1861 and  is buried at Kirkstall Parish Church.

Richard Oastler was often at loggerheads with Liberal industrialists who supported the campaigns against the international Slave Trade and slavery, but did not want regulations to control how they treated the workforce in their own factories.

Description: notice, Kirkstall Abbey House Museum - Opened to  the Public on 11th July 1927 - Penny Paid for the  first Ticket of Admission by the Lord Mayor of  Leeds, Ald. Hugh Lupton J.P.; framed and glazed
WebDescription: This framed notice reads "Kirkstall Abbey House Museum - Opened to  the Public on 11th July 1927 - Penny Paid for the  first Ticket of Admission by the Lord Mayor of  Leeds, Ald. Hugh Lupton J.P."  It has always seemed a little odd but quite egalitariaon to have charged an entrance fee to the person invited to open the museum!

Description: brass urn with handles, tap at front, fancy metal work at  bottom, inscribed "J. Braithwaite Maker Leeds" and used at  McConnell's, Briggate
WebDescription:
This brass urn with handles and a tap at front, is inscribed "J. Braithwaite Maker Leeds".  In the 1847 trade directory John Braithwaite iof South Row, South Market, Leeds is described as a "coppersmith and gas fitter", although there is another John Braithwaite in the same directory who was a gun maker and furnishing ironmonger.
The urn was used at  McConnels, who were wine and spirit merchants on Briggate, Leeds.

Description: silver plated ornament in the form of a lidded cup made from an emu egg. The lid of the cup has a small emu on top  and other decorative features include heraldic lions holding shields around the base, cherub heads on the stand and the two handles incorpo
WebDescription: This elaborate silver plated ornament  is in the form of a lidded cup made from an emu egg.  The emu is a large flightless bird native to Australia and is often used as an emblem to represent the country.  The lid of the cup has a small emu on top  and other decorative features include heraldic lions holding shields around the base, cherub heads on the stand and the two handles incorporate dolphin heads. The cup is unlikely to have been used for drinking but would have been a centrepiece on a sideboard or mantle shelf.

Description: large mirror, woman's face and hands holding soup  in bowl - 'Symingtons Soups 'I find them delicious' Ellen Terry'
WebDescription: This advertising mirror has the slogan "'Symingtons Soups 'I find them delicious" endorsed by the famous actress Ellen Terry.  Symingtons wree founded in Market Harborough in 1827 and were pioneers in dried foods including soups, gravy and custard powder.  They used Dame Ellen Terry in an advertising campaign in 1909.  The company now has its headquarters in Leeds.

Description: coloured print, framed and glazed, "Leeds from  Little Woodhouse"
WebDescription: This print shows a view of Leeds from Little Woodhouse, then still very rural.  The figure on the right appears to be carrying bales of cloth over his shoulder.

Description:
riding crop with antler handle, two silver bands, one engraved "B.H. BUTLER / KIRKSTALL / JUNE 20TH 1905"; silver bands are also stamped DEANS OF LEEDS and have Birmingham hallmarks for 1901 and 1902 respectively
Presented to Basil Harding Butler on his
WebDescription:
This riding crop with an antler handle had two silver bands, one of which is engraved "B.H. BUTLER / KIRKSTALL / JUNE 20TH 1905"; silver bands are also stamped DEANS OF LEEDS and have Birmingham hallmarks for 1901 and 1902 respectively.  This was presented to Basil Harding Butler on his 21st birthday.  
Basil Harding Butler was the son of Ambrose Edmund Butler who moved into Abbey House from 1902.  Basil Butler did not spend his childhood at Abbey House, but spent two years living there from 1923 to 1925 while winding up his father's estate.

Description: silver snuff box, hallmarked Birmingham 1826, maker Robert Mitchell, engraved on the lid "J. HAINSWORTH / Inspector / LEEDS"
WebDescription: This silver snuff box is engraved on the lid "J. HAINSWORTH / Inspector / LEEDS".  It is hallmarked Birmingham 1826 and the maker was Robert Mitchell.   Joseph Hainsworth was a police inspector, appointed by the Watch Committee and is listed in the Leeds trade directories of 1839, 1842 and 1843.  He was one of the earliest officers working for Leeds City Police who were established in 1836.

Description: set of false teeth or dentures, Simeon Mosely's  patent (with real human teeth set into brass  plate)
WebDescription: This set of false teeth or dentures is made of real human teeth set into a brass plate and is stamped  "Simeon Mosely's  patent".  Mr Simeon Mosely, Surgeon-Dentist, by appointment to his Majesty the King of Hanover (from 61 Grosvenor Street, London), 15 Whitefriargate, Hull (next door to the Custom House), was the sole inventor and patentee and was advertising in the Eastern Counties Herald (Hull) in 1854.

Description: rocking horse; rectangular wooden base with 4  wheels mounted inside varnished rocking frame;  horse on base with hair, leather saddle etc.
WebDescription: This rocking horse has a rectangular wooden base with four  wheels mounted inside varnished rocking frame, which implies that it could be used in two ways.  The horse itself is covered with animal skin and has a real horse-hair mane.

Description: set of three pawnbroker's balls, gilded metal with suspension hooks; used as the shop sign above Mark Zermansky's pawnbroker, North Street, Leeds.
WebDescription:
This set of three pawnbroker's balls, made of gilded metal with suspension hooks was used as the shop sign above Mark Zermansky's pawnbroker, North Street, Leeds.
One suggested origin for the pawnbroker's sign is that it was linked to the legend of St Nicholas (later Santa Claus) who rescued three girls from a life of ruin by dropping three bags of gold down their family's chimney (their impoverished father had threatened to sell them into prostitution).   St Nicholas was later adopted as the patron saint of pawnbrokers.

Description: Silver Cross doll's pram, blue and white (given as birthday present to donor when aged 5 or 6)
WebDescription: This Silver Cross doll's pram was given as birthday present to the donor, Pauline Beveridge,  when she was aged 5 or 6.

Description: Columbia Double Crown printing press constructed in cast iron with wrought iron platen frames and ornate weights and counterbalances in the shape of crescent moons, sea serpents, mermaids and an eagle. footings in the shape of eagle claws. black paint fin
WebDescription:
This Columbian Press was built under license in 1845 to American George Clymer's patent at 120 Aldersgate Street, London. The press was built for printer and bookbinder William Witts & Sons Ltd of Bramley. Witts was best known as the publisher of the Bramley 'Weekly Advertiser'. In the mid-1880s Witts moved to a bigger property on Lower Town Street which allowed him to use these Columbian Presses to improve the company's output.
George Clymer brought his Columbian Press to England from America in 1817 following an unenthusiastic reception to the press in his homeland. The press was an instant success in Britain, with several London printers quick to order copies of his impressive machine.
The Columbian has been described as "the ultimate triumph of the lever press", using a system of counterweights and levers to produce accurate impressions even on large formes, and with much less strain on the pull. The highly decorative detailing on the press including an eagle, serpent and half moon is not just for show but forms part of the printing mechanism.

Medium/Materials: cast iron, wrought iron, steel, brass, glass
Dimensions:
object height: 2300mm
object length: 3900mm
object depth: 1600mm
Description:
Steam locomotive 'Jack' bearing original name plate, 0-4-0 well tank engine no.684, painted in 'Midland Red', brass fittings and black trim.

18 inch gauge contractors locomotive, with well tank and outside frame Walschaert's gearing to provide extra st
WebDescription:
One of only 14 locomotives built in the 18" gauge by hunslet and unusual for leaving the works painted in 'Midland Red' rather than the usual olive green. This was because the buyer, John Knowles & Sons (Wooden Box) Ltd of Burton on Trent, had track running close to the Midland Railway lines.
'Jack' hauled fireclay on a lightweight track with tight curves and for extra stability has a well tank and walschaerts gearing outside the frame, probably the first Hunslet locomotive to do so. After retirement in 1958 'Jack' was bought by Leeds Museums & Galleries and was fully restored in 1980 at Bradford Industrial Museum.

Dimensions:
object height: 6500mm
object width: 19500mm
object depth: 3300mm
Description: Joseph Booth of Rodley steam crane, serial no. 4161A. wrought iron frames with railed wheels, boiler, gearbox and cable drum mounted on top and covered by corrugated metal cab. crane jib made of angled wrought iron.
WebDescription:
Established in 1847, Jeremiah Booth set up his crane making company at Union Foundry in Rodley before his son Joseph took over in 1855 and changed the name to his own. For most of its existence, the company worked alongside Thomas Smith & Sons' Old Foundry, also in Rodley, before the two companies eventually joined together.
This railed steam crane was manufactured by Joseph Booth of Rodley in 1931 and was originally one of a pair. The crane was also spent its working life in Leeds on the Co-operative Society's Victoria Coal Wharf, better known today as a part of Granary Wharf, where it plied its trade loading and unloading coal barges on the River Aire. The crane was last used in 1975 before being dismantled, brought to Armley Mills, and re-assembled in the museum's grounds.

Medium/Materials: cast iron, wrought iron, steel, tin, rope, wood, leather
Description: Self Acting mule manufactured by Platt Ros, Oldham, 1904.  Rim at side 72" draw, 150 spindles per carriage. 1871 pattern headstock.  Delivered January - February 1904
WebDescription:
Armley Mills currently has two woollen mules, both by Platt Brothers & Co. Ltd. of Oldham. One dates from 1871, the other from 1904. They are arranged as a pair but were not originally as they were each acquired from different mills. Both mules are of 300 spindles on 2 ? gauge and superficially appear to be of the same design but the earlier mule has an 1866 pattern headstock while the later one has an 1871 headstock.
 
The 1871 mule is thought to be the oldest surviving self-acting mule but it is no longer operational and has several parts missing. It was acquired by the museum from F. A. Lodge & Sons of Stone Bridge Mills, Wortley, Leeds. This company are also listed as at Winker Green Mills in Armley as ?woollen makers? and were also known to weave woollen cloth.
 
The 1904 mule is operational and is run for demonstration purposes. This mule came from James Ives & Co. Ltd. of Leafield Mills, Yeadon, Leeds. James Ives also owned Manor Mills in Yeadon and it is possible that the mule came from here rather than Leafield Mills. This machine is readily identifiable as one of eight mules originally order by James Ives which appear in the Platt Brothers Mule Production Book for 10th August 1903. The accompanying delivery book shows that the first two machines were delivered in December with the rest of the machines following in January and February of 1904, making ours one of the later machines in this run.
 
The 1904 mule is maintained both by staff at Armley Mills and by technicians from our commercial woollen textiles partners A. W. Hainsworth & Sons of Stanningley, Leeds. It is run twice a day and the quality of the spun wool is so high that it is being used by Hainsworth?s for commercial blanket production.

Dimensions:
object height: 2140mm
object length: 4270mm
object width: 1680mm
Description: The Hattersley Standard Power loom with 84" reed space, overpick with four shuttle drop box.  Fitted with a "V" dobby controlling 28 shafts. The first production power loom model to be standardised. This is the 1933 model, patent no. 109467-116410.
WebDescription:
The Hattersley standard loom was manufactured by George Hattersley & Sons Ltd. of Keighley. In addition, the firm made every type of loom and a vast range of associated textile equipment until their closure in 1981.
Each loom was assembled at the Hattersley works in Keighley before being packed in order to ensure that all the parts worked properly. Then before dismantling, various parts of the loom were numbered and marked with paint in order to make it easier to assemble later. The loom was then placed in a crate - which on arrival at its destination was then unpacked and assembled with only reference to a simple guide.
The Hattersley standard loom was introduced in 1921 and was a huge success, which accounts for how many of these looms survive today. This particular loom was used at James Ives & Co. in Yeadon and has recently undergone a lengthy restoration project to prepare it for weaving our new, specially-designed 'Armley Weave' cloth on site at Armley Mills.

Medium/Materials: cast iron, wrought iron, steel, wood, rope, leather
Description: Self acting mule manufactured by Platt Bros. Oldham, 1871.  Rim at side, 72" draw, 300 spindles.  1866 pattern headstock, originally order 27.7.1871 for Pawson & Wood

Dimensions:
object length: 267mm
object width: 152mm
object depth: 20mm
Description: The Yorkshire Commercial Motor Company', brass name plate, no. 658 from a steam lorry. Simple oval nameplate design with raised edges and a single screw to each end. The background is a crosshatched design with the outside lettering curving to the shape
WebDescription:
The Yorkshire Commercial Motor Co. was the company name of The Yorkshire Patent Steam Wagon Co. between the years 1911 and 1922. This eleven year period saw the company diversify into internal combustion engines before returning to steam engines for power. Having produced their first wagon in 1901, the company's trademark became the novel double-ended transverse boiler.
The company made their last steam wagon in 1937. We're so used to seeing vehicles powered by internal combustion that it looks quite strange to us to see a boiler and chimney attached to the front of a lorry but at one time they would have been a fairly common sight.

Medium/Materials: wrought iron, cast iron, steel, glass
Dimensions:
object length: 3200mm
object height: 5150mm
object depth: 2250mm
Description: Greenwood & Batley built 0-4-0 1'6" gauge electric battery locomotive. No. 1210 features a central steeple cab and is finished in green livery with red shunting plates.
WebDescription: Greenwood & Batley became interested in electric traction after Leeds opened its first electric tram line in 1891. Initially experimenting with American motors, they switched to battery power after World War One and produced this, their first locomotive, in 1930. Loco no.1210 has a 'steeple cab' and was used for haulage by power stations in Luton and Croydon until 1969.

Dimensions:
object length: 9500mm
object height: 3400mm
object depth: 2350mm
Description:
Hudswell Clarke 2-6-2 diesel locomotive named 'Junin'. Engine no. D.557, 2' 6" gauge with a Mclaren-Benz diesel engine, in green livery.

330 HP diesel locomotive.  D557 order no JNR 2/ 69. 2.6.2 type.  2'6" gauge.  Wheels 2'9" diameter. Engine McLaren
WebDescription:
Junin was the world's first commercial diesel locomotive, built in 1929-30 for the Junin Nitrate Railway Company of Chile, who wanted a powerful locomotive able to cope with the heat and dryness of the Atacama Desert.
The locomotive was the world's most powerful diesel when it was built. It had a 2 ton radiator, a huge cooling fan and a 300hp McLaren engine. The latter had to be built in Germany and was very large and heavy. The weight of high powered diesel engines remained a problem for several years. Junin returned to Leeds in 1990.

Dimensions:
object length: 284mm
object width: 201mm
object depth: 8mm
object weight: 1.3 kg
Description: Locomotive works plate from a Hunslet Engine Co. diesel locomotive. The raised gold lettering reads 'THE HUNSLET ENGINE CO LTD LEEDS 260HP. - NO. 6694-1967'. The background of the plate is a cross-hatched design painted black. There are two parallel raise
WebDescription:
This is the works plate from a Hunslet Engine Company of Leeds diesel locomotive. No.6694 was a stock 260hp, Gardner engine 0-6-0 locomotive. One way Hunslet Engine Company ensured they could always meet the demand for their locomotives was to build more locomotives than they had orders for at any one time. This also had the benefit of keeping the staff busy at all times. These locomotives were called 'stock' locomotives and it was relatively rare that they didn't eventually sell.
What makes this particular nameplate interesting is that diesel locomotive No. 6694 was never completed. This nameplate is all that survives from the aborted locomotive.

Dimensions:
object length: 5700mm
object height: 1200mm
object width (per member): 1500mm
Description:
Cast iron footbridge in six sections, built by Kirkstall Forge Co. for the Great Northern Railway at Retford, later transferred to Todds Green between Stevenage and Hitchin. 

The footbridge has a fish-bellied main frame with vertical members extending
WebDescription:
With rail travel in its infancy, rules for crossing railway lines were not firmly established until the middle of the 19th Century. It was common for pedestrians, horses and carriages to cross the lines wherever and whenever they wanted. The inevitable increase in accidents saw a call for bridges to be erected over the new lines.
Initially, wooden bridges were preferred for the cheapness of their construction but it became increasingly aware that iron would be necessary to bridge the ever-increasing spans and take the increasing loads. This bridge, number No. 93a - also known as 'Halfpenny Bridge' from its time as a toll bridge - was the first cast iron footbridge on the entire British railway network. 
Cast in six sections by Beecroft & Butler at the Kirkstall Forge in Leeds for the Great Northern Railway, the bridge was originally erected just north of Retford and was later moved to Todds Green, between Stevenage and Hitchin. The footbridge has a fish-bellied main frame with vertical members extending to hold horizontal wrought iron tension bars.  Wrought iron parapet base also attached, with box frame and cross members to support a timber deck. The total span of the bridge is 52ft with a 5ft rise. The shallow cast iron arch was originally supported on brick abutments incorporating arched brick piers and staircases.

Dimensions:
object height: 131mm
object width: 131mm
object depth: 7mm
Description:
Brass navigational instrument with an 'Organum Ptolemei' on the obverse and a 'sinical quadrant' on the reverse. 

- The 'Organum Ptolemei' is a close cousin to the 'de Rojas' astrolabe, though it has a rotating orthographic plate without the neccesary
WebDescription:
This instrument is the only known example in the world of an ?Organum Ptolemei? being found on the same instrument as a quadrant. It dates to the 16th Century and features two inscriptions to the obverse that both read ?Thomas Cock?. Though nothing is known about Thomas Cock, it is presumed that he was the one-time owner of the instrument rather than its creator as one inscription looks to have been done by an amateur ? possibly Cock himself - while the other is a more purposeful, professional inscription of a later date. Cock was likely a wealthy individual to be able to afford to have the instrument made from brass. Working astrolabes were made from whatever materials were to hand so an instrument like this is as much an ostentatious show of wealth and education as it is a working navigational tool.
 
The Organum Ptolemei on the obverse is a close cousin to the 'de Rojas' astrolabe, though it has a rotating orthographic plate without the necessary orthogonal cursor. The instrument has a solar longitude scale in the margin and a divided regula. The ?sinical quadrant? on the reverse is a mathematical instrument used to simplify trigonometric calculations. It has lines inscribed in a grid. The ratio of the length of a given line to the quadrant's radius gives the sin or cosine of the corresponding angle. The arc and outer square edges are divided into degrees running in both directions 0-90. A plumb bob would have been suspended on a string from the hole in the corner.
 
Adjacent to the two inscriptions, at a perpendicular angle, is the crudely stamped number '17'. It is not currently understood what this refers to. Also, a reverse 'N' can be seen crudely but boldly engraved at 90 degrees on the orthographic plate. This is likely to be an aid to an inexperienced user of the instrument.
 
The Organum Ptolemei originally entered the city?s collections via the Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society in 1918 from the widow of the renowned collector of scientific instruments, William Sykes Ward.

Dimensions:
object length: 103mm
object width: 84mm
object depth: 30mm
Description: Arching brass nameplate from a morticing machine. The plate is hand cut and formed, with hand-stamped lettering that reads: 'W.Green, Hunslet. Leeds.' There are two screw holes to the bottom of the plate. On the reverse is a number '3' hand stamped centra
WebDescription:
A mortiser is a machine tool designed to cut square or rectangular holes in timber. These machines were particularly useful when cutting mortise and tennon joints, a job which formerly required a good deal of skill and training.
Leeds was a major producer of machine tools from the mid-nineteenth century onwards with companies like Greenwood and Batley going on to produce machine tools for export across the world. The letters on this plate are individually stamped using a stamp and hammer which implies this plate is relatively early.

Dimensions:
object length: 330mm
object width: 218mm
object depth: 5mm
Description: Oval iron works plate painted dark green with embossed lettering that reads 'ROBERT STEVENSON & HAWTHORNS LTD 7204 NEWCASTLE & DARLINGTON 1945' from an Austerity class 0-6-0 locomotive. There are parallel raised borders around the edge and separating the
WebDescription:
Built as one of the Hunslet Engine Co. designed 'Austerity' class of 0-6-0ST locomotives for the War Department, Robert Stephenson & Hawthorns Ltd No. 7204 was given the War Department number 75274, later No. 176 and worked Chilwell and Bicester. 
The locomotive was later purchased by Hunslet Engine Co. and rebuilt to modern standards before being sold on Cadeby and Denaby Collieries. It was eventually scrapped in 1970. The Hunslet nameplate No.3384 for this locomotive also survives but sadly the locomotive itself does not.

Description: Fox patent boiler flue made of corrugated cylindrical steel.

Title Sort: Leeds Festival 2009 - Ellen and the Escapades 'Without You' - 7" vinyl single
Medium/Materials: felt, cotton, card, paper, plastic, ink
Dimensions:
object length: 202mm
object width: 200mm
object depth: 10mm
Description:
7" vinyl of the single "Without You" by Ellen and the Escapades. The single is encased in three sleeves. The B Side is "Run".

The outer sleeve is made of blue felt with a cotton printed label on the front. The label reads "Ellen and the Escapades / Wit
WebDescription:
The Leeds Festival Archive started in June 2009 as an annual contemporary collecting project curated by the Community History team. In 2009, we began by emailing flyers and posting adverts on online music forums to get hold of as many attending people, bands and organisations we could, to attempt to take a snapshot of the festival. We asked everyone who took part to choose and donate an object or objects that were both present at the festival and one(s) they believed represented a part of it. Each donor was also asked to submit a short piece of narrative about their experience of the festival and/or the object(s). 
This 7" vinyl single is part of a set of objects that were donated by James Warrender (Ellen and the Escapades).  
"It was an excellent experience to be able to play Leeds Festival this year, and a delight to be chosen. We had an amazing crowd and a great response to our new tracks. The vinyl is our current single 'Without You' which is pretty much sold out, but we did manage to give a few away at Leeds Fest after running out of all 300 CDs we had made in the space of 5 minutes... We are all hoping we get the opportunity to return to Leeds Festival next year as we had such a great time and such great support!".
James Warrender (Ellen and the Escapades) 2009.

Title Sort: Leeds Festival 2009 - Surprise...Fire car park pass
Description: Car park pass made of green paper with blue print. The hand written information in black marker and blue pen states - "SURPRISE...FIRE (SAT) / BBC INTRODUCING STAGE / FY53TYB / 07799080240".
WebDescription:
The Leeds Festival Archive started in June 2009 as an annual contemporary collecting project curated by the Community History team. In 2009, we began by emailing flyers and posting adverts on online music forums to get hold of as many attending people, bands and organisations we could, to attempt to take a snapshot of the festival. We asked everyone who took part to choose and donate an object or objects that were both present at the festival and one(s) they believed represented a part of it. Each donor was also asked to submit a short piece of narrative about their experience of the festival and/or the object(s).
This car park pass is part of a set of objects that were donated by Freddie Holden (Surprise?Fire).  
"After being asked to play on the BBC Introducing stage, we knew that an opportunity of a life time had been placed on our laps. The travelling included a popped tyre and members of the band having to do shifts in the boot, with a seat before you think we were breaking the law! A shift in the boot meaning 2 hours of having your face pressed against the back window and a numb bottom. Being lovers of Leeds Festival we arrived on the Wednesday, instead of the day we were playing, Saturday, over enthusiastic? Naaaaah. We are crazy guys. The weekend also included: the classic grimy toilets (which a girl apparently fell in!), lack of sleep, one of our tents covered in shaving cream, and an incredible almost over powering feel of nerves, worth it? Definitely, performing was exhilarating. The crowds at both Leeds and Reading were extremely receptive. Will, our guitarist, even having a woman's leg thrown at him. We have provided some objects that will always remind us of the weekend... an official Leeds Festival car pass just to remind us of the band wagon of 2009, The Volvo with 7 seats and a roof box! Good times. We will always remember Leeds and Reading Festivals; they were the next step for us as a band and hopefully only good will come of the weekend". 
Freddie Holden (Surprise?Fire) 2009.

Description: Black Middleman badge. Printed accross the badge in large letters is "Middleman" and below it in a smaller font is "www.myspace.com/middlemanpop".
WebDescription:
The Leeds Festival Archive started in June 2009 as an annual contemporary collecting project curated by the Community History team. In 2009, we began by emailing flyers and posting adverts on online music forums to get hold of as many attending people, bands and organisations we could, to attempt to take a snapshot of the festival. We asked everyone who took part to choose and donate an object or objects that were both present at the festival and one(s) they believed represented a part of it. Each donor was also asked to submit a short piece of narrative about their experience of the festival and/or the object(s). 
This badge is part of a set of objects that were donated by Caroline Bonser (Leeds Metropolitan University).  
"Leeds Met's partnership with Festival Republic was established in the spring of 2007. This creative and dynamic partnership provides exciting opportunities for students and staff to develop experience and skills in a festival setting, to contribute significantly to the work of Festival Republic and to enhance research in festivals and creative performance. The partnership has so far enabled over 300 students, staff and alumni to volunteer at Latitude and Leeds Festivals: being involved in stage management, filming, performing arts, playwork, running campsite DJ stations and helping festival-goers. Internships in production, licensing, artist liaison, sound, lighting and environmental health have helped students to put learning into practice and gain an in-depth insight into the running of a major festival".
"I moved to Leeds in September 2003 as a student and attended Leeds Festival for the first time in 2004. Since then I have been every year apart from a break in 2006. For the last three years I have worked at the festival: in 2007 as a volunteer Production Manager on the BBC Introducing Stage with Leeds Met, and in 2008 and 2009 as a co-ordinator for Leeds Met's volunteering projects with Festival Republic. I love the festival atmosphere and the fact that it is like another world; even though you are still in Leeds it seems like you could almost be anywhere. It quite often rains and you get dirty and smelly, but that's ok at a festival - normal rules can be abandoned for a few days. Working at the festival has enabled me to see it from a completely different perspective and given me an appreciation of what a massive job it is to organise!".
"The items donated to Leeds Museums & Galleries include: a Middleman badge - this was given out by local band Middleman to promote their Leeds Festival performance in 2009. They won the Futuresound competition at the Cockpit and opened the Festival Republic stage on Sunday". 
Caroline Bonser (Leeds Metropolitan University) 2009.

Description: Press tent wristband made of white paper with blue and red striped print running along it. "FR PRESS TENT" is printed in black text.
WebDescription:
The Leeds Festival Archive started in June 2009 as an annual contemporary collecting project curated by the Community History team. In 2009, we began by emailing flyers and posting adverts on online music forums to get hold of as many attending people, bands and organisations we could, to attempt to take a snapshot of the festival. We asked everyone who took part to choose and donate an object or objects that were both present at the festival and one(s) they believed represented a part of it. Each donor was also asked to submit a short piece of narrative about their experience of the festival and/or the object(s). 
This wristband is part of a set of objects that were donated by Sam Saunders.
"Since about 1965 I have taken an active interest in folk and popular music, as a listener and (sometimes) as an amateur performer and writer. In 2005 the Leeds Festival, provoked by Alan Raw (of BBC Radio Hull), included a stage dedicated to regional talents who were unlikely to be featured on the established main stages. I decided to try to attend so that I could document all those bands who were featured on the new talent stage. I guessed that for many this would be a high point of their musical lives. If one or two would later become professional artists with wide attention, that would leave many whose big moment went uncommented. In five years a lot of things have changed. Selection processes, the name of the stage, and the ways in which events are documented have been transformed. But I am still attending and trying to make a record of each band's performance. My reviews for each day of each Leeds Festival since 2005 have appeared on Whisperin' and Hollerin', a website edited by former Sounds journalist Tim Peacock".

"In 2009 I also contributed reviews to Leeds Music Scene (the foremost Leeds music website) and Vibrations, a freely distributed bi-monthly popular music magazine for Leeds. In 2009 I was again able to get a guest pass with access to the press tent. The guest campsite and catering area are relatively comfortable. This year my youngest son came with me to help with the running about. We cycled from Otley where I live (about 16 miles away) carrying tent, sleeping bags, food, laptop and cameras on our bikes. We arrived on Thursday, early enough to get our tent organised and walk down to what is now called The BBC Introducing Stage in time for a special pre-festival event curated by Leeds' Dance To The Radio record label. I spent the rest of the weekend (as usual) at the new talent stage, with occasional visits to other stages (especially to see Leeds bands). Wife Chris came over for the day on Saturday and we enjoyed Radiohead's headline set together. Over the weekend I saw performances by at least 50 artists. After three nights under canvas son Richard and I cycled back to Otley on a beautiful late-summer morning through rich Yorkshire countryside in a very good mood".
"Included in the package handed to Leeds Museums Service are; my press tent wristband for 2009".
Sam Saunders 2009.
