Description: Black inflatable guitar. Currently deflated. Printed on the inflatable in white writing is - "SUCK / VAMPIRES ROCK".
WebDescription:
The Leeds Festival Archive started in June 2009 as an annual contemporary collecting project curated by the Community History team. In 2010, we repeated the approach we used in 2009 by emailing flyers and posting adverts on online music forums to get hold of as many attending people, bands and organisations we could, to attempt to take a snapshot of the festival. We asked everyone who took part to choose and donate an object or objects that were both present at the festival and one(s) they believed represented a part of it. Each donor was also asked to submit a short piece of narrative about their experience of the festival and/or the object(s). 
This inflatable guitar is part of a set of objects that were donated by Laura Crapper.
"I have volunteered at Leeds Festival through Oxfam for the past three years, and 2010 was the best yet!  As arena crew, I think I get to see a different side to the festival.  Our campsite is small, quiet, and secure - a far cry from the muddy, cramped, and rowdy public campsites!  We are able to walk around the "backstage" route, which this year involved almost getting ran over by the "We Are Scientists" tour bus!".

"Oxfam stewards work three 8-hour shifts over the course of the festival, which leaves plenty of time to enjoy the music.  This year, my role was scanning tickets on the way into the festival, meaning I was able to meet loads of punters - most of whom were really friendly.  We also work closely with security, which means the shifts are never dull!".

"My personal musical highlights of the weekend were Bad Religion, Cypress Hill and Weezer.  The crowd, especially on the Saturday, seemed so happy to be there and enjoying the music, which had a nostalgic feel for the majority  - as the typical Leeds festival goer falls between the ages of 18 and 25, Blink 182 were a particular highlight, allowing us to recapture our early teens!".

"After a whole week at the festival, it was a relief to get back to my home comforts - I don't think I have ever been so excited about having a shower!  However, the festival experience is completely unique, and I am sure I will be back next year for more music, fun and revelry!".

Laura Crapper 2010

Title Sort: Leeds Festival 2010 - Guns N' Roses empty tequila bottle

Description: Empty tequila bottle  with cork stopper from the Leeds Festival 2010 Sunday 29th August main stage. Found after Guns n Roses, which was the last set.
WebDescription:
The Leeds Festival Archive started in June 2009 as an annual contemporary collecting project curated by the Community History team. In 2010, we repeated the approach we used in 2009 by emailing flyers and posting adverts on online music forums to get hold of as many attending people, bands and organisations we could, to attempt to take a snapshot of the festival. We asked everyone who took part to choose and donate an object or objects that were both present at the festival and one(s) they believed represented a part of it. Each donor was also asked to submit a short piece of narrative about their experience of the festival and/or the object(s). 
This empty tequila bottle is part of a set of objects that were donated by Gavin Freeborn (Leeds Metropolitan University).
"I've organised the following items for you... empty tequila bottle from the main stage - after Guns n Roses which was the last set".

Gavin Freeborn 2010.

Title Sort: Leeds Festival 2011 - Pigeon Detectives signed set list
Description: White A4 sheet of paper set list signed by the 'Pigeon Detectives'. There are 3 signatures in green pen and either 'A', 'K' and 'E' are written in pen infront of several of the song titles. The main text is printed in black ink and has some duct tape on t
WebDescription:
The Leeds Festival Archive started in June 2009 as an annual contemporary collecting project curated by the Community History team. In 2009 and 2010 it had generally been a one man show where the assistant curator of community history did all the administration. In 2011 we decided to hand the majority of collecting over to a group of volunteers, whom we sent to the festival to actively collect while there. Each of them returned submitting material that included audio recordings of interviews, digital images, pieces of purchased ephemera and donated objects form bands. They then presented the material to our collections committee like any of our curators would. Even though the committee ultimately decide what is accessioned into the collection, it was a group of young, none museum, local people that selected the material. We did also leave it open for people to donate material in the same way as the two previous years, if they approached us.
This signed set list from the 'Pigeon Detectives' is part of the set of objects that were collected by the Leeds Festival 2011 Volunteer Group. 
The set list is signed by three members of the band and has the remnants of duct tape from where it was stuck to the stage at Leeds Festival 2011. The initials before each song symbolise the following: 'A' - Acoustic, 'K' - Keyboard and 'E' - Electric.

Title Sort: Leeds Festival 2011 - Tuborg and Gaymers pint cup
Description: Tuborg' and 'Gaymers' branded paper pint cup. Red, green and white printed design promoting the lager and cider drinks available. These cups were the official pint cups for Leeds Festival 2011.
WebDescription:
The Leeds Festival Archive started in June 2009 as an annual contemporary collecting project curated by the Community History team. In 2009 and 2010 it had generally been a one man show where the assistant curator of community history did all the administration. In 2011 we decided to hand the majority of collecting over to a group of volunteers, whom we sent to the festival to actively collect while there. Each of them returned submitting material that included audio recordings of interviews, digital images, pieces of purchased ephemera and donated objects form bands. They then presented the material to our collections committee like any of our curators would. Even though the committee ultimately decide what is accessioned into the collection, it was a group of young, none museum, local people that selected the material. We did also leave it open for people to donate material in the same way as the two previous years, if they approached us.
This pint cup is part of a set of objects that were donated by Katherine Baxter.
"I wasn't intending to go to Leeds Festival at all this year because I wasn't bowled over by the line-up, plus I got married in June followed by an exotic Mexican honeymoon so money was tight.  But friends from Wales said they were going to Leeds Festival for one day and persuaded (very easily) both myself and my husband Stu to join them".  

"So we got tickets for Friday 26th August.  In true Leeds Festival tradition, it decided to rain all day and I was actually glad I wasn't camping.  In terms of the Friday line-up, I was most excited to see Interpol, who I have seen several times before but they remain one of my favourite bands, but I wasn't too bothered about seeing anyone else - I just knew it would be a great atmosphere and a fun day spent with friends.  As usual the bands I wanted to see were spread over different days - I would have loved to go on the Saturday for Metronomy and The Vaccines, and the Sunday for Everything Everything and The National, plus crowd-pleasers Pulp and The Strokes, but I wasn't prepared to pay for a whole weekend ticket".

"In the end we had a brilliant time in the rain and the mud.  I saw lots of bands that I wouldn't normally have gone to see; 'The Streets' for instance - (they were surprisingly good), followed by a band called 'F*cked Up' (not so good).  I managed to eat three portions of noodles and drink plenty of Gaymers cider, and finished off the day by dancing to Muse in the rain, which brought back memories of Leeds Festival 2006".

Katherine Baxter 2011.

Title Sort: The Who 'Live At Leeds' - 12" vinyl album
Description: 12" vinyl album 'Live At Leeds' by The Who. The 12" vinyl has a white coloured label on either side with its track information printed in blue; it sits in a paper sleeve, which is inserted into a card album cover. The front of the album has a purposely ha
WebDescription:
This album was collected along with several other items to enhance our existing collections for the community driven "Silver 70s" exhibition. The space was divided up into the rooms of a house and dressed to reflect typical 1970s decor. It was on display at the Leeds City Museum from January 2012 to April 2012.
Though 'The Who' are not from Leeds, this is a significant Leeds associated album as it was recorded at the University of Leeds on February 14th 1970 and is regarded by many as the best live rock album of all time. It was released on the 23rd of May 1970 in the UK and the gatefold cover was inspired by bootleg LP's of the time. 'Live At Leeds' contained 12 facsimiles of various material relating to the band and this recording.

Description: The lamp is primarily made of copper alloy, with a circular chrome alloy emblem screwed on, reading "PARALYMPIC / TORCH RELAY". An embossed plate on the adjacent side reads "THE PROTECTOR LAMP & LIGHTING CO. LTD / TYPE / GR6S / M & Q / SAFETY LAMPS / APPR
WebDescription:
Even though the London 2012 Olympic & Paralympic Games took place in the capital, there were associated and connected activities taking place in Leeds, like many other major cities. The Community History Team wanted to draw specifically on these activities to collect some Leeds oriented ephemera.
A splinter of the Paralympic flame was carried from London to York by Yorkshire's Flame Ambassador, eight-year-old Evan Whitton, where it was divided into smaller flames and carried on to Leeds, Huddersfield, Beverley and Sheffield in special lamps. This is the London 2012 Paralympic Flame lantern that carried the flame to Leeds. It went on show at the John Charles Centre for Sport in Leeds on Saturday 25th August 2012, as part of a Paralympic celebration event hosted by Leeds City Council and the Leeds Disability Sport Youth Panel.

Title Sort: London 2012 Paralympic Canadian Men's Wheelchair Rugby Team - wheel guard
Description: The wheel guard comprises a large red plastic disc, bolted onto a carbon alloy ring, partially coated in black rubber. The disc has one large hole in the middle, with a smaller hole 30mm away. Next to this smaller hole is a rip about 40mm in length, proba
WebDescription:
Even though the London 2012 Olympic & Paralympic Games took place in the capital, there were associated and connected activities taking place in Leeds, like many other major cities. The Community History Team wanted to draw specifically on these activities to collect some Leeds oriented ephemera.
The Canadian Men's Wheelchair Rugby team completed their pre-Paralympic training at the University of Leeds from 22nd to 28th August 2012, having used the university's facilities twice before. The team won a silver medal at the London 2012 Paralympic Wheelchair Rugby event, which was held in the Basketball Arena from 5th to 9th September 2012. The sport incorporates elements of basketball, handball and ice hockey and is extremely physically demanding. This wheel guard was affixed to Zak Madell's wheelchair while competing at London 2012 and was given to Leeds in thanks. It is signed by him and the rest of the medal winning team.

Title Sort: London 2012 Olympic Dutch Women's 4x100m Freestyle Relay Team - sports bag

Description: Sports bag, predominately orange with white piping, with a double zip. The word "NEDERLAND" is embroidered in orange, blue and white cotton down each side of the bag. The bag has a white front pouch, with "E-ON" embroidered on it in red cotton and 4 signa
WebDescription:
Even though the London 2012 Olympic & Paralympic Games took place in the capital, there were associated and connected activities taking place in Leeds, like many other major cities. The Community History Team wanted to draw specifically on these activities to collect some Leeds oriented ephemera.
The Dutch Swimming Federation chose to use the Aquatics Centre at the John Charles Centre for Sport in Leeds as the training base for approximately 25 swimmers ahead of the London 2012 Olympic Games. The team included the Dutch Women's 4x100m Freestyle Relay team, who won a silver medal at the Freestyle Relay event, held on 28th July 2012 at the London Aquatics Centre. Marleen Veldhuis, a member of the relay team, also won a bronze medal for the 50m Freestyle event. The team had previously held the Olympic and world records for the 4x100m Freestyle Relay. This bag was signed by the four medal winning swimmers and was given to Leeds in thanks.

WebDescription:
Even though the London 2012 Olympic & Paralympic Games took place in the capital, there were associated and connected activities taking place in Leeds, like many other major cities. The Community History Team wanted to draw specifically on these activities to collect some Leeds oriented ephemera.
The Chinese officials selected Leeds as the country's training base ahead of the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games. The Chinese team, which comprised around 220 athletes, coaches and support staff, used a number of sporting facilities owned by the council, private sports clubs and the city's two universities. China won a total of 88 medals, finishing second in the global medal standings. This tracksuit was given to Leeds in thanks.

Description: dark blue leather bag with applique decoration in brown and black with white stitchings. Rectangular satchel like shape with top flap. Handle strap.
WebDescription: This bag is made from dark blue leather and is decorated using appliqu.  The different patterns are made separately of black and brown leather and then stitched on using white thread. The long strap is made from plaited leather strips and is fastened with a flap over the front.  The bag was made by the Yoruba people, most of whom live in South Western Nigeria.

Description: circular hat of grass and palmleaf. Conical, rim bound with red leather, cone topped spike finial of decorated leather, mainly red. Exterior covered with a 'pile' of grss fibre in sections of black and natural, threaded through from inside between the coi
WebDescription: This hat is made of palm leaf and plant fibre with a basketry weave base and pile of palm leaf strips on top.  Contrasting natural and black coloured fibres are used. Reddish brown leather is bound over the rim and at the peak, which is finished at the top with a leather pommel.

Description: skirt of brown blanket cloth, stitched with blue and white beads, horizontal bands of slanting lines and chevrons alternating with oval rings. Matches F.1959.91 blanket wrap. For a woman.
WebDescription:
This outfit would be worn by a woman, a member of one of the Xhosa communities who live in South Africa.  The skirt is made out of several pieces of woollen blanket fabric which have been sewn together, whilst the wrap is made from a single piece of material.   They are decorated with blue and white glass beads in a pattern of alternating stripes and circles.  The fabric is plain woven and has been brushed to give a furry appearance.  Brushing makes the fabric thicker and helps it to trap an extra layer of air inside which keeps the wearer warm.  

Both skirt and wrap have been dyed to a reddish brown colour using ochre.  Ochre is a type of yellow or reddish coloured earth or clay that is traditionally used as a pigment.  When Western missionaries began to visit South Africa to try and convert the Xhosa to Christianity, they often insisted that traditional modes of dress be abandoned.  A division appeared between people influenced by the white settlers, and those who clung to traditional beliefs.  Traditionalists who continued to apply red ochre to their bodies and clothing were nicknamed "Red People".  Traditional dress is sometimes still worn.

Description: red-ochre blanket, worn folded double; lines and circles of blue and white beads sewn on. Wool blanket, machine made and imported, stained with local red ochre on top of pale brown original. Skirt or body wrap, cloak, for a woman.
WebDescription:
This outfit would be worn by a woman, a member of one of the Xhosa communities who live in South Africa.  The skirt is made out of several pieces of woollen blanket fabric which have been sewn together, whilst the wrap is made from a single piece of material.   They are decorated with blue and white glass beads in a pattern of alternating stripes and circles.  The fabric is plain woven and has been brushed to give a furry appearance.  Brushing makes the fabric thicker and helps it to trap an extra layer of air inside which keeps the wearer warm.  

Both skirt and wrap have been dyed to a reddish brown colour using ochre.  Ochre is a type of yellow or reddish coloured earth or clay that is traditionally used as a pigment.  When Western missionaries began to visit South Africa to try and convert the Xhosa to Christianity, they often insisted that traditional modes of dress be abandoned. Description: deep collar of beadwork; beads dark blue, red, dusky pink, white, with long black ones at lower edge.
WebDescription:
This collar would be worn by a Pondo woman.  It is made from coloured glass beads strung on cotton thread, with a fringe of looped beads along the bottom edge.  It would be fastened around the wearer's neck using a small beaded loop hooked around a larger bead.

Glass beads were first imported to Africa from Europe during the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.  At first they were so expensive that only wealthy people could afford to buy and wear them.  By the time this collar was made at the end of the nineteenth century the use of imported beads was extremely widespread, and a massive variety of shapes and colours of beaded ornament were being produced all over Africa.

Description: flat ring of leather with red, white and dark blue beads sewn on.
WebDescription:
This necklace is made from a circular flat piece of leather, to which the glass beads have been sewn on one side.  It has wide alternating stripes of black, red, and white beads, interspersed with narrow stripes of white beads.  At the bottom is an extra U shaped piece of leather which is also beaded.  This style of beading only developed during the nineteenth century as glass beads were increasingly imported to Africa by European settlers.  Before then, Maasai jewellery was made from coiled copper and brass wire and seeds.  

Maasai beadwork is usually done by women.  All of the colours used have certain meanings, and there are rules about which colours can be put next to one another.  Young women put on even more necklaces after they are married, often wearing several at the same time.

Description: flat ring of leather with beads sewn on (red, white, dark blue, green, black).
WebDescription:
This necklace is made from a circular flat piece of leather, to which the glass beads have been sewn on one side.  It has wide alternating stripes of black, red, and pink beads, interspersed with narrrow stripes of white beads.  At the bottom is an extra U shaped piece of leather which is also beaded.  

This style of beading only developed during the nineteenth century as glass beads were increasingly imported to Africa by European settlers.  Before then, Maasai jewellery was made from coiled copper and brass wire and seeds.

Description: cap with a loop on the peak and a button at the back; red plaited cord; round shape. Made of black cloth heavily beaded in floral pattern; mostly 1mm glass beads, but some 5mm white ones. Fabric worn, some beads missing/loose. Red silk lining is rotten (V
WebDescription: This cap of black cotton cloth has both a brim and side flaps that are folded round the front,  and a factory made silk neck cord. It is embroidered with tiny glass beads in a floral design. The flowers and large leaf shapes have paper linings, showing that the beadwork was prepared on a paper pattern before the shapes were cut out and applied. The cap is lined with red silk. Though now rather worn, with many beads missing, the cap is still an impressive sight.

Description: pair of beaded moccasins. Made of tanned hide; shield-shaped inset over instep and cuff around ankles made of black velvet covered with multi-coloured floral bead embroidery. Shoe lined with cotton.Hole in each toe, ankle cuff loose stitching, binding rib
WebDescription: This pair of beaded moccasins is made of fairly soft tanned hide, with a cuff and vamp of black velvet which is covered with multi-coloured floral bead embroidery. The inside of each shoe is lined with cotton, and the top of the cuffs are bound with silk ribbon. The flowers and large leaf shapes of the glass beadwork have paper linings, showing that these elements were prepared on paper patterns before being applied to the rest of the design.

Description: Skirt of leather thongs, knotted at waist, with network of green and white beads; tassels of black and white beads with shells at the ends; mounted (stitched to) padded board covered with linen (done by LCC). Originally described as a dancing apron.
WebDescription:
Fine strips of leather have been knotted together to make this woman's dance skirt.  They are tied together at the top to make a fringe that would be fastened around the waist of the wearer using leather cords.  The cords are made by twisting several leather strips together. Three tassels hang down, one in the middle and one at each side. They are made from leather cords decorated at the ends with shells and small green and white glass beads.

The front of the skirt is formed by a wide netting made from leather strips strung with the same glass beads, interspersed with regularly spaced small white shells.  The beaded net covers about half of the front of the skirt and hangs from the waist band.  From the bottom of the beaded net hang a row of slightly larger white shells.  These would swing with the leather fringing every time the person wearing the skirt moved.

Description: mask carved from soft wood (possibly silk-cotton tree). Front stained black with parallel incised lines left unpainted, showing the white wood underneath. Original provenance given as Zambia, but Margret Carey, 1986 said not Zambia, but Basongye, Zaire. M
WebDescription: Kifwebe dance masks are used by healers. They are believed to hold supernatural spirits or forces. This example was made for the tourist trade but it uses the traditional design formula of contrasting narrow black and white bands, a prominent nose ridge, mouth and eyes.

Description: Woman's pointed cap, made of palm spathe, formed from network of fibres, with three tiers made by folds. Unseamed. At the top the end of the sheet has been left with the outer bark on. Brown colour.
WebDescription: This cap is made of palm spathe, taken from the area where the large palm leaf stalks or fronds branch off from the main trunk of a palm tree. The coarse brown network of fibres is seamless; the palm spathe has just been flattened and folded in three tiers. The peak has been twisted into a narrow spoke. The donor described this as a woman's cap, but it may have been worn by men too. This type of headgear could have been used in West Africa centuries ago, as a painting in the Wilberforce House Museum, Hull, of a slave-trading scene on the west coast of Africa, shows a man wearing a cap very like this.

Description: Comb made of whale bone. Worn by men as an ornament in the hair at the back of the head.
WebDescription: Comb made of whale bone. Worn by men as an ornament in the hair at the back of the head.

Description: 2 large white shells joined by wood bar to which are attached 4 triangles of tightly-looped fibre edged with discs of shell; looped fibre disc hangs on cord below each triangle; cord above, for attachment to head. Red and green pigment?
WebDescription:
Two large cowry shells attached to each end of a short piece of wood are the base of this head or chest ornament.  A short strap made from woven plant fibres is fixed to the back of the piece of wood.  

Four triangular panels have been woven as well, and fixed to the front of the wood so that they overlap, coming together at the bottom to form a single point.  Four small woven circles are hung from the bottom.  The edges of the circles and triangles are decorated with small white circular discs that look like buttons.  They are actually cut sections of shells.  The woven areas are decorated with a red pigment which is probably ochre, a special coloured mineral found in the earth.

Lots of different types of plant fibre are used from place to place all over the world depending on which plants are available nearby.  A few of them can be twisted together to form a yarn, or thread, or they might be thick enough to use on their own.  Either the yarns, or the fibres on their own, can then be woven together in different ways to make bigger pieces of material that can be used for different things.  The plant fibre used to make this head dress is probably rattan, from a type of palm tree found all over the Pacific region.

Description: small drum-shaped beadwork cap, for a man. Sides lined with panel of tightly twisted fibre (cf. belts); strap-like panel attached by cords; beads blue, white, red, pink, black, and 8 large green. Attachment is chin piece. Upper of two pieces photographed
WebDescription:
This cap, which would have been worn by a man, is constructed from coloured glass beads and has a beaded chinstrap attached by pieces of cord.  It is lined with a material made from twisted plant fibres.  
Different types of African beadwork can convey lots of different things about their wearer, from the region where they live, to their age or social status.  When this cap was made imported glass beads would have been very expensive.  Beaded garments were also highly valued spiritually because the bead working tradition linked the living to their ancestors.

Description: leather thong with pairs of teeth separated by a bead (some blue facetted, some blue with white spots). Length of teeth 4.6 cms.
WebDescription: This necklace is made from a strip of leather which has been strung with baboon teeth.  The teeth were attached through holes drilled in their root ends.  They are strung in groups of two, alternating with faceted black glass beads, and in order so that the biggest teeth are at the front, graduating round to the smallest at the back.

Description: necklace collar of concentric beadwork curves in a tight lattice. Mainly dark blue, red, pale blue and white beads, with bead and seed tassle round edge, and bead loop and button fastening.
WebDescription: Large collar made of a lattice of tiny glass beads. Concentric beadwork curves and diagonals make a tight lattice. Mainly dark blue, red, pale blue and white beads, with bead and seed tassels round edge, and a bead loop and button fastening.

Description: necklace of beadwork and wooden squares. Three rectangular beadwork panels with geometric designs in blue, green, red, white and yellow. Joined by strip of beads from which hang total of six wooden squares, in three groups. Wood squares have punched or in
WebDescription:
The necklace is made from small glass beads strung into a loop which is decorated with three flat rectangular panels of woven beadwork.  Three pairs of two flat wooden pendants carved with geometric shapes are also attached; each pair placed between the flat beadwork panels.  
White is the dominant colour.  Contrasting colours of red, orange, yellow, green and blue have been used to create a geometric pattern on each flat beadwork panel, as well as strung in alternating rows.

Description: necklet of coloured beads, arranged in 8 small rectangular panels and one long central panel. Mainly white, pale blue, black and red beads, zigzag design. Brass button and loop fastening. Diameter given is diameter of brass button. The glass beads measure
WebDescription:
This necklace is made from a series of flat rectangular panels woven using glass beads.  The front panel is much longer and larger than the rest and is decorated with a striped zig zag pattern.  Four small square panels are attached at each side by their corners, making a symmetrical arrangement.  The smaller panels are decorated with a striped chevron pattern.  The same pink, red, blue, black and white beads are used throughout.  The circular neck opening would be secured at the back with the loop of thread and conical metal button which can be seen at the top.
The catalogue information for this item indicates that the necklace could have been made by either the Xhosa or the Zulu people, both from South Africa.  However, the beaded panels have been constructed using brick stitch, where the beads are placed in staggered rows.  This and the patterning, together with the type of button fastening used, suggest that the piece is likely to be Zulu in origin.

Description: costume for child, padded coat. One of three children's clothing items. Red cotton with printed floral pattern, cross-over closing and green silk ribbon tie.
WebDescription: This child?s jacket is made from red cotton fabric with a floral print in blue and pink.  The garment is T shaped, with the fabric for the sleeves cut all in one piece with the front and back panels.  It has a round neckline with a simple collar made from an extra piece of material attached to the top edge.  A cross over front fastening is closed by a green silk ribbon.  The jacket is fully lined and has been padded to keep the wearer warm.

Description: sleeveless vest of threaded cane beads, originally described as a jacket (similar vests and cuffs are used in Korea). Worn under a robe like a string vest, to prevent the silk robe sticking to skin. Probably for a woman (Linda Wrigglesworth, July 1986).
WebDescription: This vest is made from pieces of hollow bamboo cane which have been netted together.  It would have been worn during hot weather to stop outer garments sticking to the skin.  The edges are finished with cotton cord, and it would be secured by a button around the neck.  At the front is a tie fastening finished with two ornate metal buttons.

Description: textile fragment, woven cotton near rectangular in shape, main red band in centre has repeated design of semi-abstract birds in black, pink and natural. Band borders, top and bottom, are of interlocked spiral shapes, black and natural. Natural fringe belo
WebDescription:
This tiny textile fragment survived in a Peruvian grave. It is made of cotton, tapestry woven on a small handloom. The main red band in the centre has a repeated design of birds in black, pink and natural, with borders of interlocking spirals or keys.  Attached to the top of this is an undyed area of plain woven fabric; at the bottom is a tapestry woven fringe. One end is quite tattered and torn.

Weaving in Peru goes back to 2000 B.C.  Techniques such as tapestry weaving have been practised for thousands of years.  Tapestry weaving produces a weft faced fabric.  This means that the yarns used for the weft can be seen on the front of the cloth, and the warp threads are usually not visible.  'Weft' is the term used for the yarns which pass from left to right across the loom.  The 'warp' yarns go from top to bottom.

In tapestry weaving, there are many separate wefts, one for each colour area.  These coloured weft threads are worked back and forth across the cloth, but only in the pattern area where they are needed.  They do not extend from selvedge to selvedge of the finished cloth.  In many tapestry woven textiles vertical splits can be seen in the cloth along the edges of pattern areas.  This is one way of helping to identify them as tapestry woven.

Description: one of 3 ear pendants, long strings of beetle wing cases, tied together. Green wing cases of beetles strung on natural cotton fibre with tassels of feathers and hair at the ends. Some beetle wings or carapaces have fallen off.
WebDescription:
All over the world beetles have been used in different ways to adorn the body.  They have been captured and used as live decorations for hair and clothing.  In some cases the hard outer wings, or 'elytra', which shield the abdomen of the beetle, are incorporated into textiles or other forms of decoration such as these ear ornaments.

These amazing ornaments are made from long strings of iridescent green beetle wing cases.  The ends are decorated with tassels made from brightly coloured feathers and human hair.  They would be worn looped over the ears by both men and women.

Description: cap for a chief. Decorated with large cowrie shells (Ovula ovum). Made of heavy plaits of brown fibre, probably coir, sewn together to form cone like shape. Shells attached through holes with fine plait of same fibre. Illustrated in A W Franks (British Mu
WebDescription:
This hat is made from plant fibres which have been plaited into cords.  These were then stitched round to form the cone shape of the hat.  Three of these plaits are attached to the bottom and hang down.  Large cowry shells are attached all over.  The hat is very large and heavy - it must have been quite uncomfortable to wear!

It has been in the Leeds collections for many years.  In 1829 the Calvert museum catalogue described it as a Tahitian chief's cap.   About 1870 a Mr Gay of the British Museum, working as a researcher for Augustus Wollaston Franks, sketched and described it as a chief's cap from Papua New Guinea, a long way across the Pacific Ocean from Tahiti!  We are still not certain where it comes from exactly, but Papua New Guinea is a definite possibility.

Description: ornament for forehead of cowry or nassa shells and plaited fibre. Two triangular wings with centre ridge. Centre ridge has row of 6 dogs teeth, and red split cane decoration. Plaited fibre head-band (broken).
WebDescription: Lots of small white nassa shells decorate the front of this head ornament.  They have been attached during the process of weaving the plant fibres together to make it.  The ornament's shape is a broad strap which widens in the middle.  The centre is decorated with several dog's teeth as well.  At each end is part of the band which would support the ornament on the wearers head; this was left undecorated and has now been partly broken.

Description: dragon robe, red silk ground, beautifully embroidered with gold thread with dragon designs. Large central dragon front and back, and one each on the sleeves. Two smaller dragons, and two phoenixes each side. Woman's wedding gown, or possibly theatrical or
WebDescription: Dragon robes symbolise the cosmic power of the Emperor, whose robes were a special Imperial yellow. The design includes seven heavenly dragons flying above mountains and waves. Officials or mandarins wore deep blue dragon robes, and wives, brides and actors often wore red ones. In China red is the lucky colour. This red silk robe is thickly embroidered with coloured silks and gold thread.

Description: dragon robe, red silk ground, beautifully embroidered with gold thread with dragon designs. Large central dragon front and back, and one each on the sleeves. Two smaller dragons, and two phoenixes each side. Woman's wedding gown, or possibly theatrical or
WebDescription:
Dragon robes symbolise the cosmic power of the Emperor, whose robes were a special Imperial yellow. Here the embroidered silk design includes four large dragons, with several smaller dragons and phoenixes, and dancing lions on the gold hem.  Officials or mandarins wore deep blue dragon robes, and wives, brides and actors often wore red ones. This small robe may well be for a young bride or an actor.  
Donated by Miss H M Rowntree, 1962

Description: Embroidered silk banner, not a Mandarin's cloak, as originally entered. Red fabric casing to take pole across top. Three flaps with large gold character on each. Central panel with lion dogs, figures and large gold characters. Border with inset cartouches
WebDescription:
This embroidered silk banner has a coarse red cotton or linen fabric casing across the top, to take a pole for hanging it up or carrying it. The banner is double-sided and was mainly used in processions. If it was on static display the pole would have to stand out from any wall it was fixed to, inside a temple building, or above a doorway, so that both sides could be seen. Below the casing are three flaps with a large gold character on each. These are the same on both sides and read 'Tai Ping She' which translates as '[Heavenly] Peace Society' or community. The main or central panel has two large appliqued characters, also of couched gold thread, which read 'Jin Gu' which means Golden Drum. On New Year a golden drum was transported through the village or community, beaten loudly, and the banner would have been held or fixed above it on the cart or sedan.  Repeated in the purple border is the character Xi meaning double happiness. 

Other references to New Year on the banner are the lions or lion dogs chasing balls in the bottom corners, commonly performed as a New Year dance. Smaller characters in the deep blue or purple border say 'Double Happiness' and ' Luck'. The four larger appliqued figures, two on each side, are four of the Eight Taoist immortals. One side has the flute player Han Xiangli, and a bearded scholar with a scholar's cap and a Taoist fly brush, Lu Dongbin. The other banner side has a lady with a lotus flower, He Xiangu, the patron of housewives, and a man carrying a flower basket, Lan Caihe, who is the patron of florists and gardeners. 

Down the sides and along the bottom the deep blue border silk has more couched gold thread work which include phoenixes, symbols of luck and prosperity, and inset cartouches which include happy children, associated with fertility and future generations. Fine silk tassels, in different colours, hanging from a netted fringe along the bottom.

Description: bag of brown blanket cloth (twill weave) decorated with geometric design of blue and white beads, sewn on. Two threaded bead strings for carrying with a bone button at each end where they are attached to the bag. Length of strap 28.2cms.
WebDescription: Small bag of blanket cloth, which matches the skirt and wrap (F.1959.90 and 91), with similar mainly white and blue glass bead decoration. A personal bag for a woman's prized possessions.

Description: woman's girdle or pubic dress, a rectangle of red and black leather work, with mica inside geometric cut work, and three long thick red leather strings along bottom, hung with cowry shells as clustered fringe. Signs of hanging cord at rectangle corners.
WebDescription: This is a woman?s girdle made from a rectangular piece of leather which is decorated with a pattern of triangles made from mica.  Mica is a type of naturally reflective mineral which is found throughout the world.  Many cultures have used it to add decoration to their clothing.  From the leather panel hang three tassels made from braided leather strips with lots of cowry shells attached.

Description: headdress of hide with flap behind, for a married woman, from Damaraland (later known as Hereroland, and now part of Namibia). Donated by J N Brigg, Phil and Lit Report listing for 1862-3. Concave piece of hide to fit forehead. Top front has 2 leaf shaped
WebDescription: Before the introduction of long full skirts and cloth head wraps by Victorian missionaries,  married Herero women wore a hide head cover with pointed flaps. The shape probably related to cattle horns as a symbol of wealth

Description: Single moccasin. Made of hide; vamp decorated with red and white quills in horizontal rows; ankle edge wound with white quills. JCH King: Probably Ojibway, unusual, early.
WebDescription:
Quillwork has been used for hundreds of years by Native American craftsmen as a form of decoration. It uses porcupine quills which are dyed, split, and flattened, and then stitched to the surface of the fabric in different patterns.
This moccasin is made from tanned hide. The front of the shoe, or "vamp", is decorated with bands of red and white coloured quills. The quills would be stitched down at one end of the band and then bent backwards and forwards, making a zig zag pattern.  Quills have also been used to bind along the edge of the opening of this moccasin.  It has a slightly different style from many other moccasins, which often are higher and fit around the ankle as well.  The maker might have been influenced by seeing the styles of shoes worn by European settlers who were moving to North America in larger numbers during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.  The moccasin also might have been made specifically to sell to them.

Description: pair of sandals of red leather with cross-straps. Heavy leather soles with red corners. Broad crossed thongs of red leather with punched pattern and large round boss with palm-fibre or grass interwoven. No indication of provenance, but fibre interweaven l
WebDescription: Men's sandals of intricate stamped, cut and laced leatherwork of the sort that has been fashionable for men's footwear for centuries in West Africa.

Description: single shoe, red velvet with embroidery and shells
WebDescription: The main body of this well decorated shoes is made of red silk velvet. The shoe has a rounded toe and floral designs made from a combination of raised metallic thread work and tiny pieces of shell cut into different shapes, including a five pointed star.  The metal thread embroidery extends to a leaf pattern that decorates the inside of the sole.  The metal threads have become badly tarnished but would originally have been a bright gold colour. A plain woven dull red fabric binds around the edges of the sole and the upper.  A fine strap made from a narrow strip of twisted metal is attached to the back of this shoe to help secure it onto the foot.

Description: pair of moccasins (A&B), embroidered with moose hair work. Made of one piece of blackened hide; seams at heel and over toe; decorated with red, white and blue moose hair (not quill work as originally described), in vaguely floral design. Printed label "43
WebDescription: Moccasins are a style of footwear that have been made and used by Native Americans for centuries.  This pair has been constructed from a type of blackened hide widely used by the Huron nation, who also frequently embellished their clothing using moose hair embroidery. The moose hair used is from the animal's winter coat, it can be left in this natural colour, or dyed to red and blue using vegetable dyes. A pattern of plants and flowers is embroidered around the front of the shoe using a simple running stitch. The cut edges of leather around the opening at the top have also been decorated with this stitch.

Description: cloth of woven cotton, red, black and white with double ikat dyed design of flower heads or stars and lozenges. Designed to be cut into two square cloths. Tie-dye of warp and weft threads is done before weaving.
WebDescription: This woven cotton cloth is formed by two large squares of similar design (the photograph shows only one of these), made by the ikat method. In single ikat only the weft threads are bound in sections before dyeing. In double ikat both warp and weft threads are bound in sections. The main panels here, of flower heads or stars and lozenges, have been made with double ikat, using red and black dyes to contrast with white to make up the final design. This is a fairly crude example of a patolu type ikat from Gujerat, where the best pieces are often woven in silk.

Description: Block-printed cloth, dark red and black pattern on white. Possibly some painted designs. Probably a bedspread or table-cloth rather than a sari.
WebDescription: This cotton cloth has been block-printed with a variety of floral patterns in a series of concentric panels. The main colours are black and red on white. It was probably made for use as a bedcover or tablecloth.

Description: sari cloth, double ikat tie-dye of warp and weft before weaving, with supplementary warp and weft patterning. In red, white, black, gold. Design known as Sakta.
WebDescription: This woman's sari has been woven using an ikat technique, where the warp or weft threads are bound in different places to resist the red, yellow and black dyes before weaving. This is a double and single cotton 'saktapar' sari from Orissa. The sari has been folded over itself so the photograph only shows some of its full length.

Description: one of 2 armlets or bracelets of woven rattan, coloured. Diagonally woven in very narrow strips of rattan, coloured yellow, red and dark brown. Design of longitudinal stripes and bands of opposed chevrons which form lozenges in centre.
WebDescription: This pair of armbands have been woven using different plant fibres to produce a geometric pattern of red diamonds and zig zag lines in brown and bright yellow.  People wore armbands and belts made from these materials, because they are naturally shiny and decorative.  The yellow is probably from an orchid vine and red shades could be achieved by using plant dyes.

Description: fan in lacquered case. Fan is painted in many colours with ivory overlay on faces of figures. Sticks lacquered black and gold. In rectangular wooden case lacquered black and gold with painted silk lining. Robes of figures made with appliqu cloth.
WebDescription: Colourful landscape scenes with buildings and figures in the foreground decorate the mount of this folding fan.  The mount is made from paper, pleated to allow the sticks to fold away neatly.  The sticks are wooden and are lacquered in black with more figures picked out in gold.  Attached to the rivet at the bottom of the fan is a multicoloured silk tassel.  The fan is accompanied by a wooden storage box with a pink silk lined interior and shiny black lacquered finish.

Description: Yellow silk skirt piece embroidered with floral rosettes in red and white, with deep embroidered border. Blue lining. Border of very large red and white flower heads. Conservation by Caroline Rendell, 1 section (larger) mounted for display), 2nd section (
WebDescription: This is one of two fragments from a yellow silk skirt length embroidered with diagonal rows of single flowers in red, green and white, with a deep embroidered border. The border has larger red and  white flower heads or rosettes. A blue silk lining is still attached in places.

Description: cloth fragment, grey silk embroidered with floral patterns in red, white, yellow, green, etc. Primavera ticket reads: "Embroidered fragment possibly of a corslet. China or Philippine Islands, for European market, 18th century". However it may be a cushion
WebDescription: This cloth fragment of grey/green silk is embroidered with floral patterns in red, white, yellow, and green silk thread. It probably comes from China or the Philippine Islands. It was made for the European market in the mid 19th century if not before, as a furnishing fabric, or possibly for a dress coat or jacket. Latterly it may have been part of a cushion cover.

Description: all-in-one masquerade costume, covering head to feet, made of natural and black string, knitted in looped technique. Large vent or hole on stomach or centre back, to get in and out of costume. Fringed with raffia at wrists, ankles and vent. Broad bands of
WebDescription:
This one-piece costume would cover the wearer?s entire head and body.  It is made from looped and knitted plant fibres which are probably raffia. Some parts of the naturally brown coloured raffia have been dyed black to produce a horizontal stripe.  The openings at the hands and feet are decorated with a raffia fringe.  By comparison with a more modern example in the collections (F.2002.0003.0016) we know that another fringe would have covered up the large horizontal opening across the front of the chest through which the wearer would get in, putting the bottom half on like a pair of trousers, then pulling over the top. The costume covers the entire head.  You can just see where a cord is attached to the head on the left hand side.  This would pull the fabric away from the masquerader's face so that he could see where he was going more easily.  
The costume would be worn by a male masquerader on feast days to play practical jokes and entertain onlookers.  A wooden mask would be worn on the front or top of the head.

Description: tall mask; brown human face with tribal marks; striped and spotted "cap" with 2 pairs of "horns" - front ones short, held by spotted quadruped, back pair tall, ending in hands, snake catching bird at sides; acrobat between taller horns; female figure at b
WebDescription: The Egungun Society is associated with ancestors and the cult of the dead.  Some characters in their masquerades have great religious significance, whilst others are more entertaining and satirical. Between the long horns of this taller mask is a spotted animal and an acrobat.

Description: tall mask with black face and beard; tall curved ears facing outwards, pink inside; pink quadruped between ears at back. Carved wood. Face has white eyes and Egba scar marks on forehead and cheeks, and chaplet? on top of head. Animal between ears stands o
WebDescription: Egungun society mask from the Yoruba area of Nigeria. Collected by the Yorkshire artist Jacob Kramer, and William Fagg believed the mask was by the famous carver Adugbologe, who died in the early 1940s, or by one of his family, who still work around the Olumo rock in Nigeria.

Description: basketry foundation, cloth-covered, with beadwork all over; represents woman carrying child on her back; two stylised faces on base, with pair of eye-holes one side. Face above eye holes has stylised parallel scar marks below its eyes. See note by William
WebDescription: This elaborate beadwork form is a masquerade headdress worn during masked dances by the Yoruba of southwest Nigeria. Tiny glass beads, imported from Europe, are laid in coils round a cane and cloth frame. Amongst them are a few coils of longer red bead tubes, imitating coral. The lower half has a face front and back, with projecting eyes, similar to those that decorate the elaborate beaded crowns worn by Yoruba chiefs. The top half is a three dimensional sculpture of a mother's head, with breasts and arms, and a baby carried on her back. The headdress was probably made by one of the craftsmen who make the chiefs' crowns. Its use for masquerade is indicated by the two rectangular eye holes at the front near the base.

Description: Hand-woven narrow strip cloth, indigo; white hand embroidery. Narrow blue strips are woven by male weavers and stitched together, in the Northern Emirates, e.g. Kano and Sekotoa; it is patterned with white in the weaving, and then embroidered with a tradi
WebDescription: This man's robe is made of indigo dyed cotton cloth woven locally in narrow strips, which are then sewn together and sent to an embroiderer. The strips on this robe include a small amount of plain white threads in the weave. The embroider has decorated the centre top front and the centre top rear with the complex geometric 'knife' patterns done in chain or ladder stitch in cream silk. This very large robe is worn by the Hausa and other northern traders with the sleeve sides heaped in folds on the shoulders. The size of the robe and the number of strips it is made from are a sign of wealth and status.

Description: pair of chaps, or leather leggings, for a cowboy. Made of commercially tanned leather, machine sewn, buckle at waist; pockets; fringes on outside of legs. Brown colour. Non-Indian manufacture.
WebDescription: These leggings, or chaps, are a type of trousers which hang from the belt but are not joined together in the middle.  They would be worn over a pair of ordinary trousers to protect the legs of the wearer from thorny bushes or cacti.  This example has leather fringing down each side, and two front pockets.  They are made from commercially tanned black leather.  The name chaps comes from the Spanish word "chaparejos", which refers to a pair of stout leather trousers.  Lots of Spanish terms were used by cowboys in North America, which they learned from working with Spanish and Mexican people.

Description: man's fringed shirt with beadwork over shoulders and down sleeves; triangular beaded cloth panel at neck. Made of white-coloured, cured hide; has long sleeves decorated with rectangular panels of beadwork sewn over shoulders and on sleeves; glass beads ar
WebDescription:
Sioux or Lakota beadwork can often be identified by the use of geometric, symmetrical designs on a white background.  Glass beads like the ones used on this shirt were imported to North America in huge quantities during the nineteenth century.  Beadwork eventually replaced traditional techniques such as quillwork.  Beads were available in many different colours.  Using them was less time consuming than using porcupine quills, which had to be dyed and flattened before they could be used.  

The beadwork on this shirt was carried out on separate pieces of leather and then applied.  The beads are sewn to the leather using 'lazy stitch'.  The thread passes through from the reverse side of the fabric and is threaded through several beads before stitching back down through the material.  The process continues in rows until the area to be beaded is covered.  This technique can often be identified by the appearance of ridges in the beadwork where the beaded thread has arched up slightly, away from the surface of the fabric or leather.  Four beaded bands decorate this shirt.  One runs across each shoulder, and there is a beaded band on each sleeve.  The bands are decorated with geometric patterns in green, light blue, dark blue, black, red and yellow, on a white ground.  

The shirt is T shaped, with the sleeves fitted at right angles to the body.  It is slit part of the way up each side seam.  The leather has been cut to give a notched zig zag edge all the way up each side seam, and at the cuffs.  The round neckline has an insert at the front, of a triangular panel of fabric which gives the effect of a V neckline.  The panel is made up from two smaller triangles of fabric, one blue and one red.  Some geometric patterned beadwork decorates the edge and middle of this insert, using red, black, light blue and yellow beads.  Leather fringing runs around the edges of the V shaped neck panel and along the bottom edges of all the beadwork panels.

Description: woollen picture on wooden panel, wool strands glued down. Design of two animals (possibly squirrels?) climbing two trees (pine trees?). Maroon or purple lower ground, black upper ground. Trees in red and maroon, animals in blue/grey, the right one having
WebDescription: Woollen picture made with wool strands glued down onto a wooden panel. Typical yarn image, or nearika (meaning 'face', 'aspect', 'design'), originally made as a record of a shaman's journey into the Other World by the Huichol of Western Mexico, and then popularised as a form of folk art. The design has two animals (possibly squirrels?) climbing two trees (pine trees?), against a maroon or purple lower ground, and a black upper ground. The trees are in red and maroon, and the animals in blue/grey, the right one having a yellow patch in its centre, the left one a red patch.

Description: sleeveless tunic with embroidered full-length skirting. Part of a 3 piece festival costume, purchased for 10/- from Clough, a shop.  The Menidi are Albanians who settled near Athens in the early 20th century, EM May 1985.
WebDescription: On the combined costume photograph the long sleeveless tunic worn under the waist coat and bodice is most visible at the bottom. It has full-length skirting which is embroidered in a deep band at the hem. The three-part festival costume is worn by the Menidi who are Albanians who settled near Athens in the early 20th century. The hem panel is embroidered in a dense pattern in a style typical of mainland Greece.  Figures of fertility goddesses and plant forms accompany horizontal geometric lines. The scalloped edging along the top is another typical feature of Greek embroidery.

Description: bodice with embroidered sleeves. Part of costume set A-C.
WebDescription: This bodice or short jacket has sleeves with panels of very dense gold thread embroidery, floral coloured embroidery, and black on white embroidery. The neckline is deeply curved and trimmed with red. The bodice is one of 3 items which make up the Menidi festival costume.

Description: embroidered waistcoat. Part of costume set, A-C.
WebDescription: This waistcoat is the third item in the Menidi festival costume. It is made from red and cream wool cloth lined with a dull green calico. It is trimmed with complex embroidery of couched gold thread, on a cream or black ground.

Description: wooden mask with curved protrusion on forehead and tribal marks on cheeks. Has purple raffia fringe. Modern work, probably in imitation of traditional "juju" mask. Old insect infestation holes.
WebDescription: A modern Nigerian mask, made of wood, with curved protrusion on forehead, and tribal marks from the Ikot Ekpene region carved on both cheeks. The purple hair is made of raffia (for with Ikot Ekpene is famous), and the mask is probably an imitation of traditional "juju" masks found in the area.

Description: Tiny square of cream barkcloth, with black star design, painted on irregularly. Just a fragment of a larger cloth. D Starzecka, 4/2/1994: Hawaii is possible, or Tahiti. One of a group of three fragments.
WebDescription: This tiny square of cream barkcloth has been stamped or painted with small black star shapes in an irregular pattern. It must be a fragment of a much larger cloth. Pacific barkcloth is made from the inner bark of the breadfruit tree, whose fibres are felted together with wooden beaters.

Description: small sample of barkcloth, formerly described as paper made from bark
WebDescription: This second barkcloth fragment is much more darkly coloured with a resinous dye. The surface varies a fair deal, and has an embossed or indented design of fine lines produced by ribbing or ridges on the barkcloth beater. The underside of the barkcloth is a much paler plainer colour. Originally both fragments were labelled 'Paper from North America' but they are both definitely from the Pacific.

Description: costume doll, a mother with child on her back. Heads probably of non-Indian manufacture and are painted. Doll's hair is black human hair; child wears headband, mother has wooden legs, hide boots, skirt of printed red, black and white cotton and blanket of
WebDescription: Costume doll, a mother with a child on her back. The dolls' heads are probably of non-Indian manufacture and are painted. The hair is black human hair and the child wears a headband. The mother has wooden legs, hide boots, and a skirt of printed red, black and white cotton. A wool blanket of cream, yellow, green and red colour bands, is wrapped round the mother and baby together, as a shawl.

Description: woman's kimono, probably circa 1910. Grey silk crepe, stencilled and embroidered with designs of flowers, streams, huts and birds. Includes plum blossom and chrysanthemums. Crane on front left shoulder, on front left centre above hut and two other birds,
WebDescription:
This kimono is made of grey silk crepe, lined with bright orange silk.  The floor length hem is padded inside with cotton wadding.  It would have been worn by a woman on formal occasions, and is known as a 'furisode' because of the long sleeves.  It is a simple t-shape with a cross over front opening which would be fastened with a wide fabric belt called an obi.  This would probably be brightly coloured to contrast or coordinate with the kimono, and be tied around the waist with a layered decorative padded knot, usually at the back.

Landscape scenery with streams, trees and flowers forms most of the pattern, with a crane on the front and two turtles on the back, both symbols of long life.  The pattern has been achieved with a combination of embroidery using brightly coloured silks and gold metallic threads, and stencilled patterns.  The stencilled patterns were probably resist dyed.  A thick rice paste would have been applied to the cloth through a patterned paper stencil.  The stencil would be removed and the cloth dyed.  Finally, the fabric would be washed to remove the resist paste.

Kimonos have been worn in Japan by men and women for hundreds of years.  Nowadays they are usually only worn for special occasions.  Women?s kimono are much more highly decorated than those for men.

Description: conical knitted cap, very fine yarn, rows of white figures on multicoloured horizontal stripes, red, dark green and purple. Large band of dark green at tip, and a little further down. Primavera label: S.V./63/34/5 "Antique Knitted Hat".
WebDescription: This conical cap is hand knitted with very fine wool yarn. The main design is several rows of tiny white figures on a red ground, with green and purple bands in between. There is a deep green band at the top, and another larger one further down. The tip is decorated with a red wool tassel. The white figures include birds, llamas, cows and horses. Images of animals are included in many textiles from South America.

Description: one of a pair of silk cloth hangings made into curtains by their British owners, which go with a third cloth, made from matching secondary pieces. The two large long cloths are to be labelled A (with lady in panel centre) and B (with man in panel centre)
WebDescription:
Cloth hanging with Hsi Wong Mu, the Queen Mother of the West. 
Embroidered silk and satin, now much faded, Hsi Wong Mu is in the red centre panel and the dark blue side panels feature Taoist Immortals. Conservation work on this panel was undertaken by Kate Stockwell. 
Donated by G. Blenconner, 1964.

Description: one of a pair of large silk cloths and joined extensions, made into curtains by their British owners. This cloth, B, features Shou Lao, Taoist or Daoist God of Long Life, or longevity, in the centre. He is the prototype of male success. Length of central
WebDescription: Cloth hanging with Shou Lao, God of Long Life, paired with the cloth that features the Queen Mother of the West. Embroidered silk and satin. Shou Lao stands in the centre panel with a deer holding his long staff which has a dragon head, in his left hand, and a peach, a symbol of a long life in his right. The dark blue side panels feature the eight Taoist Immortals. Donated by G. Blenconner, 1964

Description: rectangular piece of barkcloth, 19th century, three of the edges with pointed scallops. Designs in black, brownish red and white of squares, diagonal, leaf-shapes and cross-hatching. D Starzecka, 4/2/1994: 2 layers, top one pasted onto a 2nd one which has
WebDescription: This large piece of barkcloth, made from the inner bark of the breadfruit tree, has been decorated with a geometric design of squares with diagonal lines, using a stencil. The edges are scalloped or toothed. The paint used is a dark resin applied in both thick spreads and fine lines.

Description: bark-cloth dress, early 20th century European style, of decorated brown and black on white barkcloth. Very fine, full of holes. Needs conservation. Provenance confirmed by Dorota Starzecka of BM, 7/2/1994.
WebDescription: This bark-cloth dress is tailored in an early 20th century European style that is now badly creased. The cloth itself is quite fine in texture. It has painted stencilled decoration in broad bands of feathers and zigzags in shades of brown and black.

Description: H-shaped skin with fringes of red and white beads. Originally described as goat skin. Central line of red and white bead fringe, two tassels at two of the four leg corners. Arranged to be worn 'horizontally' at waist.
WebDescription: This piece of hide still has black and white hair still attached to it, and may have come from a goat.  It is H shaped, and would be worn around the waist using the top two "tails" as ties, leaving the bottom two hanging free.  Across the middle the hide is decorated with a striped fringe of alternating red and white glass beads.  Several strings of each of these also decorate the bottom of the hanging sections.

Description: Hand-woven narrow strip cloth, indigo dyed. Hand embroidered short robe called RIGA. Narrow strips are sewn together, the native cotton dyed locally with indigo, but inside is band for lower hem with some imported thread. Typical Hausa work and design. Ro
WebDescription:
This man's robe, called Riga, has a flared body and long sleelves. It is made from narrow strips of locally handwoven cotton cloth sewn together. The warp threads are dyed with indigo, and there are embroidered details in running stitch and ladder stitch of concentric lines and interlaced knots at the neck, and on the body round false pockets. 

This is one of many costume and textile pieces at Leeds originally collected by the Church Missionary Society.

Description: red seed headdress or headdress part. Two pear-shaped rings lying one on top of the other with connecting spine at top. Covered with red seeds, wound round spirally.
WebDescription: Headdress, or headdress part, formed by two pear-shaped rings made of plant fibre completely covered in red abrus seeds. The seeds are threaded onto a string and wound round spirally. Amongst the Angas people such red headdresses are worn by successful warriors.

Description: pointed cap-shape with U-shaped pieces over ears; fibre base with red and black abrus seeds sewn over surface. Originally described as a 'witchdoctor's' headdress, "The ? Murder of the Witch", No. 5 Witch Doctor - D Headdress". From pagan tribes of Nigeri
WebDescription: This is a much more elaborate or complete Angas warrior's headdress, in the form of a conical cap with side rings, almost completely covered in red and dark brown abrus seeds. The seeds are threaded onto a string, which is then couched onto the basketry and plant fibre base. One long seed thread with a pendant wood disc hangs down the front centre. Although several of the seeds are now missing the overall effect is still stunning.

Description: Basketry cone shaped headdress decorated with cowries all over, with knob shaped finial. Cowries stitched in vertical lines except for horizontal row along rim. Label reads: CMS Cowry shell headdress as worn by a chief, Uganda, no. 148.
WebDescription:
This helmet like headdress has a basketry base of plant fibre which is almost completely covered by cowry shells. According to the original collector from the Church Missionary Society it was worn by a Ugandan cheif. 
Cowry shells were shipped in large quantities from India to Africa for hundreds of years. Africans valued them both for decorative use, and as a widespread form of money counter or currency.

Description: Described as a "juju skirt" of raffia. Dyed grass or fine vegetable fibre with crimped resist pattern in centres. Original provenance West Africa, but this looks much more like Papua New Guinea woman's skirt, than part of a masquerader's outfit from West
WebDescription: This woman's skirt is made of dyed grass or fine vegetable fibre strips which have a crimped resist pattern in the centre. The fibres are knotted together like long tassels with a thicker fibre which winds along the top through a series of tassel knots.

Description: garter or leglet for dancing, with reddish brown seed rattles attached. Cord to encircle leg below knee. From it are suspended short strings with the half seed or bean shapes at their ends. The button on the cord is formed by an Arabic? coin, dated 1941.
WebDescription: Leglet or anklet with seed rattles made of short strings with half seed or bean shapes at their ends. The button on the cord is formed by an Arabic coin, dated 1941. The label reads: 'Bean beads worn just below the knees during dancing. Oji River Leper Colony, Nigeria. Mrs A Garrett, September 1953'.

Description: white, locally woven cotton cloth, with regular horizontal bands of openwork, formed by twisting pairs of warps etc. Provenance not known. From West African cupboard of CMS Institute room.
WebDescription: This cream cotton cloth was woven locally on a medium width loom, using locally grown cotton fibre. It has regular horizontal bands of openwork, formed by twisting pairs of warps. It was probably sold as a scarf or shawl, for fairly everyday use.

Description: indigo dyed cloth, woven in narrow 2" strips, white and indigo threads mixed. Locally spun cotton. May be Hausa or possibly Ilorin. Woven by men.
WebDescription: This locally woven cotton cloth is made up of several narrow strips, woven by men on narrow back strap looms, then sewn together. It incorporates both white and indigo dyed threads. It is the sort of cloth that would be made into men's trousers or everyday robes.

Description: Small shirt of factory cloth, indigo-dyed with tie-dyed circles. Imported cotton cloth. Local indigo dye. Probably Yoruba. Cloth is factory-woven damask (on Jacquard loom) VBJ.
WebDescription: This woman's shirt or blouse is made of factory woven cotton cloth, indigo-dyed with a fairly regular pattern of tie-dye circles. The cloth itself is an imported damask, but the dyeing was done locally, with locally made indigo dye.

Description: small shirt of white handwoven cotton, with red and black woven stripes, and black embroidery. Originally described as from West Africa, provenance identified as Toda in May 1996 by VBJ.  Made from shawl cloth?
WebDescription: This short sleeved shirt is made of handwoven cotton, mainly cream with red and black woven stripes, and black embroidery. It may have been sewn up from pieces cut from a shawl cloth. The neck line, sleeve ends and hem are machine stitched. It has been photographed with a matching cloth length (F.1966.0348) wrapped round as a skirt.

Description: factory print, orange and blue, man's cotton shirt with variety of African motifs, zodiac signs etc. Industrial printing made to look like batik (VBJ). Motifs include a comb, cocoa-pod?, mask?, bird, chintzy style musical instrument, "Hausa knot", motif o
WebDescription: This man's shirt is made from machine printed cotton that imitates batik in style. The design is a grid of African motifs, including combs and gourds, with larger lozenges featuring Muslim knotwork. It was probably made in Europe for the West African market.

Description: pair of hide sandals, boat-shaped. Moulded hide of pachyderm. Interior scored and decorated with red and black lines. Skin ring for great toe.
WebDescription: This is one of a pair of sandals, of thick elephant hide, moulded into a boat-shape, with the sides curled up. The inside has been scored and painted with red and black lines. A skin ring is sewn on directly for the great toe, and a larger main grip is threaded through side rings.  These straps have been damaged by clothes moth, originally they would have been furred. These fine sandals would have been worn by a man of high status.

Description: cotton scarf, wall hanging or other type of furnishing textile. Printed with geometric design with lobed circle in centre and short edge border bands featuring flower clusters, and domes.
WebDescription: Cotton scarf, wall hanging or other type of furnishing textile that has been hand-printed with a geometric design. There is a lobed circle in the centre and short edge border bands featuring flower clusters and domes.

Description: woman's embroidered robe, full-length of coarse linen? material, local weave in natural cream colour. Elaborate embroidered pattern in red, black and pink cross-stitch embroidery on chest panel, tops of sleeves and two side lengths down front of robe. Ram
WebDescription: This full-length women's robe of coarse linen was woven locally in a natural cream colour and embroidered in cross-stitch with red, black and pink threads. The densest embroidery is on the chest panel. The thread used for the embroidery is a mercerized cotton, which replaced the silk floss popular at an earlier date. The long triangular sleeves and broad body of the robe are really distinctive. This sort of robe was worn at weddings in the village of Ramallah.

Description: woman's gown or robe, of coarse woven striped cotton, with gussets and insets of imported cotton and silk piece. Front of breast elaborately embroidered. Originally described as man's dress, more likely to be a woman's (VBJ), the front panel applique and
WebDescription: This woman's gown or robe is made from coarsely woven striped cotton, with gussets and inserts of imported cotton and silk. The chest front is elaborately embroidered, with applique and couching similar to that found at Bethlehem. However, it could have been made in Hebron where more of the women worked in the fields for most of the year, and so had less time to sew themselves. They often incorporated Bethelehm front panels purchased from traders in their robes.

Description: factory print, probably resist-printed; blocks of yellow/greeny patterns imitating tie-dye, on indigo; fringed ends. Worn by woman as a wrapper. D.M.Hann, Leeds Univ. 5/4/95: this is Jacquard-woven fabric, resist-printed with engraved copper roller, using
WebDescription: Cotton cloth length worn by women as a wrapper. The fabric was woven in a factory on a Jacquard loom, and then resist-printed with an engraved copper roller with a synthetic dye that imitates indigo. The design is a deliberate imitation of tie dye. The weaving may have been done in Europe, and the printing in Africa, or the whole process done before importing to Africa.

Description: Shirt of factory-woven cotton, tie-dyed indigo pattern. Most of shirt or tunic plain indigo. Two rows of white tie-dye dots at junction of sleeves with body, and cross band of white tie dye near mid height of body.
WebDescription: This is a woman's shirt or blouse of factory-woven cotton with tie-dyed indigo pattern on the shoulders, and in a band across the body. The cotton cloth was probably imported, whilst the tie-dye was done locally. The design of two rows of tie-dye dots at the shoulders, and two broad ties on the body is simple and dramatic.

Description: Factory-woven cotton cloth, with all-over starry pattern, tie-dyed indigo. Possibly a headtie.
WebDescription: This square of factory-woven cotton cloth was probably used as a head tie by women. It has an indigo tie-dyed pattern of irregular all-over knots or stars, that was done locally in Africa.

Description: factory cloth, indigo discharge print with white motifs, probably worn as a wrapper. Imported cotton piece dyed in West Africa, with reserved pattern of squares, arrows etc. May be Nigerian. Dr. M. Hann, Leeds University, 5/4/95: "Design is typical of scr
WebDescription: This cotton cloth was probably worn by women as a wrapper. It was woven and dyed in a factory, probably in Nigeria rather then Europe. It is an indigo discharge print with a white reserved pattern of squares, arrows, etc, probably done with a roller.

Description: white handwoven cloth, with red and black woven stripes, black embroidery. Originally described as West African, provenance identified by VBJ in May 1996. Woven on wide loom, with red and orange vertical stripes near edges, red and black horizontal woven
WebDescription: The large white handwoven cloth, shown here wrapped round as a skirt, is usually worn over other clothing as a full length shawl or wrap. The cream cotton has been woven on a wide loom with red and orange vertical stripes near the edges, and red and black horizontal woven bands with black zigzags worked warp ways and weft ways. On top of these is some additional black embroidery.

Description: cotton tunic or blouse. Original colour seems to have been yellow; then dyed dark blue, leaving band of yellow at bottom and "reserved" patches for design. Pattern then ?stencilled on with black background leaving yellow 'herring-bone' design, later touch
WebDescription: This man's cotton tunic or blouse was probably printed to look like batik.  The first layer of dye colour seems to have been yellow, the next dark blue or brown, leaving band of yellow at bottom and "reserved" patches for the more detailed pattern. The herring bone or fern pattern may have been applied with stencils which left the design as background, to be touched up afterwards in red.

Description: calico cloth, hand block-printed, 19th century (see comments by J. Wearden for F.1966.354). Square with central circular design, similar to Turkish turban covers, but this one probably a table cloth. Border with Persian calligraphy infilled cartouches, bl
WebDescription: Calico cotton cloth, for domestic use as a table cloth. Block-printed by hand with floral design and border of Persian calligraphy repeats. The Persian translates to something like 'in awe of your munificence that continues daily'. This is part of a longer quote from a saying or poem, which would be very appropriate for a table cloth.

Description: calico cloth, block printed by hand. Probably 19th century (see comments by J Wearden for F.1966.354, 1989). This one probably a prayer mat, with central mihrab arch shape. Ulrike al-Khamis (NMS) 29/9/2005: but unlike a proper mat it has no border or lini
WebDescription: Calico cotton cloth, block-printed by hand with a mihrab arch shape and floral designs, that would make the cloth appropriate to use as a prayer mat. The finials along the top represent alams or ornaments that were carried in the Muharram or commemorative processions recalling the martyrdom of Hussein at Kabala. As this cloth has no border of quilted lining it may be a decorative hanging rather than a prayer mat.

Description: Jacket or coat of printed cotton. Front patterned with red stripes alternating with cream with curious interlocking design. Lined with sprigged red cotton.  J. Wearden (V&A 1989). This is late 19th century Persian. Good lining, but outer cloth probably im
WebDescription: This jacket or short coat is made of printed cotton. The front is patterned with deep red stripes alternating with cream with a curious interlocking design. The lining is a sprigged red cotton cloth.  The lining may have been printed locally but the outer cloth is more probably imported from France or Britain.

Description: man's robe or gown, of printed cotton or calico, with floral sprig design. Lined. Comments by J. Wearden (V&A 1989): Good one, would be worn with trousers and a white shirt (c.f. JMW 1989 Persian Printed Cottons, V&A, plate 13).
WebDescription: This man's robe or gown is made of cotton or calico, printed locally with a floral sprig design. It is lined and would be worn with trousers and a white shirt.

Description: printed cotton coat for a child. Floral designs in stripes, red, blue, green on white. Lined with white cotton. Cuffs decorated with silver wire etc on blue velvet and with row of brass buttons. This decoration added later and can be removed. Fitted with
WebDescription: This printed cotton coat or jacket would be worn by a child, either a girl or a boy. The fabric has floral designs in narrow stripes, of red, blue and green on white. It is lined with white cotton. The cuffs are decorated with silver wire threadwork on blue velvet and a row of brass buttons. The pocket contained a white cotton handkerchief with a border of grey spots and a child's nursery rhyme in English.
