The velvet is an addition to the sleeves which could be removed, and is definitely not original.

Description: boy's coat or robe of cotton with tiger design, printed in black on a yellow ground. Label reads "Boy's Tiger Coat to frighten the evil spirits. China. C.M.S. Case 145, no. 562". Found with bundle labelled Malaya. L Wrigglesworth July 1986: "Not Chinese s
WebDescription: This cotton coat or robe has a tiger skin design, printed in black on a yellow ground. The old Church Missionary Society display label reads "Boy's Tiger Coat to Frighten the Evil Spirits. China". It may have come from an expatriate Chinese community in Malaysia, rather than China itself. It was probably made and worn for a special dance or a play.

Description: woman's dress-coat or tunic, blue and white thick cotton. Dark blue background, white design of flowers and rondels with knotwork inside. Narrow collar, right side fastening, and neck opening on diagonal (Chinese-style), from centre to side. Depth measure
WebDescription: This woman's tunic is made of thick cotton printed with a blue and white floral design. It has a narrow collar, right side fastening, and a diagonal neck opening which is Chinese in style, from the centre to the right side. It came with a matching pair of trousers, and was probably made by Chinese tailors for Malaysian wear.

Description: blue and white cotton trousers, which go with the tunic F.1966.380. Large rough white cotton waist band. Dark blue background, white design of flowers and leaf sprigs.
WebDescription: These blue and white cotton trousers go with the tunic that has a similar but more complicated floral design (F.1966.0381). The trousers have a deep white cotton waist band and broad straight legs. They are printed with a pattern of white leaf sprays on the dark blue ground.

Description: sarong of floral printed batik cotton in cream with lattice and dark red floral border ends. Labelled No. 13, Malay Man Sarong, C.M.S. Sewn rather than worn open, two edges would be stitched together.
WebDescription: This sarong length of floral printed batik cotton has a cream ground in its centre, with a lattice motif behind large colourful flowers. The borders and deep end panel are brown with a russet red and cream flower pattern. This cloth is for a man's sarong, which would be sewn up as a tube for wear, rather than just wrapped around. The batik is done with both wax resist printing blocks made of copper, and wax line drawing pens for some fine detail.

Description: pair of caribou skin gloves or mitts. Confirmed by JCH King that this is caribou rather than reindeer. Now rather dried out, but fur still in marvellous condition.
WebDescription: Pair of thick caribou skin gloves with the fur on the outside. The caribou migrate southwards in the winter, but the temperatures in arctic Canada are so low they still need this thick fur to keep warm, and it makes ideal glove material.

Dimensions:
object length: 90mm
object width: 45mm
object depth: 15mm
Description: Kaffir' boy's badge. Brass belt buckle stamped as a badge with name, date 1897, and number. Oval with straight short ends, and long oval piercings at these ends. Dented and worn.
WebDescription: Boy's badge, worn as a belt buckle. It has a name, number and date which suggest it was a 'pass' badge, which enabled the wearer to work in a European or Whites only area.

Description: locket on a chain, with Brahma riding on goose. Made in India for Europeans?. Chain broke and is now separate (AL March 2012). Locket opens to reveal to oval photograph holders with paper inserts. One will not come out, but the other is loose. The workman
WebDescription: From the mid 19th century silver lockets with Hindu deities on them were popular with Europeans. They were often used to carry miniature photographs of loved ones. The deities were often shown riding their animal vehicles, such as here with Brahma on his goose.  Many were lised in the catalogue of  P. Orr and Son, a Britsih firm in Madras who were renound for making silver jewelry decorated with Hindu deities and marketed as 'swami ware''' - See J Bloom (2009) The Grove encyclopedia of Islamic art and architecture, Volume 2. OUP. The source of this locket is not recorded.

Description: Pair of embroidered leather slippers, Arab type, probably from Egypt. Reddish leather with outer surface tanned a littled darker, with embroidery in cream, gold and red silk thread, and some painted designs on the heels (to check).
WebDescription: This pair of embroidered leather slippers are embroidered with a floral and curved geometric design typical of Egyptian traditional fashion. The heels also have painted decoration.

Description: single shoe for lady with bound foot. Embroidered green silk upper with three different silk brocades above, black, pink and yellow. Tiny pointed toe, small heel covered with quilted cream cloth over card or wood base. Brocades have different floral desig
WebDescription: This single shoe is for a lady with bound feet. It has a tiny pointed toe, and a small heel and sole, covered with quilted cream cloth over a card or rope base. The embroidered green silk upper has three different silk brocades above, in black, pink and yellow. It was mainly upper class women of the Han Chinese majority who had their feet bound. This was a very painful process which began at the age of five or six, when the toes were broken and pushed back under the instep. The feet were then bound tightly with ribbons and bandages. The result was meant to be as beautiful as a lotus bud. Many missionaries campaigned against foot binding and the practice was outlawed by the Chines People's Republic after 1949.

Description: Polish Gala boots of black leather with decorative applique design in red, yellow, green and white leather.
WebDescription: Man's Gala or dancing boots of black leather with decorative applique design in red, yellow, green and white leather.

Description: circular basketry hat, black and natural basketry with reddish brown and green leather work on rim of brim and crown. Originally described as a chief's hat but could have belonged to any important man or trader. Top of crown has square of green leather wi
WebDescription: This circular basketry hat has contrasting bands and details in black and natural basketry with reddish brown and green leather work on the brim rim and the crown. The top of the crown has a square of green leather with four spokes or leaves embroidered in red wool or floss silk. The other main design on the crown are panels with a lozenge chain in red and green leather. Originally this was described as a chief's hat but it may have belonged to any important man or trader.

Description: pair of leather boots for a child, with thong for tying on snow-shoes?. Soles stitched on separately. Paler skin tops with rectangular cut work, or 'ladder' band.
WebDescription: Pair of leather boots for a child, with thongs for tying round the ankles. The soles are stitched on separately. The paler skin tops are decorated with rectangular cut work, making a 'ladder' band.

Description: Bag of silk with birch bark panels embroidered with moose hair flowers. Hexagonal panel at base with design of pipe smoker, tree-trunk and flowers.
WebDescription: This drawsting bag was probably used by a Canadian or European woman for storing sewing threads or more precious items. It is made of  factory woven silk with 7 birch bark panels embroidered with moose hair. The hexagonal panel at the base has a design of a pipe smoker, tree-trunk and flowers. Two of the other panels also include figures, whilst the rest are of plants or flowers, and a small canoe outline. The panels would have been produced by Woodlands area Amerindian women for sale as souvenirs.

Description: skin apron of dressed cow or calf skin, with pale yellow or white hair on inside, decorated outside with upper edge band of thick blue glass beads, then narrow band of blocks of pink, white, red and green beads, then fringe panels of mainly pink and white
WebDescription: This large skin apron of dressed cow or calf skin has pale yellow or cream hair on the inside, and is decorated outside with glass beads. These would have been acquired through trade at local shops. The upper edge has a band of thick blue glass beads, then a narrow band of blocks of pink, white, red and green beads. Below this are several fringe panels of mainly pink and white beads, with a few green and red. The fringe strands are fairly long and would have moved when the wearer walked. It was probably worn by a woman.

Description: pair of ladies shoes, with raised heels. Tops have floral design, edged with blue, and two parallel ridges down toe. Soles raised 102 mm on central block.
WebDescription: This pair of ladies shoes have large platforms or raised heels. The tops are of tapestry woven silk with a floral design, edged with plain blue silk. There are two parallel ridges covered in pale green silk down the front over the toes, and a reinforcing flap over the back ankle. These shoes would have been worn by wealthy Manchu women whose feet were unbound.

Description: pair of wooden sandals, Arab type. Raised up 5 cms, on four 'feet'. Fibre cords threaded through holes in heel and sole for instep and big toe. No provenance, but similar to Arab type (F.1962.103), and may be Central or East African.
WebDescription: A pair of Arab style wooden sandals, raised up on four 'feet', with plaited fibre cords threaded through holes in the heel and sole for instep and big toe.

Description: more likely to be an armlet than a headdress as first thought. Made of twisted fibre, seeds and rectangular panel covered with peccary teeth. Panel is made of woven fibre cord with 12 rows of teeth sewn on. Originally thought to be peccary teeth, identifi
WebDescription: This elaborate ornament was probably worn on the upper arm by an important man. It is made of twisted fibre, large black seeds and many rows of tiny teeth. These are monkey teeth, and there are 12 rows of them sewn on through tiny piercings in the teeth roots. The long side cords for tying the ornament round the arm are crossed and lashed together to form a circlet. One cord has a piece of lizard skin attached. The cord ends continue to form long tassels, the ends of which are usually decorated with round black seeds, Job's tear seeds, small beans, shell pieces or bone beads.

Description: spiral brass armlet with eight turns, of quarter inch brass rod.
WebDescription: Spiral armlet of steel, worn by a man on his upper arm.

Description: circular block of red pigment, which seems to have been collected in a basket, and presumably used as a dye.
WebDescription: Block of red clay pigment for face and body colour. It is dry and hard and the outer surface is rough and worn.

Description: wooden frame covered with red felt, coxcomb effect at top with blue and yellow cord sewn on. Band of embroidered braid, then panel of check silk. Flaps at front with strings to tie under chin. Lace along bottom edge. Broad ribbon, with gold embroidery, fo
WebDescription: This hat for a Sami or Lapp child with its distinctive curved peak has a wooden body or frame which is covered in red wool felt or blanket cloth. Blue and yellow cords are sewn into the upper seams, and a band of metal foil braid followed by a lace topped panel of check silk goes around the lower body. The hat extends with flaps at the sides and strings to tie under chin. The bottom edge is trimmed with lace.

Description: bone comb with five teeth and long handle with four pierced circles in centre, one broken off. Then long handle end with lozenge incised pattern, and rounded top. Curved in profile.
WebDescription: Narrow bone comb with waisted grip, now damaged and four long teeth.

Description: child's brass wire bracelet, with open work design.
WebDescription: A child's brass wire bracelet, with open work design. Provenance unknown.

Description: cross pendant made of large red glass or coral beads, on metal wire, with ring loop at top for suspension.
WebDescription: This cross pendant is made of large red glass or coral beads, strung on metal wire, with a small loop at the top for suspension.

Description: Embroidered silk robe, probably an actor's or opera singer's robe, with large gold dragon head centre front and back. Raised effect produced by wire ripples, at edges of head, and under some of the gold stitching. Medium quality stitching in fairly coarse
WebDescription: This embroidered silk robe probably belonged to an actor. It has a large gold lion or dragon head in the centre on the front and back. The open mouth and some of the edges of head are made more dragmatic by the raised effect produced by wire and cotton thread stuffing under some of the gold thread work. The rest of the embroidery is of medium quality stitching in fairly coarse silk twist, originally in very bright cerise, red, purple and green. The robe has a cotton print lining with a floral design and side flaps of cerise silk with gold against purple character emroidery. Other characters are embroidred on the sleeve ends.

Description: pair of wood and twisted hide snowshoes. Narrow hide twistings, darker wood frames than F.1969.6.
WebDescription: Pair of wood and twisted hide snowshoes, with complex netted patterns in three sections.

Description: fan of natural palm leaf, very similar to F.1969.83. With semi-transparant border edged with diamond pattern.  Probably from Bengal, see notes.
WebDescription: Fan made of natural palm leaf with a semi-transparant border of mica edged with a diamond pattern.  The main body has been painted with a multi-leaf design in deep orange against a green background. Probably from Bengal.

Description: fan of natural palm leaf, very similar to F.1969.83. With semi-transparant border edged with diamond pattern.  Probably from Bengal, see notes.
WebDescription:
Palm leaves make an ideal natural source for a fan to cool one down.  This painted leaf is decorated with mica diamonds. It was probably used by servants attending a wealthy family.   
Transferred from Leeds Art Gallery, 1969

Description: robe or coat of reindeer fur, the fur on the inside, with tall neck, and long sleeves to which mits are attached. Red wool cloth band at cuffs, and near hem, which also has fur trim. Attacked by moth in late 1950s, early 1960s. See postcard.
WebDescription: This robe or coat of reindeer fur would be worn by a Samoyed hunter. The fur is on the inside, and the sun-bleached hide on the outside. The tall neck would keep the wind out, and can also be folded down. Fur mitts, made separately, are attached to the end of the long sleeves. The robe is decorated with bands of red wool cloth at the cuffs and near the hem, which is also trimmed with fur.

Description: pair of fur boots, probably reindeer fur. Fur on outside, many seams, some red cloth and other fur fringe inserts in seams. Large, probably for a man. Came out of Park Row stores in 1960s, but unlike the coat F.1969.138, were not attacked by moth.
WebDescription: These men's boots go with the Samoyed hunter's coat and are also made of reindeer fur. Here the fur is on the outside. Shorter lengths have been cut into tapering panels and stitched together with many seams. Some of the seams have red wool cloth and other fur fringes inserted.

Description: Long cloth of multicoloured cotton, with vertical stripes and knotted fringe. Colours: red, green, yellow, blue, cream, with supplementary weft designs in red on cream ground. Depth measured at knots, 18 mm.
WebDescription: This long cloth of multicoloured cotton has a pattern of vertical stripes and a knotted fringe. The main colours are red, green, yellow, blue and cream. The cloth has supplementary weft designs in red on a cream ground. It would probably have been worn on festive or important occasions wrapped round the body, or draped like a shawl over the head.

Description: Purse or bag of red silk, embroidered with floral design in green, pink, yellow, white, purple, blue and gold thread. Lined inside with blue figured satin. Green drawstring intricately knotted. Catch consists of blue woven thread loop and metal ball. When
WebDescription: This small purse or bag of red silk is embroidered with a floral design in green, pink, yellow, white, purple, blue and gold silk thread. It is lined inside with blue figured satin. The green cord drawstring is intricately knotted. The fastening consists of a blue woven thread loop and a metal ball. It is made from a rectangle of cloth folded diagonally. It was collected by a famous traveller, Isabella Bird Bishop, and is said to have been worked by the Empress of Korea.

Description: bag, flax, old labels read (i) Maori bag (New Zealand) made by a native woman whose husband fell fighting HM troops in the North Island, (ii) Maori bag 1870. Cream coloured criss-cross patterns of brown and purple fibres on both sides. Handle of twisted f
WebDescription: This small rectangular bag was made from New Zealand flax by a Maori woman in 1870. The cream coloured fibres are finger woven together with a criss-cross stitching in a purple brown colour on top. The handle is of twisted fibre with tassels where it joins the bag.

Description: headdress of emu feathers on fibre string, old label-"Head ornament of emu feathers worn by aboriginal men at some of their dances. N.Queensland. Feathers are white, tipped with black or brown. Thinner fibre strings at ends.
WebDescription: This headdress is made of emu feathers fastened together and suspended from a fibre string with long thin tie ends. The feathers are a pale orange and white in colour, tipped with black or brown. An old label reads: "Head ornament of emu feathers worn by Aboriginal men at some of their dances".

Description: large flat rectangular bag of black cloth, faced with beadwork, white with large floral patterns; opening on face, near top; wide long shoulder band, with similar beadwork face. Originally described as an apron. Black cloth is cotton. 17 woven beadwork ta
WebDescription: This large flat rectangular bag is made of black cotton cloth completely faced with beadwork. Large floral patterns stand out on a white ground. The opening for the main pouch is a bound slit near the top centre. The bottom of the bag is decorated with woven beadwork tassels wthat have a design of white and gold squares and purple woollen pom-poms at their ends. A broad shoulder band enables the owner to carry the bag diagonally across the front of the body. This is a late 19th century example of a type of bag used by hunters and traders in the 18th century. It became a part of ceremonial dress, still worn today by men, even over a western suit.

Description: long narrow bag, with beaded panel on both sides at base, blue with triangles; skin stained yellow; 15 strips hang from base, bound with red and other coloured quills; long fringe. For storing a pipe. Decorated with green, blue, gold, yellow and silver be
WebDescription: This long narrow bag of tanned hide is used by a Plains Indian man for storing his tobacco pipe. It has a  beaded panel on both sides at the base with a design of mainly red triangles on a blue ground. The skin or hide above has been stained yellow. Below the beadwork panels are 15 strips of hide bound with red and other coloured porcupine quills and a very long hide fringe.

Description: Rectangular bag of white tanned hide, with fringe at bottom; section of bead embroidery, light blue ground with geometric pattern in yellow, dark blue, red and pink; section of 19 strands of hide, each wrapped with quills - pink ground with dark and light
WebDescription: This is another Plains Indian hide bag for storing a tobacco pipe. Here the white tanned hide has not been coloured. The beadwork panels have a similar blue ground, with a smaller triangle pattern, and a larger number of hide strands, 19, have been overbound with quill strips. Much of the quillwork is a really bright pink probably achieved with aniline dyes. Below this is a shorter hide fringe.

Description: small skin bag with beadwork on front; bird and other motifs; fringe at base; thonged loop handle. Beadwork decoration of a spread eagle and two crosses, on pale tanned hide.
WebDescription: This small skin or hide bag was probably used to store tobacco. It is embroidred with beadwork on the front, with a distinctive design of a spread eagle, two crosses, and a flower form. A narrow hide handle is sewn on at the top, and the rim, side seam, and bottom of the bag are decorated with more simple beadwork strands. The hide fringe at the bottom is now rather worn and untidy. The bag is probably from the northern Plains, as the flower form shows some Eastern Woodlands influence.

Description: flat sole; upper covered with glass beadwork, bands of white with motifs, bright green between. Uppers are of soft skin, soles of hide. Called moccasins, made of hide; side seam; rawhide soles have traces of fur. Flap on instep divided into 2 points and d
WebDescription: These are men's moccasins. The uppers are of soft skin, and the soles of harder rawhide. The uppers are almost completely covered with glass beadwork, in bands of white with geometric motifs, and bright green curves between. The tongue or top section of the vamp has been split and cut to make two pointed flaps whose ends are decorated with metal cones holding small orange feathers. The top of the ankles are bound with red cotton cloth.

Description: pair of moccasins of soft-tanned hide, with centre seam and shield-shaped white inset on vamp, cuff around ankles and ties; skin white on inside. Embroidered with silk thread in floral pattern, reds, blues, greens, yellow; vamp edged with border of bird q
WebDescription: This is one of a pair of moccasins made of soft-tanned caribou hide with large turned over ankle cuffs, where the white underface of the hide can be seen. The moccasins also have white moose hide insets on the vamp. These vamps are embroidered with silk thread in a floral pattern of reds, blues, greens and yellow, using chain stitch. The vamps are edged with a narrow border of dyed bird quills and possibly moose hair. The donor says that the moccasins were sent home to her grandmother by her great aunt, probably in late 19th century. The great aunt was secretary to the first bishop of Fort Churchill.

Description: single mitten (left); multicoloured silk floral embroidery on back of hand. Made of tanned hide. JCH King: Unusually large quantity of embroidery. See notes by Dr Ruth Phillips, May 1990; and Alexander folder in donor file.
WebDescription: This single surviving mitten of fairly thick tanned hide has been finely embroidered in chain stitch. The floral design has been sewn in silk threads of many colours. The donor said that the mitten was sent home to her grandmother by her great aunt, probably in the late 19th century. The great aunt was secretary to the first bishop of Fort Churchill, located on the western shores of Hudson's Bay.

Description: Embroidered panel from Hausa gown (RIGA), green on white. Largely discoloured. This is a panel for a pocket.
WebDescription: This embroidered panel is from the front of a Hausa man's gown called Riga. It seems to have been cut from the top right near the neck opening. The design of bars with spokes or knives, and rectangles of interlacing is typical of these robes, and is mainly done in ladder or chain stitch. The brown silk thread has now discoloured and is slightly green. As this embroidery is done by separate craftsmen from the weaving and tailoring of the robes, and is fairly costly it is often cut off robes that are worn out, and reapplied to newer or second best robes for reuse. This fragment was collected by the donor in the Hausa Emirates of Northern Nigeria between 1920 and 1930.

Description: dancing skirt of flax, red, purple and natural. Bands of about 30 stems of one colour, unravelled at top for c. 5cms, and knotted and stitched to form waist-band. The c. 8 cms length of stems unravelled and twisted with similar lengths of natural stems in
WebDescription: This dancing skirt is made from lengths of New Zealand flax, left natural or dyed red and purple. The flax is tied together in bands of about 30 stems of one colour, which are knotted and stitched together at the top to form a waistband. A series of crimped lines has been achieved by cutting away the outer surface of the stems. Both men and women would wear this sort of dance skirt. The colours used here are modern rather than traditional.

Description: circular shaped hat. Turned up brim, blue silk lined with red cotton with Chinese writing on it, centrepoint surmounted by brass 'hemisphere' with dragon on it, which is in turn surmounted by a glass ball. Red fringe attached to centre point, hangs over c
WebDescription: This man's circular hat was worn by a Qing official. It is made of dark navy and black silk with a turned up brim, and a large central tassel of red silk cord. The inside is lined with blue silk, with some red cotton with Chinese writing on it. The centre top is surmounted by a brass hemispherical fitting engraved with a dragon, which is in turn surmounted by a clear glass ball. The hat is the sort worn in autumn, and the clear glass ball is a standard hat ornament indicating a fairly low rank.

Description: pair of boots with pointed toes and black silk uppers. Lined with white cotton. Cotton soles.
WebDescription: These man's boots have black silk uppers, thick compressed rag soles, and a white cotton lining. They are of good quality and would have been worn by a merchant or mandarin official.

Description: pair of boots with pointed toes and black silk uppers. Lined with white cotton. Cotton soles.
WebDescription:
Good quality boots for a merchant or mandarin, with black silk uppers, thick compressed rag soles, and a white cotton lining. China, 1880-1910
Purchased from Heppers & Sons auctioneers, Leeds, 1974

Description:
on black silk with a backing of blue silk. Gold and silver thread embroidery, also two shades of blue motif. Bird design appliqud on. Valery Garrett 7/8/08:
This small badge is a birthday badge rather than a rank badge, has three symbols for long life,
WebDescription: This is a rank badge which would have been sewn on the back of an official's coat or over-robe. It has a blue silk backing, and embroidery in coloured silks, and couched gold and silver threads of a bird, possibly a phoenix. The same badge, in two halves, would appear on the front of the coat.

Description: black tunic with coloured silk brocade and strip of gold edging. Front as well as side openings. Red silk lining. Brocade shows dragon. Badges on back and front show bird. Knotted fringe of turquoise thread hangs from double-pointed front and back. Fringe
WebDescription: This tabard or tunic was worn over an official's dragon robe. It is a silk brocade with a square rank badge panel in the centre and a large collar above. The badge has a bird motif or symbol, probably a phoenix, together with other smaller symbols. Dragons, flaming pearls, bats and clouds can be seen below, and eternal knots and other symbols above. At the base is a knotted silk cord fringe with metal discs attached.

Description: large collar of appliqu work. Ground of white silk. Both purple and green ribbon, edged on top. Sides with blue. Lined with red (faded). Knotted fringe with tassels in many colours. Metal discs sewn on to knotted areas, white silk embroidered flowers, pe
WebDescription: This large applique work collar would have been worn by a woman on top of a silk robe. The ground fabric is white silk, with some embroidery of flowers and people and purple, green and blue silk ribbon stitched round the edge. A long knotted fringe with tassels in many colours hangs below. Metal discs are sewn on to the knotted areas.

Description: White handwoven cotton with faded red and blue supplementary weft patterns. Made of narrow strips sewn together.
WebDescription: This cotton cloth is made from several handwoven narrow strip weave lenghs sewn together. Each strip has a variety of faded red and blue supplementary weft patterns, which are particular dense at the bottom near the short fringe.  Although it is now badly stained and worn this would once have been a very good quality cloth, probably worn as a wrapper.

Description: mask face made of green leather with red leather lips and tongue and gold leather teeth. Back of head in red and black woollen fabric, green hair; 2 gilded wood horns with gilded carved skull in between. Superstructure decorated with large wooden beads, g
WebDescription: This horned mask has a face made of green leather with red leather lips and tongue and gold leather teeth. Large numbers of gilded beads are glued onto the face on the cheeks and forehead. The back of the head is made of red and black woollen fabric, woven and felted, with green wool hair attached. The two horns are of gilded wood and a small carved and gilded skull sits between them. Wire loops threaded with large wooden beads, glass beads and yellow wool tassels and pom-poms rise around the horns. Below the mask are four red velvet flaps which would cover the wearer's shoulder. They are trimmed with curled and coiled foil braid and modern costume jewellery that is clipped on. We are not sure which character the mask represents, or which dance or performance it would have been worn for. The owner of the antique shop who sold the mask, and a skirt and staff to go with it, described the set as a 'Devil Dancer's Outfit'.

Description: Necklace made of bones, some large, some smaller.
WebDescription: A necklace made of bones.  Purchased at auction, at a cost of 7.00, from Adair Davy Fine Art Sale Rooms in 1975

Description: tunic dress, called a KAMIZ. Made of peach coloured polyester cloth, with square neck, machine embroidery around cuffs and neck done in gold and purple thread. Flower motif. Long sleeves, shoulder fastening.
WebDescription: This woman's tunic dress, called a Kamiz, is made of peach coloured polyester satin, with a square neck and machine embroidery around the cuffs and neck done in gold and purple thread. It was specially commissioned from a Yorkshire Pakistani seamstress, Mrs Khan, in 1975. The embroidery uses a flower motif. The sleeves are full length. The tunic dress fastens at the shoulder and centre back. It is worn with matching trousers and a contrasting orange chiffon scarf or shawl.

Description: skull cap of white cotton, crocheted. Worn by men especially, but not exclusively when in mosque.
WebDescription: This crocheted skull cap of white cotton is worn by men, especially when visiting a mosque or praying. Some religious men wear them all the time.

Description: Made of coiled copper and silver coloured white with 3 groups of 2 seeds arranged around middle. Attached label reads "Kaffir bangle".
WebDescription: A bracelet made of coiled copper and silver coloured wire, with 3 groups of 2 seeds arranged around middle. Collected by Mrs Nunney's uncle, who worked in a leather factory in South Africa in the 1920s.  The attached label reads "Kaffir bangle".

Description: Made of coiled copper wire and silver coloured wire in 7 strands.
WebDescription: A bracelet made of coiled copper and silver coloured wire in 7 strands.  Collected by Mrs Nunney's uncle, who worked in a leather factory in South Africa in the 1920s.  The attached label reads "Kaffir bangle".

Description: SARI, nylon, green with red border, motifs arranged in squares composed of squares with circular holes, red, white, and yellow. With pink cotton facing for hem.
WebDescription: This sari is of machine woven nylon fibre. It is worn with a short blouse or choli. The sari is green with a red border, and a geometric design. The long cloth length is folded round the lower body to begin with to form a skirt, leaving the best decorated end to throw over the shoulder (here front to back), as a shawl.

Description: Pointed toe, toe decorated with brass coloured sequins and embroidery, upper made of red plastic cloth.
WebDescription: These tiny pointed shoes have red plastic uppers decorated with gold and silver foil coloured sequins and embroidery with gilt thread. A young child would have worn them for best dress.

Description: Pointed toe, toe decorated with brass coloured sequins and embroidery, upper made of red plastic cloth.
WebDescription:
Young girl?s shoes with sequinned red plastic uppers, worn for best dress. Ludhiana, India, 1975 
Purchased new by curator Elizabeth Fisher, 1975

Description: Phulkari shawl of red cloth embroidered with geometric pattern in orange, green, purple, and white floss silk.
WebDescription: Phulkari shawl of red cloth embroidered with geometric patterns in orange, green, purple, and white floss silk. Probably used as a shawl or bedcover. Phulkari is a Punjabi word that originally meant flower working, which was applied to the style of embroidery whatever the uses of the cloth. But more recently it has become associated with the larger cloths alone, and these densely embroidered designs have became famous all over India, and elsewhere in the world.

Description: Phulkari shawl of red cloth embroidered with geometric pattern in orange, green, purple, and white floss silk.
WebDescription:
Phulkari is a Punjabi word that originally meant flower working, that was applied to this style of embroidery in Chinese silk floss threads on homespun cotton, whatever the uses of the cloth. Now it is associated with these larger cloths, whose geometric and floral designs are have become famous world-wide.
Purchased in Afghanistan by Leeds curator Elizabeth Fisher, 1975

Medium/Materials: cotton, metallic thread, silk, mirror pieces
Description: Yellow cotton fabric embroidered with figures, the main one being the elephant god (Ganesha) decorated with many small mirrors and 3 larger ones, tabs decorated with appliqu, including cheaply made silver braid.
WebDescription: This small torah or hanging would decorate a wall, a small window or a house doorway at a wedding or other celebration. It is made of yellow polyester silk embroidered with figures and decorated with mirror work. The main figure is the elephant headed god Ganesha. There are 3 larger mirrors and many small ones. Five applique cloth flaps form a fringe along the bottom.

Description: robe of dark blue silk with multicoloured design of dragons and other motifs. Side fastening, long sleeves with multi-coloured striped extensions from the elbow. Tear on left sleeve, and silk badly frayed and torn elsewhere, particularly on left side edge
WebDescription: This dragon robe of dark blue silk has woven rather than embroidered designs over the main body. The very long sleeves have horse-shoe shaped cuffs decorated with an brown and black silk. The toggles and loops which fasten the side opening are of gilded brass. The fairly open weave of the main body does include gold coloured thread but the dragons hardly stand out in comparison to the more usual embroidered robes.

Description: woman's purdha dress or veil, called a BUIBUI. Tubular with central front slit and rectangle of material attached to back of neck, for covering the head. Of black satin fabric. Length of separately attached veil piece 91.5cms, width 68.5 cms.
WebDescription: Full-length black polyester silk cloak and head cover called a Buibui, worn by strict Muslim women when they are out shopping, or on their way to visit friends.

Description: rag rug, circular with material scraps arranged in colours in concentric circles. When new these rugs are used indoors, later as a doormat on the exterior step.
WebDescription: This circular rag rug has been made with fabric scraps arranged according to their colour in concentric circles. The maker starts by tying twists of cloth together in the centre. When new these rugs are used indoors. Later, when they are fairly worn, they are used as a doormat outside on the house step.

Description: large parasol with wooden frame, and detachable material cover, of red silk and biscuit coloured cotton. With three black bands and 4 applied black Chinese characters on top tier, made of silk velour. Three tiers of attached multicoloured silk ribbons, ea
WebDescription: This enormous parasol was made to appear in a particular celebration procession. It has a large wooden frame, and a detachable material cover, of cream cotton on top, and red silk round the sides. The inside of the parasol is lined with pink cotton. The red coth outside is divided by three black bands and around the top are a series of large black Chinese characters. These characters translate as love (ai), writing brush or writing (han), arrange or agreement (yue) and alike, similar or together (tong) (Linda Rosen October 2007). Three tiers of multicoloured silk ribbons are attached to the sides, each printed or painted with black Chinese characters. One of the long ribbons (ribbon 2) gives the date in both the Qing dynasty and western calendar, as March 1904. The others give the names and places of people at the celebration event, which appears to have been the visit of an important London Missionary Society churchman, to a Chinese Christian near Wuhan in Hebei province.

Description: rectangular white wood frame, for model carpet loom. Strung with white string, with a sample of carpet woven in red, with green, blue and beige.
WebDescription: This small model carpet loom has a rectangular white wood frame, strung with white string. In process is a wool carpet, woven mainly in red, with green, blue and beige added to make a geometrical design. Two heddles are shown.

Description: Blue velvet waistcoat, heavily embroidered with brass thread along borders, pockets and in centre of back. Black silk lining. Part of complete man's costume (F.1977.53-58).
WebDescription: This deep blue silk velvet waistcoat is heavily embroidered with gold thread work along the edges, around the pockets and in the centre at the back. The gold thread is in the form of a thick braid which is couched down in patterns that include figure of eight twists, leaves and tendrils. The waistcoat has a black silk lining.

Medium/Materials: cane, plant fibre, glass beads, brass
Description: Girdle with pouch.  Girdle of blue, black, red and white beadwork.  Pouch of reed stems, front covered with multicoloured beadwork. Pouch is rectangular, has flap top front, fastening with brass buttons and bead loops. Another pair of brass buttons bottom
WebDescription: This rectangular pouch on a long beaded roll was worn as a girdle by a Zulu woman.  The core of the long roll is twisted plant fibre or cotton rag, and the tiny glass beads are wound round the roll on a long thread, to produce a design of bands in the different colours: blue, black, red and white beadwork.  The pouch is made of reed stems, and its front is covered with multicoloured bands of beadwork. The top front flap is fastened with brass buttons and loops and another pair of brass buttons decorate the bottom corners.

Description: Beadwork cap, circular with openwork bead top, solid beadwork sides and layered fringe along base. Chin strap of double string of white beads. Mainly pale blue and white beads, with some black, red, yellow and dark blue. Length of chin strap 22 cms hangin
WebDescription: This circular man's cap is made up of tiny glass beads on cotton threads. The sides are tightly woven, with a diagonal striped design, and a layered fringe along the base. The chin strap is a simple string of white beads. The top is more complex, with a concentric lattice or openwork design. The outer edges have bands of white and red beads, the main top area is pale blue, and the centre black and white.

Description: natural cotton cloth hanging, richly embroidered in polychrome silks with stylised mosques and cypresses. Rectangular, fringed with maroon fringe at both narrow ends. All embroidery in satin stitch to give double-sided effect. At edges motifs of stylised
WebDescription: This door curtain of locally woven cotton cloth is embroidered in multi-coloured silk threads with a design of stylised mosques at top and bottom, and cypress trees in the centre. At the very bottom is a maroon silk thread fringe with a lattice or net body.

Description: white factory cotton cloth with bright multicoloured satin-stitch silk embroidery, virtually the same both sides; plaited red fringe with bobbles, on tablet-woven band, at each end. Originally described as a curtain. Rectangular piece of thin white cotton
WebDescription: One of a pair of curtains or cover cloths, with silk thread embroidery on top of factory made see-through cotton damask with a floral repeat. The embroidery along one side edge, and the bottom, has been done in double-sided satin stitch in local workshops, on a base cloth imported from Europe. The embroidery designs are now very worn. The deep red and purple contrast on a white ground is an older colour scheme than the more brightly coloured door-curtain that was also collected in Rabat (F.1978.23).

Description: child's slippers of red and green silk, embroidered. Toe tops look like animal faces with ears (lions or tigers?). Sides embroidered with flowers. Soles embroidered with red silk, very unworn compared to top.
WebDescription: These child's slippers of embroidered red and green silk have toe tops in the form of tiger or lion heads, with ear flaps that stick out, and raised eye knobs. The soles are of crushed rag, dyed white, and the undersoles are embroidered with red silk, which is very unworn compared to the animal heads on top.

Description: ceremonial barkcloth - cream strip with grey and reddish brown bands. Ends fringed with suspended brown nuts and shell circlets. Length of fringe 15cms. Half length 2040 mm including tassels. Very fine quality barkcloth. Would be worn by a man (Liz Bonshe
WebDescription: This cream barkcloth strip, painted with grey and reddish brown bands, was worn by men as a waistband at important ceremonies. The ends are twisted into fringes with brown nuts and shell circlets attached.

Description: part of complete man's costume, with F.1979.2.A&B. Man's head-covering, used to protect from sun. Two pieces of woven red cloth joined by ornamental yellow stitching. Three parallel lines of green woven into each side of both cloth pieces. Symmetrically e
WebDescription:
This man's headcloth is made of two pieces of mainly red cloth woven in wool and cotton, with long plaited wool ties at the corner. The red ground is embroidered in cross-stitch with four figure panels in brightly coloured silk floss thread. These show women, birds and pairs of llamas. 

The bright colour of this headcloth contrasts with the black jacket and trousers that make up the rest of the man's outfit.

Description: short jacket of heavy black woollen cloth. Plain style, with straight sleeves and stand-up collar. Fringed along back hem with twisted purple silk strands. Front and back each embroidered with two stylised floral motifs in shades of pink and purple silk.
WebDescription:
This man's short jacket of heavy black woollen cloth was photographed with the matching black wool trousers, and contrasting red headcloth which were purchased as part of the same outfit. Here the headcloth (F.1979.0001) is worn draped over the shoulder as a shawl. The jacket is in a very plain style, with straight sleeves and a stand-up collar. It is fringed along the back hem with twisted purple silk strands. On both the front and back are two stylised floral motifs embroidered in shades of pink and purple silk. All the edges and seams are embroidered with pink, purple and blue silk. The cuffs are also embroidered with spiral motifs.

The heavy black wool cloth is woven in a 2/2 twill, and embroidered in chain stitch. The amount of embroidery suggests that this is an outfit for an older man with several children or grandchildren, as the more descendants a man has the more embroidery he can wear. The costume would be completed with a shirt, a long colourful sash around the waist, and sandals. The traditional costumes of Guatemala are immensely varied, each town and village has its own particular patterns and style. Until recently most of the cloth used was woven and embroidered in the home.

Description: bundle cloth, a woven cotton square, fringed at two ends, of red, green and blue stripes. Woven on backstrap loom. Top side richly brocaded and embroidered with symmetrical design of llamas, birds and people.
WebDescription: Bundle cloth, a woven cotton square, fringed at two ends, with red, green and blue stripes. Woven on a backstrap loom. The top side is richly brocaded and embroidered with a symmetrical design of llamas, birds and people.

Description: man's KIMONO, of narrow-width tie-dyed cotton in white and indigo. Unfinished. Traditional style, roughly stitched together, hems and seams incomplete.
WebDescription: This man's kimono, of unlined cotton, has a bold indigo tie-dye design of water wheels and rope twists. The ragged hem shows that it has been roughly shortened at some time, usually such an informal robe would have a simple turned up hem. Contemporary unlined cotton robes are called yukata.

Description: originally described as mandarin man's jacket this is actually for a Manchu woman. Of pink/lilac silk (more pink than lilac), with appliqud black silk decoration, and multicoloured embroidery of flowers and butterflies. Blue cotton lining. No collar, sid
WebDescription: This lilac and black silk jacket is for a wealthy Manchu woman. The lilac is a silk damasc with some floral and butterfly embroidery, a border of pale blue/green polychrome braiding, and a broad outer band of black silk with applied cut work curves and silhouettes of fruit shapes. The jacket or short robe has a side fastening, and no collar, and is lined with blue cotton.

Description: bolero of pale leather on the outside, fur turned to the inside. Large overlap at front. Back decorated with appliqud pieces of dyed leather, mainly cherry red, in a symmetrical floral design. F.1979.20-23 is a costume set.
WebDescription: This bolero or waistcoat is made from hide with the fur or hair left on, turned inside out so that the outside surface is of pale buff leather. The back is decorated  with appliqud pieces of dyed leather, mainly cherry red and yellow, in a symmetrical floral design.

Description: female bride doll in red satin skirt and jacket, embroidered; red embroidered hat with back flap and bead fringe; red kerchief in R hand; red shoes. Underclothes a red silk jacket and blue silk trousers, and white cotton jacket and trousers. Painted woode
WebDescription: Bride and groom doll pair. On their wedding day a couple are dressed up in the fine silk robes worn by the wealthy and successful. The groom wears a mandarin's badged coat and hat and the bride wears lucky red. These dolls come from a set made by abandoned girls saved by the Door of Hope Mission in Shanghai. The mission sold the girls' work to raise funds.

Description: Man Mourner' doll in long robe of coarse white linen with plaited straw overcoat. Domed plaited straw hat. Beige canvas shoes. Underclothes of black silk leggings and white cotton jacket. Dated c. 1910. Painted wooden head and arms, stuffed body. Three w
WebDescription: Doll dressed as a mourner, a man wearing white cotton under a straw or hemp over robes and hat. Made by girls at the Door of Hope Mission in Shanghai. Purchased at auction, 1979.

Description: Woman Mourner' doll in long suit of coarse white linen with plaited straw overjacket and rope belt. White linen hood with plaited straw. Underclothes of purple cotton trousers and white cotton jacket and trousers. Canvas shoes. Dated c. 1910. Painted woo
WebDescription: Doll dressed as a mourner, a  woman wearing white cotton under a straw or hemp over robes and headdress. Made by girls at the Door of Hope Mission in Shanghai. Purchased at auction, 1979.

Description: Batik textile, yellow, black and white stellar designs on red cotton. Deep lobate curved border in same colours.
WebDescription:
This cotton cloth has yellow, black and white stellar designs applied by batik on a
 bright red ground. It looks as if it may have been intended for cutting into a table cloth with four matching table mats.

Description: large circular table cloth, cotton with ornate brown, black, blue and white designs. Traditional colours.
WebDescription: This large circular table cloth of resist printed cotton batik incorporates several different designs in brown, black, blue and white. The colours are very traditional, even if the item has clearly been made for sale to tourists.

Description: brown, orange and beige wool carpet, rectangular, with stepped geometric motifs in broader bands, divided by narrow patterned strips. Fringed ends.
WebDescription: This brown, orange and beige wool carpet has stepped geometric motifs handwoven without any pile. The ends are fringed.

Description: oval face of thin clay, painted white, with black hair and eyes and teeth, and red lips. Used in the classical Noh theatre, to represent a young woman. Black hair has centre parting, lips are slightly parted to show black teeth. Inside painted grey. Silk
WebDescription: This mask has the pale white face of a young Japanese lady. It would be worn by male actors in the traditional No theatre. It is made of wood painted over with clay. High eyebrows were much admired and many geisha and upper class beauties have their eyebrows shaved and then pencilled in to make them appear higher.

Description: child's mask of papier mache, a man's face with lips forming a circular red mouth. Painted pink with black and gold features. Toy mask, sold at most Japanese festivals. Gold and black eyes, black eyebrows and moustache. Inside painted white with black let
WebDescription: Child's mask of papier mache, copying a Kyogen theatre mask representing an old man's face with lips forming a circular red mouth, as if trying to whistle, or blow out a fire. Painted pink with black and gold features. Toy masks are sold at many Japanese festivals. This is a comic mask, as Kyogen are the comic interludes between the more serious and tragic performances of No theatre.

Description: carved softwood mask, painted. Face with prominent teeth, bulging eyes, surmounted by cobra head. Detachable "cobra" side pieces. Modern. Painted in blue, white, black, red and yellow. "Naga Raksa" form.
WebDescription: This painted wooden mask has bulging eyes and prominent teeth and includes lots of cobra snake heads. See how many you can count! There are two detachable side pieces which each have four cobras. This one was probably made for sale to tourists. The originals were used in curing rituals, where the snake demons chased away sickness. Purchased in 1982 from Glenjoy Ltd.

Description: rectangular rag rug, woven with stripes of woollen and man made fabrics. Multicoloured.
WebDescription: This rectangular rag rug has been woven with different coloured stripes of woollen and man made fabrics. The predominant colours used are browns and blues.

Description: beaded cap or bonnet in Glengarry style, of brown velvet, heavily beaded in multicoloured floral design. Coarse cotton lining. Scottish Glengarry field bonnet cap shape, with crossed brown ribbons at the back. Usually dating from between 1840-1870.
WebDescription: This cap or bonnet in Glengarry style is made of dark brown velvet, heavily beaded in a multicoloured floral design. It has a coarse cotton lining, and the rim is reinforced with ribbed black Petersham trim. The larger elements in the beadwork design have been stitched onto paper templates which are visible where bead strands are now loose. The Glengarry is a Scottish military field bonnet cap shape, with crossed ribbons at the back. The ribbons here are of black silk. The style became very popular in Canada between 1840-1870.

Description: Embroidered hanging, white cotton with design of vegetation (including palm trees), elephants and mythical figures, incorporating small round pieces of mirror. Three straight sides with lower sides arch-shaped. Inside of arch has multicoloured cotton clot
WebDescription: This cotton cloth would be hung in a house doorway during important festivals and celebrations. The inside of the arch has a multicoloured cotton cloth frill. The white cotton ground is embroidered with plants and flowers (including palm trees), elephants, lions and deities. In the top centre is Ganesha, the Hindu elephant headed god of wisdom. Either side of him are two small Hanuman monkey god figures carrying small mountains, and two devas or female deities. The embroidery is mainly in satin stitch, and incorporates small round pieces of mirror. An original owner's name is also embroidered, Patel, K.N.

Description: Embroidered hanging, white cotton with design of vegetation (including palm trees), elephants and mythical figures, incorporating small round pieces of mirror. Three straight sides with lower sides arch-shaped. Inside of arch has multicoloured cotton clot
WebDescription:
For decorating the doorway to a house during important festivals and celebrations, such as a wedding.  Cotton embroidered with plants, flowers and the Hindu deities Ganesha, the elephant headed god of wisdom, and his wives, and Hanuman, the monkey god carrying a mountain. The embroidery is mainly in satin stitch, with mirror work. An original owner's name is also embroidered, Patel, K.N.
Purchased from Gordon Reece, Knaresborough, 1981

Description: Patchwork bag, called KOTI.  Rectangular, made from pieces of printed cotton. One side has large panels, the other side is of small squares. Partially lined with cotton.
WebDescription: This rectangular patchwork bag is called Koti.  It is made from small square pieces of printed cotton arranged in a pattern of diamonds. The white border has a scalloped line done in chain stitch and the edges are bound with red cotton stitched with a cross-stitch.

Description: one of a pair of child's shoes.  Red silk, embroidered, with stylised animal head at front, possibly a tiger. Tiger has pale green ears, nose and whiskers. Other embroidery on sides includes butterflies and flowers. Circa 1905.
WebDescription: A pair of child's shoes made of red silk. They are embroidered with stylised animal heads at the front, probably tiger heads. These tigers have pale green ears, nose and whiskers. Other embroidery on the sides includes butterflies and flowers.

Description: Square of fine white ramie (rather than cotton as first thought). Ramie is the name of fibre from the woody plant (Boehemeria nivea) of the nettle family. With two bands of drawn thread work, panel of white embroidered dragons and four different Chinese c
WebDescription:
This fine white ramie tablecloth has two bands of drawn thread work and a broad inner border of white satin stitch embroidery of dragons and four different Chinese characters, one in each corner, facing outwards.  Ramie is a fibre from a woody plant (Boehmeria nivea) of the nettle family. The characters read from the cloth's right hand corner in a clockwise direction as: Fu Gui Chang Shou (from the viewer's left top corner).  Fu means wealth; Gui means valuable (also expensive, dear, honorouble, high class); Chang means long; Shou means long life. However, these characters are usually read as pairs Fu Gui = prosperity. Chang Shou = longevity. In China dragons are one of the four imaginary animals and symbolise good fortune.
This embroidery can be compared with the detail of floral embrodiery on a ramie curtain illustrated in Verity Wilson's Chinese Textiles, V&A, 2005, illus 110, p 99.

Description: plastic model of a policeman, one piece with base on which BAHAMAS is clearly printed
WebDescription: Plastic policeman figure in colonial style uniform, typical of the Bahamas love of traditional fashions.

Description: circular hat with flat top, richly embroidered in circular motifs with gold and silver thread and tiny pieces of mirrors. Decoration incorporates red and green beads.
WebDescription: This circular man's hat with a flat top is richly embroidered in circular motifs with gold and silver thread and tiny pieces of mirror. The decoration also incorporates red and green glass beads.

Description: dress with gathered skirt of blue silk with gold floral pattern. Long sleeves of maroon and orange silk edged with heavy silver embroidery. Neck edged with red velvet. Red square yoke, embroidered, edged with beadwork strips, with beaded disc at centre an
WebDescription: This Kutchi woman's dress has a gathered skirt of blue silk with a woven gold floral pattern. The long sleeves of maroon and orange silk are edged with heavy silver embroidery. The square red yoke is embroidered with a variety of geometric designs in silk floss thread, and edged with beadwork strips, with a prominent beaded disc at the centre.

Description: square beaded panel depicting two pairs of figures, possibly Krishna and Radha, and two horses surrounded by a border of many birds (peacocks). Multicoloured beads on a background of white beads. Panel is sewn onto purple silk and edged with gold thread b
WebDescription: This square beaded panel shows pairs of figures, probably Krishna and Radha, and two saddled horses in the centre. Around this is a border of many birds (probably peacocks). The panel is a diagonal lattice weave of different coloured glass beads with large background areas of  white beads. The beadwork is sewn onto purple silk and edged with a gold thread brocade. Red cotton backing has been attached, and each corner has a tiny red cotton loop so that the panel can be hung on nails on a wall.

Description: papier mache mask of a monkey face, representing the Hindu deity Hanuman. Mainly yellow with blue face. Yellow crown or hat has white and red ornament. Teeth barred. Earrings in ears. Forked mark on forehead.
WebDescription: This is a papier mache mask of a monkey face, representing the Hindu deity Hanuman. The mask is mainly yellow with a blue face. Hanuman's teeth are barred. and he has earrings in his ears. He also has a forked ritual mark on his forehead. Bought from Mr Gordon Reece, Knaresborough, in 1980.

Description: Called "GARBANDH". Rectangular blue cotton, edged with red, raised to point at centre top. Embroidery of red circles with mirror pieces. Lower edge fringed with coloured woollen tassels.
WebDescription: This highly decorated cloth piece would be tied between the ears of a bullock, so that it covered the forehead. The blue cotton ground is shaped like a rectangle with a point centre top. The embroidery, using button-hole, chain and satin stitch, includes mirror pieces in red circles and flowers. The lower edge is fringed with coloured woollen tassels.

Description: part of girl's marriage costume, with skirt B. "CHOLI" blouse, v-neck, gathered bust, long sleeves, open back with four ties across. Sleeves and side panels of coarse red cotton, bust area of blue cotton, all heavily embroidered with multi-coloured design
WebDescription: This blouse is part of a girl's marriage costume. It has sleeves and sides of red cotton, and a bust of blue cotton, and is densely embroidered with floral designs in chain-stitch. Below the v-neck the bust is gathered into two domes. The long sleeves contrast with the open back, tied together with two cotton cloth ties.

Description: part of girl's marriage costume with blouse A. Skirt called "GAGRA" or "GHAGHRA", gathered red cotton, embroidered black waistband. Coloured embroidery motifs of peacocks and ? trees. Mirror pieces incorporated. White and yellow embroidered discs at hem b
WebDescription: The girls marriage outfit also includes a gathered skirt, worn with the short choli or blouse. This skirt is of thick red cotton with a black waistband. Peacocks and trees are embroidered in chain-stitch over the main skirt body, with some mirror work. At the hem is a border band of large yellow and white flower heads, with mirror pieces in their centres, and red and green leaves between.

Description: circular cap with neckpiece, called "TOPLA". Green and beige silk panels with ornate coloured mirror embroidery. Two long tassels with modern white buttons. Used by Ahir, cattle herders. Part of a boy's marriage costume, with jacket (B), and dowry bag (C)
WebDescription: This circular cap with a long neckpiece is part of an Ahir boy's marriage or engagement costume. The Ahir are cattle herders. The cap is made from green and beige silk panels thickly embroidered with floral designs in many coloured silk threads, with mirror work. Two long tassles at the bottom include white plastic buttons.

Description: jacket called "KERIYA", part of boy's marriage costume. Coarse natural cotton. Standing collar, long sleeves, gathered border. Embroidered with floral and stylised figure motifs with mirror pieces. Large rectangular pocket of same coarse cotton, plain, se
WebDescription: This jacket is also part of the boy's marriage costume. It is made from coarse natural cotton, with a standing collar, long sleeves, and a gathered border. The jacket is embroidered with floral and stylised figure motifs with mirror pieces, using button-hole stitch, chain stitch and running stitch. A large rectangular pocket of the same coarse cotton cloth, left plain, is sewn to the inside of the right hand side. The jacket front fastens with rolled cloth ties.

Description: dowry bag, called "KHOTRIE", part of boy's marriage costume. Rectangular natural coarse cotton, with silk lower border. Embroidery of stylised women and flowers with mirror pieces.
WebDescription: This dowry bag also forms part of the boy's marriage costume. It is made from a rectangular piece of natural coarse cotton, with a silk lower border. The embroidery in silk threads forms a pattern of stylised women and flowers with mirror pieces.

Description: one of a set of four embroidered screen panels, which illustrate the story of "The tongue-cut sparrow". A shows  woodcutter, with wife and washing line and tub and broken plate. Sparrow is flying off. Red stamp, black manuscript characters. Woodcutter is
WebDescription:
This is one of a set of four embroidered screen panels, from an original set of six, illustrating episodes from 'The Tale of the Tongue-cut Sparrow'. A woodcutter's wife is jealous of the attention her husband gives a pet sparrow, and cuts off its tongue. On this first panel the woodcutter is away at work carrying wood, and the wife is hanging out washing. She has just cut off the bird's tongue, and has her head turned to watch the sparrow flying away.  At her feet is a broken dish of laundry starch. Subsequent panels show the husband, and then the wife, being entertained at a sparrow family party. Both choose parting gifts, which have very different consequences. 

The gold satin ground is decorated with applique cloth figures, in a variety of fabrics, with a layered raised effect. The panels are signed in black in and stamped in red ink at the bottom right corner. The asymmetric positioning of the figures on a largely vacant ground is a typical feature of a lot of Japanese design.

Description: one of a set of four embroidered screen panels, which illustrate the story of "The tongue-cut sparrow". C shows  woodcutter having tea with 4 dressed sparrows, two other dressed sparrows are dancing. Multicoloured silks on gold silk ground.
WebDescription: Another of the four surviving screen panels, from an original set of six, illustrating episodes from 'The Tale of the tongue-cut Sparrow'. On this panel the woodcutter is having tea with four dressed sparrows, whilst two other sparrows are dancing for him. The same gold satin ground is sparsely interrupted by the applique cloth figures, with the sparrows being more lavishly dressed than the poor woodcutter, especially the two dancers. The tea wares are shown with finely painted detail.

Medium/Materials: silk, cane, gold pain, peach nut
Description: one of a pair of embroidered silk fans, with gold painted handles, red silk tassels, with nut bead in the form of houseboat. Circular. A has a large gold dragon, clouds, white wave curls and many tiny red bats.
WebDescription: Silk fan embroidered with a five clawed dragon clutching a flaming pearl in gold thread with bats and clouds above a mountain peak with waves. The gold painted handle has a tassel with an ornament in the shape of a miniature boat with passengers, carved out of a peach kernel.

Medium/Materials: silk, cane, gold paint, peach nut
Description: one of a pair of embroidered silk fans, with gold painted handles, red silk tassels, with peach nut bead in form of houseboat. Circular. B has bats, flowers and foliage on a navy blue ground. In the centre is the circular character SHOU (for long life). T
WebDescription: one of a pair of embroidered silk fans, with gold painted handles, red silk tassels, and a peach nut bead in the form of houseboat. Circular. This fan has bats, flowers and foliage on a navy blue ground. In the centre is the circular character SHOU (for long life). The bat is a popular symbol as fu (bat) sounds similar to fu (happiness). Five bats shown together, as here, signify the five blessings: longevity, health, wealth, virtue and the right to a natural death.

Description: Woman's headdress with round cap of black silk, edged with a brocade band, decorated with silk embroidery and blue enamel trimmings. Ornate ivory silk centrepiece with gold embroidery, red pom-poms and a large metal ornament of floral form. Very long blac
WebDescription: This woman's headdress has a round cap of black silk, edged with a deep brocade band. The cap is decorated with silk embroidery and ornamented with gilt brass trimmings in the shape of butterflies and flowers, with a delicate blue surface made from cut kingfisher feathers. The cap has an ornate ivory silk centrepiece with gold embroidery, red pom-poms and a large metal ornament of floral form. A very long black silk fringe hangs down around the cap, which is shorter at the front, over the wearer's face. It may well have been added later by an English or Western owner.

Description: Woman's headdress with round cap of black silk, edged with a brocade band, decorated with silk embroidery and blue enamel trimmings. Ornate ivory silk centrepiece with gold embroidery, red pom-poms and a large metal ornament of floral form. Very long blac
WebDescription:
A lady of rank or wealth would have worn this cap trimmed with silver work and flowers filled with the bright blue segments of kingfisher feathers. The black silk fringe may have been added later by an English or Western owner.
Purchased at Phillips Auction rooms, Morley, 1982

Description: pair of embroidered boots with leather soles, and cloth uppers. Black cotton cloth decorated with green and red felt appliqu, embroidered with simple floral pattern.
WebDescription: This pair of embroidered boots for a woman have leather soles and black cotton cloth uppers. The uppers are decorated with green and red felt appliqu, embroidered with a simple floral pattern. Above the leather soles are a series of compressed rag layers that thicken thicken the soles and make them quite comfortable to wear. The boots are lined with pink cotton. They are shown here with some boot ties wound round the upper calf.

Description: Mask of Sita, wife of Rama, worn in performances of the Ramayana Hindu epic. Papier mache face with pointed headdress and elongated ears. Painted yellow, red and black.
WebDescription: Sita is the heroine of the sacred Hindu epic, the Ramayana. The demon Ravanna steals her away from her husband Rama and takes her to the island of Lanka. Rama comes to rescue her with the help of the monkey king Hanuman. Here she wears a high domed crown and has the sacred tikka mark in the middle of her forehead. This mask was purchased from the ?Bringing it All Back Home? shop, Sheffield.

Description: Mask of Sita, wife of Rama, worn in performances of the Ramayana Hindu epic. Papier mache face with pointed headdress and elongated ears. Painted yellow, red and black.
WebDescription: This is a papier mache mask of Sita, the wife of Rama, which was worn in performances of the Ramayana Hindu epic. Sita wears a pointed headdress and haselongated ears. She has the sacred tikka mark in the middle of her forehead and flower-head earrings, nose and face rings. This was bought in 1980 from a shop in Sheffield.

Description: Rectangular woven cloth, fine wool, with tie-dyed design. Red and brown background, small pink and blue motifs in abstract pattern.
WebDescription: This rectangular shawl cloth of finely woven wool has a tie-dyed design made using tiny knots in abstract geometric repeats. The designs show up in paler red or pink, and blue, against the red and brown background.

Description: Rectangular woven cloth, fine wool, with tie-dyed design. Red and brown background, small pink and blue motifs in abstract pattern.
WebDescription:
Shawl or throw of finely woven wool with a stunning tie-dye design made by using tiny knots in abstract geometric repeats.  Gujarat is famous for its tie-dyed textiles. This contemporary piece was made for sale at the Gujarat Government Emporium. 
Purchased from the Bringing it All Back Home shop, Sheffield, 1982

Description: necklace made of bundles of shells 3-4 thick
WebDescription: A necklace made of shells, and produced in Gebelin in Egypt.  The necklace was purchased by Leeds Museums at Sotheby's auction house in 1920, a transfer from the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum.

Description: camel harness of strips of red felt, embroidered with black and white motifs, and edged with orange and black wool. To decorate the felt, numerous metal and glass discs, shells and buttons are sewn on. Suspended below are tassels of knotted wool, horsehai
WebDescription: This camel harness is made from strips of red felt, embroidered with black and white motifs, and edged with orange and black wool. To decorate the felt, numerous metal and glass discs, shells and buttons are sewn on. Suspended below are tassels of knotted wool, horsehair and padded cotton cloth triangles. On the top felt strip you can also see several tassels of black and dyed horsehair and feathers.

Description: large thick wooden bat for New Year game of shuttlecock, with straight flaring sides. One face painted, with flowering plum tree, flying bird, and sun. The other face covered with padded cloth, with padded head and shoulders of human figure in kimono, bag
WebDescription: This highly decorative wooden bat is for the New Year game of shuttlecock. Such bats are given as special New Year gifts to young children, especially girls and the decoration has become so elaborate that most are never played with. One side of the bat is painted with a scene of a flowering plum tree, the sun and a bird. The other face is covered with padded cloth, with a complex appliqu form of a famous Kabuki actor portraying a ronin outlaw or thief, holding a bag of money. Details such as his face are painted on.

Description: square of cotton cloth, handwoven, plain weave (balanced), one loom width. Dyed very dark indigo with white pattern in KASURI technique (double ikat). Small white square at centre, enclosed by quatrefoil (weft ikat only), surround by chequer board of whit
WebDescription: This cotton square has been cut from an old unpicked garment. It is dyed with very dark indigo with a geometric pattern left white by resist tieing, in a double ikat technique known in Japan as kasuri. The piece is quite worn, with a few tears. Some seam stitching holes are visible at the edges.

Description: length of silk cloth, plain weave (weft faced) with weft ikat patterning. Warp: dark blue-purple; weft dyed yellow, green, light and dark red. Pattern oriented across the cloth: 3 alternating bands of stylised floral motifs and short stripes enclosing zig
WebDescription: This length of silk cloth has been woven with weft ikat patterning (where the weft threads are bound in different sections to resist the dyes). The warps are of dark blue-purple and the wefts are dyed yellow, green, light and dark red. The pattern is oriented in vertical bands across the cloth. There are three alternating bands of stylised floral motifs and short stripes enclosing zigzags. Then there is a yellow zigzag with a red and yellow dot at the top and a yellow line parallel to the selvedge on each side.

Description: cotton cloth, 2 loom widths sewn together; warp-faced plain weave with warp-ikat pattern in white, pinky-red, and dull purple with a few touches of bright orange-red. On each length, pattern is a mirror-image in both directions (ie warp folded in half acr
WebDescription: This cotton cloth is formed from two loom widths sewn together patterned with a warp-ikat design in white, pinky-red, and dull purple with a few touches of bright orange-red. The designs include two central curly floral motifs; two crowns (?), then three bands each with two opposed pairs of animals. A loose fringe decorates each end.

Description: cylinder of handwoven cotton, one end drawn together and plaited to form crown of cap. Indigo cotton, embroidered in cross-stitch with two bands of running triangles (below & above), and central band of 2 rows of swuare motifs; separated by stem-stitch li
WebDescription: This cap is made from a roll or cylinder of handwoven cotton, with the top end drawn together and plaited to form the crown. The cloth is indigo dyed cotton, embroidered in cross-stitch with two bands of running triangles (below & above), and a central band of 2 rows of square motifs; separated by stem-stitch lines. The embroidery thread colours include white, magenta, purple, dull yellow, red, and possibly brown. Some of the colours have faded in sunlight. The cap is lined with plain indigo cotton, with a finer pink and blue cloth at the gathered top. A large circular red wool yarn pompom is sewn on the top.

Medium/Materials: cotton, glass beads, shell, metal, plastic
Description: small straight waistcoat, for a child, black cotton cloth, heavily embroidered, backed with green and red (indian block?) printed cloth; armholes and hem edged with dark red cotton cloth. 2 small pockets in fronts. Embroidery mainly red, with deep blue, e
WebDescription: This small waistcoat is for a child. It is made of black cotton cloth, heavily embroidered using satin, tent and finely worked cross stitch, and backed with green and red cloth, probably imported from India where it was block printed. The armholes and hem are edged with dark red cotton cloth and there are two small pockets in the fronts. The armholes also have white glass beads sewn on, and the hem has a heavier bead fringe. Many different objects are attached to the front including  plastic and metal buttons, two brass discs and six jewellery pendants of white metal. On the back is an embroidered pattern with a central column and three pairs of large round red 'leaves' on long stems.

Medium/Materials: cotton, silk, glass beads, brass, plastic
Description: child's cloth cap, gathered into stiffened cone at top, with wide flap over neck and sides; heavily embroidered. Tassel of white beads at top, with 4 pendant strings over cone of red floral cloth, stiffened with wood strips; black cloth gathered into base
WebDescription: This heavily embroidered child's cloth cap has been gathered into a stiffened cone at the top and has a  wide flap over the rear neck and sides. The ornaments include white and red glass beads, wood strips, coins, plastic claws, and plastic and metal buttons. The stitches used include satin stitch, cross-stitch and zigzags.The cap is lined with black cotton, with a square of red cotton printed with blue and green floral sprays, set crosswise at the base.

Description: wide and short black cotton dress, deep straight sleeves and very full gored skirt, heavily embroidered on front. Vertical rectangular panels, neck to hem: front has slit at neck with floral print sewn in behind, heavily embroidered dull magenta, yellow,
WebDescription: This wide and short black cotton dress has deep straight sleeves and a very full gored skirt. It is heavily embroidered with dull magenta, yellow, green and red silk floss in satin stitch with chain stitch around the neck. White glass beads, coins, buttons and small metal ornaments are also sewn on. The hem is backed with a dark-red floral print, with six lines of machine stitching.

Description: woman's cloak, a rectangle of black cotton cloth, with two corners of one long side (front) folded back; embroidery and beadwork on front half of cloak. Hem all round, lined with red cotton cloth, reversed on folded corners; decorative lines of machine st
WebDescription: This woman's cloak would be worn with the embroidered long edge placed over the head. It is made from a rectangle of black cotton cloth, with the two corners of one long side at the front folded back. The hem is lined all round with red cotton, reversed on the folded corners, with decorative lines of machine stitching in red, yellow and green. The long embroidered panel has a geometric pattern and the forward edge of the folds are decorated with small metal penants (many of which are now missing), and short lines or groups of large plastic beads.

Description: short tight-fitting tunic with long sleeves, of magenta silk heavily embroidered on front and sleeves. Plain round neck, short opening at back with press-stud; sleeves pleated into tight cuff  13 cm slit with press-stud. Sleeve hem lining of red and white
WebDescription: This short tight-fitting tunic with long sleeves is made of magenta silk heavily embroidered on the front and sleeves with fine gold thread. The gold thread is couched down with orange thread. The designs are foliate meanders, hearts and quatrefoils with flowers. It would be worn with matching trousers by a wealthy woman.

Description: fragment of a chest panel for a blouse called a MOLA. Rectangular cloth, unstitched from garment. 3-layer reverse applique, red base, orange and yellow centre layer, black above. Ground pattern of varying vertical sub-rectangular slits; one large animal s
WebDescription:
This fragment of a chest panel for a Mola or woman's blouse has been made by 3 layer reverse applique. The base cloth is red cotton, with yellow cotton in the middle, then black on top. Tha largest design is some sort of animal, possibly a lizard, and the two smaller designs look like a helicopter body and a boat. The ground pattern is a variety of sizes of vertical sub-rectangular slits.  

Cuna women have sewn these complex reverse applique panels for at least 150 years, and in recent times many panels are just made for sale to tourists, to be framed for wall display.

Description: drawstring bag, of 4 lengths woven cotton ribbon sewn horizontally in tube, gathered at base into small piece black, red and green ribbon. No top edging; 8 small rings covered in neat button hole stitch, sewn inside top, with 2 long loops of thin red brai
WebDescription: Drawstring bag made from four lengths of woven cotton ribbon sewn horizontally into a tube and gathered at the base into a small piece of black, red and green ribbon. At the top edge eight small rings are covered in neat button hole stitch to take the drawsting. Embroidered designs of dancing figures, edelweiss and other flowers in shades of blue, orange, red and green.
