The white background has a light brown 'crackle' to imitate batiks, and a design in very dark blue and golden yellow of alternating rope and diagonal bar bands. The selvedge is marked: 'A CONE JAVA'.

Description: cotton factory print. White background with light brown 'crackle' and pattern in very dark blue and golden yellow. Alternating rope (A) and diagonal (B) pattern bands running in warp direction. B has rope colours white and red pattern on dark blue/black.
WebDescription: This is the second in a series of cloth samples purchased to show the colour variations produced for one particular design. The same rope and bar diagonal patterns feature here in reds, blacks and browns. Made by the Cone textiles factory.

Description: woman's cloth wrapper, factory print; black, orange and white; "Niyaya shina uchavi". Cotton khanga cloth, wraps around the body.
WebDescription: This woman's cloth wrapper is known as a khanga, and is traditionally worn knotted round the waist as a skirt wrap, or round the shoulders and head as a shawl or baby carrier. This factory made cotton print in black, orange and white, has a floral border and a mainly geometric centre with five flower heads inside lozenges and the phrase "NIYA YA SHINA UCHAVI".

Description: circular slightly domed topped cap of brightly coloured ikat satin, with braid trim in black, yellow and brown round rim, and bright red silk floss pompom at rear. Ikat silk colours white, pink, yellow, brown, turquoise, green and black. Inside lined with
WebDescription: This cap of brightly coloured ikat satin has a braid trim in black, yellow and brown around the rim, and a bright red silk floss pompom at the rear. In ikat the threads are resist dyed before weaving, which often leads to a blurred effect once the different colours are woven together. This cap is of a fairly rough quality, and was bought as a souvenir at a local market in Bukhoro (Bukhara).

Description: striped cotton cloth, woven in magenta, blue and white. Woven in five broad strips. 19th century. Long fringes at one end only, other end unhemmed and quite rough. Maybe it has been cut down. Length of fringes 110mm.
WebDescription: This striped cotton cloth was probably woven on a local broad loom, using magenta, blue and white threads. There are long fringes at one end only, the other end is unhemmed and quite rough.

Description: long silk scarf?, with floral pattern in bands and a long fringe. The donor wrote: "These are of native design woven and embroidered by the women of the Hora tribe, natives of Antanarivo (capital of Madagscar)". Main colours yellow, blue, green and pink,
WebDescription: This narrow silk brocade length with floral patterns in horizontal and vertical bands was woven in the Tananarive province by the Merina people of Madagascar. The ends have long fringe threads. It was probably worn as a scarf by a wealthy man or woman.

Description: cotton strip, tabby and tapestry woven, with supplementary weft motifs. 20th century. Kente cloth, Asante. Medium blue ground with length wise striped bands near edge of magenta, yellow, black and white. Transverse weft bands in polyester silk, of stripes
WebDescription: This is a modern single strip of Kente cloth, tabby and tapestry woven on a traditional narrow loom, with supplementary weft motifs. The warp threads are cotton, the weft mainly polyester silk. The design has a medium blue ground with length wise striped bands near the edge of magenta, yellow, black and white. The transverse weft bands of polyester silk have produced stripes and various geometric designs, in yellow, white, black, magenta and green.

Description: silk cloth, originally described as a scarf. White silk with stylised floral pattern in stripes in magenta and other aniline colours. Donor wrote: These are of native design (4 and 9) woven and embroidered by women of the Hora tribe, natives of Tananarive
WebDescription: This silk brocade cloth was probably worn as a waist cloth or shawl, at weddings and other important ceremonies.  It has a stylised floral pattern in white with a long series of bordered bands in magenta and other imported aniline colours. Silk used to be produced, dyed and woven locally in Madagascar, using basic looms set up with sticks stuck in the mud floors of their houses. Imported aniline dyes have been used since the mid 19th century, and this type of rich brocade was also produced in a much wider form, on non-traditional looms, as high status burial cloths by the Merina people.

Description: Off-white cotton robe for a man with yellowish hand-embroidered 'knife' pattern and spiral near neck. Second spiral with dense geometric infill in centre, at centre rear below neck opening. Heavy synthetic? silk thread used in the embroidery. Pale yellow
WebDescription: This off-white cotton robe for a rich and important man has a hand-embroidered yellow or cream silk  'knife' pattern and spiral near the neck opening, done in ladder stitch. There is a second spiral with dense geometric infill in its centre on the rear, just below the neck opening. The silk thread is heavy and is probably imported. Pale yellow buttonhole stitch, eyelet hole and laid-work fillings are also used. Tapes have been sewn to the robes' bottom corners to help hold it up when walking. The long sleeves are one piece with robe, they would be folded up onto the shoulders during wear.

Description: robe of red satin woven with vertical stripes of yellow silk. Long sleeves open at the cuff and base of robe side seams. The narrow yellow stripes which decorate the robe are patterned with small geometrical ornamentation in black, white and red. Three bu
WebDescription: This is a man's robe of red satin woven with vertical stripes of yellow silk. The long sleeves are open at the cuff, and the bottom of the robe sides are also left open. The narrow yellow stripes which decorate the robe are patterned with small geometrical designs in black, white and red. The robe fastens centre front with three buttons and button holes of red silk braid. Although the robe was collected in the Sudan, the donor (the widow of Colonel Sir Charles Watson) reports that it is the sort of robe given by the British Government in Egypt to Arab chiefs in the Sudan. It was probably made in Syria and traded through importers in Cairo.

Description: cream silk man's robe, with embroidered design of 'knives' and spirals top left of front. Rectangular straight set sleeves, rectangular body, flat oval neck opening, stitched shut. Label sewn centre front upside down: Royal Commission No. 930. Width acros
WebDescription: This man's robe of cream silk has an elaborate embroidered design of 'knives' and spirals in slightly darker and lighter silk threads top front, to the bottom and left of the flat oval neck opening. The rectangular straight set sleeves would be folded up on the shoulders during wear. A label was sewn into the centre front: Royal Commission No. 930. This robe is one of several African textiles transferred from the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1992.

Description: brown and white silk kimono with lozenge flower head design, made by the kasuri tie-dye method, where the silk threads are bound and dyed before weaving, as in ikat. A secondary pattern of small brown spots has been added after weaving. Width measured acr
WebDescription: This man's silk kimono of brown and white silk has a woven pattern of floral lozenges produced by the kasuri method, where the warp and weft threads are bound to resist different dyes before weaving (as in ikat). A secondary pattern of small brown spots may have been added after weaving. The subtle colours are appropriate for wear by a wealthy man, for a semi-formal occasion. This particular type of kasuri is a speciality of Oshima Island.

Description: child's red and black printed cotton jacket. Worn at festivals ('matsuri'), known as 'Happi'. Has large black printed character centre back, these will give the name of the town or temple associated with the festival event.
WebDescription: This short printed cotton jacket would be worn by a child at festivals or matsuri. It is a type of simple jacket known as happi. The large black character printed on the centre of the back refers to the name of the festival or organising group.

Description: thin black obi-age sash, worn under the stiff decorated Obi or waistband, with tie-dyed ('shibori') design of Mt Fuji, this would be the only part that is seen in use.
WebDescription: This thin black silk sash or obi-age would be worn under the stiff decorated obi or waistband on top of a kimono. It has a tie-dyed or shitori design of Mount Fuji, Japan's most sacred mountain. This would be the only part that is seen in use. The tie-dye is done with hundreds of single knots in rows.

Description: one of a set of 10 small textile samples, cotton cloth, sewn together. First outer one is fairly plain, horizontal (warp) stripes.
WebDescription: This set of cotton cloth samples sewn together illustrates a few of the designs made in Japan by the kasuri resist dye method, where warp and weft threads are bound to resist indigo or brown dyes before weaving (as in ikat). Common designs include stripes, checks and sprigs, sports or bars. Indigo is still a very popular colour for workman's clothes, and there is a strong folk tradition of country dyeing with this colour.

Description: blue silk handkerchief with tie-dye design in white and different shades of blue, diagonal lines or splodges or rectangles.
WebDescription: This blue silk handkerchief, for a man or a woman, has been resist patterned by the tie-dye method in the form of diagonal rows of varying sizes of individual knots. In Japan it is common for such small hand-crafted items to be sold before ironing or pressing, so that the raised effect of the knots lasts for a while.

Description: blacked wood helmet Sowie mask, for use in Bundu society by Mende women. Lozenge shaped face with complex geometric design on forehead, chevron band under neck curling round ears, neck rings at rear, together with hair plaits, birds and abstract antelope
WebDescription: Sowie is the spirit of Sande or Bundu the Mende women's secret society. The mask is worn by young women during their initiations into the society. It represents ideals of female beauty such as glossy skin and fat folds at the neck, and also female power, emotion, and other womanly qualities. The blackened wood mask fits over the head and has a charm container on top of the elaborate hair style.

Description: one of two wall hangings, an unmounted tapestry woven picture, brownish with red silk bound edge, design of a man on a cow, and a woman. Probably 1930s or 1950s in date (see letter from donor). The woman is weaving. "The cowboy and the weaving maid is a v
WebDescription: This tapestry woven picture would be hung up on the wall in a wealthy home. It has been woven with a mixture of silk and cotton threads. The main image is a herder or cowboy with a cow and a finely dressed young woman. They are characters from a famous fairy tale. The woman was a fairy disguised as a weaving maid, who fell in love with the cowboy.

Description: large rectangular barkcloth with stencilled pattern. Striped border, field has 2 panels with 8+/6 rosettes, enclosing 2 lines of zigzags etc, mottled brown centre with 3 large rosettes.
WebDescription: This large rectangular piece of barkcloth is decorated with a stencilled pattern. The designs include circles, toothed concentric circles or rosettes, striped border bands, and zigzags. Pacific barkcloth is made from the inner bark of the breadfruit tree felted together by beating.

Description: long rectangular barkcloth strip. Stencilled with horizontal bands with different geometric designs including ovals, chains, bows and scalloped circles.
WebDescription: This long rectangular barkcloth strip has been stencilled with horizontal bands with different geometric designs including ovals, chains, bows and scalloped circles.

Description: patchwork cloth, probably a cymbal cover, or for other use in a temple. Square with central panel of 4x4 squares, each made up of 4 triangles, multicoloured silk or synthetic cloth, brocade type; surrounded by 3 concentric bands of brocade. Inner brocade
WebDescription: This patchwork cloth cover was probably used to cover cymbals or other items used in religious ceremonies in temples, or at more personal shrines. The cover is square with a central panel of 4x4 squares, each made up of 4 triangles, cut from multicoloured silk or synthetic brocade cloth. This central square is surrounded by 3 concentric border bands of red, yellow and blue brocade. The whole cover is lined with plain blue cloth and a long fringe of different coloured silks decorates one side.

Description: chemise dress of white cotton, with yellow embroidery around hem, and 6 inserts of white bobbin lace. Neck opening faced with red cotton with white spots; sleeves with geometric embroidery in black, bright blue, bright green, and a little yellow. Cuffs of
WebDescription: This chemise or under-dress of white cotton has yellow embroidery around the hem, and 6 inserts of white bobbin lace. The neck opening is faced with red cotton printed with white spots. The sleeves are embroidered with geometric embroidery designs in black, bright blue, bright green, and a little yellow. The cuffs are of heavy black wool cloth with gold and silver coloured inserts. These are either ply-split darned or tablet woven. The chemise is part of a costume set for a Sarakatsani woman.

Description: Khanga or Kanga cloth, factory printed cotton. Green, red and black and white colours with  "target" motif at centre with flywhisk and club, logo: "1963-1983 / 20 / Kenya".
WebDescription: Factory printed cloth "kanga" wrapper, with green, red and black 'target' motif in the centre, with a flywhisk and club.  The slogan "1963-1983 / 20 / Kenya" represents the celebration of twenty years of Kenyan independence.  This is one of five cloths purchased from Mrs Mary Smith, and was included in the African Exhibition at Leeds City Museum in 1995.

Description: Khanga or Kanga cloth, factory printed cotton. Mainly deep yellow with some dark red and black. Design has a map of East Africa at the centre and logo: "Tunaipenda Africa Yetu", along bottom centre. Red hearts around the border. Design no. 06-3718. Slogan
WebDescription: Factory printed cloth "kanga" wrapper, deep yellow with dark red and black, with a map of East Africa at the centre.  The slogan "Tunaipenda Africa Yetu" means "We love our Africa". This is one of five cloths purchased from Mrs. Mary Smith, and was used in the African Exhibition at Leeds City Museum in 1995.

Description: Khanga or Kanga cloth, factory printed cotton. Main colours are black and white, with alternating red and yellow "Paisley" or pine-cone motifs in the border, two rows of four each. Text "ASHI-BAYE HAMJUI MWENZIE". This translates as 'The satisfied doen't
WebDescription: Factory printed cloth "kanga" wrapper, decorated with a eight large buta or Paisley motifs and red and yellow on a black spotted ground, stylised floral edging, and a map of Africa at centre with Kenya in green.  The text "ASHIBAYE HAMJUI MWENZIE" translates as "The satisfied doen't know the one who provides".  This is one of five cloths purchased from Mrs. Mary Smith, and was used in the African Exhibition at Leeds City Museum in 1995.

Description: Khanga or Kanga cloth, factory printed cotton. Black spotted ground, with map of Africa at centre with Kenya in green. Floral meander border in yellow, green, blue, white and black. Text: "Karibu mgeni" below Africa map. This means "Welcome Visitors". Pat
WebDescription: Factory printed cloth "kanga" wrapper, with black and white background  and central medallion with map of Africa that has Kenya highlighted in green. Complex floral and leaf border in yellow, blue, green, black and white. The text "Karibu mgeni" is printed along the bottom.  It means "Welcome Visitors". This is one of five cloths purchased from Mrs. Mary Smith, and was used in the African Exhibition at Leeds City Museum in 1995.

Description: Khanga of Kanga cloth, factory printed cotton. Main colours are white and black with red and green "Paisley" motifs in border area, and red cock in centre. Text: "KANU NYAYO, and CHAMA CHA AMANI". Not sure what this translates as.
WebDescription: Factory printed cloth "kanga" wrapper, a white cloth decorated with red and green "Paisley" motifs, and red cockeral at centre. The slogan text "KANU Nyayo" supports the Kenyan African National Union, and "Chama Hama Cha Amani".  This is one of five cloths purchased from Mrs. Mary Smith, and was used in the African Exhibition at Leeds City Museum in 1995.

Description: one of three items of a Yoruba woman's costume (1-3), a wrapper, known as a buba, of handwoven narrow strip cloth, dark purpley red with two narrow yellow warp stripes in the centre, 12 holes and floats (allover).
WebDescription: This cotton wrapper, known as a buba, is one of three items of a Yoruba woman's costume, all made from the same handwoven narrow strip cloth. The dark purpley red strips each have two narrow yellow warp stripes in the centre, 12 small holes and loose floats.  Here 15 narrow strips have been sewn together to make the buba.

Description: woman's blouse of handwoven narrow strip cloth, dark red with yellow stripes. Second of three items for a woman's outfit, known as an Iro. Cloth is dark purpley red with 2 narrow yellow warp stripes in the centre, 12 holes and floats (allover).
WebDescription: This blouse, known as an iro, is the second of three items of a Yoruba woman's costume, all made from the same narrow strip cloth. The dark purpley red strips each have two narrow yellow warp stripes in the centre, 12 small holes and loose floats.  The blouse has a wide neck opening and broad sleeves.

Description: woman's shawl, a handwoven narrow strip cloth, dark red with yellow stripes, making wrap around shawl, third of three items for a Yoruba woman's outfit. Shawl known as an Iburun. Originally thought to be a head-tie instead.
WebDescription: This woman's shawl, known as an Iburun, is the third in a set of woman's clothing, made from dark red handwoven narrow strip cloth, with yellow stripes, small holes, and floating wefts.

Description: woman's blouse to go with skirt(B) and belt(C). Short asleeved, of cotton printed to imitate barkcloth; black and brown patterns.
WebDescription: This short sleeved woman's blouse goes with a matching skirt (B) and belt (C). It is made of  cotton printed to imitate barkcloth with black and brown geometric patterns in horizontal and diagonal bands.

Description: woman's skirt to go with blouse(A) and belt (C). Wrap around cloth, on elasticated waist, of cotton printed to imitate barkcloth. Black and brown patterns.
WebDescription: The woman's skirt which matches the blouse (A) and belt (C) is a wrap around cloth, on an elasticated waist. It is made of  cotton printed to imitate barkcloth with the same black and brown geometric patterns in horizontal and diagonal bands.

Description: belt to go with blouse(A) and skirt(B) of cotton print woman's outfit. Thin tie belt worn over blouse.
WebDescription: The thin printed cotton tie belt which goes with the blouse (A) and skirt (B) has a much simpler chevron design. It is worn tied over the blouse.

Description: cotton print, green with black and white floral design. Large flower heads down centre of length, narrower bands of flower heads down sides. Short ends have machine stitched hems.
WebDescription: This cotton print with a black and white floral design on a green ground is the sort of cloth worn as a wrap by both men and women. It has large flower sprays down the centre of its length and narrower bands of smaller flower sprays down the sides. The short ends have machine stitched hems.

Description: pair of moccasins, separate soles, worn and dirty; uppers completely covered with beadwork, bands of white with royal blue motifs and some green, yellow and red. Tongue with two beaded tags; high at heel; pair of thong ties on each
WebDescription: This pair of men's moccasins have very worn thick hide soles, and uppers that are almost completely covered with glass beadwork. The ankle areas are quite high, with a pair of thong ties attached. The geometric design is of  bands of white with royal blue motifs and some green, yellow and red. The tongue has been split into two beaded tags. They are one of three pairs of moccasins said to have been worn by performers in Buffalo Bill's circus in the 1890s, when the circus came to the north of England, given to the donor's grandfather William Pope.

Description: pair of moccasins. Separate soles stitched to uppers. Bands of beadwork over whole of foot, but not on tongue or up the ankle. Blue cotton binding roughly tacked to ankle edge; Right shoe has thong threaded through ankle below binding. Beadwork white and
WebDescription: These men's moccasins have soles of worn thick hide, and uppers of softer hide, visible at the ankle cuffs and the tongue. The rest of the uppers are decorated with geometric patterns of glass beadwork. A blue cotton binding has been tacked roughly  to the ankle edges. The right shoe still has has a thong threaded round the ankle below this binding. The beadwork is mainly white and dark green, with blocks of white, royal blue, azure, and glass green on the vamp.They are one of three pairs of moccasins said to have been worn by performers in Buffalo Bill's circus in the 1890s, when the circus came to the north of England, given to the donor's grandfather William Pope.

Description: separate skin/leather soles (worn and dirty) stitched to lightly beaded uppers. Beadwork: angled blocks of 3 short lines of yellow, azure, glass green and pink (red over white core) around edge of foot; on vamp, 1 long and 2 short beaded "tongues", same c
WebDescription: This pair of  men's moccasins from the Plains area of North America is much less beaded than the others in the collection. The soles are of very thick worn hide. The uppers are embroidred with glass beadwork in blocks and small triangles of yellow, azure, glass green and pink (red over white core). The tongue are ankle areas are plain. A short hide thong is threaded through the inner corner of the ankle on each shoe.They are one of three pairs of moccasins said to have been worn by performers in Buffalo Bill's circus in the 1890s, when the circus came to the north of England, given to the donor's grandfather William Pope.

Description: piece of cotton factory-printed to imitate Ghanaian kente cloth. "Strips" run in warp direction. ABCB x 4.75 times. A is warp strips of yellow, green, red, black; B is blue with "supplementary weft" patterns in creamy-pink and dark red; c is "castling" in
WebDescription: This piece of cotton cloth has been printed in a factory to vaguely imitate the narrow strip geometric designs of Ghanaian kente cloth. Printed on the selvedge are the words SOTIBA DAKAR IMPRERIE.

Description: piece of cotton factory-printed to imitate Ghanaian "kente" cloth. Chequerboard effect, pattern of blocks of 4 AB,CD each c. 9.5/10.0cm square. A is warp stripes, green, orange and dark red. B is blue with 1 dark red and 1 orange zigzag across. C has blue
WebDescription: This piece of cotton cloth has been printed in a factory to be a fairly close imitation of the designs of Ghanaian kente cloth with its narrow stripes and detailed geometric repeats. Here the overall effect is like a multicoloured chequerboard. Along the selvedge the words : GRAND TEINT COTE D'IVOIRE. have been printed.

Description: cotton square, printed with head of Dr Robert Mugabe at centre, edged with colours of Zimbabwe flag: green, yellow, red and black.
WebDescription: Cotton square printed with the head of Robert Mugabe, with borders in the Zimbabwean flag colours.  In the 1980s and 1990s Mugabe was as famous a hero as Mandela, for overcoming the white regime in Zimbabwe. More recently his record on human rights and mismanagement of the country's wealth have led many to consider him a villain.

Description: factory-printed cotton cloth, to imitate Ghanaian KENTE cloth. The "strips" are 5.8cm wide, in warp direction, separated by fine white lines. Repeat pattern AB-1C-1B-2C-2 x 4 (+ 1 split strip). A is cross bands of royal blue, dark red, grass green with th
WebDescription: This piece of cotton cloth has been printed in a factory to imitate the narrow stripes and geometric repeats of Ghanaian kente cloth. It is the densest, most complex printed copy of this type of pattern in the collection. The manufacturer's paper label is still glued on.

Description: factory print cotton cloth, to imitate kente cloth of Ghana. Westways bands 11 cm wide of 2 pattern blocks (alternating for chequerboard effect). A has stripes of grass green, orange, black and dark red; separated by white from B, which has blue ground wi
WebDescription: Factory printed cotton cloth imitating kente cloth from Ghana with a design of narrow stripes and two repeated pattern blocks making an alternating chequerboard effect. Along the selvedge the words 'KUNA KINTE JAVA' are printed, but no country of origin.

Description: Factory-printed cotton cloth to imitate Ghanaian adinkra. 2 full and 2 part (at edges) blocks, c. 25-26 cm square of adinkra motifs, black on white; separated vertically by 2 lines enclosing 5 drum motifs; and across by 3 multicoloured strips imitating ke
WebDescription: A factory printed cotton cloth with a design that mixes both kente stripes and adinkra stamp repeats. Labelled KUNTA KENTE JAVA along the selvage.

Description: rectangle of raffia plain weave cloth, slightly reddish colour. Embroidered with patterns of diamonds, interlacing diamonds and zigzags, in black and natural pile and stem stitch. All four edges turned to front and tacked down, forming border 1-2m wide. E
WebDescription: This is a sample of furnishing cloth that used to be known as 'Kasai velvet'. It has a woven raffia fibre base and is embroidered in a fine cut pile technique in contrasting black and natural colours. The designs here are of zigzags and a variety of lozenges or diamonds. The Kuba people who produced these embroideries for chief's households, made the cloths as blankets, as coverings for stools and chairs for people of high status, and occasionally as clothing. Many pieces were cut up into smaller squares for sale to traders, who also cut them up again, so that small squares are very common amongst Western collections.

Description: rectangular cloth of double-weave green cotton with coloured blocks to imitate KENTE cloth. Border each ends. Centre has narrow stripes of red, blue, yellow and black. Bands with more open motifs in red and yellow, on every 2nd pick have long lozenges rev
WebDescription: This cotton and rayon broad cloth was probably woven on a 24-shaft loom with a fly-shuttle or powered shuttle, to imitate the older kente cloths woven in narrow strips. The design is in 12 vertical stripes, with a half width border stripe down either side. The green ground colour is thickly patterned by red, black and yellow geometric bars, bows and lozenges.

Description: almost square piece of barkcloth, decorated in brown and black:crown at centre, enclosed by 2 leafsprays; border of solid band with triangles facing out to edge (9 on bottom, 8 on top and sides). Possibly refers to Coronation 1953 of Queen Elizabeth II, Q
WebDescription: This small square of bark cloth was probably made for sale around 1953, at the time of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, which Queen Salote of Tonga attended. The main design which has been painted or stencilled on using blackish brown dye, is of a crown enclosed by two leaf sprays.

Description: large handwoven kente cloth, of 22 strips, width of each strip c. 9 cms, in deep orange-yellow, with green, red and blue. Alternate warp and weft faced blocks, l 14-15.5cms. Worn, some holes.
WebDescription: This kente cloth is made up of 22 narrow hand-woven strips, with alternate warp and weft faced blocks, in a mixture of cotton and silk threads. It has a repeated rectangular pattern of thicker and thinner bars in orange, green, black and blue.  These are highlighted by a variety of geometric shapes made by supplementary wefts. Large cloths like this were originally only made for the courtiers and chiefs at the Asante courts.Originally the silk threads used to make cloths like this were obtained by unravelling cloths imported from Europe.  They are worn draped and folded round the body. This is the oldest kente cloth in the Leeds collections.

Description: man's cloth wrapper, large cloth of 14 handwoven strips (w15.5-16.5cm), white warp with alternate blocks of white and black weft. Hand printed with adinkra motifs in a regular repeating pattern: 4 "gye nyame", 4 ram's horns, 4 8-pointed stars. Designs ske
WebDescription: This man's cloth wrapper with adinkra printed motifs is a large cloth made from 14 handwoven strips sewn together. The strips have alternating grey and white squares made from a white warp with alternate blocks of white and black wefts. On top of this woven base each square has diagonal repeats of three different adinkra stamp prints. The adinkra stamps are cut from dried gourds, and the thick dye or paste used for printing is made from boiling up pieces of bache bark with iron slag as a fixative. The stamps all have names and the ones used here are ram's horns, 8-pointed stars and 'gye nyame'.

Description: sample of adinkra cloth. Strip of factory-woven white cotton damask, raw edges torn or cut; hand-printed in glossy brown-black with alternate blocks of a) rectangular cross-hatching and b) either 2 gye nyame motifs or 2 cross motifs (cf maltese cross). Se
WebDescription: This cloth sample is of adinkra printing on factory woven white cotton damask. The adinkra stamps are made from gourds and the dye or paste is made from boiling up pieces of bache bark with iron slag or iron filings as a fixative. The two stamps used here include 'gye nyame'.  The rectangles of rough cross-hatching have been produced by spreading the dye on with a comb in two directions, rather than by stamping.

Description: sample of adinkra cloth. Strip of factory-woven white cotton damask, raw edges torn or cut; hand-printed in glossy brown-black. Irregular pattern repeat, 2 lines of blocks a) 6 blocks of rectangular cross-hatching; b) 8 blocks of 3 or 4 "gye nyame" motifs
WebDescription: Another cloth sample of adinkra printing on factory woven white cotton damask. The two stamps used are concentric circles and 'gye nyame'.  The rectangles of rough cross-hatching have been produced by spreading the dye on with a comb in two directions, rather than by stamping. The dye or paste is made from a tree bark cooked with iron slag or iron filings to fix it, and the stamps are cut from gourds.

Description: sample of adinkra cloth. Short strip of handwoven cotton, plain weave, 1/1 black and white in warp and weft, variable patterns; 2 small supplementary weft motifs in red and red with blue. Overprinted with random adinkra motifs in dark brown (gyenyame, dra
WebDescription: Another cloth sample of adinkra printing, this time on a short strip of handwoven cotton with alternate squares of denser and lighter black warps making different shades of grey. The three stamps used include 'gye nyame', stepped circles and bows.  The dye or paste is made from a tree bark cooked with iron slag or iron filings to fix it, and the stamps are cut from gourds.

Description: factory-woven cloth, made at Spintex factory, Tema, near Accra, "Spintex Kente". Yellow/orange, royal blue, dark red and black with few thin white stripes. Cotton and synthetic mix. Groups of warp stripes, alternating with yellow and black warp patterning
WebDescription: This is a length of factory brocade, made at the Spintex factory, at Tema, near Accra in Ghana. It is called Spintex Kente, as it imitates some of the geometric designs of handwoven kente. It is woven from a cotton and synthetic mix and was purchased near Makola market in Accra in August 1994.

Description: handwoven cotton cloth of 2 wider lengths (c. 54 cms wide) and one narrow strip, sewn together. Wider pieces have white warp and ground weft, with black and magenta supplementary weft bands across full width, supplementary weft in small zigzag and diamond
WebDescription: This handwoven cotton cloth is made of two fairly broad lengths sewn together, with a narrow strip of light and dark indigo dyed plain weave cotton along one selvedge. The main lengths have a white warp and ground weft, with black and purple supplementary weft bands making patterns of repeated zigzags, diamonds and rough circles. The donor though it might be from the Junkun people of Nigeria, but no exact parallels are known.

Description: pair of long traditional boots, new, for men or women. Hide soles, moulded up around foot. Uppers of heavy white cotton cloth. Button-hole stitching at top. Red leather applique at heel and toe. Narrow band blue and red brocade runs from toe, along centre
WebDescription: This pair of long boots has been made in the traditional style worn by both men and women. The hide soles are moulded up around the foot. The uppers are of heavy white cotton cloth with button-hole stitching at the top. Red leather applique is attached at the heel and toe. A narrow band of blue and red brocade runs from the toe, across the vamp and up the front of the leg, with a blue cord along its centre. The legs are of felted cloth, green above the upper, then black. Bright red felted cloth strips decorate the boots at centre back and front and the seams are also decorated with cords. The top edge and open part of the back seam are bound with check cotton cloth, in red, yellow, green and black.

Description: cotton cloth printed with design of palm tree, with 2 peacocks, 2 deer (?), and 2 tigers, in arch; row of mini Taj-Mahals at base; enclosed by floral borders. Black outlines, with dull red and light brown.
WebDescription: This large cotton cloth is printed with a design of a palm tree, with 2 peacocks, 2 deer (?), and 2 tigers, below an arch. Along the bottom is a row of tiny domed palaces, and the other borders are floral. The printing has been done with black outlines, in a dull red and light brown. The printers at Masulipatam where this cloth was made use printing blocks and wax resists as well as hand drawing some details with 'kalam' pens in the kalamkari technique.

Description: plain weave cotton cloth sample, in style of African print. Yellow ground with wide check of dark blue bands (rosette motifs), forming rectangles (internal dimensions 16 x 17.5cms, 6 across the cloth) in which are alternately: a) red-brown fly-whisk on da
WebDescription: Cotton printed with African designs, manufactured in Cheshire, England, in the 1990s, for export to West Africa. The bright red, blue and yellow designs include African stools and asymmetric curls that look like earrings.

Description: Commemorative cotton print, printed for South African elections in 1994. White ground, black pattern outlines with yellow and emerald green fill. Border (7.5-8cm wide) along both selvedges "VOTE ANC" over running diamonds. Centre field has bands with wavy
WebDescription: Cotton cloth printed with the face of Nelson Mandela and ANC emblems and mottoes for the 1994 elections. The ANC was formed to bring all Africans together as one people to defend their rights and freedoms. In the 1960s it campaigned against the apartheid pass laws in South Africa and was banned. Mandela and other leaders were convicted of violent protest and imprisoned for life. Talks with the South African government began in 1989, and led to the first democratic elections in 1994.

Description: child's plastic Batman mask, similar to one purchased for education activities summer 1997. Flesh-coloured lower face, black bat mask head. Pierced nostrils, mouth and eyes. Elastic strap knotted through side holes. CE label inside, TM 1992 DC Comics Ltd,
WebDescription: Batman mask for a child with a flesh-coloured lower face, and the distinctive black bat headdress that this comic book and film hero wears. The eyes, nostrils and mouth are pierced, and the eye-holes are large enough for the wearer to see out though. The mask fits round the head with an elastic strap knotted through side holes. Made in China for export to the UK where it was purchased.

Description: black cotton cloth printed with heads of Black leaders and logo 'BLACK IS BACK'. Portraits are of Bob Marley, Malcolm X, Martin Luther-King and Haile Selassi, printed in blue and white. Logo in yellow and red in a cross shape between. Edges machine hemmed
WebDescription: Cotton cloth printed with the portraits of black heroes: Bob Marley, Malcolm X, Martin Luther-King and Haile Selassi.

Description: circular crochet rasta hat of cotton, with horizontal stripes and teethed bands in yellow, red, green and black. Tighter and smaller than most rasta hats one sees worn. Stall was from a Birmingham shop, Blockbuster Products Ltd, T/A Blackseal, 349 Soho Rd
WebDescription: This hat is crocheted in the Rasta colours of red, yellow and green in thick cotton. The design is of toothed and plain bands in a concentric series with a black flowerhead in the centre. Only a few people in the Caribbean and the UK are Rastafarian believers.  Many others like to wear the colours as a symbol of their link with their African heritage. This hat is tigther and smaller than most rasta hats one sees worn, and is was purchased new from a market stall at Leeds Carnival in 1997. The stall was from a Birmingham shop, Blockbuster Products Ltd, of Handsworth.

Description: circular crochet rasta hat of cotton, with horizontal stripes and teethed bands in yellow, red, green and black. Tighter and smaller than most rasta hats one sees worn. Stall was from a Birmingham shop, Blockbuster Products Ltd, T/A Blackseal, 349 Soho Rd
WebDescription:
This crochet rasta hat of cotton, with horizontal stripes and teethed bands in yellow, red, green and black was bought at a stall at the Leeds West Indian Carnival in 1997. The stall was from a Birmingham shop, Blockbuster Products Ltd, T/A Blackseal, 349 Soho Rd, Handsworth, Birmingham.  It is tighter and smaller than most rasta hats one sees worn.

The Carnival was first held in Potternewton Park, Chapeltown, Leeds in 1967 and takes place each year around August bank holiday.

Description: metal thread embroidery of Taj Mahal, on turquoise or pale green satin cloth, backed with cotton. Central motif is Taj Mahal in silver, gold, red, blue, with pink and yellow lattice base. Floral border in silver with pink crenellations, and yellow frame.
WebDescription: Wall or table display cloth of pale blue silk with a raised silver thread embroidery design of the Taj Mahal, one of India's most famous monuments. The Taj Mahal was built by the Moghul emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal, in 1653. This cloth was brought back from India in 1920 by the husband of the original owner, Mrs Marion Leach.

Description: metal thread embroidery of Taj Mahal, on turquoise or pale green satin cloth, backed with cotton. Central motif is Taj Mahal in silver, gold, red, blue, with pink and yellow lattice base. Floral border in silver with pink crenellations, and yellow frame.
WebDescription:
Display cloth with a silver thread design of the Taj Mahal, India's most famous monument. It was built by the Moghul emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal, in 1653. 
Donated by Mrs Mamie Wood, 1997. Brought back from India by a Mr Leach in 1920

Description: cotton panel for chest section of a blouse, called a MOLA, framed. Black cotton ground, design of circle with mask-like tongues at outer corners in multicoloured cut-outs and additions. Main colours red, orange, yellow, blue and green. Outer ring of circl
WebDescription:
This cotton panel is the sort made by Cuna Indian women for the chest section of a blouse, called a Mola. The technique is reverse applique, using at least three layers, of red and yellow, with some blue and green inserts, and then black cotton cloth. The main design is a circle with mask-like tongues at the outer corners, butterflies in the middle ring, and birds and leaves in the centre. 

Cuna women have sewn these complex reverse applique panels for at least 150 years, and in recent times many panels, like this one, have been made for sale to tourists, to be framed for wall display.

Description: acryllic plush silk rug, purchased new, beige background, design of mihrab or prayer niche, beneath mosque dome and minarets, in black, orange, red and green. White plastic compass, with black degrees and direction signage, immediately above mihrab. Beige
WebDescription: This prayer rug, of woven acryllic plush silk, has a white plastic compass with black degrees and direction signage, placed immediately above the mihrab arch, to enable the user to face Mecca when praying. Above the compass is a mosque with two minarets. Below the arch is a lamp and a flower stand. The rug has borders with a complex lobed floral design, and a beige fringe along the top and bottom edges. The rug is a typical example of a fairly cheap modern kind, made in Pakistan. and widely used in Britain.

Description: quilted red silk brocade cloth covers, for bell and dorge set, F.1998.9.1&2. Foliage patterns in green, dull red, gold and purple. Separate covers for wand (flattish and smaller with single bobble and loop fastening) and bell (taller with almost circular
WebDescription: Bell, Ghanta, and Thunderbolt , Vajra set. The bell and thunderbolt are used in rituals to represent supreme knowledge, and compassion as the means to liberation. They are shown here with the brocade cases in which they are usually kept. Made in Nepal for use by exiled Tibetans and Western Buddhist centres. Purchased per Jamyang Buddhist Centre, Leeds, 1998.

Description: quilted red silk brocade cloth covers, for bell and dorge set, F.1998.9.1&2. Foliage patterns in green, dull red, gold and purple. Separate covers for wand (flattish and smaller with single bobble and loop fastening) and bell (taller with almost circular
WebDescription: Brocade cases for the bell and thunderbolt which are used together in Buddhist rituals to represent supreme knowledge, and compassion, as the means to liberation. The cases are sewn together so the items are kept together at all times. They were made in Nepal for use by exiled Tibetans and Western Buddhist centres.  Purchased per Jamyang Buddhist Centre, Leeds, 1998.

Description: man's white baggy cotton 'long johns', which reach below the knee. Part of man's costume 5A-5E, made in 1989, which was a gift to donor's Yorkshire husband, for best wear. Width at bottom of each leg 25 cms.
WebDescription: These man's baggy white cotton trousers would be worn as 'long johns' or undertrousers. They would reach below the knee. They are part of man's costume set, made in 1989, which was a gift to the donor's Yorkshire husband, for best wear.

Description: man's jacket, part of man's outfit, A-E. Same fabric as waistcoat, wide cut with small side slits, wide sleeves rounded at bottom, and low collar-less v-shaped neck line. Fastens with two huge green plastic buttons, elipse-shaped beads suspended on white
WebDescription: This man's jacket belongs to the same outfit as the undertrousers, and is made of a fine semi-transparent silk. The jacket is wide-cut with small side slits, with wide sleeves rounded at their bottom, and a low collar-less v-shaped neck line. The jacket fastens with two huge green plastic buttons, like elipse-shaped beads, which are suspended on white thread, with loop fastenings.

Description: manilla-shaped copper alloy bracelet, probably bronze, open ovoid with expanded ends. Cast, decorated with wire and shot work geometric designs just behind expansions. Dark patina, slight green corrosion deposits. One of two, the other to be kept for educ
WebDescription: Bronze bracelet in the traditional shape of a manilla, but with ornamental rings and shot near its open ends.

Description: full-length body stocking shaped costume of applique cotton. With projecting conical breasts of cloth covered wood or gourd. No hood or head, finishes at wrists and ankles. Thick blue/indigo base fabric of country cotton, with geometric designs all over i
WebDescription: This full-length costume like a body stocking is worn during a masquerade performance by a dancer who would have a masked headdress on top of his head. The base cloth is of thick locally woven indigo dyed cotton, closely covered by narrow strips of applique wool and cotton cloth in a complex geometric pattern.  Open slits under the arms allow some freedom of movement, but the dancer must be very thin to get into the costume through the neck opening! Stitched to the chest are two narrow pointed breasts of cloth covered wood or gourd.

Description: Afikpo mask of painted wood with concave lower face. Excised eyes. Bar shape projecting at forehead with ovals and in-curveds. Vegetable fibre crest and side tassles. Painted black, white, orange and ochure. Good condition. Thick dust hoovered and brushed
WebDescription: The Afikpo believe that wearing a mask turns a person into a spirit. This mask has a concave face, pierced eyes and a fringed vertical bar on top.

Description: Afikpo mask of painted wood with concave lower face. Excised eyes. Bar shape projecting at forehead with ovals and in-curveds. Vegetable fibre crest and side tassles. Painted black, white, orange and ochure. Good condition. Thick dust hoovered and brushed
WebDescription: A Nigerian Afikpo spirit mask of painted wood with concave lower face and hollow eyes. The crest and side tassles are made of vegetable fibre, and the mask is painted black, white, orange and ochure.  Part of the Paul Hambley collection, made in the mid-1970s.

Description: Afikpo mask of painted wood, with ovoid head and mainly white face. Plaited leaf near rim. Bar or flange projects from head-top with ovals, horizontal bands and in-curves. Painted black, white, orange and ochre. Good condition, thick dust hoovered and bru
WebDescription: The Afikpo believe that wearing a mask turns a person into a spirit. This mask has a convex face with prominent nose and cheek marks, pierced eyes and a bar on top painted with a striking geometric design.

Description: Afikpo mask of painted wood, similar to F.2002.3.10, but with broader head top flange with diagonal bands, ovals and triangular marked square. Painted black, white, orange and ochure. Fair condition, thick dust hoovered and brushed off.
WebDescription: The Afikpo believe that wearing a mask turns a person into a spirit. This mask has a convex face with prominent nose and cheek marks, pierced eyes and a bar on top painted with a simple geometric design.

Description: Afikpo mask of painted wood with flattish face and projecting semi-oval forehead, eyeballs and nose. Curves up and out at chin. Vegetable fibre rim at rear and across top, with long fibre tassles each side of top. Black, white and orange. Fair condition,
WebDescription: The Afikpo believe that wearing a mask turns a person into a spirit. This mask has a convex face split into two by contrasting colours and a short bar on top with thick fibre fringes.

Description: Afikpo mask of painted wood with flattish face and projecting semi-oval forehead, eyeballs and nose. Curves up and out at chin. Vegetable fibre rim at rear and across top, with long fibre tassles each side of top. Black, white and orange. Fair condition,
WebDescription: Nigerian Afikpo mask of painted wood with flattish face, and a projecting semi-oval forehead with eyeballs and nose.  The rim and long tassles are made of vegetable fibre, and the mask is painted in black, white and orange.  Part of the Paul Hambley collection, made in the mid-1970s.

Description: Afikpo mask of painted wood, ovoid, double beaked shape with excised lentoid eye. Palm fibre rim at rear. Painted orange, black, white and yellow/ochre. Fair condition, dust hoovered off.
WebDescription: The Afikpo believe that wearing a mask turns a person into a spirit. This mask has a tight oval face with large eye surrounds and similar forehead and chin ridges that make for a beak-like profile.

Description: Afikpo mask of painted wood. Similar ovoid double beaked shape to F.2002.3.14, but different paint pattern in ornage, black, white and yellow/ochre. Fair condition, but major paint smudge and one beak point chipped.
WebDescription: A Nigerian Afikpo mask of painted wood. An ovoid double beaked shape, with a simple painted pattern in orange, black, white and yellow/ochre.  Part of the Paul Hambley collection, made in the mid-1970s.

Description: Afikpo masquerade costume, one piece twine body suit with fibre fringes. Bands of black, orange and natural. Good condition, as new.
WebDescription: This one piece costume for a masked dancer is made of coarse twine, dyed red and brown, netted together, with long fringes at the wrists and ankles, and across the chest. The wearer would put the body suit on by climbing through a large gap under the fringe on the chest.

Description: One of a pair of leather shoes. Man's slip-ons. Tan uppers with embroidered design in thick silk floss, navy, red and green. 3 pompoms, now faded to green from blue. Layered leather soles. Pale red/tan insides with geometric designs, at heel.  Fair condit
WebDescription: These leather slip on men's shoes or sandals were purchased in a market in northern Nigeria. The tan uppers are embroidered with a banded linear design in thick silk floss thread in navy, red and green. Three pompoms, now faded to green from blue, decorate the tongue. The soles are made from layers of the same tan leather, and the insides show faint traces of painted decoration.

Description: Man's hat, circular, tall, with flat top. Bright blue velvet  with pale blue silk pattern of elephants. Leaf shapes and rings woven in. White cotton and blue nylon lining.  Condition: good. Comment by Muntaka Musa, 8 April 2011: Machine woven deep blue si
WebDescription: This man's hat is made from factory woven artificial silk velvet which was probably produced in China. The deep blue plush contasts with the pale blue base layer revealed in the design of elephants and arrow shapes. The hat was sewn by a local tailor, and its tall tubular shape is typical of men's hats in this area of northern Nigeria, even if the fabric is very modern.

Description: Man's hat, circular, concial, gathered centre top. Thick 'country cotton' os striped weave. Cream with black, orange and blue. Possible moth debris hoovered off.  Condition: good. Comment by Muntaka Musa, 8 April 2011: Rural simple cotton cloth hat, made
WebDescription: A man's hat from Northern Nigeria, made of thick 'country cotton', with a striped weave of cream, black, orange and blue.  Part of the Paul Hambley collection.

Description: Man's hat, circular, concial, gathered centre top. Thick 'country cotton', striped weave. Cream with black, beige, yellow and red. Possible moth debris hoovered off.  Condition: fair.
WebDescription: A man's hat from Northern Nigeria, made of thick 'country cotton', with a striped weave of cream, black, orange and red.  Part of the Paul Hambley collection.

Description: Boy's hat, curve of quilted cotton with right-angled sides. Black with vertical lines of grey stitching (machine-done) and border in red, yellow and white. Curled fork from open corner to closed one. Lined with white cotton. Condition: fair, dirty.
WebDescription: A Nigerian boy's hat, a curve of quilted cotton with right-angled sides. Black with vertical lines of machined grey stitching, with a border of red, yellow and white, and lined with white cotton.  Part of the Paul Hambley collection.

Description: Man's wedding robe, long tunic shape, with short square set sleevs. Of cream cotton, embroidered all over with lozenges of red floss silk and fret of green and yellow. Bib of curved zigzags adds purple and white colours. Blank lines and rosettes make up r
WebDescription: This elaborately embroidered wedding robe was worn by a Kunari man living near Lake Chad. The long tunic shape of cream cotton has short square set sleeves. The robe is almost completely covered with floss silk plain stitches making a design of red lozenges across a fretwork of green and yellow. These are puntuated by vertical lines and bare edged rosettes. The bib area has additional zigzag curves in purple and white.

Description: Shawl or wrap cloth. Purplish blue with similar woven design to 136. Slightly different colours on warps, turquoise blue for a star, rather than a darker blue. Pink and orange striped bands and other bands of lozenges, stars, toothed rectangles, triangle
WebDescription: Igbirra women use a vertical single heddle loom to weave these broad cloths with their colourful supplementary weft designs. This cloth is woven from machine-spun cotton and ?silk? (rayon).

Description: pale yellow silk quilted jacket for a lady. Hand sewn, with beige silk crepe lining. Square set sleeves with rolled cuffs. Front opening, no buttons, deep front edging, pockets inset into mid front. Very good quality, with finely worked quilting in design
WebDescription: This pale yellow silk quilted jacket was made for a well-off lady. It is hand sewn, with a finely worked quilting design of zigzags and triangles, and a beige silk crepe lining. The square set sleeves have rolled cuffs. The front opening has no buttons or other fastenings down the deep front edging. Pockets are inset into the mid front. The style is slightly adapted to pleae European or American purchasers. It was purchased in China during World War II by Dr Mick Baker, a friend of the donor's mother.

Description: Figure of masked dancer representing Hanuman, on a painted wood base. Identifiable by his small tail. Stands in a classical pose, withleft arm raised up, holding a trident in his right hand, and wears a removable helmet form paper mask. Made of silk, gilt
WebDescription: This figure of a masked dancer represents the Hindu deity Hanuman, the monkey god. He is identifiable by his tail and snout. He stands in a classical pose, with the left arm raised up, and the right arm lowered, holding a trident in his right hand. He wears a removable painted and sequinned paper mask over the top of his head. Most of the figure is made of polyester silk brocade and other cloth stuffed over a wire frame, with gilt cord and sequins for decoration.

Description: Doll in Barbados national dress, of deep blue and yellow. Brown plastic doll with beaded hair plaits, straw hat and high heeled shoes. On circular plastic stand. Cost 20. Carries Barbados flag.
WebDescription: National dress doll with Barbados flag. This plastic doll has beaded hair plaits, and wears a straw hat and high heeled shoes. Her huge huge blue and yellow cotton skirt and her yellow blouse are in the same colours as the flag.

Description: Rasta hat of corchet cotton. Circular with concentric design in red, yellow and green, with narrow black rings. Laid flat for measuring. Condition: Good.  Cost 9.
WebDescription: This hat is crocheted in the Rastafarian colours of red, yellow, black and green. Many people who wear the colours are not Rastafarian but wear them as a link with their Jamaican or African heritage.

Description: prayer rug, possibly from Afghanistan or Iran, or Iraq. Yellow and red main colours, with design of stepped mihrab or prayer arch in centre. Several framing borders with stars and other geometric designs, and stylised lions. Frayed fringe top and bottom.
WebDescription: This prayer rug is probably from Afghanistan, Iran, or Iraq. It was handwoven on a loom. The main colours are yellow and red, and the main design is the stepped mihrab or prayer arch in the centre. There are several framing borders with stars and other geometric designs, and stylised lions. The fringe at top and bottom is now badly frayed.

Description: silk cloth, a suit length given to Judith as an important wedding guest, by the bride. Dark red silk with green, yellow and violet ikat design for half of its length. Design geometric, including lozenges, v's and curls. Medium quality. Good condition (as
WebDescription: This suiting or dress length of silk cloth was given to an important wedding guest by the bride. It is a finely woven dark red silk with a green, yellow and violet ikat resist design for half of its length. The design is geometric and includes diamonds, v's and curls.

Description: Pair of sleeves of coarse cream cotton or linen, mostly embroidered with black cross- stitch stars and diamonds. Navy wool fringe at the wrist end. Border bands of dark blue wool cloth edging seperate at top and bottom. Narrow gilt wire braid near fringe.
WebDescription: This pair of sleeves are made of handwoven coarse cream cotton or linen cloth, embroidered with black cross-stitch stars and diamonds. The wrist ends are decorated with a navy wool fringe and a narrow strip of gilt wire braid. The tops are edged with dark blue wool cloth.

Description: Apron? Rectangle of coarse cream cotton or linen embroidered in deep blue, brown and a little green, in Greek fret designs. Central square panel with a broad band across the bottom with a blue wool tassel fringe. Some stitching worn and the top has been c
WebDescription: This rectangle of coarse cream cotton or linen was probably worn as an apron. It is embroidered in deep blue, brown and a little green, in Greek fret designs. These are arranged in a central square panel with a broad band across the bottom which has a blue wool tassel fringe.

Description: robe, kaftan style, full-length. Made from rough cream cotton or linen with black geometric key design embroidery on cuffs, sleeves and the sleeve seams, also around the neck. Has inlaid blue fabric and dyed goat/horse hair fringing around bottom of the n
WebDescription: This full length woman's robe is made from rough cream cotton or linen with a black geometric key design embroidered on the cuffs, sleeves, the sleeve seams, and around the neck. Blue fabric and a dyed goat or horse hair fringe decorate the bottom of the neck panel and the cuffs.

Description: Shawl of striped cotton cloth, the ends covered in cream net embroidered with flowers and birds in gilt wire thread work (now badly tarnished) in green, blue and beige. Crocheted scalloped edging in red and cream just along ends. Very grubby. Printed tape
WebDescription: This woman's shawl of striped cotton cloth has cream net cloth at the ends embroidered with flowers and birds in gilt wire thread work (now badly tarnished), and green, blue and beige silk threads. A crocheted scalloped edging in red and cream runs along the outer edge.

Description: Very fancy short or half-length jacket of black or deep purple velvet with dense gilt wire thread embroidered scrolls and braiding, tassels, knotwork buttons and pom-poms. The sleeves are open under the arm and are only attached to the jacket by a few sti
WebDescription: This very fancy short or half-length jacket of black or deep purple velvet is densely embroidered with gilt wire thread work, braiding, knotwork, buttons and pom-poms. The sleeves are open under the arm and are only attached to the jacket by a few stitches. They are very long with pointed ends. The paper backing for the embroidery is visible on the inside. The bottom edge of the jacket is very rough, indicating that it may have been cut down. The jacket has red silk ribbon on its inside edge. It was probably worn by a male dancer, bull-fighter or bandsman.

Description: rectangular piece of thick creamy barkcloth with painted and embossed geometric designs in pale brown and a larger more open pattern in thick dark brown paint in diagonals bands and crosses. Very clear, stored on a cardboard roll. From Castleford.
WebDescription: This rectangular piece of thick creamy barkcloth is painted and embossed with geometric designs in pale brown, with a larger more open pattern in thick dark brown paint in diagonal bands and crosses.

Description: elder's cape or kaross, early 1960s. Rectangular cape made from 18 wild cat skins, sewn together very regularly. Backed or lined with pale green flet or blanket cloth to make a rug or throw after arrival in England.
WebDescription: This rectangular item, used as a bedspread and rug by its English owner, was purchased in Botswana in the early 1960s. The vendor described it as a cape or kaross for a San (Bushman) elder. It is made from 18 wild cat skins, sewn together very regularly. The tails and ears of the some of the cats can still be seen. The lining and edging of pale beige felt or blanket cloth was added on arrival in England.

Description: purple and gold silk, printed design in gold of flower heads in lozenge trellis. Tailored narrowing sleeves with tiny buttons along forearm and long cuffs. Flares at bottom sides. Fair condition.
WebDescription: Purple and gold silk jacket with a printed design in gold of flower heads in a lozenge trellis. The jacket has tailored narrowing sleeves with tiny gilded metal buttons along the forearms and long cuffs. It also has pronounced flares at the bottom sides.

Description: gold coloured silk robe with woven design of large floral leaf shapes in gold, white, green and red. Gold coloured yellow silk lining. Gold braid trim round edges and vertically over seams. Short rectangular sleeves. Flared robe base. Good condition.
WebDescription: This gold coloured silk robe has a woven design of large floral leaf shapes in gold, white, green and red. It has short rectangular sleeves and a flared skirt or base. The lining is a plain yellow silk. The robe has gold braid trim around the edges and vertically over the seams. It is an over-robe which could have been worn by either a woman, or a man, from a wealthy background.

Description: Turkoman chapan, a coat or jacket, Central Asia. Black silk and cotton mixture with red, yellow and white ladder stitch embroidery down front opening, round hem and down front of sleeves. Lined with blue glazed cotton with printed design of red and green
WebDescription: This luxury coat or over-robe is made of black and red silk and lined with quilted cotton. It is called a 'chapan'. The elaborate ladder stitch embroidery designs combine plant motifs and geometrical friezes.

Description: Pair of smoked skin moccasins with hair and quill decoration, tin cones and orange hair tassels. Probably for a child. Labelled A & B.
WebDescription: This pair of small moccasins was probably made for a child. The soft skin or hide has been smoked to make it a dark brown colour. The vamps and ankle areas are finely embroidered with dyed porcupine quills and moose hair, in contrasting white and orange. Tin cones with orange hair tassels have been sewn on round the ankles.

Description: pair of moccasins, labelled A & B. Brown skin beaded vamp. Cloth cuff (red under, black over) with beadwork. Small paper label sewn on with cotton has inscription: "Moccasins of the North American Indians - Col. Walsh."
WebDescription: This pair of hide moccasins were probably made by Iroquois women. The vamp and ankle cuffs are of red and black trade cloth embroidered with glass beadwork. The vamps have a floral design where the larger areas of beadwork have been made over paper templates. The ankle cuffs have a simpler zigzag border, with two rows of contrasting pale blue and pink beads.

Description: thick 2 ply cord with 24 sections of rectangular polished shell attached. Length of shell pieces 3 cms by 1.2cms.
WebDescription: This necklace has 24 rectangular sections of polished shell tied onto a core of thick two-ply cord. The shell was imported to the area through a network of traders reaching back to the coast, and was originally cut up into sections and pierced with stone tipped knives and stone-tipped awls or drills.

Description: white downy bird feather tassels in bird beaks or claws, attached mainly in pairs to vegetable fibre cord; single feathers also knotted around cord.
WebDescription: This neck or head ornament has been made from white downy bird feathers, tied together as tassels with some bird beaks or claws. The tassels are knotted onto the vegetable fibre cord in pairs, in three main clumps, with a few single clipped feathers also knotted on in between.

Description: purse or wallet of buckskin, with red, blue, brown and white quill work. Woodlands Indian. Flat rectangular shape, whitish hide, decorated with two strips of woven quillwork with geometric pattern, and fringe along bottom of each strip. Strap of plaited r
WebDescription: This flat rectangular buckskin purse is decorated with two panels of fine woven quillwork, with long looped fringes. The long strap is of imported plaited red and white wool. Most of the quillwork is porcupine quill but there is some bird quill at the sides, and on the fringes. The dyes used to produce the range of purple, red, blue and brown or yellow colours for the quillwork were probably vegetable dyes. The pouch would have been used by a man for storing shot (for gun-firing).

Description: demon dancing mask, of red canvas on thick card (?), with cream and blue silk headband roll stitched on. Painted wood skull fixed to centre front of headband. Mother of pearl covered teeth, 3 gilt and black eyes, scrolled eyebrows and mouth corner masks.
WebDescription: A demon mask with large shell teeth and fangs, bulging eyes and a large snout-like nose. The angry red colour of the face shows how fierce he can be, and the third eye in the middle of his forehead indicates that he has special sacred powers.

Description: blackened wood mask with bulbous cheeks, and large oval eyes. Large curved chin flange, projecting ears, and curved hair/headdress and chin inlaid with white paint, as are nostrils, eyes, teeth and eyebrows. No holes for attachment of grass fringe or head
WebDescription: The power of spirits from previous generations are represented in ancestor masks. This blackened wood mask has bulbous cheeks, large oval eyes, a large curved hairstyle or headdress and a large curved chin flange. The white toothed smile suggests its power is positive and friendly.

Description: painted wood mask, pink face with pointed nose and gold teeth. Probably an evil prince character in WAYANG-TOLENG, the masked Hindu dances of Java. Paint worn off end of nose. Red and black eye pupils, open work underneath them and in mouth. Black concent
WebDescription: This Evil Prince mask was worn by professional actors performing epic theatre dances in royal courts and busy towns. The character's evil nature is shown by his long pointed nose, glaring eyes and open mouth with teeth and fangs.

Description: rectangular panel of woven beads looped or hung from badly corroded brass rod (rod not original). Lozenge design, of black on yellow hooked curves, and concentric green, red white and black lozenge or diamonds.
WebDescription: This rectangular panel of woven beadwork has a striking design of black on yellow hooked curves, and concentric green, red, white and black lozenges or diamonds. The brass rod it now hangs from is not original. The panel probably once decorated a special basket or a man's bag.

Description: Beadwork apron for a woman, late 19th century. Trapezoid outline with shorter top edge and multi-stranded cotton string ties at the four corners. Design of opposed red fret hooks on white ground. Three rows with openwork red bead columns near bottom edge
WebDescription: This Amazon Indian woman's apron is made from tiny red and white glass beads, woven into a broad trapezoid shape, with a shorter top edge and multi-stranded cotton ties at the four corners. The design is of opposed red fret hooks on a white ground. At the bottom are three rows with openwork red bead columns and a thick cotton fringe. Tin cone rattles are attached to the bottom corners and there is one extra cluster near the bottom left side. Empty and broken off strings down the sides suggest where more tin cone rattles were once attached.

Description: coarse red wool and black cotton woven cloth with supplementary weft geometric bands in yellow, black, blue, green, white and pink. Seam down middle, two loom widths sewn together. Becomes much less dense red on back, with swastika pattern for most of len
WebDescription: This skirt cloth is woven with coarse red wool and black cotton with supplementary weft designs of geometric bands in yellow, black, blue, green, white and pink. The cloth is seamed down the middle of its length. It is made of two loom widths sewn together. The front is more red than the back which has a swastika like pattern for most of length.

Description: whale tooth pendant, a single large tooth on sennet cord, plaited. No inked number and label missing. Surface scratched. Sonia and Terry O'Connor 23.6.2011: Definitely sperm whale tooth, with plaited sennet.
WebDescription: In Fiji these large whale teeth are very valuable, and form part of important ceremonial exchanges or gift giving. The teeth are hung as pendants on plaited coconut fibre cord (called coir or sennet). Teeth with deep yellow patinas are most admired.

Description: fourteen long teeth from a necklace, with remains of string and copper wire that once held them together. No inked no. or label. Very dirty and copper corroded, but all of similar size. Restrung with polyester silk yarn by AL, after corroded copper wire r
WebDescription: These fourteen long teeth or tusks once formed part of a necklace worn by an important man or chief.

Description: finely modelled clay costumed figure of woman with painted face and hair, wearing cream muslin shawl edged with red and brown check skirt and bodice. Bangles on left forearm. Stands upright on rectangular white painted clay base. Number &17/57 inked on ba
WebDescription: Costumed clay figure of a servant or poor woman, India, 1890-1910. She has a painted face and hair and wears a cream muslin shawl edged with red, over a brown check skirt and bodice. Although she is poor she has some jewellery, a few bangles on her left forearm.

Description: bronze comb with 5 teeth, with almost full relief figure of Lakshmi holding lotus bud inside arched canopy as openwork handle design. Old no &170/67 (58) inked on back. (Looks at first like a 56). Sir Stuart Mitford Fraser collection, described on RHM lis
WebDescription: Bronze comb with five tines or  teeth. The handle top has a figure of the Hindu deity Lakshmi, holding a lotus bud inside an arched canopy. The figure is in almost full relief, with lots of detail. This is the sort of comb that would have been worn by a professional dancer, as part of an elaborate hair do.

Description: bronze comb with 5 teeth, with almost full relief figure of Lakshmi holding lotus bud inside arched canopy as openwork handle design. Old no &170/67 (58) inked on back. (Looks at first like a 56). Sir Stuart Mitford Fraser collection, described on RHM lis
WebDescription:
Comb with female dancer or deity, gilt bronze, India, 1880-1910
Transferred from Hampshire County Museum and Archive Service, 2007

Description: cotton and wool bag of woven cloth with broad black cotton strap, red felted wool panels, lots of red felted wool cloth fringes or tassels, white seeds and glass bead ornaments. Height of strap 48 cms, width (folded double) 7.5cms.
WebDescription: This bag is made of woven cotton and wool cloth with a broad black cotton strap, red felted wool panels, and lots of red felted wool cloth fringes or tassels. Above the tassels is a pattern made with rows of white seeds and black glass beads.

Description: small beadwork covered papoose, or cradle on cloth and hide base, supported by two wooden sticks. Plains Indian style of beadwork, geometric. For a doll, a toy used by a girl. Old no. E66 inked on back. Tassels of red and blue beads on hide. Cream, red an
WebDescription: This small beadwork covered papoose was probably made for a young girl, so she could carry her doll, and learn how to babysit brothers and sister. The beadwork is strung with bands of loose threads, stitched down to form a geometric design of stepped triangles and rectangles. Inside, at the bottom, and to the rear the cotton lining cloth is visible. It is a factory printed cotton with a delicate floral and foliate striped pattern. Tassels of larger red and blue glass beads on hide decorate the sides of the papoose.

Description: necklace of tiny white conical whorled shells. Strung in opposite directions alternativing
WebDescription: Tiny white conical whorled shells are strung closely together on this simple necklace.

Description: double thick necklace of tiny white ovulum or cowrie shells, on string.
WebDescription: This long shell necklace is made of a double row of tiny white ovulum or cowry shells, on string.

Description: pig tail or que of human hair, dark brown in colour, plaited. Coarse red string or cotton thread coiled at top, twisted red string at bottom. No old label. Possibly CRM.1956.20.2 (Que, China), from Mrs H W Brough Slack, 119 Castlemain Avenue, W56, Bournem
WebDescription: Pig tail or que of human hair. It is dark brown in colour and plaited with a coarse red string or cotton thread coiled at the top, and twisted red string at the bottom. It would have been by a Han Chinese man worn attached to a servant's or official's cap.

Description: one of a pair of huge brass anklets with tubular centres and large circular flange incised with geometric designs on the top surfaces. Display wire removed by AL, April 1999. Circle flange has narrow opening at one side and piercings at rim nearby.
WebDescription: One of a pair of heavy brass anklets worn by women of wealthy families as a sign of prestige. They were specially fitted and restricted movement so that a woman who wore them would have needed help with housework. The tubular centres and large circular flange are incised with geometric designs on the top surfaces. The circular flange has a narrow opening at one side and piercings at the rim nearby.

Description: Double ended comb of blackish wood, with grooves and ring and dot markings, similar to the previous two from Zanzibar. Hook curles project from central barred waist.
WebDescription: Double ended comb with waisted grip. Shorter body and teeth at the top, longer at the bottom. Decorated with dotted circles and scored lines.

Description: Cloth stamped with Daoist symbol by priest at the City God temple, Shanghai, 9 March 2008. Souvenir item.
WebDescription:
Square handkerchief-like cotton cloth, personally stamped by a Daoist official or priest at the City God temple, Shanghai, 9 March 2008. The main characters which make up the seal are: Shang hai xian cheng huang xian you bo yin: The seal of the lord city god of Shanghai. 

City gods are deities in Chinese mythology, responsible for the affairs of the city.
This seal was created in the Kangxi period of the Qing Dynasty and is now kept by the Shanghai Daoist Association. In the old days, the city god's seal was highly respected by the general population. Where ever there is plague, disaster or burial, this seal must be applied for blessing.

The smaller black characters below the red seal read: Ming chi feng shang hai xian zheng tang: Appointed office of the government in Shanghai; Cheng huang xian you bo yin: The seal of the lord city god.

Description: Silk scarf with design in black red and blue of Chinese warriors round the edge of a central blue square. By manufacturer's called WENSLI, in presentaiton box, as received by curator as an official gift on a visit to the National Silk Museum, Hangzhou, Ma
WebDescription: Silk scarf trademarked Wensli, an official gift from The National Silk Museum at Leeds twin town of Hangzhou, where these scarves are made.

Description: Souvenir handkerchief embroidered with mother and young panda design, silk thread on white silk. Pandas are eating bamboo. Folded in a cellophane packet with Chinese and English wording in gold, including: 'High Class Embroidered Handkerchief'. Packet to
WebDescription: Souvenir handkerchief embroidered with a mother and young panda design, in silk thread on white silk. The pandas are eating bamboo. Still in its cellophane packet with Chinese and English wording in gold, including: 'High Class Embroidered Handkerchief'. The Chinese text translates as 'Premier embroidered handkerchief' and 'China tour commemoration' (Hattie Lam 2010).

Description: Green glass pendant on green and brown silk cord, in presentation box. A special vegetable (type of cabbage or possibly spring vegetable?) which symbolises fertile thoughts. Given to AL in thanks for mentoring design student Liu Li for her project work on
WebDescription: This green glass pendant on a green and brown silk cord is still in its presentation box. The 'cabbage' looks like a pale and flawless jade and its Chinese pronunciation is the similar 'bai chai'  which means a 'hundred fortunes'. The pendant was a gift to the Leeds curator from a design student Liu Li for her project work on designing a portable museum display whilst in Leeds in 2008 (Hattie Lam 2010).

Description: Fang style mask from Gabon (or possibly a copy made elsewhere in Africa). Narrow ovoid mask with domed forehead, narrow nose ridge, whitened face, tiny eyes and open mouth with teeth shoing. Mouth almost rectangular. Small cusp shaped ears at sides. Lots
WebDescription: The white face gives this mask a ghostly feel. It is probably a modern copy, deliberately aged to look more ancient, and could have been carved in Gabon, or nearby Nigeria.

Description: Gelede mask of carved and painted wood. Coloured red, yellow and black. Original Welcome description says "mask in form of man's head, negroid features, carved wood, painted brown, black and yellow, 3 tribal marks on each cheek and above nose, elaborate h
WebDescription: The Gelede Society is a secret society for combating threats from evil-wishers. The members are mostly men, and they keep much of their sacred knowledge secret to enhance their authority. This mask shows a beautiful woman with a multi-knotted hair style. She has the distinctive cheek scars of initiated Yoruba people.  The mask is worn flat on top of the dancer's head and titled slightly forward. It is worn with a multi-layered costume.

Description: flat antelope head, black with white and buff lines. Wooden mask with crocodile like mouth, and antelope like horns. Tip of left horn and left side of mask have old woodworm infestation, repaired with polyfilla in Museum, 7/10/1964.
WebDescription: This antelope horned mask is worn by men in the secret Zamle Society for warriors and hunters.  The antelope and ram are symbols of fertility and prosperity because of the growth of their horns. Some areas of the mask have been cut out in low relief and coloured with white and brown pigments to contrast with the rest of the blackened surface.

Description: one of a pair of beadwork arm, waist or leg ornaments. A rectangular paenl of 8 bead-covered rolls, 2 white, enclosing 4 white with black, blue and red, and pink at the ends. 5+3 brass buttons at ends. Old Wellcome label: 48774/2 - S AFRI WEM Cos 20.02 B.
WebDescription: One of a pair of beadwork leg or arm ornaments with tiny glass beads strung in coils round cloth or grass fibre cores.
