Six long horizontal cores with bands of white, black, blue and red beads are bordered at the fastening ends by shorter cores coiled with pale pink beads. Brass buttons attached to these pink beaded cores are both decorative and help with fastening the ends together (usually with loops, which are now missing).

Medium/Materials: beads, cloth, leather, thread, brass buttons
Description: one of a pair of beadwork arm, waist or leg ornaments. A rectangular paenl of 8 bead-covered rolls, 2 white, enclosing 4 white with black, blue and red, and pink at the ends. 5+3 brass buttons at ends. Old Wellcome label: 48774/2 - S AFRI WEM Cos 20.02 B.
WebDescription: Beadwork armlet made of six horizontal grass fibre rolls wound with glass beads in a simple vertical stripe design in blue, white, black and red, with white outer bands and pink ends. It would fasten with grass loops and brass buttons.

Description: strip of leather with red, white and light blue beads sewn on; divided into two bands except for rectangular section in centre. Two thongs at one end with two holes for threading through at the other.
WebDescription: Arm or leg ornament of leather decorated with strings of red, white and pale blue glass beads, which are sewn on. One unbeaded end of the leather has been split to make ties, and the other has a hole punched through to thread these through.

Description: fibre and beads bracelet, or part of larger ornament. Narrow bead strand with thick fibre fringe with pink, white and black beads at base, attached to rectangle of mainly white beads, with black and red triangles and some pale blue beads. Button fastening
WebDescription: This fibre and glass bead bracelet may once have been part of a longer girdle. A thick fibre fringe hangs from a narrow beaded strand, with beads at the fringe bottoms. The shorter joining section is formed by an interlocking bead lattice, with a brass button for fastening at its top corner.

Description: woman's cap of palm spathe, beaten fibre without seam. Very similar to F.1960.72. Old Welcome Historical Medical Museum number 190784. There is a third similar cap in the Natural History Department, also from Wellcome collection, provenanced as from Panam
WebDescription: This tiered cap of palm spathe, with a conical peak, is made from a flattened and folded piece of spathe fibre. Palm spathe fibre forms at the base of old palm tree fronds. See cap F.1960.0072 for another example in better condition.

Medium/Materials: feathers, palm leaf, cane, plant fibre
Description: circular headdress of cane, palm-leaf, fibre and feathers. Black, red and gold feathers. Two strings or tassels of cotton cord at back. Badly moth-eaten.
WebDescription:
This feather headdress has a cane and plant fibre ring, which would encircle the head almost horizontally. The trimmed yellow, black and red feathers protrude at right angles. They probably include macaw and parrot feathers. These birds were often kept as 'pets' by women, who would pluck the birds from time to time. Men rather than women make and wear the feather headdresses. This headdress is fastened on with long ties made of local cotton. 
Different sorts of feather headdresses are worn by many Amazon Indian peoples, this type with a cane ring is found amongst the Makano and Tukano peoples. Looking through published photographs of these peoples one finds that most headdresses are of a simpler form with a vertical feather row, and it is only the shaman's headdress which usually has a basketry ring.

Description: headtop mask of carved wood covered in skin on basket-work base. Elaborate horns and headdress, black pegs for hair, bone teeth, yellow face, black horns. Two side horns turn downwards, front horn spirals outwards. Circular black tribal marks on cheek sid
WebDescription: This headtop mask represents a beautiful ancestress. The men who wore it were members of a secret society with sacred powers and authority. Masked up as this famous ancestress they were recognising and adopting her fame and child-bearing success. The mask is made of carved wood covered in skin with a basket-work base. It has elaborate horns and a forward spiralling headdress, black pegs for hair, black tribal marks on both cheeks and bone teeth.

Description: comb with 4 long teeth, stylised head at top with tip-tilted nose, distinctive Yaka style. Old Wellcome numbers 44306 and 90755.
WebDescription: Wooden comb with four teeth below rectangular shoulders, and a figure head that has the distinctive upturned nose of Yaka style woodcarving.

Description: girl's pubic shield of white pottery with pattern of black dots. Slightly concave truncated triangle shape, shiny with translucent glaze. Geometric design of vertical bands of dotted lines, alternating with plain white bands.  Old label: A 162428 - COS AF
WebDescription: Waist ornament for a young girl, made of white glass pottery imported from Europe.

Description: soft hide pipe bag with fringe at bottom, above that are 19 strands of hide wound with porcupin quills forming purple square with red one inside, on white ground. Above quillwork is band of bead embroidery consisting of orange, red and blue beads in geome
WebDescription: This long bag was used by a man for storing his tobacco pipe. It is made of soft hide, with a long fringe at the bottom, above which are 19 strands of hide wound with dyed porcupine quills forming a purple square with a red one inside, on a white ground. Above the quillwork is a band of glass bead embroidery with orange, red and blue beads forming a geometric design. The hide above has been dyed slightly yellow. A narrow row of bead embroidery decorates the top of the bag, and a strip of beadwork lines up with the seam down the side.

Description: string bag, embroidered with coix seeds (Job's tears).Fairly open net weave, with darker band of black or dark green across centre. Seeds in nine columns, split in half by this dark band. Netted handle strap across top. Tassels of twisted fibre, now at ir
WebDescription: This string or net bag has a fairly open net weave, with a darker band of black or dark green across the centre. On the front this band is partly hidden by the nine split columns of white coix seeds. Tassles of twisted fibre now survive at irregular points across the front. A netted handle strap is attached at the top corners. The back of the bag is plain. This sort of small highly decorated bag would have been used by men to store their personal valuables such as tobacco, charms and small weapons.

Description: rectangular panel beadwork, white with asymmetric black shapes; eyes (for hooks) sewn on at one end, single thong at other. For ankles or wrists? Very similar to FL.1965.349, so provenanced as Botswana too.
WebDescription: Anklet in the form of a rectangular leather panel decorated with strings of white and black beads, sewn down to form a bold geometric design of triangles and a trapezoid. European brass eyelet fastenings are sewn on at one end, to hold the single leather thong tie at the other. This anklet was probably worn by a man of some importance.

Description: small basketry cap decorated with two pairs of dog teeth and strips of red cane. Mainly natural cane basketry, with black chevron pattern in broad band, and smaller black ring near top centre. Old Wellcome label 192907, see below
WebDescription: This small basketry cap is decorated with two pairs of dog teeth and strips of red cane. The basketry is a plain natural colour with a black chevron pattern in a broad band, and a smaller black ring near top centre. This sort of  cap is worn by bachelor's amongst the Bontok people. They wear it at the back of the head, and sometimes store small personal items under it.

Description: basketry hat, probably made of split spruce roots, twined with cedar bark warp, with painted faces and other motifs. Old label: 164888, Hat Haida Indian, British Columbia. JCH King: Nootka, twined cedar bark, strands of grass at edge. Late 19th century.
WebDescription: This basketry hat is made of split spruce roots, twined with cedar bark warp. It has been painted with a face of a seal, a seal's foot, and a bird. This shape of hat was usually made by the Nootka in the North West Coast area of Canada and Alaska, and occasionally worn by their neighbours, the Haida.

Description: Tall mask; yellow face with tribal marks, beard; 2 tall ears facing outwards, with man riding bicycle between; drum in front, spotted quadruped (chameleon or lizard) at rear. Leopard's spots and hare's long ear's.  Raffia fringe, very dry.
WebDescription: The Egungun Society is associated with ancestors and the cult of the dead.  Some characters in their masquerades have great religious significance, whilst others are more entertaining and satirical. This mask has the beard of a respected elder. Between the large hare's ears is a chameleon and a cyclist.

Description: beaded armlet or anklet, with core of 8 cloth rolls. With brass buttons one end. Old Wellcome label 162824 South Africa. Long stretches of white beads with pale blue lozenge shapes, interrupted by cross bands of red, yellow, black and blue beads.
WebDescription: Beadwork armlet or anklet made with a core of 8 cloth rolls coiled round with a spiral thread of tiny glass beads in a geometric design. There are long stretches of white beads with pale blue lozenge shapes, intgerrupted by cross bands of red, yellow, black and blue beads. At the ends brass buttons and a few remaining thread loops act as decorative fastenings.

Description: leather band with with fringes of black, red and black hair lying up and down, row of thin white seeds at centre; long fringe of black hair hanging down. This hair may be human.
WebDescription: This man's armlet is formed by a leather band with cut fringes of black and red hair either side of a row of thin white seeds. From this main band hangs a very long fringe of black hair, which may be goat or human hair. The Naga are famous warriors, and many of their spears and helmets, as well as their personal ornaments, are decorated with hair.

Description: flat brass circlet, probably a neck ornament. Decorated with cross-hatched engraved bars and chevrons, punched circles, etc. With rectangular projections.
WebDescription: Bronze neck ornament with incised geometric designs, worn by women of high status

Description: basketry armlet covered with cowries. Old label Acc.No.43795 of 25/8/1925 (4/-). Cowrie shell armlet, Africa. Check No. 2712 6/1/33.
WebDescription: A basketry armlet covered with cowries, from Uganda.

Description: cap of woven basket work, with tiny knobs projecting from the weave. Pale natural brown colour. Circular.
WebDescription: This circular basket work cap is woven with tiny knobs projecting from the weave. It is pale natural brown in colour, and made from plant fibres.

Medium/Materials: plant fibre, leather, shells, buttons, glass beads
Description: woman's headdress. Cap lined with leather and covered with black fibre plaits, cowrie shells, and white buttons; long fringe over each ear of strings of blue and red beads. Fringe continues round back. Black fibre plaits go from back to front of head, in
WebDescription: This headdress worn by a Fang woman is made of different sorts of plant fibre, cowry shells, glass beads and buttons. The shape copies an earlier helmet-like hair style, with a similar forehead brim and ridged peak.

Description: Wooden mask with coloured patina, oval face, pointed chin, two birds at top, their beaks pointing to the top of the mask head, their bodies at the sides. Loop curve at bottom of chin. Some grass tassels in holes around side rim.
WebDescription: Spirit mask with birds, Senufo people, Ivory Coast, Africa, 2000-2005. Wooden mask with a coloured patina, deliberately done to make the mask look old. The oval face has two birds on top, their beaks pointing to the middle of the mask head, their bodies at the sides. The pointed chin continues to form a curved loop at the base. This is a modern copy made for sale to tourists.

Description: Machine woven cotton hand printed and dyed with lizard stamps for indigo resist.
WebDescription: This hand-dyed fabric is made by Musa Jaiteh, using carved wooden stamps and melted candle wax to print the wax resist designs. It was imported by Maggie Relph of www.africanfabric.co.uk.

Description: 3/4 length robe, of dark navy net, with the same rank badge, an embroiderd silk panel, on front and back featuring a bird, sun, etc. Long sleeves. Centre fastening. A see-through summer surcoat, with self-coloured motifs woven into the net material. Plain
WebDescription: Three quarter length over robe or surcoat of dark navy net or gauze for summer wear, with embroidered silk rank badges on the front and back featuring a silver pheasant, the bird worn by the 5th civil rank. This robe would be worn over a dragon robe in the presence of the Emperor.

Description: part of a man's "Parsee suit", with trousers (A); long coat (B); and waistcoat  (C). Skull cap of red and gold silk brocade with insets of blue and white silk brocade and orange satin. Flat top, point at nape of neck.
WebDescription: This man's cap is made of  red and gold silk brocade with insets of blue and white silk brocade and orange satin.  The top is flat, and the sides converge in a point at the nape of the neck. The belongs to an outfit for a Parsi man which also includes a long coat, trousers and a waistcoat.

Description: square of barkcloth painted brown, with one border black stripe. Reverse is finely ribbed.
WebDescription: This square of barkcloth has been painted brown, with one black stripe along one edge. The reverse is finely ribbed by the ridges on the beater used to make the cloth from the inner bark of the breadfruit tree. The cloth is very creased from old fold lines.

Description: shell necklace, long heavy necklace of sections of white beach washed gastropods shells.
WebDescription: This long heavy necklace is made of sections of white beach-washed gastropod shells.

Description: necklet or charm of three polar beath teeth, suspended on plaited gut cord. Length measured with neckloop pulled out. Width is length of longest tooth. Sonia O'Connor 23.6.2011: More likely to be walrus 'peg' teeth or stump teeth, than polar bear teeth.
WebDescription: This necklet has three polar bear teeth, suspended on a plaited gut cord. The teeth are probably amulets or charms.

Description: one of two sandals made of carved wood with fluted heels and circular knobs for grips between toes. A is painted red with floral pattern.
WebDescription: Two sandals made of carved wood with fluted heels and circular knobs for grips between the toes. Although they are said to be a pair their shape and painted designs are different. One is redder with a more central band of flowers, the other broader, more waisted, and mainly painted in green and yellow.

Description: one of two sandals made of carved wood with fluted heels and circular knobs for grips between toes. A is painted red with floral pattern.
WebDescription:
Raised wooden sandals with a different floral design painted on each one. India, 1880-1910
On loan from Clifton House Museum, Rotherham, since 1981

Description: heavy brass bracelet, curved with greatly expanded triangular shaped ends. Chased and welded ornament. Very clean and shiny.
WebDescription: Thick gilt bronze bracelet with broad flanges that almost meet and linear geometric designs incised in the surface.

Description: tunic of cotton cloth with applique ornament, known as a JIBBAH or JIBBA, described in an old typewritten brown card label as 'Costume worn by the Umbrella bearers at Kumassi. Ashanti Expedition. 1894. Presented by Capt. Phillips, R.E.". Type of patchwork
WebDescription:
Warrior's robe or tunic, known as a jibba, worn by followers of the Mahdi, a warrior prophet who led an uprising against the British in the Sudan in the 1880s and 1890s, that spread across Sub-Saharan African. The cream cotton tunic has patches of beige and dark navy wool cloth, embroidered with curled and lobed designs in chain stitch. The patchwork was a symbol of poverty that denoted religious purity. 

This example was confiscated from the Asante court at Kumasi, Ghana, by officers in the Prince of Wales's Own Regiment of Yorkshire in 1896.

Description: pair of deerskin moccasins, with embroidered vamp, two boot buttons and buttonholes. Metis style.
WebDescription: This pair of deerskin moccasins have deep ankles, which could be turned over like cuffs, or kept upright and fastened as here with the two boot buttons and stitched buttonholes. They are more Metis than Inuit in style, and have vamps embroidered with floral designs in chain stich.  The vamp seams are decorated with a twist of red and black cord.

Description: pair of mittens of white felted wool cloth, with white fur edging, red and green stitching. Red zigzag stitch round base of thumb seam, small berries with leaves above.
WebDescription: For many decades mittens have been made of imported white felted wool cloth as well as local furs. The cloth is extremely thick and warm. These mittens are decorated with red and green stitching and a white fur trim. The embroidered designs are a red zigzag band in running or plain stitch round the base of the thumb seam, and small berries with leaves above done in satin stitch.

Description: pair of mittens of spotted fur, probably sealskin, with brown and white fur edging. Some moth damage.
WebDescription: This pair of mittens are made from spotted sealskin fur, now badly moth damaged. The wrists are trimmed with thicker fur, probably dog fur, for extra warmth.

Description: pair of boots, deerskin sole and vamp; leg mottled brown/white fur, white skin edging, laced at back. Leg fur is probably sealskin.
WebDescription: This pair of boots has deerskin soles and vamps, which look very similar to Metis moccasins. They are much worn by use. The legs are made of mottled brown and white fur, from a much thicker sealskin. At the top is a casing of white de-haired fur or hide, for a tie string or hide thong lacing.

Description: pair of boots of white felted wool cloth, with bright red braid binding at top.
WebDescription: This pair of boots for a woman is made of white felted wool cloth, with a red braid binding at the top. They are everyday wear, probably worn indoors, as they have no hard soles.

Description: mat of white polar bear skin, edged with dark brown fur (possibly dog fur) and fringe of red felted cloth; backed with canvas. Label tied on: Baby polar bear. Mrs Smith, Knebworth", and "& puppy dog skin round the edge". Length of central fur section 68cm
WebDescription: This rug or mat is of baby polar bear skin, with puppy dog skin around the edge and gathered fringe of felted red wool cloth. It was made for sale at a trading store, and collected by the local Moravian Mission to send to the UK to raise funds for their work in Canada.

Description: wooden doll in female clothing, white cotton overshirt, large hood, hem dips front and back, skin boots.
WebDescription: Wooden doll in female clothing, a white cotton overshirt with a large hood and a hem which dips down at front and back. Worn with grey wool trousers and skin boots. The hood is embroidered with flowers.

Description: circular deerskin mat, embroidered. Metis style. Border ring of floral trellis embroidery, in mauve, blue, green and black.
WebDescription: This small circular deerskin mat was embroidered for sale to tourists. It is more Metis or mixed culture, than Inuit in style. The embroidery is in coloured silk threads, with a design of a floral trellis.

Description: Open robe closed bodice dress of cream silk woven with a pattern of a subtle floral stripe, with matching petticoat.  The same fabric has been used to trim and add interest to the dress throughout.  The front of the bodice and the skirt are both decorated
WebDescription: In the eighteenth century dress bodices closed at the front with a triangular piece of fabric called a stomacher.  This had to be pinned to the dress every time it was worn, which made getting dressed very time consuming.  In the middle of the eighteenth century some more practical types of dress began to appear.  This dress is an example of this style.  Instead of a stomacher, it has two flaps of fabric with buttons covering the front of the bodice, called "compres".  These are connected to the front opening of the robe, so a separate stomacher is not needed.

Dimensions:
Waist: 60 cm (23 5/8 in.)
Bust: 82 cm (32 5/16 in.)
Description: Open robe closed bodice dress of cream cotton which is both block printed and pencilled with a design of floral sprays reds, blues, greens and yellows.
WebDescription: Towards the end of the eighteenth century everyday clothing for women became much simpler.  The bodice of this dress has a closed front with no need to be pinned into a stomacher.  It does not have the exaggerated wide shape of earlier garments, and so would have been worn without a pannier or hoop.  It would be worn with a petticoat.  It has three quarter length sleeves which are pleated and stitched to achieve shaping for the elbow.  The fabric is white plain woven cotton, printed with a delicate pattern of flowers and foliage in brown, black, blue, pink, red, green and orange.

Description: Pair of stays (corset) with 20 eyelet holes for straight lacing at the back (laces missing). Short waisted with curved front neckline. Shoulder straps fastened by tape at front (one tape remains). The outer layer is twill weave brown cotton. There are lin
WebDescription:
The corset is a closely fitting inner bodice stiffened with whalebone or wood.  It would mould the body of the wearer to the fashionable shape.  This particular example is made from brown calico and has a curved front neckline.  The shoulder straps are fastened at the front with tape.  It is lined with pale brown linen.  

At the back two rows of holes are where the corset would be fastened using lacing.  It is hand stitched throughout.  The stitching on the outside is white, and follows the edges of the channels where stiffening was inserted.  At the bottom the shaped and boned tabs would splay out over the hips of the wearer and give extra fullness to a petticoat tied at the waist over the corset.

Description: Pair of stays (corset) with 20 eyelet holes for straight lacing at the back (laces missing). Short waisted with curved front neckline. Shoulder straps fastened by tape at front (one tape remains). The outer layer is twill weave brown cotton. There are lin
WebDescription:
Stays were an essential foundation garment for any fashionable woman throughout the 1700s. The laces at the back, when tightened, manipulate the shape of the upper body pulling the waist and flattening the bust creating a firm almost conical shape. The stays are made up of many layers and stiffened with strips of whalebone, inserted between rows of fine hand stitching. 
They woudl be worn under a dress and over a loose fitting linen garment called a chemise.

Description: This banyan is made from 18th century Chinese embroidered white silk satin, with patterns of flowers, insects and butterflies using rich coloured silk threads.  The embroidery is done using satin stitch, stem stitch and split stitch.  The garment is full
WebDescription:
This banyan is made from white silk satin embroidered with a Chinese pattern of flowers, insects and butterflies using rich coloured silk threads.  The embroidery is done using satin stitch, stem stitch and split stitch.  The garment is full length and slightly fitted, with a full skirt and sleeves.  The sleeves are finished with deep turnover cuffs.  It is lined with ivory coloured silk.

The fabric used to make this banyan was embroidered in China and then imported to England where it was made up into this European style.

Description: This banyan is made from 18th century Chinese embroidered white silk satin, with patterns of flowers, insects and butterflies using rich coloured silk threads.  The embroidery is done using satin stitch, stem stitch and split stitch.  The garment is full
WebDescription:
A banyan is a garment that is very similar to a dressing gown and worn by men as a garment of undress. They were often made of exotic fabrics. This banyan dates from the 1830s in style but it is made from imported embroidered Chinese silk which dates from the 18th century. 
The banyan is one item of a larger collection of mainly 18th century fashions which came to Leeds Museums and Galleries via the Leeds born collector Kenneth Sanderson (1896 - 1977). It was possibly one of Sanderson's favourite pieces as there are photographs showing him wearing this banyan along with an 18th century wig.

Description: Collarless sleeved waistcoat with twenty one buttons down front. Fourteen buttonholes and seven false buttonholes correspond. Three buttons below arch-shaped pocket flap. Deep turned back cuff with three buttons and buttonholes. Metal thread embroidered s
WebDescription: The style of this garment is quite different to the idea of a waistcoat that we have today.  It has long sleeves which have large turned back cuffs decorated with three buttons and buttonholes.  It is made from a vividly patterned silk brocade with swirling design of flowers and foliage in shades of pink and green along with silver thread.  A coat would have been worn over the top of the waistcoat, so only the patterned silk body and cuffs would actually be visible when worn. This type of brocade was very expensive, so it was more economical to use it only where it would be seen. During the early eighteenth century it was very fashionable for your coat cuffs to match your waistcoat.

Description: Black silk tunic dress embroidered in silver, gold, pink and green glass beads and gold wire. The design of the embroidery is a lattice with mythical birds, butterflies, blossoms and bullrushes in the manner of a Japanese screen, the greatest massing of t
WebDescription:
This dress is made from black silk fabric and is a simple sleeveless tunic, with a V shaped neckline.  It is decorated with a beaded Japanese style design of white cranes, standing in the gold coloured reeds which run along the hem, as well as in flight.  A bold pattern of silver branches of pale pink flowering cherry blossom has been added on the skirt, extending into a background pattern of a silver lattice with silver butterflies flying amongst it and up towards the neckline.

From the 1910s onwards there were crazes for new kinds of upbeat dance music like the tango and the Charleston.  The 1920s came to be known as the "roaring twenties" or the "jazz age".  Garments with materials like sequins and beadwork, which could be shown to their full effect whilst moving and dancing, became very popular.

Description: Black silk tunic dress embroidered in silver, gold, pink and green glass beads and gold wire. The design of the embroidery is a lattice with mythical birds, butterflies, blossoms and bullrushes in the manner of a Japanese screen, the greatest massing of t
WebDescription: The "roaring twenties" saw crazes or new kinds of upbeat dance music like the tango and the Charleston.   Garments with materials like sequins and beadwork, which could be shown to their full effect whilst moving and dancing, were highly fashionable. This simple sleeveless silk dress is decorated all over with a beaded design of flowers with cranes and it is inspired by Japanese embroidery.

Description: A full length dress in purple rayon crepe with satin collar, waistband/belt and cuffs. The dress has long sleeves with turn back cuffs and the shoulders are padded. The bodice is gathered under the bust into deep waistband with 4 buttons, and continues ar
WebDescription:
One of the most important designers of the 1960s and 1970s was Ossie Clark. Having grown up in the north of England Ossie Clark headed to London to train at the Royal College of Art where along with his wife and creative partner textile designer wife, Celia Birtwell, became a part a talented groups of young designers and artists. 
The genius of Ossie Clark?s dresses was often in the cut. He chose to reject the structured mini dress of the mid-1960s. Instead he took influence from the romantic silhouette of the 1930s and 1940s.  He wanted everybody to feel special and glamorous in his clothes. Long dresses such as this one were cut with plunging necklines and he made much use of the bias cut to create a silhouette that flowed over the female figure. 
Ossie Clark?s collections were first sold in the London boutique ?Quorum?. Later he worked with the manufacturer Radley to produce his designs in larger quantities and make them more accessible to a wider market.

Description:
This outfit was designed by Vivienne Westwood for Autumn/Winter 1982 to 1983 for her third collection of clothing to be exhibited on the catwalk, entitled "Buffalo".  There is a matching pair of shoes, long knitted stockings and a brown felt hat.

The u
WebDescription: This outfit was designed for Vivienne Westwood's Autumn/Winter 1982 to 1983 collection entitled ?Buffalo". Sometimes also known as "Nostalgia Mud" this was the British designer?s third catwalk collection. The design of the collection and this outfit was heavily influenced by traditional Peruvian folk dress. The layered skirt has printed folk art designs and the outfit uses distressed looking fabrics. However Vivienne Westwood is well known for reinterpreting historical dress and giving it a contemporary edge. A satin 1950s inspired conical bra is worn over the top of the outfit. This look plays with the idea of wearing underwear as outerwear.

Description: Shoes to go with the outfit designed for the Autumn/Winter 1982 to 1983 season.  It comes from Vivienne Westwood?s third collection of clothing to be exhibited on the catwalk, entitled "Buffalo".  The same collection is also sometimes known as "Nostalgia
WebDescription:
This outfit was designed for the Autumn/Winter 1982 to 1983 season.  It comes from Vivienne Westwood?s third collection of clothing to be exhibited on the catwalk, entitled "Buffalo".  The same collection is also sometimes known as "Nostalgia of Mud".  The outfit combines influences based on ethnic and primitive dress with distressed fabrics and folk art patterns.  There is a matching pair of shoes and a brown felt hat.

The underskirt is of layered tattered brown felt.  It supports a full skirt in a shade of orange, with the hem printed with a folk art pattern in red.  Floral elements of this design are picked out with yellow embroidery to give an almost brocaded effect.  A distressed jumper is knitted with the same pattern in shades of pink and brown.  It is hooded and has exaggerated long sleeves.  

Over the top a brown satin bra with suede trim is worn.  The bra has a conical shape which echoes underwear styles of the 1950s.  Vivienne Westwood is well known for her reinterpretation of historic fashions in contemporary dress.  She was one of the originators of the idea of underwear as outerwear during the 1980s.

Bust: 84 cm (33 1/16 in.)
Waist: 69 cm (27 3/16 in.)
Description: Strapless dress worn with a sleeves jacket and both made of silver grey synthetic fabric. The jacket fastens at the back with a zip. The dress has a fitted and boned bodice and the fitted waist is emphasised with a bow trim. The skirt is lined with to sup
WebDescription: This neat outfit is made from a strapless dress with a tulip shaped skirt worn beneath a sleeveless jacket.  The jacket fastens at the back and flares outwards slightly at the bottom.  This provides a pleasant contrast with the fitted waist of the dress, which is emphasised by a bow tied at the front.  The front of the skirt is further embellished with two large flat self covered buttons on each side.

Bust: 84 cm (33 1/16 in.)

Description: Strapless dress worn with a sleeves jacket and both made of silver grey synthetic fabric. The jacket fastens at the back with a zip. The dress has a fitted and boned bodice and the fitted waist is emphasised with a bow trim. The skirt is lined with to sup
WebDescription:
This neat little outfit was bought from Marshall and Snelgrove, which was a department store in Leeds. Opening, in 1870, the shop stood on the corner of Bond Street and Park Row, where a Lloyds bank stands today.  Marshall and Snelgrove was the Harvey Nichols of its day and was best known for selling upmarket fashions. 
 
The Leeds shop was one of many Marshall and Snelgrove stores across the country. The history of the firm can be traced back to 1837 and its first shop was situated on Vere Street, just off the highly fashionable Oxford Street, in London. One of the original founding partners of the firm was aYorkshire mann,named Mrr James Marshall. The firm had great success and opened up many branches outside of London, providing good quality goods for the rising rich Victorian middle classes.

In the late 1950s when this dress was purchased, Marshall and Snelgrove had merged with Debenham Freebody, another large firm. They continued to sell high end goods, however shopping trends had started to change and by the 1960s luxury stores such as Marshall and Snelgrove went into decline.  The firm had to close many of its stores including the Leeds shop, in 1973.

Description: black cotton coutil corset with pink braid trim, "The Celebrated  W.F. Corset, W.F. Launce - Registered". Boned (in metal) throughout with a split busk centre front and metal eyelets for lacing centre back. White lining and pink embroidery at top and bott
WebDescription: The corset is made of black satin and is stiffened with steel boning.  The centre front has a steel busk with a stud and eye fastening.  This was a nineteenth century innovation to enable the corset to be put on more easily, without having to undo all of the lacing at the back.  The back of this corset is laced.  Decorative pale pink top stitching has been applied to the ends of some of the steel "bones" of this corset.  The top edge is trimmed with a strip of pink scalloped ribbon.

Description: This small bag is square in shape, with an opening along one edge which is secured by a drawstring.  It is entirely made using needlepoint techniques.  The side of the bag is patterned with a design of rectangular shapes which interlock diagonally.  The d
WebDescription:
This small bag is square in shape, with an opening along one edge which is secured by a drawstring.  It is entirely made using needlepoint techniques.  The side of the bag is patterned with a design of rectangular shapes which interlock diagonally.  The drawstring is of braided threads, and terminates at each end with a tassel.  The bottom of the bag is decorated with three tassels of the same construction.  

The tassels are made from clusters of three dimensional acorn shapes and oak leaves.  The cups of the acorns are of silver coloured metallic threads, with the ends made from either pink or blue silk threads.  They have been made by wrapping the threads around a wooden core.  The leaves use needlepoint techniques and are constructed from green threads.

WebDescription:
This small bag is square in shape, with an opening along one edge which is secured by a drawstring.  It is entirely made using needlepoint techniques.  The side of the bag is patterned with a design of rectangular shapes which interlock diagonally.  The drawstring is of braided threads, and terminates at each end with a tassel.  The bottom of the bag is decorated with three tassels of the same construction.  

The tassels are made from clusters of three dimensional acorn shapes and oak leaves.  The cups of the acorns are of silver coloured metallic threads, with the ends made from either pink or blue silk threads.  They have been made by wrapping the threads around a wooden core.  The leaves use needlepoint techniques and are constructed from green threads.

Description: Short silk jacket with a screen printed design all over of a copy of a 1700s Toile de Nantes, copperplate print design called 'Le mouton chri' (see LEEAG.2005.0315). The jacket has pointed puffed sleeves and flared cuffs.  It has a large collar covered i
WebDescription:
Vivienne Westwood is known for her insubordinate and wicked approach to fashion.  With its puffed sleeves and pretty "cottage style" fabric this jacket seems a little too traditional. However the inside of the jacket is lined with diamante studs, which press against bare skin in a sensual manner.  A closer look at the fabric also shows a print telling a story.  The sheperdess, from the story, seems to have lost her top, much to the delight of her companion.  So the jacket is actually rather subversive, and very punk.
The fabric used is a screen printed copy of a famous design for a 1700s printed cotton called "Le Mouton Cheri".  Such designs were considered slightly naughty and really only suitable for bedrooms. An original print of the design can be found in the Leeds Museums and Galleries Ginsburg collection of textiles. 
This jacket was purchased in June 2008 as part of Leeds Museums and Galleries policy of collecting British couture. It comes from the collection of Jerry Hall.  Westwood's use of antique fabric designs confirms one of the reasons why museums collect textiles: to inspire designers, artists and the general public.

Description: Blue striped silk taffeta dress with a separate bodice and skirt. The bodice has an attached long peplum or overskirt. It fastens centre front with buttons and is trimmed around the bust, cuffs and bottom of the peplum with blue fringing. There is a blue
WebDescription: The overskirt attached to the bodice of this dress is known as a ?polonaise?. This style makes a direct historical reference to fashions worn by women, a hundred years earlier in the 1770s. The shape of the skirt would be supported by a crinoline frame underskirt which would be shaped to help create the fullness at the back. The overskirt of the bodice helps to further enhances this look which in emphasises how tiny the corset waist of the wearer is.

Dimensions:
Bust: 99 cm (39 in.)
Waist: 84 cm (33 1/16 in.)
Description: Dress with a bodice and skirt of a cut velvet with a light blue silk background and olive green velvet design in olive green of undulating flowers and seed heads. The bodice opens centre front, fastening with facetted crystal glass buttons and green velve
WebDescription:
Mary Holden Illingworth (1838 - 1908) wore this dress to her daughters? wedding, in 1881. Mary came from a wealthy Yorkshire mill owning family. Her father, Isaac Holden, was a self made man originally from Glasgow. After educating himself, Isaac made his way to Yorkshire where set about making his fortune in the weaving industry. He went on to have mills in both Bradford and Paris. Having come from such a humble background Isaac Holden wanted the best of everything for his children.
 
Mary?s great interest was fashion, which is clear from this dress. It was designed by Charles Frederick Worth, an English fashion designer, regarded as the father of couture. Based in Paris his clients included Royalty and many other women of great wealth and influence. 
 
Thidress wasas not Mary?s first Worth dress and she later recounted how ?fittings were of dubious delight, as Monsieur Worth was of the habit of taking a cup of warm fresh blood straight from the local abattoir at 11am.?

Description: Tailored couture suit of a jacket and skirt of grey wool, with velvet collar, designed by Hattie Carnegie. The jacket has a fitted waist with padding in the hips, to make it flare out over the full skirt, giving the suit a typical 'New Look' style.
WebDescription: An American socialite called Anne Moen Bullitt owned this couture outfit by the New York based fashion designer Hattie Carnegie. The curvaceous hourglass shape with the nipped in waist which is accentuated by padding in the hips of the jacket, and a full skirt is very much associated with the post World War Two 'New Look' style. First coined by the fashion press as description of Christian Dior's first collection in 1947, the New Look style was extremely popular and revolutionised fashion.

Description: travelling chemical set, with hinged lid and three drawers in side, bone plaque "ACCUM / CHEMIST / OLD COMPTON STREET SOHO / LONDON", associated with Joseph Dawson, c1800-1813 - some items made and used by Dr Joseph Priestley (according to register)
WebDescription: This travelling chemical set, with hinged lid and three drawers in side has a bone plaque reading "ACCUM  CHEMIST  OLD COMPTON STREET SOHO LONDON".  It is associated with with the Rev. Joseph Dawson, who was a friend of Joseph Priestly, and some items in the set are supposed to have been made and used by Dr Joseph Priestley, according to the records of the Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society.  The case itself probably dates from 1804 (which is the year that Priestley died).

Dimensions:
object length: 1100mm
object width: 340mm
object height: 230mm
Description: Skin of a juvenile Wandering Albatross.
WebDescription: Museums keep specimens for many reasons - only one of them is display. This Wandering Albatross is preserved as a 'study skin'. At Leeds Museums and Galleries we have many bird and mammal study skins: animals that are not posed and do not have glass eyes. These are used for scientific research and other study.

Medium/Materials: skull; bone; mandible; jaw; cranium; skeleton; teeth
Description: The upper and lower jaw of a Javan Rhinoceros. It is a sub-adult (partially erupted last molars). The upper maxilla and one molar are missing. Teeth contain vegetable matter.
WebDescription: Leeds Museums and Galleries has been collecting objects for more than two centuries. This means that some of the specimens we have that would have been commonplace in the 19th century are now extremely rare. This Javan rhinoceros skull is one of them. Javan rhinos are probably the most endangered mammal in the world with only a handful left alive.

Description: The bones of several Dodos.
WebDescription: In 1865 Harry Higginson, a railway engineer from Thormanby, near York, spotted bones protruding from an embankment in Mauritius. They were identified as Dodo bones - a bird that became extinct between 1650 and 1700. He sent boxes of them back to York, Leeds and Liverpool museums. Harry later went on to a successful career in New Zealand where, in the cathedral in Wellington, he and the Dodo are commemorated in stained glass.

of stand: 163  1030  1326mm
Description: The complete skeleton of a Heavy-footed Moa. Although most of the bones appear to be from one individual, some are definitely not (see the feet for example) i.e. this is a composite of more than one Heavy-footed Moa.
WebDescription: This fabulous skeleton came into the collections in 1868. At the time only one other Heavy-footed Moa was to be found in the UK (at the NHM in London). It is probably made up of more than one bird - its feet are different sizes. At the time, it cost the Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society a lot of money but this kind of collecting reflects Leeds' importance as a burgeoning scientific city.

Dimensions:
object length: 240mm
object width: 130mm
object height: 110mm
Description: The skull of a Thylacine or Tasmanian wolf. The upper and lower jaws are wired together with a straight piece of metal and part of the left malar and postorbital process are missing. The two bones of the lower jaw are wired together.
WebDescription: Leeds Museums and Galleries is lucky to have a large collection of Tasmanian Wolf material: five skulls and one full mount. The museum records show that at one time there were eighteen wolves in Leeds, sadly these have been lost - probably during the war.

Description:
The cranium of a European Beaver.
One broken incisor and one molar present.
WebDescription: European Beavers have been extinct in the UK for a few hundred years and so it is exciting to have this one in the collection. It was found buried in Wawne, East Yorkshire. Specimens like this one help scientists work out what used to roam the British Isles and may even help to choose which animals to reintroduce.

Description: Mount of an adult male Buff-throated Sunbird.
WebDescription: This specimen makes up part of Leeds Museums and Galleries' bird collection. The collection has over 5,000 bird specimens comprising both study skins and mounted specimens.

Description: A Precious Wentletrap shell.
WebDescription: Leeds Museums and Galleries' mollusc collection is one of the best in the country. We have over 200,000 data-rich shells from around the world with many type specimens and rarities. This Precious Wentletrap is part of the C. H. Moore collection. 'Wenteltrap' is from the Dutch for spiral staircase.

Description: The whole empty egg of an Elephant Bird. It has a small, irregularly shaped hole in the side.
WebDescription: This is the complete egg of an Elephant Bird. It is subfossilised but has nothing inside (there is a small hole in one side...). Whole eggs are rare and Leeds Museums and Galleries is lucky to have a complete one. Elephant Birds are extinct, lived on the island of Madagascar and were related to Emus and Ostriches.

Display Name: Mr Sylvanus Charles Thorpe Hanley B.A., F.L.S.
Alpha Sort: Hanley, Sylvanus Charles Thorpe B.A., F.L.S. Mr
Description: Seven Neritina virginea shells.
WebDescription: These shells form part of Leeds's outstanding mollusc collections. Leeds has one of the most important shell collections in the country including many type, figured and cited specimens.

Description: Seven adults. Card cut into two pieces, other half being 1972.2.2.
WebDescription: Found locally and only on Great Reedmace (Bullrush), this inconspicuous bug can be abundant when a population is discovered.

Description: The dried lenses of the Humboldt Squid. Used in a human mummy in Peru.
WebDescription: These are the eye lenses from a type of squid. They were probably taken from one that had washed up on a beach in South America. Peruvians used these lenses to replace the eyes of human mummies. They give the corpse a more life-like appearance. The mummies are placed in a sitting position on salt beds and occur in their thousands.

Description: The bones of several Great Auk (the full collection is catalogued in subnumbers of this record).
WebDescription: Great Auks are large extinct seabirds that lived across the northern Atlantic. Leeds Museums and Galleries is lucky to have a collection of Great Auk bones. Along with a few stuffed specimens, this is all that remains of these beautfiul birds.

Description: An adult male Rajah Brooke's Birdwing butterfly.
WebDescription: This specimen was one of several that were seized by HM Customs in 1981. A dealer was attempting to bring these endangered animals into Britain to sell. If there wasn't a market for it then these rare butterflies wouldn't be killed for display. This Rajah Brooke's birdwing butterfly comes from south east Asia. It was named by Alfred Russel Wallace who, with Charles Darwin, proposed the theory of evolution in 1858.

Dimensions:
object height: 1200mm
object depth: 500mm
object width: 280mm
Description: A Palm Cockatoo mounted walking up a stick with crest erect.
WebDescription: This large Australian cockatoo was seized in a raid on a farm in North Yorkshire. The owner had been smuggling rare birds into the UK illegally and was sent to jail. The Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) makes it illegal to trade in these animals. We have 45 other parrots in the collections that were seized from the same farm.

Description: Almost complete logboat carved out of the trunk of a single ash tree.  Its ends are braced with cross-pieces to prevent splitting.  Long triangular-sectioned timbers are pegged down each side to act as spray deflectors, rubbing strakes and stabilizers at
WebDescription:
On May 25th 1863 Mr. Joseph Taylor came across a dug-out canoe while carrying out drainage works on the site of the former Giggleswick Tarn. He thought it to be ?evidently of Celtic or British workmanship?. The landowner, Mr. William Hartley, promptly donated the boat to Leeds Museum where it was put on display.

On the evening of 16th March 1941 Leeds Museum received a direct hit in one of the wartime bombing raids, devastating parts of the collection. The logboat was shattered into forty-five pieces. Each piece was carefully sifted from the debris, wrapped in sheets of the News Chronicle, and stored in a crate.
 
It wasn?t until 1974 that the fragments were re-examined with a view to reconstructing the vessel. The pieces were sent down to the National Maritime Museum at Greenwich to be researched, conserved and re-assembled.

As a result of the research done at Greenwich, we now know that the boat was made from a single ash tree and dates to around 1335 AD. It was designed to carry one person sitting on the D-shaped board, from which the boat could be propelled with a paddle. There was also some room for carrying cargo. It is likely that the boat was used to fish from the tarn.

The logboat was returned to Leeds Museums in 1988.

Dimensions:
object length: 99mm
object width (cutting edge): 50mm
object thickness: 20mm
object weight: 172.3gm
Description: Highly polished jadeite stone axe head.  Dark green mottled with black, rounded butt and faceted sides.
WebDescription:
This is a fine example of a Neolithic jadeite axe head. Around 130 examples of these axe heads are known from Britain and Ireland.  We have two in the Leeds collection, although we don't know where they were found.
The Neolithic quarries used to make these axe heads were in high-altitude locations in the Italian Alps at Monte Viso and Monte Beigua.  Associated charcoal samples indicate that the quarries may have been in use from as early as 5200 BC, on a seasonal basis.  
Jade axe heads may have arrived in the UK from France in packages of Neolithic goods associated with the farming lifestyle. They seem to have been so special that occasionally they were broken and shared around. Some axe heads would have already been old when they arrived here.

Description: Head of bearded Bacchus / Dionysus (The god of wine), wearing a vine-wreath with grapes and a plain fillet across the brow.  The tip of nose and one grape of wreath missing. Back of specimen very smooth and shiny but with regular pecking marks.
WebDescription:
A carved marble head of Bacchus (or Dionysus), discovered during exavations at the Roman site of Lanuvium.
Bacchus was the god of wine and fertility, and patron of agriculture and the theatre.  He was believed to bring an end to care and worry, but he had a dual nature and could bring both joy and rage.

Description: Antefix in the form of a large female head within an arched frame (pierced). Remains of zig zag lines on the stephane (headdress). Necklace, pendant and wheel-like earrings. Top hem of the woman's garment represented by four lozenges in a rectangular comp
WebDescription:
Part of an antefix depicting a woman's face, probably from the temple of Juno Sospita (an early form of the goddess Juno) in  Lanuvium, near Rome.  She wears a necklace, pendant and wheel-like earrings.

Terracotta ornaments like this were fixed at the edges of the temple roof to mask the ends of the wooden beams.  It would have originally been brightly coloured and some of the red paint still survives.

Description: Circular silver-gilt hook, pinked backplate and raised dome covered with filigree circles and knops.  On the back there are indications of the shape and location of the original hook, now missing, which suggests the object was a cap hook.
WebDescription:
A small silver-gilt cap hook dating to the 16th century.  This object was found by a metal detectorist in the Thorner area of Leeds, West Yorkshire, in 2008.
Cap hooks and other hat ornaments were fashionable for men to wear in their caps from the late 15th century. The size and style of these cap hooks changed over time, and it was common to wear several at once.  This example is purely decorative, but others could be worn for religious or symbolic reasons.

Description: A mount which consists of a circular frame decorated with five-petalled flowers placed at equidistance around its circumference. In the centre is a sinuous three-lobed foliate form, on the reverse of which are the remains of a stud.
WebDescription:
A pretty Medieval silver mount dating to the late 14th to 15th centuries.  It was found by a metal detectorist in the Thorner area of Leeds, West Yorkshire, in 2008.
Mounts were decorative fittings which could be pinned to clothing or accessories.  They were also used to decorate furniture, horse equipment, book covers, and a variety of other objects.

WebDescription: This oil painting shows Dr Hook (the vicar of Leeds) appealing to the textile  merchants in Leeds Coloured Cloth Hall for funds to rebuild Leeds Parish Church.  The church was rebuilt in 1838.  The painting is a reconstruction of the historic event, probably painted in the 1880s.

WebDescription: Wooden truncheon with ribbed handle and leather carrying strap, brass end marked "V.R. 346".  This is said to have  belonged to John Thompson of Hunslet, who was a special  constable during the Chartists Riots in 1848.

WebDescription: Tommy Atkins character glove puppet, with stuffed head, painted features; and black button eyes. He wears a red and blue felt uniform and a pillbox hat with 'Tommy  Atkins' on it.

WebDescription: This is a memorial plaque, R.I.P. Private Thomas Atkins, 20th  Battalion Yorks regiment who was killed in action on 11th April 1916.  . The carving has been made in chalk and was made in trenches 1916-18 by  Private N. Nelson.

Description: commemorative knife in box, presented to the city  of Leeds by the 'Trustees of Wades Charity July  1920, Alderman. J. R. Ford - Middleton Park', silver
WebDescription:
This silver commemorative knife was presented to the City of Leeds by the Trustees of  Wades Charity, July 1920, Alderman. J. R. Ford - Middleton Park.  

The charity was founded in 1530 by the will of Thomas Wade, initially for the repair of local roads. From 1890 the funds were used for the creation of public open spaces.
Middleton Park belongs to Wade's Charity and is leased to Leeds City Council on a 999 year lease.

WebDescription: pastry roller or rolling pin with various moulds, motifs of birds, flowers, fruit & "TEA VR"; for decorating butter or pastry

WebDescription: This late Victorian doll's pram of burgundy coloured leatherette and a cream upholstered lining is a scaled down version of a real pram model.  Leeds had several firms making prams in the late 19th century, including Sillers and Simpson & Fawcett.

Description: Kirkstall Girls' Friendly Society banner.  Silk embroidery on brocade background
WebDescription:
This banner for the Kirkstall Girls' Friendly Society is decorated with silk embroidery on a brocade background.  

The Girl's Friendly Society was a church youth organisation aimed at working class girls and this branch was attached to St Stephen's Church, Kirkstall, Leeds.

WebDescription: The Museums and Gallery service has just this one tinplate dolls house which is colour printed and has 3 sections.  The base includes a stable block, the first storey has arched  windows on all sides and the  green roof has four dormer windows   and two chimneys slot onto the top.  Access at the back reveals a balustrade across the bottom, a small staircase with handrails and the wall mounted hay troughs.

WebDescription: clear pressed glass plate with fluted edge, "TO COMMEMORATE THE 60TH YEAR  OF QUEEN VICTORIA'S GLORIOUS REIGN"

Description: Large red Thornes toffee tin with sloping hinged  lid and clasp. "Henry Thorne and Co Ltd" written  on it.
WebDescription:
Thorne's Extra Super Creme Toffee'. 

Henry Thorne & Co. Ltd. were a famous cocoa and toffee maker based on Lady Lane, Leeds. The company was established in 1837 and incorporated 1889. The factory was closed in 1972.

From humble beginnings in a mustard and chicory shop in the 1830s, Henry Thorne?s business grew to become a leading name in confectionery. With similar Quaker roots to Cadbury, Terry and Fry. By the 1960s the Thorne business was producing over two million pieces of confectionery a day until its closure in the 1970s.

Description: white glazed earthenware jug, green transfer  printed picture of "J. HUSTWICK, FAMILY GROCER"  premises at EUNICE PLACE and motto "WITH  COMPLIMENTS XMAS 1912"; printed on base  "SWINNERTONS / HANLEY".  In 1912 J Hustwick of Eunice Street, off Jack Lane i
WebDescription: white glazed earthenware jug, green transfer  printed picture of "J. HUSTWICK, FAMILY GROCER"  premises at EUNICE PLACE and motto "WITH  COMPLIMENTS XMAS 1912"; printed on base  "SWINNERTONS / HANLEY".  In 1912 J Hustwick of Eunice Street, off Jack Lane in Hunslet, presented his customers with Christmas presents in the form of these green transfer printed jugs.  They show in some detail, including advertisments for ales by Bass, Bates, Coombes and Sam Smiths, in addition to Brook Bond's teas and Sunlight soap.

Description: glazed stoneware vase, bulbous, with fawn coloured  cameos on opposite sides; portrait of H. Gladstone  and Yorkshire rose; white lettering in beaded  white border, "LEEDS ELECTION / 1880 / HERBT.  GLADSTONE / RETURNED UNOPPOSED"  between cameos, blue and
WebDescription:
This stoneware vase, bulbous is decorated with a portrait of H. Gladstone and the Yorkshire rose. The inscription reads "LEEDS ELECTION  1880  HERBT.  GLADSTONE  RETURNED UNOPPOSED".  It was made by Doulton of Lambeth to celebrate the Liberal victors in the 1880 general election.

Herbert John Gladstone was the youngest son of W.E. Gladstone. He was Liberal MP for Leeds from 1880 to 1910 and served as Home Secretary from 1905-1910.

Description: DOLL'S HOUSE KIT, designed by Maureen Roffey  A.R.C.A., selected for the Design Centre, made in  England, Robor Ltd., Lancing, Sussex  components of a press out cardboard doll's house  with furniture
WebDescription: Leeds Museum and Galleries have five cardboard dolls house kits of which this is believed to be the latest dated 1969.  It was designed by Maureen Roffey A.R.C.A. a published author and illustrator of children?s books.  The dolls house was made at Robor Ltd in Lancing, Sussex.  The kit comprises of printed cardboard components for the house and furniture as well as characters that children could imagine living in the house.  The house appears to have been designed in order that it should be assembled with glue.

It's Quite Impossible - Read's crinoline sketch no  4, Jan 27, 1859.

This satirical cartoon mocks the impractility of the fashion for wide crinoline skirts.  In this case the lady is unable to negociate a kissing gate.

WebDescription:
Temperance banner, suspended on wooden pole and  cords, with paper lettering on textile with the motto: "Strong Drink is Raging".

The Temperance movement (campaigning against the consumption of alcohol) was very strong in Leeds.  The Leeds Temperance Society started in the 1830s and the Band of Hope, an organisation aimed at young people, was founded in Leeds in 1847.

Description: Knur and spell spring board
WebDescription:
This iron contraption is a spring board used in the traditional game of Knur and Spell.  The iron spikes would be hammered into soft ground.  The flexible steel bar clips under the wooden block and has a socket to hold the knur (ball).  The player would then hit the block with the spell (bat) to release the knur into the air and then try and hit it as far as possible.

Knur and spell was sometimes referred to as "poor man's golf" and was played on Hunslet Moor, Leeds,  throughout the 19th century.

Description: model of Theatre Royal, Leeds, made by Harold  Brown; in two sections; with electric wiring for lighting; also loose pieces of scenery
WebDescription:
This model of the Theatre Royal, Leeds, was made by Harold Brown in 1960.

The Theatre Royal had been built in 1876 on the site of the Royal Casino, Royal Alhambra and Royal Ampitheatres in King Charles Croft, Leeds. Francis Laidler came to the theatre in 1909 and was responsible for the successful pantomimes. The theatre was closed on March 30th 1957 and the building was demolished in May 1957 to make way for Schofields department store.

WebDescription: This white cotton pillow case has a lace edging.  It is embroidered in red thread with the initials "B L".  It was made by the mother of the donor who was a Jewish immigrant to Leeds from Russia.

WebDescription: This Torah mantle came originally from the United Hebrew Congregation in Leeds.  It is designed to cover the Torah scrolls in the synagogue.  It is made from blue velvet.  On the front there is an appliqud crown of white silk, embroidered with gold coloured metallic threads.  Below the shape of the Jewish tablets of the law is appliqud, also in white silk.  This is flanked by two lions rampant.  At the bottom a vase with flowers is embroidered using gold coloured metallic threads.  Underneath this the letters "Donated by Nicol in memory of Grandma Lilah Levine" are embroidered.

Title Sort: Portrait of Pamela Hopper, Queen of Leeds Children's Day
Description: painting, oil on canvas, portrait of Pamela Hopper  as Queen of Leeds Children's Day, 1947, by Ina  Kitson Clark
WebDescription:
This portrait shows Pamela Hopper as Queen of Leeds Children's Day in 1947 and was painted in oils by Ina  Kitson Clark.  The painting was  exhibited at the Leeds Fine Art Club exhibition at  the City Art Gallery in Nov. 1948.

Leeds Children's Day was an annual event which was first held in 1920 and led to formation of Leeds Elementary Schools Sports Association and the camp at Ben Rhydding.  The 1921 event was abandoned due to stormy weather and the following year there was a week's delay due to rain before the first Queen Elsie Oldfield was crowned on July 15th.  The Children's Day at Roundhay Park in 1923 raised 2000 for the camp but by 1962 interest was dwindling.  The last Queen was crowned by Ronnie Hilton in 1963.  The events in 1964 were combined with Leeds Printer's Gala and briefly revived again in 1968.

Description: circular tin and lid, Zam-Buk ointment, man. by C.E. Fulford Ltd., Leeds 2
WebDescription:
This is a tin of ointment sold under the name "Zam-Buck".  It started to appear on British chemist shelves in 1909 and it remained popular throughout the first half of the twentieth century. It was recognised as a skin treatment that could succesfully kill germs. It was also used for sprains, muscle soreness, burns, and many other skin ailments. Apparently made from vegetable ingredients and ingredients listed were : Petrolatum, colophonium, eucalyptus globulus (eucalyptus oil), camphor (camphor oil), cera alba (beeswax), thymus vulgaris (thyme oil). 
Although no longer made by the original company, the trademark for Zam-Buk has been kept alive and is now being manufactured by Rose and Co. England and can be found to order online.
