WebDescription: Doll's pram dating from 1918 with a lightweight cane body with hood and  removable part to  base which turns it into a pushchair.

Medium/Materials: graphite, pen, ink and watercolor on laid paper
Description: Stone archway over a road lined by trees, arch is part of a building to the right. Female figure stood in doorway of the building holding a baby.
WebDescription:
This drawing clearly shows the influence of Abbott's teacher Francis Towne (c. 1739 - 1816); indeed when this drawing was originally purchased for Leeds Art Gallery's collection in 1924 is was attributed to Francis Towne. It was only later, when the inscription on the verso was revealed, that White's authorship was re-established. Although Towne is known to have had a number of pupils, few seem to have followed his work as much as White. 
Buckfast Abbey, at Buckfastleigh on the river Dart, was founded in the tenth century, but by White's time the building had long since fallen into ruins and the remains were relatively modest. White frequently extended his sheets of drawing paper with additional pieces, as found in this example.

Medium/Materials: pencil and watercolour with scratching out (on wove paper)
Description: landscape: woodland scene (right to centre) of a large (oak) tree with twisted trunk in serpentine form. To the left is a female figure in a bonnet crossing a wooden bridge; behind another group of thin-trunked trees, and beyond and in the background, tre
WebDescription: Constable visited Helmingham, the seat of the Earl of Dysart, in July 1800, producing sketches which later formed the basis of a number of oil paintings. There is a smaller sketch which extends the composition to include the whole bridge, and the tree to the left of the watercolour. Constable wrote from Helmingham Park, 'There are abundance of trees of all sorts; though the place upon the whole affords good objects rather than the fine scenery'.

Medium/Materials: graphite and watercolor on wove paper
Description: Wooded landscape, to the far distance is Barnard Castle. In the immediate foreground are trees within a steep ravine.
WebDescription:
This is one of the remarkable 'Greta series' of watercolours produced by Cotman while staying with the Morritt family at Rokeby Park, near Barnard Castle in 1805. It was exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1806 and is one of a few watercolours from this period which found a buyer. It has been suggested that the innovative execution of the subjects with daring disregard for finish, may have been the reason for Cotman's failure to gain membership of the Water-Colour Society in 1806.
A few years later the poet Sir Walter Scott also stayed with the Morritt family at Rokeby Park and was equally impressed with the fine view on the river Tees looking towards Barnard Castle. He wrote in his poem Rokeby: 

'The Sultry summer day is done,
The western hills have hid the sun, 
But mountain peak and village spire
Retain reflection of his fire.
Old Barnard's towers are purple still,
To those that gaze from Towler Hill'.

Medium/Materials: graphite and watercolor on wove paper
Description:
View across a river in which four cows are standing, beside them is a flight of stairs with a figure at the top, the stairs are attached to the side of a double arched bridge. Hills in the distance.
Subject: landscape; cows; bridge
WebDescription:
This drawing was originally called 'Brecon Bridge', but stylistically it belongs to those from the period of Cotman's visit to Yorkshire which are characterised by the skilled laying of washes in almost abstract design, and an overriding stillness - this in contrast to his earlier Girtinesque compositions, in which powerful compositional curves sweep the eye from one element to the next. Cotman had succeeded Girtin as the leader of the Sketching Society on the latter's death in 1802. The compositions, rapidly executed in an evening in monochrome and without the aid of sketches, were drawn from memory. This encouraged the intervention of the artist?s imagination in the portrayal of landscape. 
See British Museum: 1949,1012.1, for pencil drawing of the same subject.

Medium/Materials: pen, ink and watercolor on laid paper
Description: Drawing of man on horseback, two men on either side walk on foot caring long poles, three hounds run alongside group chasing a Hare. In the distance - a country house and surrounding grounds.
WebDescription:
This drawing is typical of Barlow's work as an illustrator. The action takes place in the foreground with a strong diagonal composition countered by a static landscape backdrop. The main figures are highly finished and heavily outlined. 
The drawing was used as an illustration to Richard Blome's 'The Gentleman's Recreation' published in two parts in 1686. The second part contained thirty-eight full page illustrations and six in an oval format.  The contours of the figures and dogs have been scored with a stylus for transfer on to an etching plate. 
Barlow made sporting scenes his speciality and returned to this particular theme a number of times. There are drawings of the same subject in the British Museum, The Mellon Collection, the Ashmolean Museum, Christ Church, Oxford and Birmingham Art Gallery. 
In 'The Several Ways of Hunting, Hawking and Fishing according to the English Manner', published in 1671, Barlow's drawing, etched by Hollar, is accompanied by the verse:
The timorous Hare, when started from her seat,
by bloody hounds, to save her life soe sweet,
with several shifts, much terrour and great payne,
Yet dyes she by their mouths, all proves but vayne.

Description: Watercolour, pen and pencil drawing of a man standing with arms outstretched with four people kneeling at his feet and a fire burning behind him.
WebDescription:
This watercolour illustrating Job 42:8 is related to plate 20 (which takes verse 13-15 as its theme) in Blake's 'IIllustrations of the Book of Job' published in 1825. 
The subject of the Old Testament prophet, Job, had interested Blake since 1786 when he produced the etching 'The Complaint of Job'. In about 1805 he produced a series of studies from the book of Job for his patron Thomas Butts, the outlines of these were later traced by John Linnell, and Blake produced a second set from the tracings in 1821. It is thought that Butt's original set of illustrations did not include one from the last chapter and this was added later possibly after Linnell's version. The Leeds watercolour may be either a preliminary sketch for the Linnell drawing, or an intermediate study between the Linnell and Butt's version. The cruciform pose of Job reflects Blake's belief in the parallels between Job and Christ. 
This watercolour is a typical example of the freedom of line and wash associated with Blake's style.

Medium/Materials: pen, ink and watercolour on laid paper
Description: A lively scene showing several figures stood watching a donkey that has fallen in the street seconds before it is whipped by a male figure.
WebDescription: In the tradition of Hogarth, Collet cast his critical eye over the urban mles of London streets, although his scenes lack Hogarth's biting satire. Collet specialised in street affrays; here a donkey stumbles on the cobbles and is beaten by its master, while the ladies to the right cover their eyes in refined horror at the scene. The image includes an example of the 'Italians who came to sell plaster statuettes which they balanced on their heads', referred to by the artist Thomas Jones in his Rhyming Memories. The presentation of figures in the form of a tableau with no reference to the setting, and the sparing use of colour over shading in Indian ink wash, suggest that this drawing was originally conceived as the basis for an engraving.

Title Sort: Ehrenbreitstein and Koblentz from the heights of the Pfaffendorf
Medium/Materials: watercolor, bodycolour and gum arabic on wove paper
Description: Scene overlooking the river Rhine, buildings on both sides, three male figures in the foreground.
WebDescription: This watercolour was painted from sketches made during the artist's tour of Switzerland and the Rhine in 1838. It was exhibited at the Water-Colour Society in 1839 as 'Ehrenbreitien and Coblentz, from the Nutha of Pfaffenany' and sold for 25gns to George Cooke Esq, Carr House, Doncaster. It is a typical example of the continental picturesque which was then in vogue.

Medium/Materials: watercolor and bodycolour on wove paper
WebDescription:
Cattermole's popularity rested on a showy technical proficiency and choice of subject matter, as Thackeray observed:
 'A few glittering dashes of the brush, and wonderful cups and salvers, and shining suits of armour, are represented by this marvellously facile pencil. Monks, cavaliers, battles, banditti, knightly halls and awful enchanted forests in which knights and distressed damsels wander, the pomp and circumstance of feudal; war, are the subject in which Mr Cattermole chiefly delights'.

Description: view of Kirkstall Abbey ruins (with collapsed tower), from river
WebDescription:
This painting of Kirkstall Abbey, Leeds, shows the ruined Cistercian monastery after the tower collapsed in 1779.

During the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries the ruins of the abbey attracted the attention of a small number of historians and artists, but the growing Romantic Movement, with its great interest in picturesque antiquities, soon established Kirkstall as the most significant of all gothic ruins.

Description: View of Kirkstall Abbey from a hill.  River on the left trailing off into the distance.  Various figures engaged in agricultural tasks in the middle distance.  In the foreground a man in a red coat on horseback waves a stick over a labourer in a white smo
WebDescription:
This watercolour shows the technical skill achieved by watercolour artists by the mid 19th century. Their work had become as impressive as artists working in oil paints. By this time the ruins of Kirkstall Abbey inspired artists' imaginations often because of their closeness to the new industrial scene. Here Fripp has shown the wide sweep of the Aire valley looking west towards Horsforth. The bucolic figures in the foreground, whose red jacket and cap provide the only touches of hot colour in the picture, act as a contrast to the dimly-glimpsed smoking chimneys in the background. These symbols of industry suggest that the peace of the valley is about to be overwhelmed. 
Given by Sir Edward Brotherton 1926.

For more information please see Corinne Miller, 'Watercolours from Leeds City Art Gallery', (1997), Leeds City Art Galleries

Description: Subject: landscape-Leeds
WebDescription:
This view of Kirkstall Abbey from the west is by the Leeds artist Joseph Rhodes.  
Joseph Rhodes was a self-taught artist, a native of Leeds, where he was born in 1782. He has the credit of being the instructor of his more celebrated son John N. Rhodes. 

During the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries the ruins of the abbey attracted the attention of a small number of historians and artists, but the growing Romantic Movement, with its great interest in picturesque antiquities, soon established Kirkstall as the most significant of all gothic ruins

Description: One-handled Cistercian ware mug, restored and incomplete.  The original sherds show piped linear decoration with pellet terminals, yellow through glaze on dark brown/purple fabric.  These sherds are set into an undecorated brown partial-restoration.
WebDescription:
Original Cistercian-ware sherds set into a partially reconstructed mug.  The name ?Cistercian ware? refers to the finely thrown, glazed pottery first found on the sites of Cistercian abbeys in the north of England.  Despite its name, however, this pottery was not actually produced at Cistercian abbeys.  A number of secular sites in the north of England and the Midlands were making this type of pottery from the late 15th century right up until the 17th century, long after the Cistercian abbeys had closed down during the Dissolution of the Monasteries. 
A range of Cisterican ware sherds were discovered at Kirkstall Abbey in the 1890s when it was being cleared.  These sherds were from pots used by the last generation of monks living in the Abbey between about 1475 and 1539.  The pots were probably produced in Potovens (Wrenthorpe), a small village north-west of Wakefield.

Description: Square fired clay tile with white inlay pattern of dark diagonal with two double curves symmetrically arranged either side. Glaze survives on surface and edges and underneath. Fabric is orange pink.  Edges slightly concave.
WebDescription:
This tile was excavated during the 1950-64 Kirkstall Abbey excavations.  Most of the original tiled flooring in Kirkstall Abbey was probably laid some time before 1284, but many tiles were relaid in different parts of the Abbey in the 19th century.  The original location of this tile is unknown.  

Floor tiles were probably made in mobile workshops which moved around to different sites in the region.  Most patterned floor tiles were made using a wooden block or matrix which had a design cut out on its surface in relief.  The block was pushed down into the soft clay tile to leave an impression of the design, which was then filled with a clay slip inlay and fired in a kiln.

Description: Upper portion of a solid bronze tap handle terminating in a zoomorphic head with elongated ears and a ball grasped between its jaws. Broken off across neck.
WebDescription: From the 12th century onwards Cistercian monks in Britain exploited the landscape for their own benefit, including converting stagnant pools into running water.  When this solid tap handle was in use it would have been connected to a system of lead water pipes around Kirkstall Abbey, and water would have exited from a hole in the base of the key.  This tap handle was found in the kitchen yard and is one of the earliest examples of tap handles known from Cistercian abbeys.

Description: Rectangular lead tray with all four corners roughly folded upwards.  Surface and sides uneven.
WebDescription: This lead tray was discovered in the 1890s during conservation work in the south transept of Kirkstall Abbey.  According to documentation the remains of a wooden box with iron hinges and fittings was also found, although this has since been lost.  Was this tray the original lining of the box?  Was it a deed box for holding parchment documents, or part of the Abbey treasury?  Whatever it once held, it was empty when it was discovered.

Title Sort: The South Prospect of the Ruins of Kirkstall Abbey near Leeds
Description: The South Prospect of the Ruins of Kirkstall Abbey  near Leeds.  John Alpage 1770 (20th Nov. 1770)
WebDescription: This is an early drawing of Kirkstall Abbey?s south end, made before the partial collapse of the church tower in 1779. The tower is the only visible part of the abbey church. The other parts of the building include, from left, the malt house, refectory, kitchens and ending with the Abbot?s lodgings. The drawing is almost identical to an earlier engraving by landowner Samuel Buck and dated 1723.

Description: watercolour, Kirkstall Abbey. Abbot's Lodging by J.N. Rhodes, of Leeds
WebDescription: watercolour, Kirkstall Abbey. Abbot's Lodging by J.N. Rhodes, of Leeds

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey. Corner of Visiting Abbot's Lodging
Description: Kirkstall Abbey. Corner of Visiting Abbot's Lodging by J.N. Rhodes, of Leeds
WebDescription: Kirkstall Abbey. Corner of Visiting Abbot's Lodging, watercolour painted by J.N. Rhodes of Leeds.

Description: Kirkstall Abbey. "Arch of the Cemetery" (?Kitchen  Arch?)  By J.N. Rhodes, of Leeds; c 1809-42
WebDescription: Kirkstall Abbey. "Arch of the Cemetery" (?Kitchen  Arch?) watercolour by J.N. Rhodes of Leeds

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey. Part of the Ruins, Looking towards Armley House
Description: Kirkstall Abbey. Part of the Ruins, Looking towards Armley House, by J.N. Rhodes, of Leeds
WebDescription:
This watercolour shows part of the ruins of Kirkstall Abbey and the view across the Aire Valley towards Armley House, which was owned by the industrialist Benjamin Gott. 

The artist John Nicholas Rhodes was a native of Leeds and painted many different views of the Abbey.

Description: Kirkstall Abbey. Vesper Gate 1906; by Joseph Lye  of Kirkstall, oil on canvas laid on board, framed  and glazed
WebDescription:
This is an early 20th century oil painting of the gate to Vesper Lane by artist Joseph Lye. In the background is a view of Kirkstall Abbey church and tower. Vesper Lane 
lies inside the original boundaries of the abbey grounds, within what was known as the Outer Court north west of the abbey.The lane named after a type of prayer, provided outside access to the inner gatehouse, now Abbey House Museum.

Description:
Samuel Prout, "Kirkstall", soft ground etching,  published May 27th 1816
Kirkstall Abbey. west end of Nave.  Drawn and etched by Samuel Prout.
WebDescription: This is an etching from 1816 by English Watercolour painter Samuel Prout. It is a view of the North West entrance to Kirkstall Abbey church. After years spent studying the works of the rising school of landscape Prout made a significant change of artistic direction. Around 1888 he discovered his niche in picturesque architectural studies first made on the continent and enjoyed great success. This etching of Kirkstall Abbey is perhaps one of Prout's earliest ventures into architectural drawing.

Title Sort: The south east prospect of Kirkstall Abbey in the county of York
Description: print after James Walker, line engraving by H  Gravelot, The south east prospect of Kirkstall Abbey  in the county of York... published 1st July 1745 by  the proprietor, James Walker, framed
WebDescription: This is an etching of 18th century visitors to Kirkstall Abbey. The etching is a copy of a painting by artist James Walker. During the 18th century a road ran through the centre of the church leaving a huge hole in the east end where the Rose window once was. In 1779 parts of the church tower collapsed and were never replaced, this picture dates back to 1745 and shows the tower intact.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey.  Entrance to the Chapter House
Description: Kirkstall Abbey.  Entrance to the Chapter House, by A. Brunet  Debaines, c1880  Ruined Abbeys of Yorkshire (1883) p.38
WebDescription: This is a print of the entrance to the chapter house at Kirkstall Abbey by French painter and printmaker Alfred Louis Brunet Debaines. The print was made after restoration work was carried out on the back of the chapter house. This restoration work included the blocking up of several windows making the building much darker.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey. North east corner of cloister
Description: Kirkstall Abbey. North east corner of cloister. lithograph By  W. Hunt, undated; published by Hunt and James,  Leeds; title "KIRKSTALL ABBEY";  reverse has engraving of "Moses exposed on the  Nile" from a painting by Paul Delaroche
WebDescription: This is a picture illustrating the north east corner of the cloister at Kirkstall Abbey. It was produced by W.Hunt of Hunt & James printers based in Leeds. The cloister is the courtyard at the centre of the abbey, originally surrounded by a covered walkway. The wall in the background of the picture belongs to the abbey church. On the right-hand side of the image is the entrance to the abbey's chapterhouse or crypt.

Description: lithograph, Kirkstall Abbey from the West  W. Hunt, undated; published by Hunt and James,  Leeds; title "KIRKSTALL ABBEY from the West";  reverse has engraving of "The Home of the  Mountaineer" by Frank Wyburd, in the Exhibition of  the British Institutio
WebDescription: This is print was made by W.Hunt of Hunt & James printers based in Leeds. The picture dates back to 1860 and shows an elegant lady having her portrait painted outside the ruins of Kirkstall Abbey. Her shadow and that of the artist's easel show the time of day to be around evening.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey. View from South East
Description: lithograph, Kirkstall Abbey. View from South East. W. Hunt  undated; published by Hunt and James, Leeds.; view  with fishermen
WebDescription: This is a picture of the abbey from the south printed by W.Hunt of Hunt & James printers in Leeds. In the foreground a tall thin figure fishes in the River Aire, to the left of which is the Kirkstall weir. A kind of man-made waterfall, the Kirkstall weir was first built in medieval times to raise the level of the river and create large pools of water needed to run the local mill. In the background the abbey is largely hidden from the river by overgrowth and a clump of trees.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey from the Old Road
Description: lithograph "Kirkstall Abbey from the Old Road."  lithographed by W. Hunt; published by Hunt &  James, Lithog., Leeds; sepia wash.  Reverse is colour profile of woman in ornate bonnet.
WebDescription: This is a view of Kirkstall Abbey and the turn pike road from the east and framed by foliage in picturesque fashion. The picture was printed by W. Hunt of Hunt & James printers in 1860, the yellow-brown wash over the print is known as sepia. The road seen here running almost parallel to the abbey church was built in 1827 dividing the abbey grounds into two.

Description: print of drawing of Kirkstall Abbey, signed J.G.  1859 (Jules Georges), mounted on card
WebDescription: This is a print of the abbey by artist Jules George from 1859.The print gives a view into the back of the chapter house with its vaulted ceilings and supporting arches. In the background is the faint outline of the abbey church and tower. Printing the church using lighter tones gives the impression of distance.

Title Sort: Figures in front of Kirkstall Abbey
Description: painting, oil on canvas, "Kirkstall Abbey from the  South East" by Charles Nicholson, (although  collapsed tower means it must be after 1779), shows Abbey House on the right (with the extention which was later remodelled in 1842)
WebDescription: This is an oil painting attributed to artist Charles Nicholsonl The abbey church tower is incomplete and so the painting cannot pre-date its collapse in 1779. On the right side of the church are a number of farm buildings including Abbey House (with the early 19th century extention which was later remodelled in 1842).

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey. View from South East
Description: Kirkstall Abbey. View from South East by George  Alexander, 1879
WebDescription: This is a watercolour of Kirkstall Abbey from the east by George Alexander. In the foreground a group of cows sit under a tree and a young woman follows a winding path the towards the abbey.

Description: watercolour, in card mount, view of Kirkstall  Abbey, signed S. Wagstaff
WebDescription: This is a painting of the abbey church's east end from the nave. It was painted by Samuel Wagstaff sometime between 1875 and 1880. In the 15th century the original Rose window was replaced with the perpendicular window seen in this picture.

Title Sort: wood carving from Abbey west door
Description: Wooden carving taken from the Abbey's West door.
WebDescription: This is a wooden carving taken from the West door of Kirkstall Abbey's church. It is thought to be early nineteenth century and certainly predates 1892 when the door was replaced with gates.

Title Sort: wood carving from Abbey west door
Description: carved wood section from Abbey west door prior to gates of 1892
WebDescription: This is a wooden carving taken from the main door to Kirkstall Abbey church when it was replaced with gates in 1892. The panel is decorated with the figure of a woman accompanied by an angel. Although it remains uncertain the characters could be the Virgin Mary and the angel Gabriel.

Description: white glazed plate with black lines round  border and black transfer print of "KIRKSTALL  ABBEY"; marked "H. FOGGITT / RD. NO. 92391 /  KIRKSTALL"
WebDescription: This plate and other souvenirs like it were sold by Mr H. Foggitt from his shop on commercial road in Kirkstall at the turn of the century. This particular design was registered in 1888, the year that the abbey was sold to Colonel North and probably appeared on all kinds of Kirkstall Abbey memorabilia.

Description: Kirkstall Abbey. The Chapter House. Etching by Axel  H. Haig, 1893, monogrammed and dated 1893 in etching  and signed  (lovers meeting in the chapter house)
WebDescription: This is a print made of Kirkstall Abbey by Swedish artist Axel Hermann Haig and described as two lovers meeting in the chapter house. Framed by the building's arches and vaults the pair of lovers are posed on a pile of ruins. The young woman avoids her suitor's gaze, instead innocently casting her eyes down to the floor.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey, View from South East
Description: print by Axel Haig, figures and sheep in the pasture  before Kirkstall Abbey ruins.  Etching with monogram  and date 1892 within print, signed and numbered 11 in pencil, framed
WebDescription: This is a print of Kirkstall Abbey by Swedish artist Axel Hermann Haig dated 1892. In 1890 work began on the abbey and surrounding land transforming it into a public park. This print is significant because of how it illustrates the abbey's transition from agricultural centre to City Park. In the foreground of the picture local farm workers continue to put their animals out to pasture in the grounds of the abbey, whilst in the background huge crowds of well dressed visitors flock to see the landmark.

Description: An etching of Kirkstall Abbey's North West facade by John Sell Cotman, published May 30th 1811in Cotman's hometown of Norwich. The etching shows a blockade of the church's West door, possibly erected to prevent access to a thoroughfare running through the
WebDescription:
This is an etching of Kirkstall Abbey's North West facade by John Sell Cotman, published May 30th 1811in Cotman's hometown of Norwich. The etching shows a blockade of the church's West door, possibly erected to prevent access to a thoroughfare running through the centre of the church and closed in 1804. However the picture also shows water reaching right up to the church entrance suggesting flooding of the precinct (although no flood is recorded/ floods were recorded)
    Between 1803 and 1805 Cotman made three tours of Yorkshire where he visited his patrons, Mr and Mrs Cholmeley of Brandsby Hall. It is likely that it was during one of these trips that he first visited Kirkstall. On his return to Norfolk he issued his first series of etchings entitled 'Miscellaneous Etchings of Architectural Antiquities of York'. The figure on the far right of the image could be a depiction of the artist himself at work. 
      In the early part of the 19th century Cotman became a prominent member of the Sketching Club founded by the artist Thomas Girtin, also famous for his paintings of Kirkstall. 
       This print is mounted in a large green board bound scrap book, titled 'Kirkstall Abbey' and compiled by Mr Harold.P. Boyes.

Description:
Kirkstall, Yorkshire (view of Abbey House), 1820, published Rowney & Forster's Lithographic Press, London
p.120 in large green board bound scrap book, titled "Kirkstall Abbey", compiled by H.P. Boyes
WebDescription: This is a rare view of Abbey House built around the old abbey gatehouse. The abbey gatehouse built in the later 12th century now forms the oldest part of the house. This print was made before the building was converted into a family home and extra wings were added to the structure. From the mid 19th century until the turn of the century the Beecroft and Butler families leased the house in succession.

Description:
Kirkstall Abbey near Leeds, Yorkshire, painted by J. Farrington R.A., engraved by P. Roberts, Hamstead Heath, published April 12th 1792
p.124 in large green board bound scrap book, titled "Kirkstall Abbey", compiled by H.P. Boyes
WebDescription: This is a printed copy of a picture originally painted by Royal Academician Joseph Farrington famous for his eye for detail. Joseph Farrington made two trips to Kirkstall Abbey, painting this scene on the occasion of his first visit to the area.It is a picture of the weir near Kirkstall Abbey with the tower of the abbey church just visible in the background.A kind of manmade waterfall, the weir was used to raise the level of the river near the abbey and create large pools of water needed to run the abbey mills.Before it was closed down the abbey had its own cornmill for making flour.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey from the South East
Description:
Kirkstall Abbey from the South East, etching by J. Chalmers Park
p.127 in large green board bound scrap book, titled "Kirkstall Abbey", compiled by H.P. Boyes
WebDescription: This is a picture of the east end of Kirkstall Abbey masked by trees. It was produced by artist James Chalmers-Park who studied at Leeds College of Art and was based in the city for most of his career.

Title Sort: The Queen's Visit to Leeds - Kirkstall Abbey
Description:
The Queen's Visit to Leeds - Kirkstall Abbey, Illustrated London News Sept 18 1858, p.258
p.136 in large green board bound scrap book, titled "Kirkstall Abbey", compiled by H.P. Boyes
WebDescription:
In 1858 Queen Victoria was invited to Leeds to open the new town hall. This is a newspaper illustration of the Queen's visit to Kirkstall Abbey. There are several ladies present, but the Queen is instantly recognisable in her impressively large dress.
       This print was found mounted in a large green board bound scrap book entitled 'Kirkstall Abbey', and compiled by Harold.P. Boyes, who died in 1966.

Description:
music, The Old Abbey Waltzes, Dedicated to Colonel North, composed by Mervyn Fairfax c.1889, A. Hammond & Co., 5 Vigo St, Regent St. London W
p.173 in large green board bound scrap book, titled "Kirkstall Abbey", compiled by H.P. Boyes
WebDescription: This is a book of sheet music featuring the image of Kirkstall Abbey on the front cover. 'The Old Abbey Waltzes' was composed by Mervyn Fairfax and dedicated to Colonel North. The book probably dates from 1889, the year that the Colonel presented the abbey to the City of Leeds. The picture views the abbey from the south east and in the foreground are the exposed ruins of the abbey infirmary, not fully excavated until the 1950s.

Title Sort: Queen's Visit to Leeds 1858 - Kirkstall Abbey
Description:
Queen's Visit to Leeds 1858 - Kirkstall Abbey, see p.263
p.204 in large green board bound scrap book, titled "Kirkstall Abbey", compiled by H.P. Boyes
WebDescription:
In 1858 Queen Victoria was invited to Leeds to open the new town hall. This is a newspaper illustration of the Queen's visit to Kirkstall Abbey. There are several ladies present, but the Queen is instantly recognisable in her impressively large dress.
         This print was found mounted in a large green board bound scrap book entitled 'Kirkstall Abbey', and compiled by Harold.P. Boyes, who died in 1966.

Description: Kirkstall Abbey Interior of the Nave drawn by Nathaniel Whittock and engraved by J.F. Lambert.Published in 1829 by Hinton.
WebDescription:
This engraving by Nathaniel Whittock shows the overgrown interior of Kirkstall Abbey church, from the Nave or central aisle to the church's east end. This print was published in 1829 and predates repairs carried out to restore the great east window frame. Here we can see how despite the partial collapse of the church tower in 1779, both arcades remained intact. 
Nathaniel Whittock was lithographer and printer to the University of Oxford, but although he himself was a successful printer this image was produced by another engraver, namely Mr J.F.Lambert.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey. The Nave looking East
Medium/Materials: engraving on paper and backed on card.
Description: Kirkstall Abbey. The Nave looking East; drawn by W. Richardson, engraved by  Richardson, engraved by G. Hawkins,; title  "Interior of Kirkstall Abbey", hand-coloured  lithograph; Day & Haghe, lithographers to the  Queen;  reverse has part of history of Ki
WebDescription: This is a colour copy of a painting by architect and artist William Richardson picturing the ruined interior of Kirkstall Abbey church around 1840. As an artist Richardson was well-known for his detailed depictions of country houses, ruins and abbeys in watercolour and his works were featured in 'Monastic Ruins of Yorkshire' published in 1843 .He had a great interest in historic building reflected in his choice of artistic subject matter.

Medium/Materials: oil on canvas; gilded wood & plaster frame
Description: oil painting of Kirkstall Abbey, by Joseph Rhodes,  mounted in gilt frame; scene of Abbey from across  River Aire, 2 horses and 4 men in foreground, cows  in field, between River and Abbey, large trees to  left
WebDescription:
This oil painting of Kirkstall Abbey is by Joseph Rhodes and shows the abbey from the other side of the River Aire, with cattle and figures in the foreground.

Joseph Rhodes was a self-taught Leeds artist, father of the more famous John Nicholas Rhodes.

Title Sort: North West View of Kirkstall Abbey
Medium/Materials: print on paper backed on card
Description: engraving "North West View of Kirkstall Abbey",  Leeds, published by Heaton May 12. 1806
WebDescription: This is a print of Kirkstall Abbey published by John Heaton in 1806. Between the 18th and early 19th century the 'picturesque' movement in landscape painting popularized ruins in landscapes.On the right side of the print are the remains of the laybrother's cellerium.

Description: Paper mache table with folding top, pedestal and three claw feet. The circular tabletop was decorated with a scene of the abbey at Kirkstall sometime between 1800 and 1850. The scene includes the portrait of a farmworker and his cattle pictured infront of
WebDescription: This Papier mache table with folding top, pedestal and three claw feet dates back to the 19th century. The circular tabletop was decorated with a scene of the abbey at Kirkstall sometime between 1800 and 1850. The picture includes the portrait of a farm worker and his cattle in front of the abbey church.

Description: This is a view of Kirkstall Abbey from Vesper Gate by local artist and musician William Nelson of Fulneck near Pudsey. Vesper Lane was inside the boundaries of the Abbey grounds, but within what was known as the Outer Court.The lane provided outside acces
WebDescription: This is a view of Kirkstall Abbey from the gate to Vespers lane by local artist and musician William Nelson of Fulneck near Pudsey. Vespers was a type of prayer service celebrated by the monks everyday before supper. Vesper Lane lies inside the original boundaries of the Abbey grounds, but within what was known as the Outer Court.The lane provided outside access to the inner gatehouse. This picture shows men on horseback riding through the gate heading down Vesper Lane and towards the Abbey. Altogether Nelson produced six views of Kirkstall Abbey to be turned into prints by various lithographers.

Description: large mustard pot, white pottery, on front in black design of "Genuine Abbey Mustard Warranted Prepared from the Finest Seed at Richard Gay & Co. Mustard & Spice Mills Kirkstall near Leeds" Patterned border surround in border "Manufactured Middlesbro' Pot
WebDescription: This earthenware mustard jar was manufactured by Middlesbrough Pottery for Richard Gay & Co producers of Abbey Mustard. The jar is decorated with a romanticised view of Kirkstall Abbey church. For centuries local businesses have associated themselves with the abbey as a local landmark and as a mark of distinction.

Title Sort: North Aisle of Kirkstall Abbey Church
Description: painting of North Aisle of Kirkstall Abbey Church  by J. Rhodes.
WebDescription:
This watercolour painting shows the North Aisle of Kirkstall Abbey Church by J. Rhodes.   It is a unique picture as it shows the Church of the Abbey  in use as a barn.

Joseph Rhodes was a self-taught Leeds artist, father of the more famous John Nicholas Rhodes.

Title Sort: Morning, With A View Of Kirkstall  Abbey
Description: Oil painting by Henry Pether of Kirkstall Abbey and the river Aire by moonlight.
WebDescription:
It is thought that this oil painting of Kirkstall Abbey was painted by Henry Pether, son to painter Sebastian Pether and grandson of celebrated artist Abraham 'Moonlight' Pether of Chichester. Henry Pether was the third generation of his family to paint moonlit landscapes and although it can be difficult to distinguish between the three artists given the date of this particular work we can confidently attribute it to him. 

The painting pictures Kirkstall Abbey and the laybrothers reredorter or toilet block from the River Aire, with Kirkstall village and St. Stephen's Church in the distance. Although the scene depicted takes place early in the morning the riverbank is a hive of activity, with boats and figures on shore. Henry Pether was known for creating a sense of local atmosphere in his paintings, which also helps to distinguish his work from that of his predecessors.

Title Sort: The North East Prospect of Kirkstall Abbey
Dimensions:
object height (frame): 1675mm
object width (frame): 1310mm
object height (painting): 1473mm
object width (painting): 1118mm
Description:
anti-papal scene in sky.Title and date : THE N.E.PROSPECT OF KIRKSTALL- ABBEY ANo DOM 1738
Subject: ruins; landscape;Leeds
artist not signed, but prob. John Bouttas;  in wooden frame; painted in oil on canvas  view of Kirkstall Abbey, with farm workers
WebDescription: This fascinating allegorical oil painting attributed to John Bouttats has the rather mundane title "The North East Prospect of Kirkstall Abbey - Ano Dom. 1738".  Above a reasonably straightforward painting of the ruined abbey in a romantic rural landscape (with rustic figures in the foreground) there are a group of strange figures in the sky.  These figures with chariots who are holding up the painting's title scroll represent the "Overthrow of Catholicism".

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey. Interior View (sic).  View from East
Description: After John Cawthorn Jun, "Interior View of the  Abbey of Kirkstall", engraved by J Fittler,  published 4th June 1804 by Clay & Scriven, Ludgate  Hill, dedicated to Wm. Lee Esq. of Grove
WebDescription: This is an engraving of a man and his dog walking by the Kirkstall Weir towards the abbey taken from a painting by artist John Cawthorne Junior. During the 18th century a road ran right through the centre of the abbey church.This is the first picture of the abbey to record the new walling introduced below the Rose window after the closure of the road.

Title Sort: The South Prospect of the Ruins of Kirkstall Abbey near Leeds
Description: Samuel Buck, "The South Prospect of the Ruins of  Kirkstall Abbey near Leeds in York-shire" engraving  with dedication
WebDescription: This is a very early engraving of Kirkstall Abbey?s south end made before the partial collapse of the church tower in 1779.The tower is the only visible part of the abbey church. The other parts of the building include, from left, the malt house, kitchens and end with the Abbot?s lodgings.The engraving was made by wealthy landowner and printmaker Samuel Buck. Buck was a friend of Ralph Thoresby known as the first Leeds Historian. Ralph Thoresby had an intimate connection to Kirkstall and the abbey and in the 18th was the first person to discover original floor tiles at the abbey.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey in the Wapontake and Deanery of Skyrack
Description: engraving, "Kirkstall Abbey in the Wapontake and Deanery of Skyrack & in the Archdeaconry of the West Riding  of the County of York"; After Dall, engraved by  Burrell, published 7th Feb 1812, by Robert  Wilkinson
WebDescription: This is an engraving taken from an oil painting by N.T Dall of the abbey from the Kirkstall Weir. On the right two goats climb rocks by the river. Goats are mentioned at Kirkstall Abbey in records going back to the time of the monks. Although the Cistercian monks ate a mostly vegetarian diet they kept all kinds of livestock including many rare breeds cared for by the laybrothers. Having their own mill and farm meant that the monks could be self sufficient and remain relatively isolated from the outside world.

Description: etching "The Tower, Kirkstall Abbey, Yorkshire", George  Cuitt, 1823
WebDescription: This is a picture of the tower at Kirkstall Abbey church from behind the chapter house by artist George Cuitt Jnr. Thick overgrowth covers the building. Cuitt was well known for his etchings of historic buildings in particular the castles and abbeys of Yorkshire. Whilst studying in Rome he developed a distinctive style of drawing closely modelled on the work of etcher Piranesi famous for his pictures of ruins covered in thick vegetation. Piranesi's influence on Cuitt is clear when looking at his prints of the abbey such as this.

Description: etching "Kirkstall Abbey, West Entrance, Yorkshire",  George Cuitt, Masham 1823; plate 26
WebDescription: This is an almost eerie scene of the ruins of Kirkstall Abbey church by artist George Cuitt Jnr. Thick overgrowth covers the building and two old women sit beneath a twisting tree. Cuitt was well known for his etchings of historic buildings in particular the castles and abbeys of Yorkshire. Whilst studying in Rome he developed a distinctive style of drawing closely modelled on the work of etcher Piranesi famous for his pictures of ruins covered in thick vegetation. Piranesi's influence on Cuitt is clear when looking at his prints of the abbey such as this.

Description: etching, "The Refectory, Kirkstall Abbey, Yorkshire", by  George Cuitt
WebDescription: This is a picture of the ruins of the refectory or dining hall at Kirkstall Abbey by artist George Cuitt Jnr. Cuitt was well known for his etchings of historic buildings in particular the castles and abbeys of Yorkshire. Whilst studying in Rome he developed a distinctive style of drawing closely modelled on the work of etcher Piranesi famous for his pictures of ruins covered in thick vegetation. Piranesi's influence on Cuitt is clear when looking at his prints of the abbey such as this.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey, Yorkshire, from the  N.W
Description: Lithograph dated April 22nd 1844. Engraved by G.Hawkins and published by R. Sunter of York for Day & Haghe Lithographers to the Queen.Original image by artist and architect William Richardson of York.
WebDescription: This lithograph was published by R.Sunter in April of 1844 for Day & Haghe lithographers to Queen Victoria. The print views Kirkstall Abbey church from the North West and was originally drawn by local artist William Richardson the son of a cabinetmaker based in York. As an artist he was well-known for his depictions of country houses, ruins and abbeys in watercolour. Richardson had a great interest in building reflected in his choice of artistic subject matter, eventually becoming an architect.

Description: engraving, by John Scott from a drawing by J.M.W.  Turner "Crypt in Kirkstall Abbey, Yorkshire"  published London May 1 1814 by Longman & Co.,  Paternoster Row; printed by Bishop
WebDescription: This is an engraving by John Scott from a painting by celebrated artist J.M.W. Turner. The original painting was made in 1798 and shows cows in the undercroft of the monks' dormitory before the collapse of the vaulted ceiling.

Description: engraving, from Illustrated London News, Sat. Sept  21 1895, No. 2944/vol. CVII  "Re-opening of Kirkstall Abbey, Leeds", engraving  by Holland Fingham "The Bishop of Ripon Delivering  the Address", with inset view of ruins at top
WebDescription: This is an engraving from an illustrated Newspaper dated September 1895. It was used to illustrate a service held at the abbey to celebrate the opening of the abbey park and the completion of restoration works to the building. The bottom part of the illustration shows the congregation listening to a speech given by the Bishop of Ripon. The programme of celebratory events also included a tea party held by the Mayor in the cloister. An inset at the top of this view shows the abbey ruins seen from the River Aire.

Medium/Materials: wood, mahogany; wood, oak; glass; metal
Description: long case clock of mahogany and oak, with a  painted white dial depicting a view of Kirkstall  Abbey, Leeds in the arch and floral spandrels.  The dial has Roman numerals and enclosed two  smaller dials.  The inscription on the dial is  "Jas Galloway, Lee
WebDescription: This long case clock of mahogany and oak has a painted white dial depicting a view of Kirkstall  Abbey, Leeds in the arch and floral spandrels.  The dial has Roman numerals and enclosed two smaller dials.  The inscription on the dial is  "Jas Galloway, Leeds".  The clock has an 8-day  movement which strikes on a bell. James Galloway listed in local directories between 1822 and 1850.

Dimensions:
object height: 2230mm
object width: 670mm
object depth: 255mm
Description:
long case clock, painted dial with picture of  Kirkstall Abbey at top, shells in corners,  "Cordingley, Leeds", veneered and inlaid case; 14  inch break arch dial; eight day movement;  c1830-1840
There are two Cordingleys recorded as clockmakers:  Thomas
WebDescription:
long case clock, painted dial with picture of  Kirkstall Abbey at top, shells in corners,  "Cordingley, Leeds", veneered and inlaid case; 14  inch break arch dial; eight day movement;  c1830-1840
There are two Cordingleys recorded as clockmakers:  Thomas (1780-1836) in  Lower Headrow and  William (1866-1871) at 62 Kirkgate.  The clock was probably made by Thomas.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey, View from the South-East
Description: Richard Carrick, Figures and cattle before Kirkstall Abbey ruin from the South East,  chromolithograph, framed
WebDescription: This print after artist Richard Carrick was produced sometime between 1860 and 1870 using a technique known as chromolithography. The majority of the print is taken up with Kirkstall Abbey's east range, including the choir monks? dormitory and the chapterhouse leading on to the abbey church. In the foreground a woman and child tend to a herd of cattle. Pastoral scenes of country life like this were exceptionally popular in the 19th century.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey, View from the East
Description: colour print (chromolithograph?); Kirkstall Abbey  from the East; after R. Carrick 1841-1874; cows in  foreground
WebDescription: This is a coloured copy of a painting by artist Richard Carrick produced sometime between 1860 and 1870 using a technique known as chromolithography. Here the abbey appears much smaller than in reality, there are also parts of the building which have been excluded from the painting. The old Abbot's lodging has been removed from the scene and replaced with the large tree on the left-hand side, allowing for the artist to bring the river much closer to the abbey church.Pastoral scenes of country life like this were exceptionally popular in the 19th century.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey, a distant view  through the central span of the Bridge
Description: mezzotint print "Kirkstall Abbey, a distant view  through the central span of the Bridge", John  Varley del., F.C. Lewis sculp., publ. Feb 1806 by  F.C. & G. Lewis, 88 Queen Ann Street East, London;  in card mount
WebDescription: This mezzotint print shows "Kirkstall Abbey, a distant view  through the central span of the Bridge" by the artist John Varley, engraved by F.C. Lewis and published Feb 1806 by F.C. & G. Lewis, 88 Queen Ann Street East, London.

Description: etching, Kirkstall Abbey, The Cloisters, by Axel  H. Haig, 1893; in card mount
WebDescription: This is a view of the chapter house from the cloister at Kirkstall Abbey by Swedish artist Axel Hermann Haig. It dates back to the 1890s when the abbey grounds were first opened up as a public park. Here three well dressed ladies gather outside the chapter house entrance while other visitors take a walk around the cloister courtyard.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey on the River Aire
Description: "Kirkstall Abbey on the River Aire" after Thomas  Girtin, mezzotint engraving by W. Say; from a  drawing in the possession of B.G. Windus Esqr.;  (published July 1, 1824: The Rivers of England  pl.9)
WebDescription: This is a view of Kirkstall Abbey's south end from the River Aire. A couple walk along the riverside path through a large wooden gate and into fields surrounding the abbey. It is a copy of a painting by artist Thomas Girtin, engraved by William Say. William Say was one of the first engravers to be able to print different shades of colour. Before the invention of the kind of printing known as Mezzotint, artists would use different patterns to show shade on a print.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey, The Nave, looking East
Description: Kirkstall Abbey. The Nave, looking East. by W.  Nelson (1836) of Fulneck
WebDescription: This picture of the inside of Kirkstall Abbey church was drawn by Yorkshire artist and musician William Nelson. In the middle of the church stands a man with what appears to be a large shovel slung across his shoulder. He is probably a local farmer and tennant of the Brudenell family, Earls of Cardigan and owners of the Abbey at this time. The roof of the church was taken down when the church was closed in .The church tower collapsed in 1779 leaving only the parts we see here in this picture left.

Title Sort: KIrkstall Abbey, View from South West
Medium/Materials: print on paper, backed on card
Description: lithograph; Kirkstall Abbey From The South West,  after a drawing made by W. Nelson (of Fulneck)  1836 (men fishing)
WebDescription: This is a lithograph after a drawing by local artist and musician William Nelson of Fulneck near Pudsey. Here we get a good overview of both the West and South sides or ranges of the Abbey. In the foreground three men fish in the River Aire behind which stands the Laybrother?s reredorter or toilet block. Over the centuries the reredorter has been an animal shelter, Blacksmith's workshop and is now home to the Abbey Visitor's centre. The Laybrothers carried out day to day tasks for the Monks and in return were given accommodation in the West side of the Abbey. In the background of the picture is the Abbey church itself. On the right hand side we can identify the ruins of the Abbey's two kitchens and the Abbot's lodgings under years of overgrowth.

Description: Kirkstall Abbey. The Tower; etching by George  Cuitt, 1823
WebDescription: This is a picture of the tower at Kirkstall Abbey church from behind the chapter house by artist George Cuitt Jnr. Thick overgrowth covers the building. Cuitt was well known for his etchings of historic buildings in particular the castles and abbeys of Yorkshire. Whilst studying in Rome he developed a distinctive style of drawing closely modelled on the work of etcher Piranesi famous for his pictures of ruins covered in thick vegetation. Piranesi's influence on Cuitt is clear when looking at his prints of the abbey such as this.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey on the River Aire
Description: engraving "Kirkstall Abbey on the River Aire",  with cattle and woman with water pot on head  drawn by J.M.W. Turner, R.A.; engraved by John  Bromley for "The Rivers of England" (1775-1851);  "River Scenery Plate 16"
WebDescription: This is an engraving by John Bromley. It is a copy of an original painting of Kirkstall Abbey from the weir by celebrated artist Joseph M.W.Turner. On the left a woman collecting water balances a pot on her head and a herd of cows drink from the river. The River Aire was an important source of water for the monks at the abbey. The weir at Kirkstall was built in medieval times to raise the level of the water creating large pools and making it easier to collect water with which to run the abbey corn mills.

Description: The Tower of Kirkstall Abbey. Drawn by E.  Dayes (1763-1804); engraved by John Goldar(1729-95)  soft ground etching  Published in the "Gentleman's Magazine" Supplement  1803 PlI, p1197
WebDescription: This etching of the Tower of Kirkstall Abbey was drawn by E. Dayes (1763-1804) and engraved by John Goldar (1729-95)  and was published in the "Gentleman's Magazine" Supplement in 1803.

Description: Kirkstall Abbey Church from the North West drawn by Nathaniel Whittock and engraved by J. Rogers.From 'Views in County of York' by R. Radstock, published in Leeds 1872 . Framed with another 5 prints recorded under KA 37, 38, 51, 52 and 61.
WebDescription: This print of the church at Kirkstall Abbey from the North West was originally drawn by Nathaniel Whittock a lithographer and printer to the University of Oxford. Although Whittock himself was a successful printer this image was produced by another engraver, Mr J. Rogers in 1829. The image pictures the abbey at a time when the estate was used for grazing livestock. This particular image features a flock of sheep.Along with another five prints in the Leeds Museum and Galleries collection the picture was later published by R.Radstock in a book entitled 'Views in the county of York', 1872.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey, view from the East
Description: Kirkstall Abbey, view from the East  by I. Sutcliffe, 1791  black & grey watercolour picture
WebDescription: This is a fairly simplistic painting of the abbey from 1791. It was painted in grey watercolour by I.Sutcliffe.In the painting two stone walls divide the abbey grounds into fields. The most detailed part of the painting is the abbey tower which partly collapsed in 1779.

Description: etching ink drawing of Kirkstall Abbey by Stanley Medway  1880, framed (not glazed)
WebDescription: This is a print of the abbey church from behind the chapter house by artist Stanley Medway. The print dates back to 1880. In 1779 a large part of the church tower collapsed leaving only this side, the south face, of the tower complete.

Description: Kirkstall Abbey and River Aire from South.  By A. Brunet Debaines, 1880.One of a series published in the portfolio under the title of the Ruined Abbeys of Yorkshire; hand coloured.
WebDescription: This picture was one of many in a series of 'Ruined Abbey's of Yorkshire' by French artist Alfred Louis Brunet Debaines, published in 1883. This particular print of Kirkstall from the South is thought to date from 1880 and was hand coloured. The gloomy print views the Abbey from the River Aire on an overcast day making for a particularly Romantic scene. During the 18th century it was considered fashionable and exciting to create work in this manner, otherwise known as gothic.

Title Sort: The Crypt at Kirkstall Abbey, Yorkshire
Dimensions:
object height (frame): 435mm
object width (frame): 510mm
object: 300 x 225mm
Description: line engraving drawn and engraved by John Coney 1812. Framed but severe foxing.
WebDescription:
Here is a picture of the Crypt or Chapter House at Kirkstall Abbey produced by artist John Coney in 1815.From this print you can see how the Chapter House, originally such an important part of the Abbey, was severely neglected during the 18th and early 19th centuries. The bare earth floor is scattered with debris while the roots of trees and plants covering the building hang down from the ceiling. 
    In the 1920s the Crypt underwent extensive restoration in which late unsympathetic 19th century repairs to the entrance were replaced and the whole crypt was paved. 
    In the same year that this print was produced, illustrator James Duffield Harding employed Coney to produce a series of etchings documenting the cathedrals and abbeys of England. This included Kirkstall and it is likely that Coney completed this picture whilst visiting the Abbey for James Harding. The project took fourteen years to complete and was published in 1829 under the title 'Views of English Abbeys and Cathedrals'.

Description: engraving, Kirkstall Abbey. View from West; drawn by P.S. Munn;  engraved by S. Middiman; published Oct. 1, 1805
WebDescription: This is a print of Kirkstall Abbey's West range by artist Paul Sandby Munn from 1805. To the right of the drawing is the Laybrothers Reredorter which still stands as the Abbey Visitors centre.In this picture the building is clearly being used to shelter livestock. There is also evidence that at one time this building was a Blacksmith's workshop.

Description: engraving, Kirkstall Abbey, Yorkshire  artist E. Dayes; published 1805 for Mrs Dayes, 42  Devonshire Street, Queen Square; engraved by T.C.  Smith;  with Hark to Rover Inn;  paper sticker EDMUND WILSON / LEEDS
WebDescription: This engraving of Kirkstall Abbey, Yorkshire by the artist E. Dayes was published 1805 and engraved by T.C.  Smith.  This view shows the Hark to Rover Inn to the right.

Description: oil painting of Kirkstall Abbey, by moon light,  with tram and Abbey Road in foreground; signed W.  Meegan; gilt frame with acanthus moulding
WebDescription: This is an eerie oil painting by artist Walter Meegan of Kirkstall Abbey and passing tram. It was painted sometime between 1880 and 1899. By this time the old turnpike road had been replaced by the more modern Abbey Road.Meegan made a number of paintings of the abbey during the late 19th century all by moonlight.

Dimensions:
object width: 1003mm
object height: 745mm
object width (painting): 766mm
object height (painting): 507mm
Description: oil painting of Kirkstall Abbey, by moon light, view from river, signed W. Meegan  gilt frame, oak leaf moulding
WebDescription: This oil painting shows Kirkstall Abbey, by moon light, viewed from the river.  It is signed W. Meegan.

Title Sort: North East View of Kirkstall Abbey
Description: This watercolour and ink work was painted by Welsh 'drawing man servant' Moses Griffiths in the latter part of the 18th century. Dated May 1st 1777 it is the earliest existing painting of the Abbey by Griffiths. Griffiths was an amateur artist in the serv
WebDescription:
This watercolour and ink work was painted by Welsh 'drawing man servant' Moses Griffiths in the latter part of the 18th century. Dated May 1st 1777 it is the earliest existing painting of the Abbey by Griffiths. Griffiths was an amateur artist in the service of typographer and antiquarian Thomas Pennant of Downing in Flintshire. Pennant employed Griffiths to paint the most memorable places he visited whilst touring the country, describing him as 'a worthy servant I keep for that purpose'.

The painting is considered to be an accurate representation of Kirkstall Abbey at this time, despite the artist's reputation for romanticism. Here we see the Abbey from the North East, just two years before a large part of the Abbey church tower collapsed and was lost forever. The painting also shows how the church's East facade probably looked before repairs to the wall underneath the large East window. The existing ruins of the Abbots lodgings can be seen to the left hand side of the painting, missing are the ruins of the abbey infirmary which were not excavated nor even located for another . 
Another view of the abbey from the North West by Griffiths dated May 15th 1777 also survives as part of the Leeds Museums and Galleries Collection and is also held at Leeds City Art Gallery.

Description: watercolour, card mount, Kirkstall Abbey by J.  Halfpenny (1748-1811), inscribed on reverse "The  Chapter House at Kirkstall Abbey near Leeds, taken  July 14th 1789 by Jos. Halpenny"
WebDescription: Joseph Halfpenny, of York, made a name for himself as the artist and author of 'Gothic Ornaments' a collection of drawings of ornamentation and architectural detail from York Minister published in 1800, but before this he produced a number of sketches of Kirkstall Abbey. This particular print is of the abbey chapter house exposed from behind before repairs to the external walls. In the 19th century all access to the vaulted building except from the cloister courtyard was blocked off.

Description: coloured engraving; "Kirkstall Abbey, Yorkshire,  P.3" view from North East; by V.M. Picot;  published May 4, 1785 by S. Hooper; unmounted
WebDescription: This coloured engraving of Kirkstall Abbey was published in 1785. It is a copy of an original drawing by French printmaker Victor Marie Picot. The original picture was first published in 1774, 5 years prior to the partial collapse of the church tower.

Title Sort: Kirkstall Abbey in the Wapentake and Deanery of  Skyrack
Description: engraving, Kirkstall Abbey in the Wapentake and Deanery of  Skyrack..........  Engraved from an original Painting in oil by T.N.  Dall. London, Published 7 Feb. 1812
WebDescription: This is an engraving taken from an oil painting by N.T Dall of the abbey from the Kirkstall Weir. On the right two goats climb rocks by the river. Goats are mentioned at Kirkstall Abbey in records going back to the time of the monks. Although the Cistercian monks ate a mostly vegetarian diet they kept all kinds of livestock including many rare breeds cared for by the laybrothers. Having their own mill and farm meant that the monks could be self sufficient and remain relatively isolated from the outside world.

Medium/Materials: papier mache and mother of pearl
Description: Large black papier mache tray, decorated with a painted view of Kirkstall Abbey from the North West and inlaid with pieces of mother of pearl. An incredibly dark image picturing two figures in the foreground, one of whom is dressed in red.
WebDescription:
This large tray is made from papier mache and dates back to the mid 19th century.
A view of Kirkstall Abbey from the North West is painted on the bottom of the tray and inlaid with pieces of mother of pearl. This painting is an incredibly dark image excepting the shiny mother of pearl detail and one of two figures picked out in bright red.

Description: Large papier mache tray dating from the mid nineteenth century. Decorated with painted scene of Kirkstall Abbey church from the North West and part of the abbey's West range. Executed in oil with some details picked out in gold. In the foreground a trio o
WebDescription: This tray was made from papier mache sometime during the mid 19th century. A picture of Kirkstall Abbey from the North West has been painted on the bottom of the tray using oil paints and in some parts real gold. In the foreground a trio of horses graze.

Title Sort: sampler by EA Dobbins work done in Leeds in the 12th year of her age
Description: sampler by EA Dobbins work done in Leeds in the 12th year of her age' showing Kirkstall Abbey;  framed and glazed; crewel-work, early 18thc?
WebDescription: A church building (Kirkstall Abbey) stands in the background of the landscape depicted in this sampler.  It is surrounded by trees, and on the right hand side one tree has a serpent coiled around its trunk.  In the foreground are two vases of brightly coloured flowers, placed one at each side.  In between them are three lambs, two dogs, a swan and a peacock.  The embroidery is carried out using brightly coloured silk threads, on a plain white ground.  At the bottom the text "E A Dobbins done in Leeds in the 12th year of her age" has been stitched in black thread.

Dimensions:
object height: 290mm
object width: 215mm
object depth: 330mm
Description: "Cromwellian" simulated lobster tailed helmet. Steel, one piece skull, with reinforcing rivets inside and rivets around the base. Fixed umbril (brow guard) with three face bars terminating in a scroll. Short neck guard attached to the body by rivets. Does
WebDescription: This helmet is of the type worn by Parliamentarian soldiers during the English Civil War

Description: Four musket balls, apparently from Marston Moor battle site (1644).
WebDescription: These lead ammunition balls were found on the battlefield at Marston Moor.  The battle took place on 2nd July 1644.  The Parliamentary troops under Lord Fairfax defeated the Royalists led by Prince Rupert.

Dimensions:
object depth: 2000mm
object width: 70mm
object height: 120mm
Description: The mount of an adult male Wild Boar.
WebDescription: This is one of the earliest acquisitions in the natural history collections. The Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society began collecting in 1822. The entry for the boar in 1827 reads: "October 22nd - A fine stuffed specimen of the Wild Boar (Sus scrofa) from the south of Prussia - Mr. Thos. Robinson." Perhaps as a mark of civic pride, it was typical for wealthy travellers to send back specimens and artefacts to their city museum in this way.

Description: The mount of an adult Polar Bear.
WebDescription: This is one of Leeds Museum's oldest specimens. It was bought in Hull in 1828 for 8 - about 6,000 today . Leeds had started collecting natural history in 1822 and wanted to be a part of the growing trend to acquire stuffed animals from around the world. The record for the day it arrived reads: "October 7th 1828 - An exceedingly fine stuffed specimen of the Polar Bear."

Description: The skeleton of a male Giant Irish Elk or Giant Deer.
WebDescription: Giant Irish Elk are neither elk, nor particularly Irish. They are a type of deer that, despite roaming the whole of Europe a few thousand years ago, are commonly found in Ireland. Leeds' Giant Deer was unearthed at Lough Gur, County Limerick and was donated to the museum in 1847. The bones would originally have been a dusty grey but they were painted by their Victorian excavators to look as if they had been stained by the peat bogs they were buried in.

Dimensions:
object depth: 2240mm
object width: 700mm
object height: 980mm
Description: The mount of a giant anteater on a wooden base - mounted specimen in walking posture. Small chip to skin on nose.
WebDescription: This Giant Anteater, originally from South America, came to the museum in the mid-nineteenth century. Natural history collecting at that time was extremely popular. It was common for people to travel the world and send specimens back to their home towns - to great acclaim. Closer to home people collected butterflies and bird eggs.

Dimensions:
object depth: 2600mm
object width: 1000mm
object height: 1400mm
Description: The mount of a Bengal Tiger.
WebDescription: This Bengal Tiger has been popular with museum visitors since 1862. It was originally shot by Major-General Sir Charles Reid in the Himalayas and came back to Britain as a rug. After stuffing it was pronounced to be "unequalled in Europe, either for its extraordinary size or its artistic and life-like setting up." The reports of the time describe its popularity:  "It has been fitly placed in the centre of the large Zoological Room, and is always the most attractive object in that collection."

Description: A large wild Yak. Base has wheels
WebDescription: When the Yak arrived in Leeds in 1862 from Tibet it was lauded by the museum as being part of "the rarest and most important acquisitions that could be added to our collection." At the time it was forbidden to enter Tibet but this did not appear to stop Colonel Edmund Smyth (1823 -1911) who sent the skin back to Yorkshire. It remains the largest and one of the most impressive objects in the museum's collections.

Description: The bones of several Dodos.
WebDescription: In 1865 Harry Higginson, a railway engineer from Thormanby, near York, spotted bones protruding from an embankment in Mauritius. They were identified as Dodo bones - a bird that became extinct between 1650 and 1700. He sent boxes of them back to York, Leeds and Liverpool museums. Harry later went on to a successful career in New Zealand where, in the cathedral in Wellington, he and the Dodo are commemorated in stained glass.

Dimensions:
object weight: 90 kg
object width: 160mm
object depth: 570mm
object height: 900mm
Description: A mounted male Thylacine or Tasmanian Wolf.
WebDescription: Tasmanian wolves became extinct in 1936. This makes stuffed examples of them very rare - there are only eighty in the world. The Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society, which ran the museum until 1921,  was very active in collecting material from Australia in the nineteenth century. They paid well to have Tasmanian wolves shipped to Leeds. We have five more skulls in the collections - you can see them at Leeds Museum Discovery Centre.

Description: A collection of shells of various varieties and band formuli.
WebDescription: Leeds Museums has one of the best shell collections in the country. These White-lipped Snails are part of one of the earliest and most important collections we have. They were collected by John W. Taylor who, along with other Leeds scientists, formed the Conchological Society of Great Britain and Ireland in 1876. More than 200,000 shells are stored at Leeds Museum Discovery Centre.

Dimensions:
object height: 1760mm
object length: 2570mm
object width: 710mm
Description: Mounted specimen of a Bison (American Buffalo). Base on wheels.
WebDescription: This Bison came from the Empire Exhibition in Glasgow in 1938. It was part of a display of Canadian wildlife, put together by the Canadian Government Exhibition Commission. Leeds Museum is well known for collecting objects from around the world and so it was natural that we wanted to collect such a large and impressive animal.

Dimensions:
object height: 1540mm
object width: 1210mm
object depth: 940mm
object weight (at death): 145500gm
Description: The mount of an adult (~7 years) male Gorilla, affectionately named 'Mo Koundje' or simply 'Mok'. Left arm is holding on to branch.
WebDescription: Mok and Moina arrived in London Zoo from French Congo in 1932. They were very popular and often in the newspapers. Mok died in 1938. Moina became distracted after he was gone, picking at sores on her feet, they became infected and she died soon after. Mok's body was stuffed by E. Gerrard and Son. Leeds museum bought this and his skeleton, which can be seen at Leeds Museum Discovery Centre.

Description: The mount of a two/three year old Giant Panda standing on a wooden base.
WebDescription: Grandma was one of ten Giant Pandas that were caught in China in 1938. Only half of them made it to Britain and sadly Grandma died after only seventeen days here. She was due to go on show at London Zoo but caught double pneumonia. Her body was sold to Gerrards, the famous taxidermists and then bought by Leeds Museum in 1938.

Description: Two dried, pressed specimens of the Lady's Slipper Orchid.
WebDescription: The Rev. William Wood (1745 - 1808) of Mill Hill Chapel, Leeds, made Leeds Museum's earliest plant collection. This orchid was collected in Yorkshire in the late 18th century. Lady's Slipper Orchids were never common but due to keen Victorian plant collectors - whether for dried collections or gardens - there are now virtually none left in Britain.

Dimensions:
object height: 1000mm
object width: 500mm
object depth: 500mm
Description: A mounted immature White-tailed Eagle. Mounted on branch looking over right shoulder.
WebDescription: This bird was killed in Barnsley in 1898. Before 1900, White-tailed Eagles were a common sight in the skies above England. These huge eagles were considered a pest and often poisoned or shot. They also suffered as pesticide use increased. White-tailed Eagles are now breeding again in Scotland; it may be that we will one day see them again in the skies above Yorkshire.

Dimensions:
object height: 500mm
object depth: 500mm
object width: 290mm
Description: The mount of an adult Tawny Frogmouth.
WebDescription: This Australian bird was bought by Leeds museums in 1964 from Mr. J.C. Hirst of Cleckheaton, West Yorkshire. It arrived with over 200 other exotic birds, probably collected at the end of 19th century.

object depth: 230mm
object height: 780mm
