Description: The mount of an adult female Ringed Kingfisher.
WebDescription: This large kingfisher was bought by Leeds museums in 1964 from Mr. J.C. Hirst of Cleckheaton, West Yorkshire. It arrived with over 200 other exotic birds, probably collected at the end of 19th century.

Dimensions:
object height: 350mm
object depth: 490mm
object width: 150mm
Description: The mount of an adult male Brazilian Tree Porcupine.
WebDescription: This porcupine came from Salford Museum in 1982. Leeds Museums took in over 300 specimens from Salford at the same time, many were from Belle Vue Zoo in Manchester which closed in 1977.

Dimensions:
object height: 1200mm
object length: 1200mm
object depth: 1200mm
Description: The mounted head of a male Moose.
WebDescription: This Moose came from Salford Museum in 1982. Leeds Museums took in over 300 specimens from Salford at the same time, many were from Belle Vue Zoo in Manchester which closed in 1977.

Description: A mounted female adult Vulturine Guineafowl.
WebDescription: This strange bird was one of a pair acquired by Leeds Museums in 1985. Vulturine Guineafowl are usually found in eastern Africa but these two lived at Lotherton Hall Bird Garden. When they died, the museum commissioned a local taxidermist to stuff them. Museums do not kill animals for display any more - they collect things that have died naturally or accidentally. Often road or cat casualties are stuffed for display.

Description: The dried lenses of the Humboldt Squid. Used in a human mummy in Peru.
WebDescription: These are the eye lenses from a type of squid. They were probably taken from one that had washed up on a beach in South America. Peruvians used these lenses to replace the eyes of human mummies. They give the corpse a more life-like appearance. The mummies are placed in a sitting position on salt beds and occur in their thousands.

Dimensions:
object depth: 440mm
object height: 590mm
object width: 470mm
Description: The mount of a Greater Bird of Paradise.
WebDescription: When these beautiful birds were first discovered it was thought that they didn't have feet or wings - they simply floated around. This led to their scientific name 'apoda' which means 'no feet'.

Dimensions:
object height: 1200mm
object depth: 500mm
object width: 280mm
Description: A Palm Cockatoo mounted walking up a stick with crest erect.
WebDescription: This large Australian cockatoo was seized in a raid on a farm in North Yorkshire. The owner had been smuggling rare birds into the UK illegally and was sent to jail. The Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) makes it illegal to trade in these animals. We have 45 other parrots in the collections that were seized from the same farm.

Description: Conical fired clay funerary cone, bearing a stamped hieroglyphic text on its circular face.
WebDescription:
Conical fired clay funerary cone, bearing a stamped hieroglyphic text on its circular face.

Funerary cones were inserted above the doors of private tombs in the Middle and New Kingdoms, with the stamped hieroglyphic text exposed as a frieze.  A funerary cone could bear the name of the tomb owner, or act as a seal to provide protection for the deceased. 
Funerary cones are usually associated with the rock-cut tombs of Thebes, but there are hundreds of cones referring to tombs which have not yet been discovered.

This cone was once in the collection of the famous Egyptologist William Flinders Petrie.  It was donated to Leeds Museums and Galleries in the 1940s.

Description: Canopic jar and lid in light cream stone.  The lid is carved in the shape of a human head with beard, representing the god Imsety (the nose and beard are damaged).  There are some traces of carved hieroglyphic inscription on the body of the jar.
WebDescription: Canopic jar from ancient Egypt in the form of the human-headed god Imsety, one of the four sons of Horus.  The liver of a mummified person would have been placed in this jar and left in the tomb with the body for the afterlife.

Dimensions:
object width (base): 56mm
object height: 203mm
object diameter (rim): 86mm
Description: Drilled and carved barrel shaped stone vessel with two stubby countersunk handles, flat rim, ancient repair on one side, patch now missing but three drilled holes and remains of three others clearly visible. Flat base. Drill marks inside vessel very notic
WebDescription:
Two-handled basalt jar, probably from a tomb in Thebes.

Stoneware production was highly skilled work and stone vessels like this one were produced for elite burials.

Description: Hedgehog shaped slate cosmetic palette, pierced in the top for suspension.
WebDescription:
Hedgehog-shaped cosmetic palette with a small hole for suspension.

Cosmetic palettes were used to grind and mix make-up paste using minerals, water and fat.  Minerals such as malachite or galena were ground into powder and applied around the eyes.

Dimensions:
object width (max): 48mm
object height: 212mm
object depth (max): 40mm
Description: Wooden shabti painted in red and black, some of black paint appears blue in places. Panel of hieroglyphs on front runs from waist to base. Nose slightly damaged and front of base missing. Cracked in places. Hieroglyphic inscription reads: "Words to be spo
WebDescription:
Wooden shabti painted in red and black. A panel of hieroglyphs on the front runs from the waist to the base.  The hieroglyphs read "Words to be spoken by the god Osiris, Lord of eternity, Lord...".

Burial chambers in ancient Egypt were filled with small models of workers like this one.  It was believed they would work for the tomb owner in the afterlife.   Rich people could be buried with a different shabti for every day of the year.
This particular shabti was collected in 1864.

Description: Wooden shabti with hieroglyphic inscription. Chipped right side of feet, dark deposit around neck and running down front of body. Arms crossed, right over left. Hands are clenched but without implements. Inscription in six horizontal registers around lowe
WebDescription:
Shabti with hieroglyphic inscriptions and two cartouches, one of them possibly of the pharaoh Seti I.

Burial chambers in ancient Egypt were filled with small models of workers like this one. It was believed they would work for the tomb owner in the afterlife.   Rich people could be buried with a different shabti for every day of the year.

Dimensions:
object weight: 10 kg
object length: 1830mm
object width (max): 430mm
object height (max): 210mm
Description:
Inner coffin lid of the mummy Nesyamun in the form of a figure wearing a wig with crossed hand, with a central strip of heiroglyphs (the foot has been roughly trimmed).
The background of the coffin has been painted black (modern), but the top depicts sce
WebDescription:
Inner coffin lid or mummy cover of the Egyptian priest Nesyamun.

This lid was placed directly over the mummy, underneath the outer coffin lid.  It was made of wood but was damaged in the 1942 air raid.  Its black colour is probably modern as early drawings and descriptions indicate it was white.

There once would have been a beard on the face and amulets held in the crossed hands, but these have snapped off.  The paintings across the coffin lid depict a range of Egyptian gods, goddesses and sacred symbols.  Of note is the winged scarab beetle holding the sun disk (across the chest), and the goddess Nut extending her protective winged arms (below the crossed arms).

Dimensions:
object weight: 21.7 kg
object length: 1950mm
object width (max): 590mm
object height (max): 300mm
Description:
Outer coffin of the mummy Nesyamun in the form of a figure wearing a wig with crossed hands, and painted with scenes from the Book of the Dead. 
The coffin is made of wood covered with gypsum plaster, paint and probably varnish.  The back of the coffin i
WebDescription:
Outer coffin of the Egyptian mummy Nesyamun.

Nesyamun's coffin is the only Egyptian coffin in the world securely dated to the 20th Dynasty (to the reign of Ramesses XI).  His coffin was made especially for him showing he was a man of high rank (coffins for less important people were bought ready made with blank spaces left for their name).  This type of coffin comes from the cemeteries of Thebes and are usually associated with the priests of Amun.  Each person may have chosen their own decoration, perhaps from a range of designs.

The coffin was made of wood covered with gypsum plaster and then painted and probably varnished.  The back of the coffin was left undecorated, indicating that it was intended to lie on the floor facing upwards.  The inside was painted black.  The hands of the figure on the coffin lid would have originally held amulets, probably the tyet-knot and djed-pillar, representing Isis and Osiris, or short wands.  The face would also have had a short beard. These features have since been broken off.

Six scenes on the front of the coffin show Nesyamun making offerings to various deities, sometimes wearing a wig and sometimes with a shaven head.  The lower part of the coffin shows the gods associated with death and funerals.  The texts contain prayers to the gods and goddesses asking for success in the afterlife and contact with the gods.  The texts were written by one person in Middle Egyptian.  

Examples of coffin text:

Nesyamun requests 'bread for my body, breath for my nose, burial in the True Place, water for my soul, and onions at my neck the day of going round the walls'.  This relates to the procession during the festival of Sokar celebrating death .  Onions have often been found in mummy coffins or lists of offerings.

'Recitation by the revered one before Nephthys, sister of god, mistress of the west:  May she give all good and pure things to the Osiris, god's-father, scribe of the temple of Montu, lord of Thebes, Nesyamun, true-of-voice'. 

'May Nut stretch out her arms over my face, in this her name of the one who stretches out both arms, driving away darkness so she may make brightness arise in every place where I shall be on earth and in the cemetery.'

Description: Pipe made from a perforated sheep bone, with an air hole and two stops in the top and one stop underneath.  The mouth end has been mended and a modern filling has been inserted so that the pipe can be played.
WebDescription: This pipe was found associated with an Iron Age burial on Seaty Hill, Malham Moor, during exavations in the 1950s.  It is one of the earliest examples of a three-holed bone whistle in the country.  The teeth marks indicate that the pipe was held between the teeth and played with either one or two hands.  Music played on the Malham pipe was recorded by the University of Leeds Phonetics Department and can be heard in The Leeds Story gallery in Leeds City Museum.

Description: Buff ware askos in the form of a bull with four short legs.  The rim protrudes from the middle of the bull's back and a curved handle adjoins the rim and the rear of the bull.  Some surviving striped and cross-hatch decoration in black on the body and rim
WebDescription:
Cypriot pottery vessel called an askos in the form of a bull.

Askoi were used to pour small quantities of liquid, such as oil.  They were sometimes made in the shapes of animals.  It is thought that they derive from containers originally made of animal skins or organs.

Description:
Milestone carved at opposite ends with two inscriptions (red infill is modern).  The insciptions read:

IMP C G M Q DECIO P F AVG ET G M Q ETRVSCO CAESAR

'For the Imperator Caesar Gaius Messius Quintus [Traianus] Decius [Pius Felix Invictus] Augustus
WebDescription: Milestones were set up at the road side and were used as signposts and distance indicators to other Roman settlements.  This example from Castleford, West Yorkshire, reads 'twenty-two thousand paces to Eburacum' (York).  When the milestone was first erected it was inscribed with the name and titles of Emperor Decius Traianus (249-251 AD), but after his death it was turned over and reinscribed at the other end with the names and titles of his successors Vibius Gallus and Vibius Volusianus (251-253 AD).

Description:
Fairly worn stone altar inscribed: 
Deae Brigan(tiae)/d(onum) Cinge/tissa p(osuit).  
The altar is dedicated to the goddess Brigantia by Cingetissa.
WebDescription: This altar is inscribed with a dedication to the goddess Brigantia by Cingetissa.  Brigantia was a native goddess of the Iron Age Brigantes tribe who inhabited a large part of northern England.  Brigantia was later adopted by the Romans who associated her with Victory or Minerva.  A variety of religions were practised in Roman Britain and altars were frequently dedicated by individuals and set up in temples or as roadside shrines.

Description: Circular altar made in white marble, decorated with ox heads, fillets, festoons and grapes. It is hollowed out and inscribed in Greek with a dedication by the board of agoranomoi to Aphrodite Timuchos.
WebDescription:
Circular carved altar showing ox-heads with fruit and corn.  

This altar is hollowed out and was used as the top of a well; grooves in the rim of the marble caused by the rope are still visible. It is inscribed in Greek with a dedication by the board of Agoranomoi to Aphrodite Timuchos.

Description: Broken white marble stele. The main face is inscribed with text in Greek referring to a dispute between the islands of Paros and Naxos. The stele is broken at the top and on the left.
WebDescription:
This inscribed stele documents a dispute between two islands in the Aegean Sea, Paros and Naxos.  The inscription itself was found on the island of Delos where representatives from Paros and Naxos came together at the court of Eretrian dikasts (judges).  

The earlier content of the settlement is lost, but what is left of the inscription translates as follows:

The settlement is now finally made
All further action between individuals barred, in respect of anything that arises out of the disputes now settled between the two cities
All action barred as against Naxos by Paros
All action barred as against Paros by Naxos
No claim of individuals against either city allowed
Nor claim against any individual by either city
The court recommends the Parians to sacrifice an ox to Dionysus the god of Naxos
Penalties for the breach of this settlement on the part of city or individual
The date of the settlement in Eretrian, Naxian, and Parian reckoning
The Eretrians to keep an official copy of this settlement, and to forward sealed copies to the cities concerned
The representatives from Paros and Naxos are to convey to their respective cities the copy of this settlement

We do not know what the dispute was about but it may have been over something like fishing or trading rights - commerce was vitally important to the maritime states of Greece.  Paros appears to have been the victim, with Naxos having to pay a fine to Paros and Paros being ordered to spend some of the payment on sacrificing an ox to the Naxian god Dionysus.  But whatever the dispute was about, it was certainly temporary; heavy fines are threatened in the case of the settlement being broken by either party.

Description: Tombstone of Laedicus made in white marble, showing Agron and his son bidding farewell to the deceased (seated). They are framed by an arch on columns, with a triangular pediment above and an inscription in Greek below.
WebDescription:
Tombstone of Laedicus made in white marble, showing Agron and his son bidding farewell to the deceased (seated). They are framed by an arch on columns, with a triangular pediment above and an inscription in Greek below.

Greek gravestones often depicted the deceased with people they knew in life.

Description: Amphora with with black-figure ware decoration across the body of men carrying spears and two sphinxes.  The two handles, base and rim are entirely black, there is a thick black band running below the figures, and there are black geometric designs on the
WebDescription:
A Greek black-figure ware amphora decorated with figures and sphinxes.
Black-figure ware was popular in Greece by about 600 BC, with major potteries in Sparta, Athens and eastern Greece.  The pots were made of iron-rich clay which turned red when fired.  The design was sketched onto the pot in outline then painted with a refined clay paint.  The pot would be fired twice, first to oxidise it (turning it red), and then to a higher temperature with no oxygen in the kiln (turning it black).  As the pot cooled the colour of the pot returned to red, while the sintered paint remained black.

Description: Sherd of pinkish brown unglazed ware, with Meroitic inscription in black ink. Ghost of narrow rectangular label on inside of sherd.
WebDescription:
Sherd of pinkish brown unglazed pottery with a faint Meroitic inscription in black ink.  Meroitic was the language spoken in the Kingdom of Kush (Sudan). The language has yet to be fully deciphered.

Ceramic pot sherds with inscriptions on them are called ostraca (from the Greek 'ostrakon' meaning 'shell'). Ostraca were used by many civilisations, usually for tax receipts and accounts or for short notes (sometimes by pupils).  The word 'ostracism' in the English language is related; the Greeks used ostraca to vote out misbehaving residents so they were effectively 'ostracised'.

Dimensions:
object height: 1550mm
object width: 1550mm
object depth: 155mm
Description: Mosaic of wolf, twins and fig tree, surrounded by a diamond pattern and with plain border. Red, dark blue, white and yellow tesserae are set into a cement base.
WebDescription:
This panel formed the centrepiece of a large mosaic floor constructed in the 4th century A.D in the Roman town of Isurium Brigantum, now Aldborough in North Yorkshire.  The mosaic depicts the figures of Romulus and Remus being suckled by a she-wolf under the fig tree Ruminalis.  
 
Legend has it that these twins, the rightful heirs to the throne, were abandoned in the River Tiber but washed ashore where they were fed by the she-wolf.  Later they were found and raised by a shepherd.  When they were older they restored the rightful King, their Grandfather, to the throne.  They set out to found a new city but during an argument Romulus killed Remus.  Romulus went on to establish Rome in 753 B.C.
The mosaic was discovered by Mr Lonsdale, a local stone mason, in 1840 and purchased by the museum in 1863.

Dimensions:
object height: 410mm
object width: 345mm
object depth: 205mm
object weight: 36.9 kg
Description:
Fragment of a carved cross from Leeds Parish Church.
Side 1 (broad): A torso of a frontal figure expressed as stylised looping curves above a long plain under-robe.  Cable moulding is visible on both edges.
Side 2 (narrow): Cable moulding on both edges,
WebDescription:
Fragment of an Anglo-Saxon carved stone cross shaft found during renovations of Leeds Parish Church in 1838.  This fragment and several others were discovered built into the church tower.  Six stone fragments, including this one, were donated to the museum of the Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society in 1856.  An entire pillar was also reconstructed out of other stone fragments, and this cross still stands in Leeds Parish Church.
One of the panels of this particular cross fragment depicts a figure wearing m-shaped drapery, with what appears to be the claws of a bird on their shoulder. This figure has been interpreted as St. John the Evangelist. 
These crosses would have been used as memorials to mark the burials of important people in Leeds, a settlement of some importance in the 9th-10th centuries.

Dimensions:
object height: 360mm
object width: 360mm
object depth: 220mm
object weight: 52.4 kg
Description:
Fragment of a carved cross from Leeds Parish Church, with three of the four carved sides surviving.
Side 1 (broad): Weland's flying machine.  Weland's legs are clearly shown strapped into the machine, with the tail between his legs.  The lower half of on
WebDescription:
Fragment of an Anglo-Saxon carved stone cross shaft found during renovations of Leeds Parish Church in 1838.  This fragment and several others were discovered built into the church tower.  Six stone fragments, including this one, were donated to the museum of the Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society in 1856.  An entire pillar was also reconstructed out of other stone fragments, and this cross still stands in Leeds Parish Church.
One of the panels of this particular cross fragment depicts the Viking folk-hero Weland in his flying machine, a good example of older traditions surviving in a Christian context.  
These crosses would have been used as memorials to mark the burials of important people in Leeds, a settlement of some importance in the 9th-10th centuries.

Dimensions:
object length: 84mm
object width (cutting edge): 41mm
object thickness: 17mm
object weight: 93.4gm
Description: Green, highly polished, pointed butt, elliptical cross-section. Polished. Flake scar on one face.
WebDescription:
This is a fine example of a Neolithic jadeite axe head. Around 130 examples of these axe heads are known from Britain and Ireland.  We have two in the Leeds collection, although we don't know where they were found.
The Neolithic quarries used to make these axe heads were in high-altitude locations in the Italian Alps at Monte Viso and Monte Beigua.  Associated charcoal samples indicate that the quarries may have been in use from as early as 5200 BC, on a seasonal basis.  
Jade axe heads may have arrived in the UK from France in packages of Neolithic goods associated with the farming lifestyle. They seem to have been so special that occasionally they were broken and shared around. Some axe heads would have already been old when they arrived here.

Description: Paper impression of the bust of Amenhotep III (left-facing) wearing the Blue Crown or khepresh war helmet with guardian cobra, from the tomb chapel of Khaemhet.
WebDescription:
Paper impression of the bust of Amenhotep III wearing the Blue Crown or khepresh, from the tomb chapel of Khaemhet. The original stone inscription was cut from the wall in around 1845 and is now in the Berlin Museum.

This is one of 24 paper impressions donated by Mr. George Morley (1802-1867) of the Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society, who acquired them while travelling in Egypt.  They were made in the 1840s and show carved stone hieroglyphs and reliefs from the walls of mortuary chapels in Thebes.  Many of the original reliefs have since been destroyed.

Description: Two-handled flask or ampulla of buff coloured fabric with relief moulded scene of St Menas standing facing in between two camels, two crosses on either side of St Menas' head and pellets around outer edge of pot. Crudely restored handles and neck.
WebDescription: Oil flask with a moulded scene of St Menas standing between two camels.  Flasks like this were used by pilgrims to carry oil back from the shrine of St. Menas at Abu Mena, Egypt.  St. Menas was an Egyptian soldier in the Roman army who was martyred because he refused to denounce his Christian faith.

Dimensions:
object height: 625mm
object width (at shoulders): 590mm
object width (at base): 610mm
object depth: 485mm
object circumference (waist): 1240mm
object weight: 324 kg
Description: Sculpted marble torso of a cavalryman wearing a plain lorica (body armour or cuirass), and a paludamentum (military cloak). He is also wearing a narrow sword-belt and a broad sash with tasselled ends tied in front in a knot. The right arm is broken off at
WebDescription:
Sculpted marble torso of a cavalryman, thought to be a copy of an original bronze statue of Alexander the Great.  The torso is part of the Lanuvium marbles, a group of life-size torsos of Roman cavalrymen and horses dating to the 1st century BC. They were discovered in the ancient town of Lanuvium, 20 miles from Rome, in the 1880s. There would have been at least nine statues in the sculptural group, although we don?t know how they originally stood. They may have been commissioned to commemorate the victory of the Roman general Lucullus in Asia Minor in the Second Mithridatic War, and erected in Lanuvium, his home town.
The marbles were brought to Leeds by Sir John Savile Lumley (later Lord Savile), who carried out excavations at various sites in Italy, including Lanuvium, while he was British Ambassador to Rome. He divided the archive of finds between Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society and the British Museum in London in 1896.

Description: Fragment of a horse statue in white marble.  The fragment is a muzzle with the veins above the nostrils carefully indicated.  The tongue and lower jaw were found broken but repaired and reattached.  There are two dowel-holes for a bit in the base of the t
WebDescription:
Detailed muzzle fragment from a marble horses head with two dowel-holes for a bit in the base of the tongue and three for the bridle.

This was found as part of a larger group of cavalrymen and horse statues in Lanuvium, near Rome.  Excavations were carried out at Lanuvium in the 1880s, directed by Sir John Savile Lumley (later Lord Savile).  Before his death he arranged that the objects he recovered should be divided between the British Museum and Leeds City Museum.

Description: This textile fragment is likely to originally have formed part of a tunic.  It is roughly rectangular in shape; three of its edges are cut.  It is woollen, and tapestry woven.  It has a pattern of purple decorated stripes.  There are three of these purple
WebDescription: This textile fragment is likely to originally have formed part of a tunic.  It is roughly rectangular in shape; three of its edges are cut.  It is woollen, and tapestry woven.  It has a pattern of purple decorated stripes.  There are three of these purple stripes, which alternate with slightly narrower grey stripes.  The purple stripe in the centre has a pattern of V shapes.  The other stripes, including the grey, are patterned with concentric circles.  All of the patterning is created by contrasting coloured pattern areas with the plain undyed ground fabric.

Display Name: Archaeology Unit, West Yorkshire Metropolitan County Council
Alpha Sort: Archaeology Unit, West Yorkshire Metropolitan County Council
Dimensions:
object height: 1820mm
object width: 1830mm
object depth: 90mm
Description: Piece of reconstructed painted ceiling plaster from the Romano-British villa at Dalton Parlours. The painting depicts 7 interlocking octagons containing roundels on a white ground. Both octagons and roundels are formed by broad bands of colours graded so
WebDescription:
This Romano-British painted ceiling plaster was excavated from Dalton Parlours Roman villa near Collingham in West Yorkshire.  It has been reconstructed from hundreds of smaller fragments.  

Dalton Parlours was occupied between c.200 and 375 AD and is the best excavated Roman villa in West Yorkshire.  Roman villas were often luxurious with mosaic floors, painted plaster walls, and central heating. 

Most of the archive from the Dalton Parlours excavations was deposited with Leeds Museums and Galleries in the 1970s.

Description:
Stone inscribed with the ten commandments in Samaritan script.  Only part of the stone survives as it was broken in the 14th century.
It was originally built into a wall or alcove containing the Ark of the Law of the Samaritan at Nablus, biblical city of
WebDescription:
This decalogue stone was carved almost 2,000 years ago.  It was originally built into a wall, either on or near the doorpost, of a Samaritan synagogue in Nablus, Palestine.  

The Samaritan script on the stone lists the Ten Commandments.  Parts of the first and last sections of each is missing because the stone was broken, probably in the 14th century.  In translation it reads:

1??. to hallow it
2??..and thy mother
3??..commit adultery thou shalt not
4??..testify against thy neighbour??.
5??..covet the house of???
6??..covet the wife of thy neighbour
7  There an altar to Yahweh (from Dt. ch.27, v.5).
8  And thou shalt write on the stones (from Dt. ch.27, v.8).
9  this law plainly (from Dt. ch.27 v.8).
10 Law Moses commanded to us (from Dt. ch.33, v.4).

The stone was discovered around 1856 by a group of Samaritan workmen digging in the garden of a ruined mosque in Nablus.  It was then secretly carried to the house of their leader, Sheik Yakob esh Shellaby.

About this time the local tax collector stole all the tax they had paid, leaving them to pay their enormous tax bill for a second time.  They were unable to do this, with the result that a governor threw the Sheik into jail, where he was tortured by having the soles of his feet beaten with sticks.

Fortunately the British Consul was able to raise funds in London to pay the tax, and secure the Sheik's release.  In 1861 the Rev. Joseph Hammond of Leeds stayed with the Sheik while on a tour of the Holy Land.  The Sheik presented him with the Ten-Commandments stone for permanent protection and preservation in the Leeds Museum collection.  The stone arrived in Leeds in 1862, and 12 years later the Sheik came to Leeds to see his gift, and to tell the story of its discovery to the Museum staff.

Description: An unusually large, complete gold finger ring with lozenge-shaped, stepped bezel. It is formed by a large lozenge, surmounted by two consecutively smaller lozenges, the upper of which in turn carries an oval garnet in a dog-tooth setting that is framed by
WebDescription:
A stunning gold finger ring with lozenge-shaped bezel set with a garnet gem. This ring forms the centrepiece of the West Yorkshire Hoard, a group of seven spectacular objects found by a metal detectorist in the Leeds area in 2008-2009.  The objects in the hoard range in date from 7th to 11th centuries, and are examples of the highest quality Anglo-Saxon workmanship.  
This ring is in near perfect condition and dates to the 10th century.  Anglo-Saxon pieces of such high quality are extremely rare; it was clearly made to be displayed as a sign of great wealth and status

Description: A very attractive and complete ring with filigree decoration, in excellent condition.  Two panels of six filigree scrolls are each separated by a fine filigree line bisecting the bezel.  Gold pellets sit in the centre of each scroll and in some of the ang
WebDescription:
A complete gold finger ring with filigree decoration. This ring is part of the West Yorkshire Hoard, a group of seven spectacular objects found in the Leeds area in 2008-2009.  The objects in the hoard range in date from 7th to 11th centuries, and are examples of the highest quality Anglo-Saxon workmanship. 
This ring dates to the 10th century and is in excellent condition.

Description: A rich and heavy complete gold ring with four enlarged, oval sections separated by groups of four ridges.  Each enlarged section carries a design on nielloed background.  These are two different floral motifs, one crouched animal and another, heavily worn
WebDescription:
A complete, heavy gold finger ring with four oval sections depicting flower and animal motifs. This ring is part of the West Yorkshire Hoard, a group of seven spectacular objects found in the Leeds area in 2008-2009.  The objects in the hoard range in date from 7th to 11th centuries, and are examples of the highest quality Anglo-Saxon workmanship. 
This ring dates to the 9th century and is different in style to the other rings in the hoard.

Description: An unusually large gold ring with a round bezel and filigree and granular decoration.  The ring is complete and in excellent condition.  On the bezel, inside two beaded frames and one upright frame, follow short sections of wire imitating a twisted cable
WebDescription:
A very large and stunningly beautiful gold finger ring with a round bezel and intricate filigree and granular decoration. This ring is part of the West Yorkshire Hoard, a group of seven spectacular objects found in the Leeds area in 2008-2009.  The objects in the hoard range in date from 7th to 11th centuries, and are examples of the highest quality Anglo-Saxon workmanship.
This ring dates to the 10th century and is in excellent condition.  Interestingly the ring rattles when moved, like something is loose inside, but we have no idea what.

Description: A gold fragment from a once-fine brooch, with elaborate cloisonn cells once containing garnet inlays.  One side of the triangular fragment is formed by the beaded rim and another looks like it was torn off the original object.  The third side was cut in
WebDescription:
A fragment of a gold booch with cloisonne cells.  This brooch fragment is part of the West Yorkshire Hoard, a group of seven spectacular objects found in the Leeds area in 2008-2009.  The objects in the hoard range in date from 7th to 11th centuries, and are examples of the highest quality Anglo-Saxon workmanship.
This brooch fragment dates to the 7th century and is the oldest object in the hoard.  When it was complete it would have been stunning, with garnets set into all the cells, but the brooch was hacked into pieces and the garnets removed at some point before burial.

Description: A gold ingot (hack gold), cut down in size in antiquity to probably half its original size.  The underside shows impressions from the open-top mould, and the criss-cross pattern on the top is a result of the cooling of the metal, which leads to the format
WebDescription:
A piece of hack gold or gold ingot.  This ingot fragment is part of the West Yorkshire Hoard, a group of seven spectacular objects found in the Leeds area in 2008-2009.  The objects in the hoard range in date from 7th to 11th centuries, and are examples of the highest quality Anglo-Saxon workmanship.
The latest object in the hoard, the ingot dates to the Viking period (late 9th to 11th centuries).  The ingot had been cut down to about half its original size at some point before burial, probably to use as currency.

Description: A flat circular lead spindle whorl with a central perforation.  A small notch is visible on one side.
WebDescription:
A flat lead spindle whorl with a central hole.  This spindle whorl is part of the West Yorkshire Hoard, a group of seven spectacular objects found in the Leeds area in 2008-2009.  The objects in the hoard range in date from 7th to 11th centuries, and most are examples of the highest quality Anglo-Saxon workmanship.
This spindle whorl would have been used to weight a spindle in order to spin wool into threads (which would later be woven into cloth).  It seems out of place in the West Yorkshire Hoard, the only domestic lead item surrounded by stunning pieces of gold jewellery.  It was, however, important enough to be buried with the gold for safekeeping.

Description: first instantaneous shutter made in Leeds in 1875,  invented by Mr A.A. Pearson
WebDescription: This device was the first instantaneous shutter for use in photography.  It was invented by Arthur Pearson of Leeds in 1875.

Description: painted wooden police truncheon or baton, with  crown and "WIVR" (William IV)
WebDescription: This painted police truncheon has the royal monogram WIVR which stands for King William IV (Queen Victoria's uncle).  It dates from about the time that Leeds City Police were established in 1836.

Description: metal bell with strap, which was formerly attached  to collar of horse of last one-horse tram which ran to Leeds
WebDescription: This bell is from the collar of the last horse to pull at tram in Leeds. The first horse-drawn tram was introduced in 1873.  Electric trams began to be introduced from 1891 and had replaced horse-drawn trams by the 1900s

Description: pencil and watercolour view of Leeds "Leeds from Rope Hill circa 1840", by the French artist Alph. Dousseau, description in French inscribed on reverse
WebDescription:
This pencil and watercolour view of Leeds is titled "Leeds from Rope Hill circa 1840" and is by the French artist Alph. Dousseau.

It shows the industrial quarter from the south.  In the centre foreground is the engine house for the Middleton Railway, which can be seen winding away to the left behind the Leeds Pottery.  Other features, numbered along the top margin by the artist, include
1. St Pauls, Park Square; 2 the Leeds Pottery; 3 Christ Church, Meadow Lane; 4 Pottery; 5 Holy Trinity, Boar Lane; 6 Woodhouse Methodist Chapel; 7 Hunslet Crown Glass Manufactory, 8 Hunslet.

Description: creamware jar, cylindrical, with lid; painted in  brown "Finest Mustard, / sold by / S. Glover,  Druggist / Leeds"
WebDescription: This creamware mustard jar was made by Leeds Pottery for Samuel Glover who is listed as a "druggist"  in local trade directories from 1807 to 1817 with addresses around the market place and Shambles.

Description: creamware mug, transfer printed in black with  green painted rim, images of man at loom, Leeds sheep (fleece) motif and barge horse, motto "Long Live the  King and Queen / Prosperity to the Nation /  Success to the Woollen Manufactury / Likewise the  Navi
WebDescription: This creamware mug is unmarked, but was probably made by Leeds Pottery.  It is decorated with images relating to the Leeds wool trade including a weaver at his loom, the Leeds fleece motif and a canal barge horse. The motto "Long Live the  King and Queen / Prosperity to the Nation / Success to the Woollen Manufactury / Likewise the  Navigation" makes reference to the canal run by the Aire and Calder Navigation Company which linked Leeds to the sea port at Hull and from there to markets across Europe.

WebDescription:
This handbill advertised the route of the True Briton Coach which could travel from Liverpool to Hull in a day, via Manchester and Leeds.  This could only be achieved by changing horses at each stop.  In Leeds the coach called in at the Bull and Mouth
 "Unequalled Travelling to and  from Liverpool and Hull in one day by Manchester  and Leeds  - The True Briton Coach".  The coach called in at the Bull and Mouth coaching inn on the east side of Briggate.  This was the busiest coaching inn in Leeds.

WebDescription: This ticket granted admission to Leeds Town Hall for the opening ceremony conducted by Queen Victoria on Tuesday 7th September 1858.  The Mayor of Leeds at the time was Peter Fairbairn who was granted a knighthood by the Queen during her visit.

Description: handbill, anti-Liberal election poster, "Leeds June 9th 1826 - To the  Freeholders of the County of York..", Mr. Marshall  putting himself up for election (represents Tory election propaganda against Marshall)
WebDescription: This election handbill was published by the Tory opponents of John Marshall in 1826, when he was standing for parliament as one of the Liberal candidates for the two Yorkshire seats.  This was before the 1832 Reform Act gave Leeds its own member of parliament.  It accuses Marshall of  being a Unitarian  (which is equated with atheism) and of investing money abroad (thus not being patriotic).  Above all he is criticised for being a manufacturer and  not a land-owner.  John Marshall was the owner of a pioneering flax mill in Holbeck.  Despite the propoganda, Marshall was elected as a Liberal MP in 1826 and served until 1830.

Title Sort: Park Row at Night by Gas Light
Dimensions:
object (canvas): 460 x 300mm
object height (frame): 497mm
object width (frame): 648mm
Description:
Wilfred Jenkins, Park Row at Night by Gas Light, oil  on canvas, signed, framed, not glazed, with a pair  (E.1952.17.B) of Boar Lane
see notes
WebDescription:
This painting by Wilfred Jenkins shows "Park Row at Night by Gas Light".

Park Row was one of the finest streets of commercial buildings to be found in Victorian England, but its most important features have now disappeared.  The City museum on the right, remodelled in the Italian Renaissance style in 1861-2 was destroyed by bombing in 1941, St Anne's Church on 1838 was removed around 1900 for road widening, while Beckett's bank to the right, a magnificent Venetian Gothic structure designed by Sir George Gilbert Scott in 1862, was destroyed by the National Westminster Bank in 1964.

The artist Wilfred Jenkins was one of several local artists who imitated the style of Atkinson Grimshaw.

Wilfred Jenkins, Boar Lane at Night , oil  on canvas, signed, framed, not glazed, with a pair  (E.1952.17.A) of Park Row at Night by Gas Light 
Junction with Bishopsgate Street, Yorkshire Banking Co. building on right. Building on left with the clock, ar
WebDescription:
This oil painting shows "Boar Lane at Night". 

The pictures shows the junction with Bishopsgate Street, Yorkshire Banking Co. building on right. Building on left with the clock, are the Royal Exchange Chambers, home of the Royal Society for Prevention of Accidents and other agencies (now demolished).

The artist Wilfred Jenkins was one of several local artists who imitated the style of Atkinson Grimshaw.

Description: green glass bottle, embossed, upside down, "THO CHORLEY / SURGEON / LEEDS / 1822"
WebDescription: This wine bottle was made for Thomas Chorley, who was a prominent Leeds surgeon.  He is listed in local directories from 1797 to 1830.  Thomas Chorley was the surgeon who helped convict the "Yorkshire Witch" Mary Bateman of the murder of Rebecca Perigo, proving that she had been poisoned and that a bottle found in Mary's possession and the pudding she made for Rebecca contained run, oatmeal and arsenic.

Description:
Long case clock, ornate brass dial, Morgan Lowry,  Leeds, c1730; walnut case; year going and striking  movement; two 48lb weights  These are extremely rare as the strike is required  to make 56,940 blows to the bell on one winding.

Morgan Lowry was a c
WebDescription:
This remarkable long case clock was made by Morgan Lowry of Leeds in about 1730.  Unlike most clocks which could only run for eight days, this clock was made to run for a year and is therefore extremely rare.  It has very heavy weights (48 lb) and the strike is required  to make 56,940 blows to the bell on one winding.

Morgan Lowry worked in Briggate and Boar Lane.  In 1725 a notice in the Leeds Mercury regarding the sale of some houses advises "enquiry of Morgan Lowry, clockmaker, over against Boar Lane in Leeds."  In 1731 he was paid 13/- for work on St John's clock.  He died in Leeds in 1757.

Arthur Aaron was shot down over Italy in 1943 and was awarded the Victoria Cross posthumously. Arthur Aaron was the only Leeds citizen awarded the VC during the 1939-1945 War.

Arthur Aaron died following the raid, but was awarded a posthumous Victoria Cross for his bravery.  Arthur Aaron was the only Leeds citizen awarded the VC during the 1939-1945 War.

WebDescription: This violin was made by the Leeds instrument-maker Mark William Dearlove who had his shop on Briggate.  In 1851 he made a quartet of miniature musical instruments which he exhibited at the Great Exhibition in London.

Description: carved oval wooden plaque, cameo style, gilded;  said to have come from Leeds Moot Hall
WebDescription: This carved wooden plaque is  said to have been part of the panelleing in Leeds Moot Hall.  The Moot Hall was originally built in 1615 as a town hall and court house and stood in the middle of Briggate.  This panel probably dates from when the hall was rebuilt in 1710-1711.  As a result of the 1824 Improvement Act, the Moot Hall was demolished in 1825 to widen Briggate.  All the court and council proceedings moved to the new Court House on Park Row.

Description: large cream glazed mug, black transfer printed  portrait and scenes "RICHARD OASTLER, THE FRIEND  OF THE POOR"
WebDescription: This mug commemorates the life and work of Richard Oastler, known as "The Factory King" because of his campaigns against the exploitation of children in factories.  Oastler's main achievement was a law limiting the working day for children to ten hours, which was enacted in 1847.  Oastler was born in St Peter's Square, Leeds and  buried in St. Stephen's Church, Kirkstall.

WebDescription:
This printed invitation from drawing by Kester of the  Leeds Savage Club reads "Come Under  De Ole Umbrella on the Very Night of Friday on  The Very Fifth of February To Do Honor To  Savages Barber, Herbert Holt & Jefferson At  Savage Jarge Barber's Hospitablery Chapel Lane  Meanwood .."
The Leeds Savage Club was a social club of artists, writers, musicians and journalists which was formed in 1898 and disbanded in 1912. The meetings were informal, with a north-American ?Indian? theme and were known as pow-wows, presided over by a ?chief? in full head-dress.

The Leeds Savage Club was a social club of artists, writers, musicians and journalists which was formed in 1898 and disbanded in 1912. The meetings were informal, with a north-American ?Indian? theme and were known as pow-wows, presided over by a ?chief? in full head-dress.

Description: booklet with loose brown cover title :  'Extraordinary Life and Character of Mary Bateman,  the Yorkshire witch ...', printed by Baines of  Leeds
WebDescription: This booklet outlining the  "Extraordinary Life and Character of Mary Bateman,  the Yorkshire witch" was published by Edward Baines of Leeds in the year that Mary Bateman was executed (1809). Born near Thirsk, Mary came to Leeds in 1788. Her twenty-year criminal career mostly involved swindling and fraud but she was finally accused of the murder by poisoning of Rachel Perigo, and convicted on the evidence of Leeds surgeon Thomas Chorley. She was hanged at York Castle and her body was take to Leeds General Infirmary.  Her skeleton is now owned by the Thackray Medical Museum.

Description: set of orthopaedic instruments in case (polished  wooden box with hinged lid and brass inlay in  corners and central plaque, engraved "Samuel  Smith, Leeds"; containing 16 implements (1 breast knife, 1 bone scoop, 1 bone drill, 2 gauges, 1 pair skull forc
WebDescription: This set of orthopaedic instruments was owned by Samuel  Smith, a prominent Leeds surgeon. Samuel Smith was  the son of a Leeds banker.  He was appointed surgeon to the Infirmary in February 1849 and served as a surgeon in Leeds for 42 years until 1864.  He was active in 1803 in the Corps of Volunteers and joined Leeds Volunteer Engineers as surgeon in 1861 when he was over 70.  Smith worked with Richard Oastler in the factory movement and gave evidence before the Select Parliamentary Committee on the medical effects of long hours on children.

Description: Framed cross stitch sampler, in memory of a dying  brother, 1858.  Sewn by MARY PARK AGED 10 YEARS  1858 in memory of her brother THOMAS although the  latter seems to be dying rather than dead.  IN MEMORY OF THOMAS PARK.  DEAR PARENTS DO NOT  GRIEVE BUT R
WebDescription:
This cross stitch sampler was sewn by Mary Park aged 10 years in 1858 in memory of her brother Thomas.  The text is ambiguous as to whether Thomas was dying or had already passed away and it is also unclear what his age was.  Child mortality in cities like Leeds at this period was very high (around one in five children died before they were five years old).

The full text reads:
IN MEMORY OF THOMAS PARK.  DEAR PARENTS DO NOT GRIEVE BUT RATHER REJOICE THAT THE HOUR DRAWS NIGH WHEN I SHALL HAVE NO MORE PAIN NO MORE SORROW DEATH TO THE CHRISTIAN IS A FRIEND A MESSENGER OF PEACE.  FROM EARTHLY CARES TO SET HIM FRESS AND BID HIS SORROWS CEASE WITH JOY HE VIEWS IN DEATHS APPROACH THE END OF MORTAL STRIFE DEATH TO THE CHRISTIAN IS THE GATE OF EVERLASTING LIFE.

Description: cream glazed earthenware mug, hand painted flowers  and brown transfer print of cross and "Holbeck  Church / Sunday School"
WebDescription: This mug commemorates Holbeck Church Sunday School.  The Sunday School movement was founded by Robert Raikes in 1780 to encourage education for working class children, many of whom were already at work during the week.  The Education acts of 1870 and 1880 greatly increased the provision of schools and made week-day school attendance compulsary, so Sunday schools could now concentrate more on religious instruction and were no longer relied on to teach basic reading and writing.

WebDescription:
This long stemmed wooden pipe was used for ceremonial purposes by members of the Leeds Savage Club. It is made from briarwood and is unusual as the bowl of the pipe has been carved as the head of a Native American wearing traditional Native American Indian headwear.
The Leeds Savage Club was a social club of artists, writers, musicians and journalists which was formed in 1898 and disbanded in 1912. The meetings were informal, with a north-American ?Indian? theme and were known as pow-wows, presided over by a ?chief? in full head-dress.

Description: The story of Barnbow, Ammunitions factory Leeds, published in 1919
WebDescription:
This booklet tells the story of the Barnbow Munitions Factory at Crossgates, Leeds.
Barnbow was Britain?s premier shell factory between 1915 and 1918 and at the end of hostilities on 11 November 1918, production stopped for the first time. The shell casings were made by the Leeds Forge Company at Armley and then filled at Barnbow.  By 1918 a total of 566,000 tons of finished ammunition had made and dispatched overseas. 

In 1916 the work force numbered 16,000. As the war continued and the death rate on front increased male labour was gradually replaced by female labour until the Barnbow workforce comprised almost 93% women or girls.

Barnbow was also the scene of one of the worst tragedies in the history of the City of Leeds, although it was never reported at the time. 5th December 1916 there was a dreadful explosion that killed 35 women and girls, and many more were injured.

WebDescription: This table-top hand sewing machine is marked PILLINGS PATENT 1866 / NUSSEY & PILLING. LEEDS / THE IMPROVED LITTLE STRANGER.  Nussey and Pilling had premises on Park Lane, Leeds and continued to be listed in local directories until 1901.

Description: large glossy advert for "Venus Soap" on cardboard,  showing lady in pink trimmed underskirt and pink  hat balanced on top of the globe
WebDescription: This colourful advertisement is for "Venus Soap" made by the Leeds firm of Joseph Watson and Sons Ltd.  Founded in 1830 by Joseph Watson, the firm moved in 1861 to a site west of the Canal Basin, between Whitehall Road and the river. This was one of the largest soap works in England, employing around 750 people, and manufacturing six hundred tons of soap a week in 1893. They made brands such as "Watson's Matchless Cleanser" and "Venus Soap". The firm was known as '"Soapy Joe's".

Description: ornamental vase, entwined with a snake and a  squirrel, liberally applied with foliage and  branches and naturalistically painted with  coloured slips on a graduated blue ground; marked  with BF monogram, and signature E. Hammond and  date 1882 incised; B
WebDescription: This highly eccentric ornamental vase, entwined with a snake chasing a squirrel, was made for Wilcock & Co., Leeds by the artist Edward Hammond in 1882.  It is marked  with the BF monogram and number 268.   Burmantofts Faience was made by Wilcock & Co. from about 1880.  The company merged with four other firms to form the Leeds Fireclay Company in 1889 and stopped making art pottery in 1904.

WebDescription: This spectacular Burmantofts pottery stand shaped as a griffin with serpent tail would originally have supported a large bowl on its head.  Burmantofts Faience art pottery was made by Wilcock & Co. from about 1880.  The company merged with four other firms to form the Leeds Fireclay Company in 1889 and stopped making art pottery in 1904.

Description: cylindrical tin labelled "The Genuine Bile Beans"
WebDescription: This tin for "Genuine Bile Beans" was made by C.E. Fulford Ltd. of Leeds. Bile Beans were originally invented and promoted by Charles Edward Fulford (b.1869 in Canada, died in 1906) and Ernest Albert Gilbert (b.1875 in England, died in 1905) and the formula was first devised in 1899 in Australia.  A central distributing depot of the Bile Beans Manufacturing Co. opened in Greek Street, Leeds in 1899.  The company of C.E. Fulford Ltd. are listed in directories from 1908 to 1961 as manufacturers of patent medicines.  Other products included Pep pastilles, Zambuk ointment and Vitapoint hair conditioner.

Description: Handkerchief map as used by servicemen abroad, Mediterranean area; one side printed with map of Cyrenaica numbered "K1" and on reverse a larger scale map of Libya, Algeria etc.  Shows Libya as Italian territory; part of a set covering N. Africa
WebDescription: This silk handkerchief map was produced for use by servicemen, 1941-1944.  One side shows shows the Mediterranean and the reverse shows North Africa, including Libya and Algeria.  Libya is shown as an Italian territory.  Maps of this sort were printed by John Waddington Ltd., Leeds, and sometimes smuggled to prisoners of war inside board games such as Monopoly.

Description: board game, "MONOPOLY"  box: cardboard; lid printed in red and white, with  title; board printed in colour on paper mounted  inside folding black cardboard covers; 28 Property  cards, 16 Community Chest cards, 16 Chance cards,  green plastic houses, red p
WebDescription: This classic edition of the board game "Monopoly" was printed by John Waddington Ltd. of Leeds.  Monopoly was first patented in 1935 by the American Charles Darrow and was published by Parker Bros. Ltd. in the USA.  The American layout featured streets in Atlantic City.  When John Waddington's were offered the game in 1935, the managing director Victor Watson went down to London from Leeds to scout for suitable street names for the British version. John Waddington had started off as a theatrical printer in 1896 and the firm began printing playing cards in 1921.

Description: long poster, printed in red and blue on white  "The City Varieties - Top of Briggate, Leeds.."  Monday March 22nd 1897, including performances by Chevalier Cliquot (sword swallower), Flora Gaunt (male  impersonator), The Grotesque Japanese puzzle Kyoto!,
WebDescription:
This theatre bill poster advertises a show at the Leeds City Varieties on Monday 22nd March 1897.  The theatre was founded in 1865 off the top of Briggate and is still going strong keeping the tradition of Music Hall alive. 
The acts include performances by Chevalier Cliquot (sword swallower), Flora Gaunt (male  impersonator), The Grotesque Japanese puzzle Kyoto!, Quinton Gibson ("the greatest female impersonator in the world"), J. A. Simpson (boy actor vocalist performing "The Auctioneer"), Jonghman (harmonising vocalists), Alma Obrey (Australia's finest character comedienne), T. B. Fayme, and the Three Romas (marvellous athletes).  
The headline act, Chevalier Cliquot was an American whose real name was Fred McLone and could swallow fourteen swords at a time.  He was much admired by Harry Houdini and another act involved swallowing an electric light bulb.
T. B. Fayme was a Leeds-born vocalist and song-writer (real name Tom B. Sharp).
The poster was printed by Alf Cooke, Leeds, who were established in 1866.

Description: oil painting, unframed, 1878; portrait of Mrs  Leonora Cohen (then Leonora Throp) aged 5 years, painted by her father  (d aged 29), propped up in bed suffering from TB  of the spine; short curly hair, dark eyes, blue  and white dress; unfinished
WebDescription: This portrait shows the five-year old Leonora Throp propped up in bed suffering from tuberculosis.  It was painted by her father Canova Throp who died soon after at the age of 29, also from tuberculosis.  Leonora survived and as Mrs Leonora Cohen became a famous militant suffragette and lived to be 105.

Description: wool comber's hand comb, wooden handle with inset  iron bristles for fixing up to the pad, 4 rows of  teeth set through the end of the stock which is  mounted with horn on either side; (identified by  Neil Dowlan as a flax hackling comb)  stamped "W * CRO
WebDescription:
This is a hackling comb, used either in the wool or flax industry.  It is stamped "BRADFORD W. CROOK  1839". 

Hackling refers to the process of cleaning the remaining woody particles and separation of the fibres. This is done by drawing the  fibres through the hackles. Traditionally, there are three sets of hackles that are used to progressively process the fibres.

WebDescription:
This engraved portrait of John Harrison is based an original picture which hung in the Church of St. John the Evangelist, Leeds.  The Church, founded by John Harrison in 1631, still stands and is mainted by the Churches Conservation Trust and is Harrison's burial place.

John Harrison was a wealthy merchant and Alderman of Leeds in 1626. He was a trustee of the Grammar School which he had removed in 1624 to a field between the present Grand Theatre and North Street.  In 1653 he financed Harrison's Hospital (almshouses) built west of his church and provided a new market cross in 1619.  He married Elizabeth Foxcroft in 1603 and moved to a house on the east end of Boar Lane.
According to Ralph Thoresby,  John Harrison was also kind to his cats and made a cutting in his door so that they could come and go at will, and then made a smaller hole for kittens.
Another anecdote about John Harrison is that he was said to have smuggled a tankard or silver coins to Charles I, when the latter was  a prisoner of the Roundhead's at Red Hall, Leeds on his way to be tried in London in 1649.

Description: surgical instrument - steel forceps, THACKRAY / LEEDS ENGLAND
WebDescription: These steel surgical forceps are marked THACKRAY LEEDS ENGLAND.  In 1902 Charles Frederick Thackray (1877-1934) and H.S. Wainwright bought from Samuel Taylor a pharmacy he had established in Leeds in 1862.  In 1905 they bought a sterilizer for dressings.  From 1918 the focus of the company was on surgical instruments.  Initially they made instruments for Lord Moynihan, one of Leeds' most prominent surgeons.

object width (wool - approx): 200 x 140mm
Description: sample of wool from first shipment of Australian  Wool 1807, from Rev. Sam Marsden's flock; unloaded in Armley and stored in Farsley; plus newspaper article and explanatory  letter
WebDescription: This sample of wool wsa from first shipment of Australian Wool to Leeds in 1808.  The wool from Rev. Samuel Marsden's flock and was unloaded in Armley and stored in Farsley. Samuel Marsden was born in Farsley, near Leeds in July 1764, died Australia 1838. In 1793 when he went as a missionary to New South Wales. In that year he married Elizabeth Tristan. Two of their children died tragically, one being thrown off a horse, the other in boiling water in the kitchen. He did much good works amongst the convict society and was celebrated by people such as Wilberforce. He received a gift of 5 Spanish sheep from the King's flock to take to New South Wales, the start of a very profitable trade.

Description: pair of steel framed spectacles in original case,  designed to be worn underneath a gas mask;  c1939-45
WebDescription: This pair of spectacles is adapted for use under a gas mask.  Gas masks had been distributed to every household in Britain in 1939, in response to the fear that chemical weapons might be used against the civilian population.  Fortunately they never needed to be used.

Description: Leeds University blazer, worn by Miss K.  Morehouse, 1930s; striped in colours of the  university (maroon, green and white); badge on  pocket of three metal thread stars on green  background over open book on which is written "Et  Augebitur Scientia" (and
WebDescription:
This Leeds University blazer was worn by Miss K. Morehouse who graduated in the 1930s.  The Yorkshire College became Leeds University in 1904 and the first women graduated there in 1905.  In contrast, women were not awarded degrees at Oxford University until 1920 and at Cambridge not until 1947.

The pocket is emblazoned with the University motto "Et  Augebitur Scientia" beneath which is the Yorkshire  Rose.  The motto means "and science will be increased".
The blazer was supplied by MacGregor & Grant Ltd., 1 Albion Place, Leeds, who advertised themselves in 1934 as ladies & gentlmen's tailors, University outfitters & appointed agents for Burberry productions.

Description: board game, "RECRUITING FOR KITCHENER'S ARMY"  board only; printed in colour on paper mounted  inside folding red cardboard covers; map of the  British Isles overlain with squares; to top left of  the map is the title, and at top right the rules of  the g
WebDescription: This board game "Recruiting for Kitchener's Army" was published by Valentines Games at the start of the First World War.  Earl Kitchener was famous for his rectruiting poster "Your Country Needs You".   The board reflects the concerns at the time that many recruits were not fit for military service.  It contains useful advice such as "Smoker's Heart - Give it up", "Teeth Defective - Dentist", "Drink - Sign the Pledge".

Description: page boy suit in dark blue velvet worn by Mr. F. Jacques as attendant to the first Children's Day Queen in Leeds (1922); the style of the jacket and  breeches is similar to that of traditional male  court dress and was worn with white stockings,  ribboned
WebDescription:
This velvet page-boy outfit was worn F. Jacques who was the page boy attendant to the first Queen of Leeds Children's Day in 1922.  It was hand made by his mother.

Leeds Children's Day was an annual event which was first held in 1920 and led to formation of Leeds Elementary Schools Sports Association and the camp at Ben Rhydding.  The 1921 event was abandoned due to stormy weather and the following year there was a week's delay due to rain before the first Queen Elsie Oldfield was crowned on July 15th.  The Children's Day at Roundhay Park in 1923 raised 2000 for the camp but by 1962 interest was dwindling.  The last Queen was crowned by Ronnie Hilton in 1963.  The events in 1964 were combined with Leeds Printer's Gala and briefly revived again in 1968.

Title Sort: photograph of F. Jaques, Leeds Children's Day
Description: tinted photograph of boy wearing page boy outfit - F. Jacques  was attendant to the first Queen of Leeds Children's Day
WebDescription:
This tinted photograph shows F. Jacques who was the page boy attendant to the first Queen of Leeds Children's Day in 1922.

Leeds Children's Day was an annual event which was first held in 1920 and led to formation of Leeds Elementary Schools Sports Association and the camp at Ben Rhydding.  The 1921 event was abandoned due to stormy weather and the following year there was a week's delay due to rain before the first Queen Elsie Oldfield was crowned on July 15th.  The Children's Day at Roundhay Park in 1923 raised 2000 for the camp but by 1962 interest was dwindling.  The last Queen was crowned by Ronnie Hilton in 1963.  The events in 1964 were combined with Leeds Printer's Gala and briefly revived again in 1968.

Description: small turquoise tin with gold floral motif -  "Health" Chocolate H. Thorne and Co. Ltd'
WebDescription: This small tin is for Thorne's "Health" cocoa. Henry Thorne & Co. Ltd. started in Leeds in 1837 and became a limited company in 1889.  The factory on Lady Lane was demolished in 1972.  Henry Thorne started by selling mustard and chicory but branched out into confectionery, especially cocoa and toffee.  In the 1880s they advertised their product as "Health cocoa".  When they took another firm to court for using the same slogan the verdict was that neither company could prove that cocoa was actually healthy (an early victory for the principle of advertising standards) and the slogan was dropped.

Description: Official key to opening of Art Gallery, Leeds Oct  3rd 1888. Bears gilt monogram, Pearce and Sons,  Goldsmiths, Leeds and Huddersfield. Complete with  original dark plum velvet box.
WebDescription:
This if the ceramonical key from the opening of Art Gallery, Leeds on 3rd October 1888.   The Art Gallery was officially opened by the Mayor Archibald Witham Scarr.

It has the gilt monogram of the makers Pearce and Sons, Goldsmiths, Leeds and Huddersfield.

Description: silver teapot, London hallmark 1836 (leopard;  lion; sovereign; WW & RP & GB"; standing on 4  acanthus feet, flattened swell body decorated with  8 acanthus leaves raised and decorated; handle  with wavy joints and curve finials; spout, base  and top pour
WebDescription:
This silver teapot has the London hallmark for 1836 (leopard; lion; sovereign; WW & RP & GB")

It is inscribed ?Presented to Mr John Yewdall Hunslet Dec 31st  1849" and continued in two lines around hinged lid  "by 32 of his friends, 20 of whom have been  overseers of the poor. As a token of their appreciation and esteem, and more especially as a record of his dauntless untiring and humane exertions during the recent visitation of cholera which in 16 weeks swept away 432 of the inhabitants of this township" "W. Heaton J.P.  Chairman"

John Yewdall was listed as an assistant overseer for Hunslet, Greenwood Street in Leeds Gazetteer 1837.  He listed in the 1845 directory as councillor of Kirkgate Ward, serving on the Watch Committee and Gaol Committee, also as assistant overseer and registrar of births and deaths. He may also be connected to the John Yewdall listed as a tea dealer at 109 Briggate.
In 1849 he is named as assistant overseer and registrar of births and deaths, but no longer a councillor.

A Hunslet diarist wrote in January 1850 '"This year, 1849, that dreadful disease cholera has made most awful ravages in almost every part of England.  The last time it visited our country was 1832, at that time the town of Hunslet suffered very little from it, but at this visitation its ravages were truly alarming, so much so that many of the inhabitants nobly ran away from the town.  May it please the Great and Wise Being, the Father Supreme, that the people of this or any other country may never again be exposed to such an awful calamity."

Medium/Materials: wood; metal, steel; textile, canvas; rubber

Description: SILVER CROSS pram (perambulator); black wood body  with folding black canvas hood and black steel  handle bar; handle white; one black steel frame, 2  larger back wheels, slightly overlapping 2 smaller  front wheels; rubber tyres
WebDescription:
This pram was made by Silver Cross of Guiseley, near Leeds.

In 1877 William Wilson founded the business at Silver Cross Street, Hunslet Leeds. In 1898 a factory dedicated to Silver Cross Prams was built on white House Street and was name the Silver Cross Works.  

By the 1920s and 1930s  Silver Cross Prams became incorporated and had royal approval. Silver Cross supplied the first baby carriage to the Princess Royal.

In 1936 Silver Cross Prams grew too big for its previous factory and moved to an old silk factory in Guiseley where they remained until 2002.

Description: Labour Party women's section banner.  Purple and  gold fringe - faded.  Rust velvet front with  appliqu and embroidered grey silk panel depicting  a crowned female figure looking over one shoulder  and with arms raised to a gold thread sun.  Motto  above
WebDescription: This banner is made from a rectangular piece of red fabric.  It has a wide hem with a channel in it at the top to allow for the insertion of a wooden rod so that the banner could be carried easily.  The rod is decorated with two tassels, one at either side.  The bottom of the banner is decorated with a strip of purple and gold fringing.  On the front an appliqud decorative panel depicts a crowned female figure with her arms raised towards the sun.  A motto is embroidered above, and reads "Named and Nameless all live in us; One and to all they lead us yet, and Hail - Dawn of Liberty Day of Equality".  The banner would have been carried during political marches and demonstrations by female members of the local Labour Party.  The Labour Party was amongst the supporters of the women's suffrage movement, who campaigned for women's right to vote.  Women in the United Kingdom were not awarded equal voting rights until 1928.

Description: Labour Party women's section banner.  Purple and  gold fringe - faded.  Rust velvet front with  appliqu and embroidered grey silk panel depicting  a crowned female figure looking over one shoulder  and with arms raised to a gold thread sun.  Motto  above
WebDescription:
This  appliqu and embroidered banner was made for the Women's Section of the Leeds Labour Party.  The central panel depicts  a crowned female figure looking over one shoulder  and with arms raised to a gold thread sun.  The motto above reads "NAMED AND NAMELESS ALL LIVE IN US; ONE  AND TO ALL THEY LEAD US YET, and HAIL - DAWN OF  LIBERTY DAY OF EQUALITY".   The style is influenced by Arts and Crafts movement socialists such as William Morris and Walter Crane.

However much detailed work has gone into making it, the banner does not hang straight, possibly indicating that its makers had their minds on higher things than sewing accurately.

Dimensions:
object height: 192mm

object depth: 342mm
Description: wood crate advertising 'Watson's matchless  Cleanser The Best Soap', 'Joseph Watson and Sons  Ltd Leeds'
WebDescription: This wooden crate advertises Watson's Matchless Cleanser soap made by the Leeds firm of Joseph Watson & Sons Ltd.  Founded in 1830 by Joseph Watson, the firm moved in 1861 to a site west of the Canal Basin, between Whitehall Road and the river. This was one of the largest soap works in England, employing around 750 people, and manufacturing six hundred tons of soap a week in 1893. They made brands such as "Watson's Matchless Cleanser" and "Venus Soap". The firm was known as '"Soapy Joe's".

Description: large hand bell engraved 'A.R.P', World War 2,  wooden handle, brass
WebDescription: This hand bell was used by an A.R.P. warden (Air Raid Precautions).  The A.R.P. wardens were volunteers and had been recruited from 1937, before hostilities started.  Their job was to protect civilians from the dangers of air raids, including enforcing black-out regulations at night and making sure that everyone reached an air raid shelter in time.

Description: sampler, framed, black painted wood & glazed;  patriotic themes relative to 2nd World War.  depicts 3 armed services & nursing service with  equipment, aeroplane, destroyer ship, tank and  ambulance, & commonwealth symbols (palm trees,  animals - elephant
WebDescription: This cross stitch is worked in cross-stitch on a linen ground and was sewn by Mary Goodison of Leeds in 1942.  It depicts various patriotic motifs relating to the war, including the three armed services and nursing service, equipment, an aeroplane, destroyer ship, tank and ambulance.  There are also symbols of the British empire and dominions (palm trees, elephant, lion, kangaroo & ostrich).

Description:
Suffragettes dress, purple & green & white, with  paper suffragette symbols pasted on; designed and  worn by Mrs Leonora Cohen at the Arts Club Ball, 1914

This dress is made from green fabric in a simple T shape.  It has a V neckline secured at the bac
WebDescription:
This dress is made from green fabric in a simple T shape.  It has a V neckline secured at the back with metal press studs.  Paper suffragette symbols are pasted on to the surface of the fabric.  A large figure of Britannia, the female warrior, is depicted on the front, waving a flag which reads "W.S.P.U.".  Above a piece of paper reads "The Suffragette".  Around the hem, neckline and cuffs small shield shapes, each depicting Britannia waving the W.S.P.U. flag have been attached.  All are printed in the suffragette colours of purple, green and white.  

The W.S.P.U., or Women's Social and Political Union, was a militant branch of the suffrage movement, campaigning for equal voting rights for women.  Established in Manchester in 1903, its founders included the Pankhursts.  They participated in rallies, petitions and held demonstrations.  The W.S.P.U. published a newspaper, called "The Suffragette".  The headline and picture of Britannia pasted to the front of this dress are likely to have come from an edition of this paper, which changed its name to "Britannia" in 1915.  

The dress was made by Leonora Cohen, who wore it to the Leeds Arts Club ball in 1914.  Leonora Cohen was one of the first women in Leeds to campaign for votes for women.

Description: Prison warder doll which was worn pinned to dress of Mrs L Cohen at Arts Club Ball 1914
WebDescription: This doll dressed as a prison warder doll was worn pinned to the dress that Mrs Leonora Cohen wore to the Leeds Arts Club Ball  in 1914.  Leonora Cohen was a Leeds Suffragette and member of the Women's Social and Political Union.  She had served prison sentences at both Holloway Prison and Armley Gaol.

Description: dance card, pink with pencil, Leeds Art Club,  Fancy Dress Club; Monday 23rd Feb (1914) (at which Mrs. L.  Cohen wore her Suffragette dress)
WebDescription: This dance card  is for the  Leeds Art Club, Fancy Dress Ball on  Monday 23rd February 1914 at which Mrs. Leonora Cohen wore her Suffragette dress with a prison warder doll attached.   Leonora Cohen was a  Leeds Suffragette and member of the Women's Social and Political Union.  She had served prison sentences at both Holloway Prison and Armley Gaol.

Description: metal funnel and rubber tube, used to force feed suffragettes c.1912
WebDescription: This metal funnel and rubber tubing shows the method used by prison authorities to try and force feed Suffragette prisoners who were on hunger strike.  The tubing was forced through the nose and throat and often caused internal damage to the women concerned.  Leeds Suffragette Leonora Cohen went on hunger and thirst strike in Armley Gaol in November 1913.

Display Name: Leeds Independent Order of the Ark

Description: plate, "LEEDS INDEPENDENT ORDER OF THE ARK"  pearlware plate with blue transfer design of the  Animals boarding the Ark, and inscription "The  Leeds Independent Order of the Ark"
WebDescription:
This pearlware plate with a blue transfer design of animals boarding Noah's Ark is inscribed "The Leeds Independent Order of the Ark". 

The Leeds Independent Order of the Ark was a Friendly Society founded in about 1835.  A copy of their Minute Book is held in Leeds City Library.
