Description: one pint bottle of "Joshua Tetley & Son LEEDS  CENTENARY ALE", in presentation limited edition  cardboard box;  specially produced by Joshua Tetley, The Brewery,  Leeds
WebDescription: This pint bottle of "Joshua Tetley & Son LEEDS CENTENARY ALE" was sold in a presentation limited edition cardboard box.  It was specially produced by Joshua Tetley, The Brewery,  Leeds to celebrate the 100 years since Leeds became a City in 1893.  It was presented to the mayor, Councillor Keith Loudon.

Medium/Materials: cardboard (box, board, cards)  paper (box, board, money, rules)  plastic (pieces, dice)
Description: board game, "RATRACE"  box: cardboard, lid covered with purple paper; 6  square humorous colour pictures of people, and title  in white and yellow;  board: printed in colour on paper mounted inside  folding yellow cardboard covers; three tracks inside  ea
WebDescription:
The board game "Ratrace" was first published by John Waddington Ltd. of Leeds in 1967.  The game is themed on social success and the aim is for players to move from "working class" to "High Society" by accumulating status symbols, qualifications and society memberships as well as money.
John Waddington started off as a theatrical printer in 1896 and the firm began printing playing cards in 1921.

Title Sort: New and Exact Plan of the Town of Leeds
Dimensions:
object height (frame): 992mm
object width (frame): 1072mm
object (map): 820 x 730mm
Description: "A New and Exact Plan of the Town of Leedes surveyed by John Cossins" line engraving by B Cote in St Paul?s Churchyard, framed and glazed. The plan is edged by the houses of the following; Hugh Sleigh, James Ibbetson, Mr Dixon, Thomas Sawer, Mr. Jacob, Mr
WebDescription:
"A New and Exact Plan of the Town of Leedes surveyed by John Cossins", line engraving by B. Cote, St Paul?s Churchyard, London. 

The plan is edged by the houses of the following Leeds merchants: Hugh Sleigh, James Ibbetson, Mr Dixon, Thomas Sawer, Mr. Jacob, Mr. Douglas, Mr Croft Preston, Alderman Brearey, Rob Dennison, Thomas Dennison, Thomas Lee, Mr Bischoff, Mr. Berkenhold, Alderman Brooke and Mr. Markham.

This was the first Leeds plan to be engraved for sale, and there was no other until 1772.  The work sought prestige and sales by having a humble dedication.  This was to the mayor and the twelve aldermen, six of whose houses were depicted on the map or in the margins, and to them he added Lord Irwin whose peerage and 41 roomed mansion at Temple Newsam gave him a social standing.  One townsman, James Ibbetson, did have his armorial bearings drawn in a vacant space on the map alongside those of Lord Irwin and the Corporation, in addition to the depiction of the family house in the margin.
The only public building among the architectural elevations was the Town Hall (also known as the Moot Hall).

Description: After T King, "John Harrison born 1693 at Faulby near Pontefract Yorkshire - inventor of the compound pendulum and of several time keepers for ascertaining the longitude at sea ...." mezzotint engraving by P L Tassaert, published Aug 1st 1768, framed, ful
WebDescription:
This mezzotint engraving is based on a portrait of the Yorkshire clockmaker John Harrison who is famous for solving the problem of how to calculate longitude on board ship.  It is titled "John Harrison born 1693 at Faulby near Pontefract Yorkshire - inventor of the compound pendulum and of several time keepers for ascertaining the longitude at sea, the last of which, on a voyage ordered by the Commissioners of Longitude was certified to have succeeded considerably within the Limits prescribed by Act of Parliament of the 12th Year of Queen Ann."   
It is a mezzotint engraving by P L Tassaert taken from a painting by Thomas King and was published on August 1st 1768

Description: Walter Braithwaite, "The Red Hall, Leeds",  watercolour, signed and dated 1879, inscribed on  label on reverse, "The Red Hall, Upper Headrow,  now Schofields where my great grandmother, Mrs  Sarah Leathley lived.", framed
WebDescription:
This watercolour by the Leeds artist Walter Braithwaite is dated 1879.  It shows the Red Hall, King Charles' Croft, Leeds

This house was built in 1628 and was probably the first brick house in Leeds. Charles I is reputed to have been imprisoned one night here in 1647 on his way to London to face trial.

Red Hall  was built by John Metcalfe, under-bailiff of Leeds in 1628.  As one of the finest residencies in the town, it received a number of important guests, ranging from Charles I in 1646 to John Wesley.  Early in the 20th century Mr Snowden Schofield restored the hall, incorporating it into his department store, but it was finally destroyed in the 1960s to make way for Schofields new development on the Headrow.  The site is now occupied by the Headrow Shopping Centre.

Dimensions:
object height (frame): 631mm
object width (frame): 730mm
object: 560 x 441mm
Description: chromolithograph of Victorian Society  perambulating around Roundhay Park, a hydrogen  balloon in the sky, framed in a rosewood frame,  label on reverse "Lent by I.C.W.S."
WebDescription: This chromolithograph shows the citizens of Victorian Leeds perambulating around Roundhay Park with a hydrogen balloon overhead. Formerly the home of the Nicholson family, Roundhay Park was purchased by the Leeds Corporation for use as a public park and was opened by H.R.H. Prince Arthur on September 19th 1872.  The central rock of the 60 foot cascade in the foreground was known as "lover's leap" and had to be removed because of the number of suicide attempts made from it.

Description: colour printed invitation card drawn by Kester,  incl. chief in head-dress etc. "The Chief of the  Savage desires most especially the presence of ..  at the Ladies' Evening.. at Collinson's Cafe,  Wellington Street, Leeds"; Leeds Savage Club
WebDescription:
This invitation card for a Leeds Savage Club event was drawn by Kester (the pen-name of local artist Jim Dodgson),  and reads "The Chief of the Savage desires most especially the presence of ..  at the Ladies' Evening.. at Collinson's Cafe,  Wellington Street, Leeds".
The Leeds Savage Club was a social club of artists, writers, musicians and journalists which was formed in 1898 and disbanded in 1912. The meetings were informal, with a north-American ?Indian? theme and were known as pow-wows, presided over by a ?chief? in full head-dress.

Description: board game, Waddingtons Leeds Monopoly - Limited  Edition (no. 496 of 500)
WebDescription: Monopoly was first patented in the USA in 1935 and in the same year Waddington's published a British edition based on London streets.  This special limited edition based on Leeds was published by John Waddington Ltd., possibly to celebrate the centenary of the City of Leeds in 1993. John Waddington started off as a theatrical printer in 1896 and the firm began printing playing cards in 1921.

Description: board game, Waddingtons "Cluedo? - Leeds Centenary  Edition - The Great Detective Game", 1993 (with  suspects Dennis Healey, Jimmy Savile, Elizabeth  Peacock, Barbara Taylor Bradford, Jack Higgins &  Jilly Cooper)
WebDescription:
Cluedo is a deduction board game which was originally published by Waddingtons of Leeds in 1949. It was devised by Anthony E. Pratt, a solicitor's clerk and part-time clown from Birmingham. This special limited edition was produced in 1993 for the centenary celebrations for the City of Leeds, and features personalities with Leeds connections as suspects (Dennis Healey, Jimmy Savile, Elizabeth  Peacock, Barbara Taylor Bradford, Jack Higgins and Jilly Cooper).   Ironically history has since revealed Jimmy Savile to have been a villain in real life as well as within the game.
John Waddington started off as a theatrical printer in 1896 and the firm began printing playing cards in 1921.

Description: one of pair of silver communion cups, inscribed  "The gift of Miss A. Norton White Hall Chappel  1756",  made by  John Langlands and John Goodrick, Newcastle, 1756;  from the first Congregational Church at White  Hall, Leeds (which later moved to Queen St
WebDescription:
This pair of silver communion cups are inscribed  "The gift of Miss A. Norton White Hall Chappel  1756".  They were made by  John Langlands and John Goodrick of Newcastle, 1756.

This was the first Congregational chapel at White Hall, Leeds.  It later moved to Queen Street (hence the incsription on the front),  and later to Weetwood Lane.

Purchased with grant aid  from Resource/V&A  Purchase Grant Fund and the Friends of Leeds City Museums.

Description: wooden toy crocodile and bird on wheels; wooden platform on top of which is carved a crocodile and bird, painted green; crocodile's jaws open and moves closer to bird (governed by wires underneath); made by German prisoner of war in Yorkshire
WebDescription: This wooden toy crocodile and bird on wheels was made by a German prisoner of war in Yorkshire.  The donor acquired it  while working at Bewerley Park Camp near Pateley Bridge, run as a holiday camp for Leeds school children by Leeds Education Authority, in 1945.  Two German prisoner's of war came to work there each day and one day brought home-made toys to sell for cigarettes.  When this was discovered by the authorities they lost their job.

Description: treadle sewing machine, marked "T. Silcock, Leeds"
WebDescription:
This treadle sewing machine is marked "T. Silcock, Leeds".  
Thomas Silcock is listed in trade directories between 1882 and 1903 at various addresses including Templar Street, Concord Street, New Briggate and North Street.

It was owned by  Lily Pulford, nee Jefferson of Harlech Road, Leeds who was born in 1888.. It was probably given as birthday present when she left school in 1901 to learn dress making at Madame Ernest's, aged 13.

Description: presentation hot water jug (or flagon), chased and inscribed "Presented to / HENRY LAMPEN Esqre / by the / OFFICERS OF THE LEEDS UNION / as a Mark of their Esteem / & Respect on his completing / his 20th year of Office as / CLERK TO THE GUARDIANS, 13 Feb
WebDescription:
Thjs presentation hot water jug (or flagon) is inscribed "Presented to / HENRY LAMPEN Esqre / by the / OFFICERS OF THE LEEDS UNION / as a Mark of their Esteem / & Respect on his completing / his 20th year of Office as / CLERK TO THE GUARDIANS, 13 Feb 1876"

Henry Lampen He was listed in 1856 as "Superintendent Registrar and Clerk to the Board of Guardians" and In 1861 as "Clerk to Leeds Guardians" and "Superintentend Registrar of Leeds District".  The Leeds Union Board of Guardians were in charge of running the Work House (now the Thackray Medical Museum).

It was presented to the museum by Lieutenant Commander A.M.D. Lampen, DSC, R.N. (Retd) in 2005.

WebDescription:
oil painting, Ralph Thoresby in his Study, signed A. Taylor 1846.  Ralph Thoresby (1658-1725) wrote the first history of Leeds (Ducatus Leodiensis) in 1714.  He also had a private museum in his home.
Donated by the Thoresby Society, the Leeds historical society

This oil painting by an unknown artist, Leeds Old Parish Church from the South West.

Medium/Materials: oil on canvas; gilt gesso & wood frame
Description:
oil painting by George Richmond, portrait of Ellen Heaton
signed G Richmond R A
WebDescription:
oil painting by George Richmond (1809-1896).  A portrait of Ellen Heaton (1816-1894), thesister of John Deakin Heaton, who lived at Woodhouse Square, Leeds. She was an influential Pre-Raphaelite art patron and an active campaigner for women's rights, education, health, environmental issues and anti-vivisection.
Donated by the Thoresby Society, the Leeds historical society

Title Sort: Review of Volunteers on Heath Common 1796
Medium/Materials: paper on board; gilt gesso and wood frame
Description: coloured print, showing Review of Leeds Volunteers on Heath Common (near Wakefield) in 1796, gilt gesso and wood frame
WebDescription:
Hand coloured print showing the Leeds Volunteers (and others) on parade at Heath Common (near Wakefield) on 4th August 1796.  The original painting was by a Mr Hopkins of Bloomsbury Square, London.  1100 men were present from Leeds, Wakefield, Halifax, Bradford and Huddersfield, Infantry, plus two Artillery and two Yeomanry Cavalry Volunteer units.  The print was available for purchase in 1798.

The Leeds Volunteers were local volunteer force created by the end of April 1794 for local defence against French invasion. Thomas Lloyd was Commander in Chief. They were not called upon to fight but often used to help extinguish fires. In 1808 the volunteers were replaced by the Leeds Local Militia who were themselves disbanded in 1815.
Donated by the Thoresby Society, the Leeds historical society

Description: small glazed pottery model of old type electric tram, c1905, with two pigs (one as driver, other passenger), "C C Latest / Improvement 1905" - these novelties were sold in the shops in Leeds
WebDescription: This porcelain toy of The Old Leeds Steam Tram 1905  was Sold by Marks & Spencers Leeds for 1d.  It features caricature pigs as driver and passenger and is very rare.

Description: Fireman's hat with golden fleece Leeds emblem in gold painted on crown, "FIRE-MAN LEEDS"
WebDescription:
This stiffened top hat is decorated with the Leeds fleece emblem in gold, plus the legend "FIRE-MAN LEEDS".

It probably dates from the early days of the municipal fire brigade in Leeds, in the early 19th century.  Before that, people had to depend on private fire brigades paid for by insurance companies.  Houses and businesses would have a metal plaque on the wall to show which company they were insured by.

Description: grey mottled enamel iron gas cooker, "CARLTON / "NEW WORLD" / WILSONS & MATHIESONS LTD / Radiation"
WebDescription: This gas cooker is the  "CARLTON 'NEW WORLD'"  model made by Wilsons & Mathiesons Ltd.  of Scotch Foundry, Leeds.  They started as iron founders and stove grate manufacturers in about 1888.

Dimensions:
object length: 370mm

Description: ceremonial trowel used a foundation ceremony of Leeds Town Hall in 1853.  "Presented to John Hope Shaw, Esq, the mayor of Leeds, on behalf of the council of the borough, by Mr Alderman Hepper, chairman of the Town-hall committee, on the occasion of laying
WebDescription:
This ceremonial trowel was used at the foundation ceremony of Leeds Town Hall in 1853. The inscription reads "Presented to John Hope Shaw, Esq, the mayor of Leeds, on behalf of the council of the borough, by Mr Alderman Hepper, chairman of the Town-hall committee, on the occasion of laying the foundation stone of the Town-hall, 17th August, 1853".

Leeds Town Hall was finally opened on 7th September 1858 by Queen Victoria.

WebDescription:
This ceremonial gavel was used at the foundation ceremony of Leeds Town Hall in 1853.  The inscription reads "Presented to John Hope Shaw, Esq, the mayor of Leeds, on behalf of the council of the borough, by Mr Alderman Hepper, chairman of the Town-hall committee, on the occasion of laying the foundation stone of the Town-hall, 17th August, 1853".

Leeds Town Hall was finally opened on 7th September 1858 by Queen Victoria.

Description: oil painting of soldier advert for Yorkshire  Relish, by Goodall, Backhouse & Co, Leeds
WebDescription: This oil painting of a soldier is actually an advertisement for Yorkshire Relish, a sauce made by Goodall, Backhouse & Co of Leeds.   The soldier is about to try and knock the Yorkshire Relish bottle off the post.

Description: tin, "Black Tom Boot Polish Outfit", with picture  of black cat on hinged lid, man. Stead & Simpson  Ltd.
WebDescription:
This tin for "Black Tom Boot Polish Outfit" features an image of a lucy black cat. 

The polish was made by Stead & Simpson Ltd., who started business in Leeds in 1834 as curriers and leather factors.  They began making ready-made boots and shoes in the 1840s .  The company became well known across the country but stopped manufacturing footwear in the 1960s to concentrate on retail.

Dimensions:
object length (framed and mounted): 300mm
object height (framed and mounted): 252mm
Description: hand tinted lithographic print in glazed frame, entitled 'Leeds, Interior of Marshall's flax Mill' by Joseph Bonomi 1838-41; view of the interior showing the roof lights which incorporated ventilators
WebDescription:
This print shows the interior of Marshall's Temple Mill in Holbeck, Leeds. 

John Marshall was the son of a linen draper with a shop at No 1, Briggate, and a house in Mill Hill. In 1788 in partnership with Matthew Murray  he adapted cotton spinning machinery to spin flax into linen yarn.

In 1840?43 Marshall built a new mill, Temple Mill on Marshall Street which covers two acres. It was designed by the Architect Bonomi in the style of an Egyptian Temple. The roof was made of brick supported on iron columns, and had over sixty conical glass skylights, each 14ft in diameter and rising 10ft above the roof, providing excellent lighting for the factory. The brick roof was covered by a layer of plaster, and then waterproofed with a layer of lime and coal tar. This was then protected by eight inches of soil, sown with grass seed. The surface was drained through the hollow iron columns supporting the roof. It is said that to keep the grass short, sheep were put to graze on the roof!

Underneath the factory were a brick-vaulted cellar which housed the engines for powering the spinning machinery, and a ventilation system which kept the air at a constant temperature and humidity (which can be seen in this print). There were also tradesmen's shops and private baths for the use of the mill workers. A second building with a faade in the style of the Egyptian Temple at Edfu was built two years later to house the mill offices.

The building still survives and is used as offices.

Title Sort: J. Blenkinsop's Patent Steam Carriage, Middleton near Leeds
Dimensions:
object length (framed): 385mm
object height (framed): 310mm
object depth (framed): 25mm

Description: framed and glazed lithographic print of Blenkinsop's steam engine for Middleton colliery railway, near Leeds, c.1812, titled "J. Blenkinsop's Patent Steam Carriage, Middleton near Leeds, Capable of moving One Hundred Tons 3 1/2 Miles an Hour on Level Rail
WebDescription: This print shows the first commercially successful steam locomotive (the "Salamanca") which was patented by Matthew Murray in 1811 and commissioned by John Blenkinsop to run on the Middleton Railway.  The engraving was printed by Topham, Leeds and is titled "J. Blenkinsop's Patent Steam Carriage, Middleton near Leeds, Capable of moving One Hundred Tons 3 1/2 Miles an Hour on Level Rail Road".

Description: symbolic mahogany axe with gilded painted decoration, inscribed:' presented by C.S.W.Thompson, DECR 2nd 1875 to the Widow and Orphan fund, Leeds district IOFMU' (Independent Order of Foresters, Manchester Unity or Independent Order of Odd Fellows, Manches
WebDescription:
This symbolic axe is made of mahogany with gilded painted decoration and is inscribed:' presented by C.S.W.Thompson, DECR 2nd 1875 to the Widow and Orphan fund, Leeds district IOFMU'.

IOFMU probably stands for the "Independent Order of Foresters, Manchester Unity" or the "Independent Order of Odd Fellows, Manchester Unity".

Description: carved oak chair, with leather upholstered seat  and back, with carved profile of "T'Owd Chief" in  Native American head-dress, with inscription  "LEEDS SAVAGE CLUB / PRESENTED TO THE CHIEF /  EDMUND BOGG, DEC. 1904"
WebDescription:
This magnificent carved oak arm chair,  with its carved profile of "T'Owd Chief" in  Native American head-dress is inscribed "LEEDS SAVAGE CLUB,  PRESENTED TO THE CHIEF EDMUND BOGG, DEC. 1904" 
The Leeds Savage Club was a social club of artists, writers, musicians and journalists which was formed in 1898 and disbanded in 1912. The meetings were informal, with a north-American ?Indian? theme and were known as pow-wows, presided over by a ?chief? in full head-dress.

Title Sort: Portrait of the Rt Hon William Pitt
Description: This is a head and shoulders portrait of William Pitt.  He wears a black jacket with large buttons over a white shirt.
WebDescription: William Pitt the Younger (1759-1806) followed his father as the greatest statesman of his generation.  He became Chancellor of the Exchequer at the age of 23 and Prime Minister at 24.  He was responsible for a period of political stability following the turbulent years of the American War of Independence, and presided over the early military and naval successes following the outbreak of war against France in 1792.  Despite his many qualities he seems to have been indifferent to the visual arts or literature.  When he sat for Thomas Gainsborough in 1787 for a portrait for the Duke of Buckingham the artist was struck by Pitt's 'hauteur and disrespectful manner'.

Title Sort: Roman Ruins with the Blind Belisarius
Description: Landscape of ruins with several figures in foreground and background. The ruins in the background has four statues positioned on it. In the bottom right hand corner there is a dog stood near a stone slab.
WebDescription: Ruin pictures or 'capricci' of Rome, incorporating views of well-known or imaginary monuments of Antiquity, were bought avidly by Grand Tourists in the 18th century.  G.P. Pannini had a particularly successful studio specialising in such scenes, often contriving to re-arrange the ruins.

Title Sort: Portrait of a man in black
Description:
Head and shoulders portrait of a man with a beard and moustache.  His dark hair is cropped short and he wears a white ruff around his neck.

Subject: portrait
WebDescription: Frans Pourbus the Younger was from the third generation of a family of Flemish artists and was to become one of the most sought after royal portrait painters working for the Catholic courts of the early 17th century. especially in Mantua, Spain and France.  He was to have a considerable influence on Rubens.

Description: Christ is pictured on the left with his hands across his chest. John the Baptist is on the right, wearing a red-pink robe, pouring water from a bowl on to Christ's head.
WebDescription: This painting was almost certainly commissioned as an altarpiece for a side chapel or a provincial church under the protection of Cardinal Pietro Ottoboni (1667-1740) whose coat of arms appear in the lower left-hand corner.  Ottoboni, nephew of Pope Alexander VIII, was a discerning intellectual and patron of artists and craftsmen.

Description:
Christ dressed in a red robe holds a cross over his right shoulder.  A crown of thorns has pierced the skin on his forehead.

Subject: biblical-New Testament
WebDescription: The subject had a particular interest for the intense devotionalism of the late 15th and early 16th centuries; the resigned expression of Christ - whose cross symbolises the sins of the world - falls between the triumphalism of earlier representations of this subject and the naturalistic pathos of later artists' impressions.

Description:
Four dead game birds hung above a table with a jacket draped across it.  A shot gun in the left foreground.

Subject: still-life
WebDescription: Willem van Aelst, from Delft, specialised in still life and flower painting.  He worked extensively for the Medici of Florence for whom he produced a series of still life pictures of hunting trophies and equipment.

Description: Half length portrait of Sir John Beckett. The male sitter is wearing a dark coat with a white shirt. His hair is short, has long sideburns and he holds part of his coat in his left hand while his right hand is directly below it.
WebDescription: The sitter, Sir John Beckett, (1775-1847) was a distinguished lawyer and head of the leading Leeds banking firm Beckett & Co who were responsible for developing much commercial activity in Leeds in the 19th century.  He was Judge Advocate-General for many years, and briefly MP for Leeds.

Description:
Stormy seascape with thick grey clouds in the sky.  A sail boat is approaching a beach in the middle distance on the right, figures on the beach.  Sailboats on the horizon.

Subject: coastal-Holland
WebDescription: This scene evokes a dramatic storm with the threatening grey sky counterbalancing the dark turbulence of the sea.  The spectator gradually becomes aware of the majestic rawness of nature.

Description:
Landscape with a body of water and two cows in the middle distance on the right and buildings on the left.  A man is seated in the middle foreground, trees in the background.

Subject: landscape
WebDescription: For many years this painting was thought to be an early work of the young Thomas Gainsborough, dating from his Suffolk period and before his move to Bath in 1759.  However, an engraving of this scene in reverse, published by a leading art dealer of the day, named the artist as Ebenezer Tull.  Tull was a schoolmaster and amateur artist as well as a considerable collector of contemporary English and 17th century Dutch landscape paintings.

Title Sort: William and Charles Chadwick at Burley Lodge
Description: Portrait of two young boys playing outside. The boy on the left wears a top hat and stands beside a pony, as if about to mount it. The boy on the right kneels on one knee with a cricket ball in his left hand and a bat in his right.
WebDescription: William and Charles Chadwick came from a well-known family of prosperous Leeds dyers whose home, St Anne's Lodge at Burley, can be seen in the background.  Charles later became chief physician of the Leeds General Infirmary and, together with the architect Sir George Gilbert Scott, was responsible for much of the planning of the new building which opened in 1868.

Description: Portrait of a seated lady and a man leaning towards her. The lady seated on the left is wearing a pink dress, she is knotting and looking at the artist and there is a small dog at her feet.  The man stood beside her on the right has with his left hand on
WebDescription:
Conversation Pictures' are a special genre of picture in which portraits of two or more figures are depicted informally in their everyday surroundings and often 'in conversation' with each other.
This picture is remarkable for its depiction of a parlour belonging to a prosperous young couple of the mid 1770s.  The fashionably dressed lady is shown 'knotting' or 'tatting' - making a decorative linen braid with the aid of a small shuttle which could be sewn onto fabric.  This fashionable occupation or 'work' had even become acceptable at Court and provided an excuse for ladies to show off the graceful attitudes of their hands.

Description:
A mountainous, stormy scene, to the left a carriage with two white horses struggles up a mountain road.  A man walks behind the carriage.  Lightening flash in the sky on the right.
Subject: landscape-transport
WebDescription: This melodramatic picture is based on a real event which took place during the artist's tour of Wales in 1792.  An inscription on the back reads: 'An actual scene.  The Honble Robert Greville's Phaeton between Pont Aberglaslyn and Tan-y-Bwlch crossing the Mountain Range in a Thunder Storm.  Painted  by Julius Ibbetson who was the passenger'.  The artist has indeed painted himself as the figure placing a brake behind the wheel to ease the horses.

Description: Full length portrait of a young man standing in a mountainous landscape.  He holds his top hat in his left hand.  In his gloved right hand he holds the glove from his left hand.  In the background to the left is a stone cottage.  A river runs from the bac
WebDescription: Although he considered himself primarily a landscape painter the Leeds-born Ibbetson occasionally  undertook portraits out of necessity 'to make the pot boil'.  A small number, including this example, depict full length figures in a romantic landscape setting somewhat reminiscent of Thomas Gainsborough (who had died in 1788).

Description: A dramatic landscape of temple-like ruins in front of which stands an obelisk, in a classical landscape, dotted with a few peasants and men on horseback.
WebDescription: Coccorante is said to have begun his career as a jailer's assistant and was taught his craft by a Sicilian painter of architectural subjects from Palermo who had been imprisioned for burglary, Angelo Maria Costa.

Description:
A young peasant woman stands counting coins.  On the left stands a donkey carrying baskets and a small child.  A dog stands in front of the donkey.  There is a chicken on the floor in a basket on the right.
 
Subject: rustic
WebDescription: The 'Fancy Picture', a genre generally dealing with moral subjects or extolling domestic virtue, had been developed by Hogarth and Mercier in the previous generation.  Such pictures tended to lapse into a prettified sentimentality.  Wheatley manages to avoid this in this example where his somewhat earthy, but pretty, young peasant woman is counting her day's takings from her stall at the market.

Description:
Young woman whose face is partially covered by a black veil holds a mask in her right hand.  She wears a crucifix around her neck.  
Subject: figure
WebDescription: The picture shows a courtesan in masquerade costume with her veil suggesting that she is a nun.  Entertainments such as masquerades in which fancy dress took a major part were hugely popular.  Here, the artist has chosen to mock the convention whereby ladies of easy virtue could employ the subterfuge of religious dress, including the use of devotional jewellery, to entice potential 'clients'.  The description of a woman as a 'nun' in 18th century Protestant England was to imply that she was a whore.

Description: The subject is taken from classical mythology when the great hero Hercules, before he embarked on his twelve hours labours 'retired to a solitary place on order to deliberate on the choice he was to make of the different ways of life [where he] was accost
WebDescription: This picture is a reduced size contemporary replica of the original painted in Naples for the Earl of Shaftesbury in 1712 (now in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford).  It was intended to be a gift to Shaftesbury's patron Lord Somers but in the event it was bought by Shaftesbury's friend Sir John Cropley.  Shaftesbury wrote to him that 'there will be no need of a carved, gilded or otherwise expensive frame: it must be plain and of dark coloured wood, not shining'.

Description: Subject: allegory
WebDescription: This sketch is a pendant to a similar 'Allegory of Africa', also at Temple Newsam, and was probably originally part of a group of four, with 'Asia' and 'America'.  They are derived from fresco paintings representing the 'Four Parts of the World', painted by Solimena for the Gabinetto of the royal palace in Naples.  Other sets have survived, including one at Palazzo Doria in Rome.

Title Sort: Eliezer and Rebecca at the well
Description: A man and a woman in the centre foreground, the woman holds a jar to the man's lips so he can drink.  To the left,  three woman fill jars from a well.  To the right men with camels and a donkey. It is a biblical-Old Testament subject.  David Connell has s
WebDescription: The story is taken from Genesis, chapter 24.  The patriarch Abraham, wishing to find a bride for his son Isaac, sent his servant Eliezir from Canaan, where he lived, into Mesopotamia.  On reaching the city of Nahor in Chaldea he prayed that whoever was the first to give water to him and his camels would be an eligible woman.  This proved to be Rebecca, a kinswoman of Abraham's who invited Eliezer to drink from her jar.  Eliezer then gave her presents of gold and received hospitality from her parents' house.  He brought her back to Canaan where Isaac, praying in the fields in the evening, saw them approach.

Description: Portrait of Arther, Sixth Viscount Irwin.
WebDescription: This portrait of Arthur, 6th Viscount Irwin was painted by Charles Jervas in 1712 for 20 guineas.  Arthur was the third son of the 3rd Viscount and Viscountess Irwin who succeeded to his elder brother, Rich, who died intestate in 172.  Arthur had trained for the Bar and became MP for Horsham, the 'pocket borough' that his mother had brought to her marriage to his father.  It was Arthur who obtained a 20,000 mortgage that helped alleviate the family?s financial difficulties following great losses when the South Sea Bubble burst and Rich's investments were lost.  In 1736 he died in Bath, unmarried. He was succeeded by his younger brother Henry who became the 7th Viscount Irwin.  A portrait of Henry and his wife (ticket no. 126) may be seen in the Picture Gallery.

Description:
Various fruits on two silver platters including watermelon, grapes and figs.  The watermelon on the left platter has a knife protruding from it.  Two wine glasses balance on the platter on the right.

Subject: still life
WebDescription: This is one of a pair of 'Still Life' paintings by Maximilian Pfeiler almost certainly acquired by Henry, fourth Viscount Irwin of Temple Newsam while on his Grand Tour 1704-1707.  They are mentioned in all the subsequent inventories of the pictures in the house.

Description:
Arthur was baptized 25 Jan 1665/6 -succeeded his brother in 1688, died 1702.
Subject: portrait
WebDescription: This portrait of Arthur, third Viscount Irwin (ticket no. 118) can be seen in the Picture Gallery at Temple Newsam House. There are also portraits of his wife Isabella, Viscountess Irwin (nee Machel) (ticket no. 133) and another portrait of Arthur, third Viscount (ticket no. 267) in the Crimson Bedroom.  This portrait of Arthur by Leonard Knyff was painted in 1700 at a cost of 30 guineas and gives an indication of the pleasure Arthur took in sports.  However, in addition to sporting and gambling Arthur also under took public duties as an MP twice for Scarborough and as Vice- Admiral for Yorkshire with responsibility for press gangs.  Isabella was the intelligent, sophisticated and accomplished heiress of John Machel of Hills, Sussex.  She also brought two parliamentary seats for Horsham to the marriage thus establishing the political power base for the family that lasted until 1832.  Letters from Arthur to Isabella indicate that theirs was a marriage of affection and during their 16 years together they produced nine sons.   Seven sons survived infancy five of whom succeeded each other as Viscounts.  In order these were; Edward of which there are two portraits  (ticket nos 263 and 269) in the Crimson Bedroom, Rich who married Lady Anne Howard of which there are portraits (ticket nos 265 and 110) in the Crimson Bedroom and Picture Gallery respectively, Arthur of which there is a portrait in the Great Hall, Henry who married Anne Scarborough of whom there is a portrait (ticket no. 34) in the Crimson Bedroom and a joint portrait (ticket no. 126) in the Picture Gallery, and George of whom there can also be found a portrait (ticket no. 268) in the Crimson Bedroom.  John, who like his brother Charles was never a Viscount.  However it was Charles's son, also called Charles who became the 9th Viscount Irwin. A portrait of Charles with the younger Charles and one of his daughters (ticket no. 72) can be found in the Picture Gallery.  A portrait of Charles 9th Viscount Irwin (ticket no. 196) can be found in the State Dressing Room.  All the portraits can be seen at Temple Newsam House.

Description: Portrait of a child wearing a magnificent outfit (he would not have been breeched until about the age of six). It consists of a bodice and skirt with appliqued black stripes, over which is an exceptionally fine lace apron.  He wears a chain with an Elizab
WebDescription:
This portrait probably arrived at Temple Newsam in the late 19th century when it was thought to represent Princess Elizabeth, daughter of James I and Anne of Denmark and later Queen of Bohemia.
However, the evidence of the coat of arms of the Howard family (Dukes of Norfolk) on the back of the panel, together with the incompatability of the Princess's age at the time this picture was painted (1611), make it much more likely that the young person is Henry Frederick Howard, the future third Earl of Arundel.  A portrait of his father, the celebrated collector Thomas Howard, second Earl of Arundel, also hangs at Temple Newsam.

Title Sort: Interior of the Pantheon, Oxford Road
Description: Interior view of the Pantheon. Fish? eye view. Several figures are walking around in the foreground and background. A man is stood in the bottom right corner wearing a light blue coat.
WebDescription: The Pantheon was one of the most spectacular sights of late 18th century London.  When it opened its doors as the venue for assemblies, concerts and social gatherings in 1772 it immediately established the reputation of its young architect James Wyatt.  The lower part recalled Santa Sophia in Constantinople, while the dome (constructed of timber painted in trompe l'oeil) was obviously in imitation of the Pantheon in Rome.  The Pantheon burnt down in 1792 having been converted into an opera house.

Description:
Full length portrait of a lady in a gold dress.  A black and white spotted dog stands on hind legs with its front paws on her skirt.  She rests her left hand on the dog's head.
Subject: portrait
WebDescription: Lady Henrietta's two sisters, Anne and Elizabeth, were married to the two Ingram brothers: Henry, seventh Viscount Irwin of Temple Newsam and Colonel the Hon Charles Ingram.  After the death of Lady Jenkinson's husband she came to live at Temple Newsam where no doubt she and her sisters constituted a considerable power in determining the affairs of the household.  They were probably largely responsible for the floral needlework which still adorns the celebrated suite of furniture in the Picture Gallery.

Title Sort: Portrait of Henry Ingram, 7th Viscount Irwin and Viscountess Irwin
Description: Subject: portrait
WebDescription: This is a large portrait of Henry, 7th Viscount Irwin and his wife Anne (ticket no. 126) that was painted by French artist Philip Mercier and which hangs in the Picture Gallery at Temple Newsam.  Henry was the 4th son of the 3rd Viscount and Viscountess Irwin and succeeded his brother Arthur in 1736.  Prior to this Henry was an MP for Horsham, the 'pocket borough' that his mother had brought to her marriage to his father.  Despite the strained family finances that resulted from losses incurred by his younger brother the 5th Viscount, Henry remodelled the west and north wings of Temple Newsam creating new bedrooms and dressing rooms along with the picture gallery and library. In the grounds he built two new stable blocks in the north and south as well as new lodges and a brick wall to practically enclose the whole park.  In 1728 Henry married Anne Scarburgh the 2nd daughter and co-heiress of Charles Scarburgh of Windsor and grand-daughter of the royal physician Sir Charles Scarburgh.  A portrait of Anne (ticket no. 34) can be found in the Crimson Bedroom.  Anne was one of three sisters.  Henrietta, her elder sister, had been Lady-in-waiting to Queen Anne and had married Sir Robert Jenkinson, Bt of Walcot, Oxon in 1717.  After his death, Henrietta, Lady Jenkinson moved to live with Henry and Anne.  A portrait of Henrietta (ticket no. 77) by French artist Philip Mercier, signed and dated 1742, hangs in the Picture Gallery.  Anne's other sister Elizabeth married Henry's younger brother Charles and was known as The Hon Mrs Charles Ingram.  A portrait of Elizabeth (ticket no. 39) can be seen on the Oak Staircase.  Charles was Elizabeth's second husband with whom she had three daughters and one son, Charles who was to become the 9th Viscount Irwin. A portrait of Charles, 9th Viscount Irwin (ticket no. 196) can be State Bedroom.  However, before Charles succeeded, his uncle George became 8th Viscount Irwin a portrait of whom can be seen in the Crimson Bedroom (ticket no. 268).  All portraits can be viewed at Temple Newsam House.

Description: Naked man and woman (Adam & Eve) lean against two fruit trees.  Eve holds a piece of fruit in her right hand.  Adam holds the fruit in his left hand.  Both have their legs crossed.  A river winds into the distance in the middle of the picture.  Rabbits in
WebDescription: Adam and Eve are shown in the Garden of Eden at the very moment they succumb to temptation and become guilty of Original Sin.  Encouraged by Eve, Adam is about to eat the forbidden fruit.   Although he is invisible the presence of the Serpent is implied in the strange shape of the trees.  God's beautiful creation is about to change forever: rabbits still play innocently in the undergrowth, swans glide elegantly on the river (both will become symbols of lust), while a resting hind (symbol of chastity) looks up in startled awareness of unholy events.

Description:
Full length portrait of a man in cream breeches and a cream waistcoat.  He leans against a stone plinth.  In his right hand he holds rolled up paper, there is white cloth (muslin) draped over the stone plinth under his right arm. 

Subject: portrait
WebDescription:
Samuel Oldknow (1759-1828) of Stockport, Cheshire, rose to become the most successful manufacturer of fine muslins by the age of 30.  His two fine mills contained the most up to date machinery including the spinning mule invented by Samuel Crompton and available from c.1780.
Oldknow was known as a most humane and enlightened employer but ran into financial difficulties soon after the outbreak of the French wars in 1792.  He had over-extended himself and was obliged to call in the assistance of the great industrialist Sir Richard Arkwright.

Description: Female figure holding small bail of straw and small flail in her right hand places a piece of the straw in a child's hair. The child has its arms open towards the female, with green and red grapes in its hands.
WebDescription: The allegory shows Ceres, the Greek goddess of agriculture, together with a young follower of Bacchus, god of wine, representing the fruits of the earth at harvest-time or autumn.  The picture is one of a set of four depicting the Seasons which were originally painted as overdoors for Fonthill Splendens, Wiltshire which was demolished around 1807.

Title Sort: Portrait of La Duchesse de la Ferte with the duc de Bretagne and the duc d'Anjou
Description:
Portrait of a lady seated with a baby on her knee.  A young boy stands to her right holding a spear in his left hand.  She holds a garland of flowers above his head.

Subject: portrait
WebDescription: This picture almost certainly represents a royal godmother - the duchesse de la Ferte, a sister of the then royal governess madame de Ventadour - who performed this duty in 1712 when the two princes contracted measles and had to be baptised at short notice.  The elder boy, the duc de Bretagne, died some days later, leaving the infant duc d'Anjou as the sole heir of his great-grandfather Louis XIV.  The garland of flowers held above the elder boy may be an allusion to his premature death.

Title Sort: Fantastic Still Life in a Classical Landscape
Description: This very decorative painting, by the Flemish specialist Pieter Casteels, is an example of the subject matter which made him a well-known artist in England in the early 18th century. He came to England in 1708, accompanied by his brother-in-law, Pieter Ti
WebDescription: This painting was probably intended to hang at Sir William Strickland's house at Boynton Hall, near Bridlington, Yorkshire, around 1730, when the owner was undertaking alterations under the supervision of William Kent who designed its frame.

Description: A group of figures stand around an open tomb. A central figure (Jesus), draped in an orange robe stands above the tomb his right arm in the air, his left arm outstretched. He looks into the tomb. Two arms rise out of the tomb.
WebDescription: This unusual pastiche of an early Rembrandt by the Dresden artist C W E Dietrich testifies to the former's enduring popularity in the 18th century.  The 'Gemaldegalerie' at Dresden, of which Dietrich became Inspector, was founded as a publicly accessible art gallery by Augustus the Strong in the early 18th century and was famous for its large number of paintings by Rembrandt.

Title Sort: Phillis, A pointer of Lord Clermont's
Description: Brown and white pointer dog.
WebDescription: Dogs were not usually given human names unless their master or mistress doted on them.  This was a uniquely English custom, unknown elsewhere in Europe at this time.  Obviously William Henry Fortescue, Lord Clermont, who was a keen sportsman and owned a substantial kennel, held Phillis in close affection.  George Stubbs, the greatest English sporting artist, had an unrivalled knowledge of anatomy which can be seen to great effect in his depiction of Phillis' posture.

Description: Portrait of Isabella Anne Ingram. She is wearing white and gold garments and faces to the left of the viewer.
WebDescription:
This is a portrait of Isabella, (as Lady Beauchamp) the eldest of five daughters born to the 9th Viscount and Viscountess Irwin.  It can be found in the South Bedroom (ticket no. 198) at Temple Newsam House and was painted by Sir Joshua Reynolds in 1777 when Isabella was just 18 years old.  A year before, Isabella had become the second wife of Francis, Viscount Beauchamp, later second Marquess of Hertford.  Isabella made connections with the very highest of English society becoming chief confidante of the Prince of Wales.  This followed the Minnie Seymour Case.  Minnie was the niece and legal guardian of Lord and Lady Hertford after her parent?s death.  However, she was also a favourite of the Prince of Wales and his wife Mrs Fitzherbert and a playmate of their daughter Charlotte.  At the Princes persuasion Minnie was relinquished to Mrs Fitzherbert, for whom it was said afterwards that she 'won a daughter but lost a husband.'  
Lady Hertford had the reputation of a woman of utmost propriety and her role may, therefore, have been more as mother and confidante to the Prince helping him with his entertaining of, amongst others, Allied Sovereigns. 
However, Isabella began to meddle in politics on behalf of the Tory Party for which she became the subject of satire in the popular press.  By 1820 the Prince had tired of Isabella who was replaced in his affections by Lady Conyngham.
Under the terms of the 9th Viscount's will, Temple Newsam was to be inherited by Isabella's husband then her second son or , failing that, to the 9th Viscount's surviving daughters and their sons in order of seniority.  It happened then, that, after the death of her mother in 1807 and her husband in 1821 Isabella inherited Temple Newsam in her own right and the title of Viscount Irwin ceased.  In the 1820's she re-modelled and re-decorated a series of rooms at Temple Newsam despite spending much time in London.  An additional portrait of Isabella (ticket no. 365) painted by John Hoppner can also be seen in the state bedroom.
It was her sister Frances, Lady William Gordon who inherited Temple Newsam in 1834 when Isabella died at 75 years old.  An engraving of Frances before her marriage can be seen in the Lady William Gordon room and a portrait (ticket no. 372) of her can be seen in the State Bedroom.

Title Sort: Portrait of a Man with Grey Hair
Description: Half length portrait of a man with long grey hair, a moustache and a beard.  He wears a black coat with a white collar. The middle-aged male subject is facing towards the left of the viewer and has his left hand across his breast, holding his coat.
WebDescription: This distinguished portrait of an unidentified man is close in style to the work of Adriaen Hanneman, the Dutch artist who spent several years of his youth in London where he may have worked as an assistant to Anthony van Dyck.  On returning to Holland he continued to work in the van Dyke manner, especially among the exiled English royalists.  Here. the furtive glance in the sitter's eyes, the turn of his head, his cascading grey hair and crumpled collar picked out with highlights convey an impression of tension and nervousness.

Description: Old man in a blue robe kneels holding a crucifix and beating his chest with a rock.  A lion lies in the right corner of the painting.  Cupid fires an arrow at the man from top right.  A woman on the left (Venus) holds a cherub in her arms (Cupid) and lead
WebDescription:
St Jerome, or Eusebius Hieronymus Sophronius (320 - 420AD), is one of the four traditional Doctors of the Church.  His translations of the Bible into Latin, the Vulgate, was to become the official text of the Gospels for the Western Church.
The picture represents an episode in the saint's life when he retired for four years into the Syrian desert where he had 'only the scorpions and wild beasts for company'.  He was a man of powerful intellect and fiery disposition who experienced violent sexual hallucinations.  In one of his letters he described how he would beat his breast until the fever passed.  A lion became his devoted companion after the saint removed a thorn from its paw.

Title Sort: The Romps, formerly called The Schoolroom
Description: Seven young girls in a schoolroom with a large fireplace. The girl in the centre of the picture has lost her cap and has ink stains on her dress. A governess, who seems to have just walked into the room, holds up the bottom of the ink stained dress. There
WebDescription: The work of William Redmore Bigg was very popular in its day and he was a frequent exhibitor at the Royal Academy.  His subjects were often moral ones, showing kind schoolboys, distressed sailors and the virtuous poor.  The pictures were often made as pairs and were frequently engraved.
