object height (support): 476mm
object width (support): 876mm
framed: 720 x 1120 x 110mm
Description: View of the islands of San Giorgio and the Giudecca with the churches of S Giorgio Maggiore, S Giovanni Battista and the Zitelle. There are two vessels in the right corner of the foreground, one has a little red flag at the tip of its mast and the other h
WebDescription: Guardi's aim with the painting was to capture the poetry of the city and its lagoon by using flickering nervous brushstrokes and by exaggerating the atmospheric effects of its unique light.  On the left of the view is the famous church and monastery of S Giorgio Maggiore (built by Andrea Palladio from 1566), with its campanile (which collapsed in 1774).

Description: Three quarter length portrait of a young woman in a white dress with a blue ribbon around her waist and a blue rosette on the front.  Her right elbow rests on a stone plinth.
WebDescription: Frances Maria (1729-1750), daughter of Thomas Whichcote of Harpswell, was the second wife of Dr John Fountayne (1715-1802), Dean of York and owner of Melton Hall near Doncaster.  Her husband was a close friend of the writer Lawrence Sterne, also a canon of York.  She had one daughter, named after herself born in 1750.

Title Sort: Horatio Walpole 1st Earl of Orford (Second Creation)
Description: Half length portrait of a man in a red velvet and gold brocade coat seated at a desk.  His right hand rests on two books open on the table.  There is also a quill pen on the table.  Hist left arm rests on the srm of the chair his left hand gestures to the
WebDescription: Horatio Walpole came from the well-known Norfolk family who rose to prominence in the early 18th century when his uncle, Sir Robert Walpole, became Prime Minister.  His father was a diplomat and ambassador to France and was created first Baron Walpole of Wolterton; his cousin, Horace Walpole of Strawberry Hill - with whom he was not on friendly terms - was the famous wit and man of letters.

Description: The subject is a popular one taken from Homer's 'Iliad'.  Hector, the commander of Trojan forces says farewell to his wife Andromache and their son Astyanax on the eve of battle.  The child is frightened by the sight of the plumed helmet and shrinks back
WebDescription: The subject is a popular one taken from Homer's 'Iliad'.  Hector, the commander of Trojan forces says farewell to his wife Andromache and their son Astyanax on the eve of battle.  The child is frightened by the sight of the plumed helmet and shrinks back into his father's arms.

Title Sort: Christ and the Woman taken in adultery
Description: This is a biblical (New Testament)  subject of man (Christ) stands in the centre of the picture.  In front of him stands a woman with her eyes downcast whose hands are tied together with rope.  A man in the far right of the picture holds the rope in his l
WebDescription: The subject is taken from St John's Gospel when an adultress is brought before Christ by the Scribes and Pharisees who were hoping to trap him into either violating the Law of Moses by refusing to condemn her, or betraying his own doctrine of forgiveness.  The artist has chosen the moment when Christ tells the accusers that they have the right to stone her only if they themselves are without sin.

Description: The shaped backs, seats and arm-pads are upholstered in contemporary gros-point (cross stitch) needlework worked in wool and silk with a broad design of palmettes and arabesques in various shades of red on a yellow ground, restuffed and secured by brass-h
WebDescription:
The shaped backs, seats and arm-pads are upholstered in gros-point (cross stitch) needlework worked in wool and silk with a design of palmettes and arabesques in various shades of red on a yellow ground.  The upholstery is secured by brass-headed nails. 

Many designs for armchairs of this form can be seen in pattern books of the same period the chair was made, where they are termed 'French Chairs'. Chippendale remarked 'Both backs and Seats must be covered with Tapestry, or any other sort of Needlework' and advised the corners be 'nailed with Brass Nails'.

The cabriole forelegs and knurl feet are ornamented with fronded cabochon motifs, plain rear cabrioles on club feet; the curvilinear slightly channelled seat rails styled with rococo scrolls, incised lines and gadrooning centre on acanthus sprays; twisted scroll-over elbows with frond enrichment; the dished feet conceal brass castors with leather rollers. Beech back frame and seat rails faced with mahogany, oak corner struts.

Description:
Wooded landscape with two men walking with dogs in the middle foreground.  A third man is seated by the side of the road.  There is a body of water to the left and a building on a hill in the distance.  

Subject: landscape
WebDescription: This beautifully wrought small painting is a classic example of a cabinet picture, so called for their original purpose of decorating a 'cabinet' or small intimate room in the house of a connoisseur.  Cabinet pictures were characterised by their small scale and exquisite quality and were intended to thrill the eye of the spectator rather than impart any other message.

Description: Mary and Joseph to the left, three shepherds to the right standing over baby Jesus .  Light radiates from the baby.  The shepherd in the centre of the picture is holding a cockeral.  The shepherd beside him has hands clasped in prayer.
WebDescription: The scene, one of the most familiar yet most potent in Christian imagery, is interpreted here in a most unusual way and with a number of hidden symbols.  To the right, in the half light, is Joseph whose face is thrown into a second shadow by a trick of the light.  This second profile has the features of the future apostle St Peter who is staring at the cockerel being held by one of the shepherds - a reference to his later denial of Christ.

Description:
The apostle, James, is dressed as a pilgrim, holding a staff and enjoining his unseen companions towards their sacred destination.  It refers to his own cult at Compostella where his relics have been venerated for centuries.
Subject: religion
WebDescription: This is one from a series of paintings of the twelve apostles ordered in 1661 by Cardinal Antonio Barberini for the family palace in Rome.  His original choice of artist was Andrea Sacchi who finished a St Peter before he died, whereupon the commission was handed over to his follower Carlo Maratta.

Description:
This genre scene depicts two seated men talking while a spaniel lies in the right-hand corner.

The painting was bequeathed as a Jan Steen (now attrib. to Michael Sweerts).  It may have been painted in his Rome period when Sweerts arrived in 1646.  He j
WebDescription: Sweerts was a Fleming who, like many artists of the 17th century from the Low Countries, travelled and worked in Rome.  Here he was greatly influenced by the so-called 'bamboccianti' who specialised in scenes of peasants and low life, often with a narrative or anecdotal content.  Sweerts' scenes are distinctive for the almost sculptural monumentality of the figures, derived from his studies of classical sculpture.

Description: Full-length portrait of the 9th Viscount Irwin. The male figure is wearing a red/brown jacket and holds a black hat in his right hand. He is beginning to walk up some steps to the right of the viewer. In the bottom right corner there is dog looking up at
WebDescription: This is a portrait of Charles 9th Viscount Irwin (ticket no.196) that can be found in the State Bedroom at Temple Newsam House.  Charles succeeded to the title of 9th Viscount in 1763 after the death of his uncle George, 8th Viscount Irwin.  By then he had married, in 1758, one of London's wealthiest heiresses Frances Gibson Shepheard of which there is also a portrait (ticket no.366) in the State bedroom painted by Sir Joshua Reynolds.  Frances was the daughter of Samuel Shepheard who was a successful business man and landowner with a parliamentary career that lasted nearly 50 years. Upon her fathers death Frances inherited a fortune of 60,000.  A portrait of Samuel Shepheard (ticket no. 89) can be seen in the Picture Gallery.  This newly acquired wealth paid off the mortgage on the property, bought new silver, china and furniture and funded the re-modelling and re-decorating of the interiors as well as the services of Capability Brown in re-landscaping the park.   The Viscount and Viscountess were thought to be happily married and produced five daughters: Isabella, Francis, Elizabeth, Harriet and Louisa.  A charming portrait of these delightful girls at play can be seen at the top of the Oak Staircase at Temple Newsam House.  In addition a portrait of Isabella (ticket nos. 198) can be found in the South Bedroom and in the State Bedroom there is another portrait of Isabella (ticket no. 365) along with a portrait of Elizabeth (ticket no. 364).  Charles died in 1778 and the title became extinct as there was no male heir.  Frances continued at Temple Newsam during a long widowhood that was spent implementing continuous change to the house and park and on her new interest in politics.  When Frances died in 1807 Temple Newsam was inherited by Lord Hertford, the husband of her eldest daughter Isabella.  When he died in 1821 Isabella inherited Temple Newsam in her own right.

Description: This is a full-lenght portrait of Sir Arthur Ingram, standing in front of a classical pillar.
WebDescription: This portrait and one 19th Century copy are the only images to survive of Sir Arthur Ingram who rose to wealth and purchased Temple Newsam in 1622 for 12,000. Currently the portrait hangs in the Picture Gallery (ticket no. 94) at Temple Newsam House.  Sir Arthur bought the property from Ludovic Duke of Lennox who himself had been given Temple Newsam by his cousin James I of England and Scotland.  Believed to be the son of Hugh Ingram a successful haberdasher Sir Arthur carved out his own career in the service of the Crown's chief ministers.  This involved farming the royal monopolies, lending money to ambitious courtiers, equipping exhibitions to the New World and developing real estate.  His notoriety peaked when as Keeper of the Privy Purse he found his business practices and modest origins made him unpopular and forced his resignation.  At this point he focused his career and success in the North. He became Secretary to the Council of the North which was the King's executive body for ruling this area.  Here, Sir Arthur's interest in property persisted and he built Sheriff Hutton (1619) and New Park (1640) as well as a mansion on the site of the former Archbishop's Palace in York.  In between these projects he purchased Temple Newsam which he rebuilt over 20 years and which was only just complete at his death in 1642. From the extensive archives of Sir Arthur?s that have survived, it is possible to identify various people who helped with the redevelopment of Temple Newsam at that time.  They included his nephew and his long-serving steward John Matteson who were his clerk of works.  In addition to other tasks associated with the redevelopment of the house and the administration of the  estate, these men employed various specialists such as Francis Gunby for wood carving and panelling, John Burridge for plasterwork and Thomas Ventris for stonework/carving.  Outside the house the walled ornamental garden to the south of the house, with its raised promenades and classical Banqueting House was laid out by Frenchman Pierre Monjoy.  In addition kitchen gardens, orchards and nurseries were all established.  The archives also indicate that over 40.00 in payments was made around 1638 and 1639 to the artist George Geldorp quite possibly for this portrait.  Sir Arthur was married three times.  Two pictures of his daughter Elizabeth, by his first wife Susan Brown, can be found in the Oak Staircase at Temple Newsam.  Elizabeth married Simon Bennet and became known as Lady Bennet.   Sir Arthur's youngest son from his marriage to second wife Alice Ferrers was known as Sir Thomas Ingram and a portrait of him (ticket no. 42) can be found in the Blue Striped Dressing Room at Temple Newsam.  He married Frances Belasyse the daughter of a Viscount and together they had one child Mary who is thought to be one of the ghosts of Temple Newsam. A portrait of Mary (ticket no. 45) can be seen in the Gothic Room at Temple Newsam.  When Sir Arthur died in 1642 it was his eldest son, Sir Arthur Ingram the younger  born to his first wife Susan Brown that inherited Temple Newsam.  Sir Arthur Ingram the younger was also married twice and had many children the eldest of whom, Thomas Ingram was next to inherit Temple Newsam.  He married Mary Paylor daughter of Sir Watkinson Paylor of Thoralby, Yorkshire.  Mary sadly died in childbirth and when Thomas died in 1660 his brother Henry Ingram inherited Temple Newsam.  A portrait of Henry (ticket no. 6) can be found in the Great Hall at Temple Newsam.

Description: Subject: townscape-Rome
WebDescription: This painting along with 'Architectural Fantasy' was acquired by Henry, seventh Viscount Irwin of Temple Newsam in c.1745 to hang as overmantels in his newly completed Saloon or Picture Gallery.  They are visually integral to each fireplace which were made after a design of William Kent by the master sculptor, Robert Doe of London.

Description: Subject: architecture-fantasy
WebDescription: This painting along with 'View on the Tiber' was acquired by Henry, seventh Viscount Irwin of Temple Newsam in c.1745 to hang as overmantels in his newly completed Saloon or Picture Gallery.  They are visually integral to each fireplace which were made after a design of William Kent by the master sculptor Robert Doe of London.

Description: This oil portrait painting is of Hugh Ingram, whose younger son bought Temple Newsam in 1622; This painting then appears in the 1703 inventory of Temple Newsam House; Acquired by the Halifax Family; Donated by the Earl of Halifax and acquired through gran
WebDescription: This portrait is of Hugh Ingram and was first recorded in a Temple Newsam inventory in 1703. The portrait currently hangs in the Gallery Passage (ticket no. 142) at Temple Newsam House.  Hugh Ingram was born in Thorp-on-Hill, Rothwell, Yorks and gained success as a haberdasher in London during Queen Elizabeth's reign.  He was married in 1652 to Anne Goldthorpe the daughter of Richard Goldethorpe who at one time was the Lord Mayor (1556) and an MP (1559) of York.  The couple had three sons.  William, who later became Canon of York Minster, Arthur and John.  It is understood to be his son Arthur who became the self made plutocrat that purchased Temple Newsam in 1622 from Ludovic Duke of Lennox  who himself had been given Temple Newsam by his cousin  James I of England and Scotland.  A portrait of Arthur (ticket no. 94) currently hangs in the Picture Gallery at Temple Newsam house.

Description:
Irwin''s dates 1686-1714
Subject: portrait
WebDescription: This is a portrait of Edward the 4th Viscount Irwin and eldest son of the 3rd Viscount and Viscountess Irwin.  The picture (ticket no.269) can be found along with another portrait of the 4th Viscount (ticket no. 263) in the Crimson Bedroom at Temple Newsam.  Edward succeeded his father aged 15 years in 1702.  His education at Eton and Cambridge was completed between 1704-7 with an extended Grand Tour of Europe where he was accompanied by his brother Rich.  This portrait by Thomas van der Wilt is thought to have been completed whilst Edward visited Delft in Holland during the Tour.  Edward appears to have made the most of this experience which involved a duel near Utrecht, purchasing books and pictures in Venice and reputed amorous adventures in Italy. Back at Temple Newsam his purchases were used to furnish the house.  In the grounds he laid out the mile-long East Avenue with its bridge and ponds and in what appears to reflect an inherited love of sport from his father, he kept a stud of race horses, a pack of hounds and huntsmen and a stock of deer.  Edward died prematurely aged 28 years from smallpox.  He was succeeded by his brother Rich who became the 5th Viscount Irwin. There is a portrait of Rich ( ticket no. 265) in the Crimson Bedroom.

Description: Subject: portrait
WebDescription: This is a portrait of Edward the 4th Viscount Irwin and eldest son of the 3rd Viscount and Viscountess Irwin.  The picture (ticket no.263) can be found at Temple Newsam along with another portrait of the 4th Viscount (ticket no. 269) in the Crimson Bedroom.  Edward succeeded his father aged 15 years in 1702.  His education at Eton and Cambridge was completed between 1704-7 with an extended Grand Tour of Europe where he was accompanied by his brother Rich. Edward appears to have made the most of this experience which involved a duel near Utrecht, purchasing books and pictures in Venice and reputed amorous adventures in Italy. Back at Temple Newsam his purchases were used to furnish the house.  In the grounds he laid out the mile-long East Avenue with its bridge and ponds and in what appears to reflect an inherited love of sport from his father, he kept a stud of race horses, a pack of hounds and huntsmen and a stock of deer.  Edward died prematurely aged 28 years from smallpox.  He was succeeded by his brother Rich who became the 5th Viscount Irwin. There is a portrait of Rich (ticket no. 265) in the Crimson Bedroom.

Description: Subject: portrait
WebDescription: This portrait of Rich the 5th Viscount Irwin (ticket no. 265) and second son of the 3rd Viscount and Viscountess can be found in the Crimson Bedroom at Temple Newsam House.  Rich succeeded in 1714 after his elder brother Edward, 4th Viscount Irwin, died prematurely of smallpox.  Rich, like his elder brother, was also educated at Eton and Cambridge and he accompanied Edward on a Grand Tour of Europe between 1704-7.  Rich also had military experience fighting in the War of the Spanish Succession.  In 1718 Rich married Lady Anne Howard the daughter of the third Earle of Carlisle and a portrait (ticket no 110) of the couple hangs in the Picture Gallery.  This picture of Rich and his wife is attributed to Jonathan Richardson and dates from 1750.  Rich like many of the aristocracy of his time, invested large sums in the South Sea Company and when the South Sea Bubble burst the money was lost.  Unfortunately, he was unable to recover his financial situation by taking up the position of Governor of Barbados, which was worth 5000 a year, as he died of smallpox.   The family finances were stretched, not least due to the three 'widows pensions' being claimed by three dowager Viscountesses.  This was ameliorated eventually by the taking out of a mortgage that was later paid off with the arrival of an heiress in the next generation of the family.  He was succeeded by his brother Arthur who became the 6th Viscount Irwin, a portrait of whom can be found in the Great Hall.

Description:
canon of Westminster
Subject: portrait; male
WebDescription: This is a portrait of George who succeeded his brother to become the 8th Viscount Irwin in 1761.  This portrait (ticket no. 268) can be found in the Crimson Bedroom of Temple Newsam House.  He was the 6th son of the 3rd Viscount and Viscountess Irwin.  After leaving Oxford George had entered the church and became a canon of Westminster and Chaplain to the Speaker of the House of Commons.  He never lived at Temple Newsam which he made over to his nephew and heir, Charles, the future 9th Viscount in 1758.  A portrait of Charles (ticket no. 196) can be found in the state bedroom.

Description: Half-portrait of Lady William Gordon. The female sitter is wearing a gold and white dress and a long red headdress. She holds aside some of the red headdress with her left hand.
WebDescription:
Frances, Lady William Gordon inherited Temple Newsam in 1834 when her elder sister Isabella died aged 75 years old.  An engraving of Frances before her marriage can be seen in the Lady William Gordon room and a portrait (ticket no. 372) of her can be seen in the State Bedroom.  Lady William's husband, Lord William Gordon, was notorious as a philanderer yet the philanthropic Frances is thought to have extended her charity to sponsoring the education of at least one of her husband's illegitimate children.  Together they had only one daughter Frances Kier Gordon who predeceased her mother.  So it was that in 1841 when Frances died, her nephew Hugo Charles inherited Temple Newsam.  Hugo shared the name of his father Hugo Meynell who was the husband of Frances's sister Elizabeth. Portraits of Elizabeth (ticket no. 364) and her husband Hugo (ticket no, 370) can both be found in the state bedroom.  Portraits of their younger son Admiral Henry Meynell (ticket no. 379) can be found in the Boudoir at Temple Newsam.  Henry had a distinguished naval career and held a number of appointments at the courts of three English Monarchs.  He died in Paris an unmarried man leaving a considerable fortune.
Hugo Charles Meynell now added the name Ingram to his own in order to perpetuate the memory of his mother's family.   Hugo married Georgiana Pigou but they spent little time at Temple Newsam.  The Meynells were celebrated sportsmen and only appeared to be at the estate for the shooting season.  So it was that the estate was run by the stewards who were three generations of the Leather family.  During this period the real potential of the estate began to be developed including mines, forestry and investment in real estate and railways.  The house, when not in use by the owners for entertainment, was a tourist attraction receiving visitors in the summer months.  
In 1869 when Hugo Charles died he was succeeded by his only son Hugo Francis, the last direct descendant of Sir Arthur Ingram.  Portraits of Hugo Francis (ticket nos. 380 &172) can be seen in the Boudoir and Oak Corridor respectively with a further portrait in the State Bedroom.

Title Sort: The Political Medley or Things as They Were in June
Description: Under the canopy of the 'Hertford Nursery', Lady Hertford dangles the Regent over a commode, her son Lord Yarmouth behind, Lord Hertford below. She says 'Really my Love it is impossible to make a Cabinet out of such discordant Materials' pointing to timbe
WebDescription:
After the assasination of Prime Minister Spencer Perceval in May 1812 Parliament called for a new 'strong and efficient Administration'. The Prince felt obliged to offer his former Whig friends a number of Cabinet seats in a new coalition. They refused, hoping that they would be offered the entire government, and insisted on the power to re-appoint the Prince's entire Household. As this would have meant turning out the Hertfords, the Prince refused and instead invited Lord Liverpool to become Premier. This political gamble was undoubtedly the inspiration of the Hertfords, but which proved to be very successful - the Prince never had to call upon the Whigs to form a government. Here, under the canopy of the 'Hertford Nursery', Lady Hertford dangles the Regent over a commode, her son Lord Yarmouth behind, Lord Hertford below. She says 'Really my Love it is impossible to make a Cabinet out of such discordant Materials' pointing to timber blocks: Liverpool's ash, Moira's heart of oak, Grenville's log wood, Castlereagh's Middleburg Yew (reference to Walcheren disaster). Lord Hertford says 'Keep him at play My Dear or we are Lost'. There are many complicated references to the personalities involved in the political crisis: eg Wellesley in turban pushing down a lid on Catholic Restrictions coming from a manhole labelled Ireland.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Description: A carriage contains the Regent and Lady Hertford being driven by the Devil and Lord Yarmouth. Lord Hertford in court dress with the Lord Chamberlain's wand and cuckold's antlers is outrider. She says to the Regent 'We have had a glorious ride my love ! It
WebDescription:
A carriage contains the Regent and Lady Hertford being driven by the Devil and Lord Yarmouth. Lord Hertford in court dress with the Lord Chamberlain's wand and cuckold's antlers is outrider. She says to the Regent 'We have had a glorious ride my love ! It is worth Half a Crown'. He answers 'I have not Half a Crown to give thee. Would that I had'. Behind is a wagon with women entitled ' For Yarmouth. Second hand Pieces from Wales'. They pass in front of 'Female Asylum' full of the Regent's discarded women, including Mrs Fitzherbert who wails ' Ah I remember the time when I myself enjoyed those loves. But he has forgot his poor F'. A sign points 'To Ragley'. A virtually identical satire was published in 1820, after it became known that Lady Hertford had been dropped, showing Lady Conyngham in the carriage with the Prince.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: The Spirit of the Book or Anticipation of the Year 1813
Description: The Regent stands exclaiming against an apparition 'Spirit of the Book, Chapter of Evidence and Delicate Investigation'. Lady Hertford collapses before it while the Princess of Wales says 'I will have justice on my enemies', surrounded by her followers.
WebDescription:
The Regent stands exclaiming against an apparition 'Spirit of the Book, Chapter of Evidence and Delicate Investigation'. Lady Hertford collapses before it while the Princess of Wales says 'I will have justice on my enemies', surrounded by her followers. The satire refers to the threatened and imminent publication of 'The Book, a report of the Delicate Investigation' the reply by the Princess of Wales' political friends to the 'Delicate Investigation' set up by the government in 1806 to enquire into her alleged adulturous conduct. 'The Book' was said to contain highly damaging evidence of the Regent's own immoral behaviour. It was obviously a blatent attempt by the Whigs and the Princess to obtain revenge for the Regent's desertion of them (see also no 17). Now in 1813 there was a proposal in Parliament to re-examine the 'Delicate Investigation'.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: Portrait of Mrs Brown, Housekeeper at Bramham Park
Description:
Full length portrait of the housekeeper at Bramham Park.  An old lady stands with her hands clasped in front of her.  She wears an apron and a mop cap.                     
Subject: portrait
WebDescription:
This is one of a group of at least eleven portraits of servants painted in the early 1820s for George Lane Fox, the squire of Bramham Park, Yorkshire.  Six of these are now at Temple Newsam House, of which five were painted by George Garrard ARA and one by the Hull artist John Widdas.  
Mrs Brown the Housekeeper was the senior female domestic servant responsible for all the lower female servants and for the supervision of the kitchen, the laundry and the general housekeeping.  She was unmarried and lived in the house.  Together with the footman she was responsible for locking up the house at night.  She was still in service at the time of the fire which gutted the house in 1826.

Dimensions:
object height: 72 cm
object width: 55.6 cm
Description: Subject: portrait
WebDescription: This remarkable self portrait almost certainly arrived at Temple Newsam in 1709 in the same consignment as approx 40 paintings of landscapes, seascapes and battle scenes ordered by Henry, fourth Viscount Irwin in Venice two years earlier.  Their authorship was soon forgotten but they are now recognised as the work of the Paduan artist Antonio Marini.  This 'Self Portrait' must have been included in the series since 'An Italian artist's head' is recorded in every inventory of the house until 1922.

Title Sort: Patent Puppets alias the Hertford Fantocchini
Description: Lady Hertford confronts John Bull in front of the Theatre Royal, Hertford. She manipulates Perceval (the Prime Minister) on stage with Carlton House in the background. She holds Tory puppets in her hand (Wellesley, Buckingham, Temple and Sidmouth) while d
WebDescription:
Lady Hertford confronts John Bull in front of the Theatre Royal, Hertford. She manipulates Perceval (the Prime Minister) on stage with Carlton House in the background. She holds Tory puppets in her hand (Wellesley, Buckingham, Temple and Sidmouth) while discarded Whig puppets are behind her (Grenville and Grey). She says '?all manufactured by me and my son. I can make them do anything. The work so easy'. He replies ' Laud Laud?what a clever lady thee must be. Whoy there can't be another in all Hertford'. The playbill advertises 'The Piece called Secret Influence'.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: Portrait of Hugo Francis Meynell Ingram
Description: This is a full-length portrait painting of Hugo Ingram, holding a shotgun, and set against a landscape backdrop.  It was probably painted to be diplayed with one of his wife as the account books record two seperate payments to the artist totalling 210.
WebDescription: In 1869 when Hugo Charles died his only son Hugo Francis, the last direct descendant of Sir Arthur Ingram succeeded as owner of Temple Newsam and Hoar Cross.  This portrait of Hugo Francis (ticket nos. 380) by Sir Francis Grant can be seen in the Boudoir.  Other portraits of Hugo Francis can be found in the Oak Corridor (ticket no. 172) and in the Sate Bedroom.  Hugo Francis continued his families association with fox hunting and became Master of the Hunt at Hoar Cross. Unfortunately, just two years after inheriting this title and the Temple Newsam estate he died from a fall in 1871.  His wife of just eight years, Emily Meynell Ingram who was the daughter of the first Viscount and Viscountess Halifax, then became a widow and a very wealthy independent woman. Emily became deeply attached to Temple Newsam and carried out various rebuilding schemes including building the Oak Staircase, creating the Darnley Room and redecorating the interiors with fine wallpapers.  Under the skill of her professional land agent John Farrer Temple Newsam became a financial success.  In addition Emily also commissioned G F Bodley to produce the Church of the Holy Angels at Hoar Cross as a memorial to her husband.  Emily was an accomplished amateur watercolourist with a particular interest in landscapes and albums of her work have survived among her descendents. Emily also enjoyed the delights of yachting with ownership of the 360 ton Ariadne that she used with friends to visit the Mediterranean and more northern waters.   Portraits of Emily can be found in the Boudoir (ticket nos. 52 & 381) as well as in the Oak Corridor (ticket no. 173) which was painted by Sir William Blake Richmond a Pre-Raphaelite artist.  Hugo Francis and Emily had no children and when Emily died in 1904 Temple Newsam was inherited by her nephew, her eldest brother?s son, Edward Frederick Lindley Wood.  He was just 23 years old and later became Lord Irwin, third Viscount Halifax and first Earl of Halifax.  A portrait of Edward (ticket no. 184) can be found in the Great Hall.

Title Sort: Princely Amusements or the Humors of the Family
Description: The Regent and his brothers the Dukes of Clarence, York and Sussex are ridiculed for their behaviour and are shown in appropriate recreations. The Regent is dancing with Princess Charlotte and Mrs Fitzherbert while the Princess of Wales exits from the roo
WebDescription:
The Regent and his brothers the Dukes of Clarence, York and Sussex are ridiculed for their behaviour and are shown in appropriate recreations. The Regent is dancing with Princess Charlotte and Mrs Fitzherbert while the Princess of Wales exits from the room. Lady Hertford holds up the political barometer in which two figures advance or recede: Grenville is advancing, Wellesley receding. Behind is her portrait inscribed Harford. The Duke of Sussex is on the extreme right is smoking a pipe behind Mrs Billington at the piano, standing on a sheet inscribed Lady Augusta Murray (his deserted wife). The Duke of Clarence in admiral's uniform plays cards opposite Mrs Jordan shouting 'I revoke' (he had recently deserted her); with the Duke of York, a notorious gambler, is ridiculed for his association with Mrs Carey.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Description: In the centre is a cross roads sign post: 'To Place' with six figures hastening off (incl. Perceval, Castlereagh, Sidmouth and Lord Hertford holding a bag labelled 'To repair and beautify old Hertford Abby'). 'To Glory': three equestrian military figures
WebDescription:
In the centre is a cross roads sign post: 'To Place' with six figures hastening off (incl. Perceval, Castlereagh, Sidmouth and Lord Hertford holding a bag labelled 'To repair and beautify old Hertford Abby'). 'To Glory': three equestrian military figures (with references to victories in the Peninsular): Wellington (Cuidad Rodrigo), Graham (Barossa) and Beresford (Merida), while behind walks Sidney Smith. 'To Ruin' shows John Bull carrying bundle of taxes with ragged children behind and a sign 'To the Union' nearby. 'To Pleasure' shows the Regent riding towards a tent with Messalina over it and the obese Lady Hertford reclining inside. Another path shows Yarmouth with a sign to Conway Castle with another reclining female in a tent with Libidinous Suk over it.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: Princely Predilections or Ancient Music and Modern Discord
Description: Madame Catalani sings from the gallery, the Prince is in dishevelled state, Lady Hertford leading him with a garter sash. Various identified friends old and new are shown, including Lady Howe who asks '?Well, since you got rid of your old friends, Howe do
WebDescription:
The title taken from the Duke of York's famous letter 'I have no predilection to indulge, no resentments to gratify?' Madame Catalani sings from the gallery, the Prince is in dishevelled state, Lady Hertford leading him with a garter sash. Various identified friends old and new are shown, including Lady Howe who asks '?Well, since you got rid of your old friends, Howe do you like your new ones ?' Lady Hertford  retorts 'Friends indeed ! You will always meet with a warm friend in Hertford'. Princess Charlotte weeps (as she had done at Carlton House) at her father's desertion of his Whig friends. Sheridan picks the pocket of John Bull.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: The Prince of Wales or the Fisherman at Anchor
Description: The Prince is the whale floundering in the Sea of Politics. Two fountains spurt from his mouth; to left the Liquor of Oblivion sprays Grenville, to right the Dew of Favour sprays Perceval on a boat, who has his anchor through the whale's lips entitled 'De
WebDescription:
The Prince is the whale floundering in the Sea of Politics. Two fountains spurt from his mouth; to left the Liquor of Oblivion sprays Grenville, to right the Dew of Favour sprays Perceval on a boat, who has his anchor through the whale's lips entitled 'Delicate Enquiry' (viz the enquiry into the Princess of Wales' adulteries). Lady Hertford is the mermaid, Lord H the furious merman, Mrs Fitzherbert a siren holding a mirror to the Prince. The anchor refers to Perceval's supposed blackmail of the Prince through his knowledge of his marital relations contained in 'The Book', the Princess of Wales' reply to the 'Delicate Investigation' which had examined her alleged adultery and which had been suppressed. Perceval was to be assassinated 11 days later causing a constitutional crisis in which the Regent was to follow Lady Hertford's advice in continuing to exclude the Whigs from power.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: The Coronation of the Empress of the Nairs
Description: Lady Hertford  is in a bath in the centre being crowned by the Regent, Lord Hertford behind. The royal princes with their mistresses and Princess Charlotte with Prince of Orange are on the right. The notorious Lady Buckinghamshire is seen with three grena
WebDescription:
Lady Hertford  is in a bath in the centre being crowned by the Regent, Lord Hertford behind. The royal princes with their mistresses and Princess Charlotte with Prince of Orange are on the right. The notorious Lady Buckinghamshire is seen with three grenadiers on the left. The satire is a skit based on the popular romance by J. H. Lawrence, 'The Empire of the Nairs' (1811), about a military caste of Malabar who practised polyandry or free love.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: The Pall Mall Apollo, or R....ty in a Blaze
Description: The Regent, dressed as Apollo is ablaze, with McMahon (his private secretary) trying to extinguish it. Next to him is the Apollo Belvedere, and beside this is Lady Hertford admiring a figure of Venus, exclaiming 'Well I think I may compare notes with her'
WebDescription:
Unknown allegory, the Regent dressed as Apollo is ablaze, with McMahon (his private secretary) trying to extinguish it. Next to him is the Apollo Belvedere, and beside this is Lady Hertford admiring a figure of Venus, exclaiming 'Well I think I may compare notes with her'. The allusion may be to the Prince's successful efforts to repatriate the Apollo Belvedere to the Vatican after the Napoleonic Wars.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: Polly & Lucy Takeing off the Restrictions vide Beggars Opera
Description: The Prince, as Macheath from The Beggar's Opera, stands between Mrs Fitzherbert (representing the Opposition) and Lady Hertford (the Administration), both untying his shackles while he sings 'How happy could I be with either'. Behind is Lord Eldon, the Lo
WebDescription:
The Prince, as Macheath from The Beggar's Opera, stands between Mrs Fitzherbert (representing the Opposition) and Lady Hertford (the Administration), both untying his shackles while he sings 'How happy could I be with either'. 'The Restrictions' probably refers to the limited political powers to which George was restricted during the first year of his Regency and from which he was now freed. Behind is Lord Eldon, the Lord Chancellor, standing between Perceval and Col. McMahon (the prince's Private Secretary) discussing topical issues. On the walls are two pictures, one of George Hanger, the Prince's boon companion, imprisoned for debt and the other of Sheridan as Bacchus.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: Delilah depriving Sampson of those Locks in which consisted his Strength
Description: In an allusion to the Old Testament story, Lady Hertford is cuts locks inscribed with the names of Whigs from the head of the Prince Regent who reclines against her knees.  Her son, Lord Yarmouth stands nearby with a guttering candle.  Behind the curtain
WebDescription:
This is the first of numerous satires directed against Lady Hertford and her influence over the Prince Regent. It appeared at the moment when the restrictions of the first year of the Regency had just expired and in theory the Prince was free to call for a government of his own choice. However, the prince's old friends the Whigs now learnt that they were not to form the new Administration on which they had pinned their hopes for so long. Lady Hertford was blamed for influencing the Prince. In an allusion to the Old Testament story she cuts locks inscribed with the names of Whigs from the head of the Regent who reclines against her knees. Her son Lord Yarmouth stands nearby with a guttering candle. Behind the curtain are Perceval (the Tory Premier) and Castlereagh (Foreign Secretary and Lady Hertford's nephew) making comments.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Description: Here the Prince rides a horse with the head of Richard Brinsley Sheridan (playwright) who tells him that he can find a way through the 'ugly road' by kicking away the features of the rejected and disappointed Whigs. He is about to enter Manchester Square
WebDescription:
In February 1812 when the Prince decided to retain the Tory Prime Minister Spencer Perceval his Whig friends considered themselves abandoned and became hostile. Only Richard Brinsley Sheridan, the playright, remained faithful. Here the Prince rides a horse with the head of Sheridan who tells him that he can find a way through the 'ugly road' by kicking away the features of the rejected and disappointed Whigs. He is about to enter Manchester Square where Hertford House was situated.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: Royal Gambols!! or the Old Oak in Danger
Description: The Prince swings on a tree with Lady Hertford to his right, Lady Conyngham (who had succeeded the former in his affections in December 1819) to his left. Devils try to demolish the tree made up with the heads of deceived husbands. John Bull exclaims 'Oh
WebDescription:
The Prince swings on a tree with Lady Hertford to his right, Lady Conyngham (who had succeeded the former in his affections in December 1819) to his left. Devils try to demolish the tree made up with the heads of deceived husbands. John Bull exclaims 'Oh dear ! My poor Old Oak - how it shakes - I fear they will break it down with their d-nd tricks'.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Description:
Cream silk ground with multicoloured pictorial embroidery worked in chain stitch showing a female figure sitting in a landscape. 

The female figure in contemporary dress is seated within a landscape of exotic birds, trees and flowers with a small dog a
WebDescription:
The cream silk ground is decorated with multicoloured pictorial embroidery, worked in chain stitch, showing a female figure sitting in a landscape. 

The female figure in contemporary dress is seated within a landscape of exotic birds, trees and flowers with a small dog at her knee. The motif of a tree rising from a mound on the right side is influenced in its compositional form by the 'Flowering Tree' motif found on imported Indian printed textiles of this date.

Description: Woven textile.  Blue dress silk with orange and white stylised decoration.  Brocaded floral sprays.  Part of a dress cuff with scalloped edging
WebDescription: The blue dress silk has stylised decoration in orange and white of brocaded floral sprays.  It is part of a dress cuff with a scalloped edging to prevent fraying.

Description: Coptic textile, wovenIt is rectangular, and the two longest edges have a border pattern of circular lozenges next to a solid black stripe.  In the centre is a pattern of three circular medallions with different motifs within.  The top circle depicts two h
WebDescription: This fragment of cloth is tapestry woven with a delicate design in black on a brown background.  It is rectangular, and the two longest edges have a border pattern of circular lozenges next to a solid black stripe.  In the centre is a pattern of three circular medallions with different motifs within.  The top circle depicts two human figures, the centre one has a geometric flower motif, and the bottom one depicts a goat and a horse.

Description: Woven silk, white ground with pattern of green and pink brocaded meandering branches on a lace ground alternated with brown, green, pink and yellow floral sprays
WebDescription: This woven silk has a white ground decorated with patterning of green and pink brocaded meandering branches set against a lace ground.  These alternate with brown, green, pink and yellow floral sprays.

Description: Woven silk chin with central design of green, red and yellow floral sprays on a cream ground, enclosed by red vertical stripes. On a jute backing stamped 'Marque Dposee Lyon. Paris. Bruxelles'
WebDescription: This woven silk chin has a central design of green, red and yellow floral sprays on a cream ground, enclosed by red vertical stripes. It is attached to a jute backing fabric stamped 'Marque Dposee Lyon. Paris. Bruxelles'.

Description: Arborescent chintz' with pattern of peonies and pomegranates. Part of a valance, faced with brown, red, yellow and green block-printed pattern on tabby weave cream ground. Backed with tabby weave cotton and quilted with a lattice design in running stitch
WebDescription: This 'Arborescent chintz' has a pattern of peonies and pomegranates. It was part of a valance, faced with brown, red, yellow and green block-printed pattern on tabby weave cream ground. The valance is backed with tabby weave cotton and quilted with a lattice design in running stitch. Areas of modern machine stitch repair can be seen.

Title Sort: Our Fat Friend Going to Roost
Description: The King is being carried to bed, dead drunk, by three peereses, one being Lady Conyngham who cries 'I'm as great as the Queen' while the other two (one of them probably Lady Hertford, the other perhaps Lady Jersey) sing 'We'll drown her in the bowl the b
WebDescription:
The King is being carried to bed, dead drunk, by three peereses, one being Lady Conyngham who cries 'I'm as great as the Queen' while the other two (one of them probably Lady Hertford, the other perhaps Lady Jersey) sing 'We'll drown her in the bowl the bowl'. It may allude to Lady Hertford's hopes of returning to royal favour nearly a year after being dumped.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: The Court of Love, or an Election the Island of Borneo
Description: The satire is a sequel to LEEAG.2000.0038, reflecting a dream in which the Prince chooses his ministers and household officers according to their proficiency in adultery. The principal characters are the Prince and Lady Hertford on the platform under a ca
WebDescription:
The satire is a sequel to 'The Coronation of the Empress of Nairs', reflecting a dream in which the Prince chooses his ministers and household officers according to their proficiency in adultery. The principal characters are the Prince and Lady Hertford on the platform under a canopy, Lord Hertford to the right with antlers, and a number of well known adulterers in the Regent's circle: the Duke of York, the Dukes of Cumberland and Clarence, Lords Melbourne, Headfort and Yarmouth. On the lower tier are figures of depravity while John Bull looks up in anger and tries to push his three young girls away crying 'Get away get away, if you go near the Platform you'll be ruined'.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: The Delicate Investigation of Secrets of ...
Description: The satire illustrated the 'The first book of the acts of the Regent' and shows an after dinner scene with the drunken Regent supported by Lady Hertford while Sheridan has collapsed on the floor. Half way down the table the Regent's brother the Duke of Su
WebDescription:
The satire illustrated the 'The first book of the acts of the Regent' and shows an after dinner scene with the drunken Regent supported by Lady Hertford while Sheridan has collapsed on the floor. Half way down the table the Regent's brother the Duke of Sussex and friends Sir John and Lady Douglas prepare more strong drink. The 'Delicate Investigation' refers to the report on the Princess of Wales' adulterous conduct set up by Parliament in 1806 in which the Douglas' had given perjured evidence. In 1813 it was proposed to re-examine the 'Delicate Investigation' again.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: Imperial Botany - or a peep at Josephine's Collection of English Exoticks
Description: The satire originally accompanied a text in the form of an imaginery letter from the ex-Empress Josephine 'to the Marchioness of H?.' (both ladies had been disappointed by their paramours). Josephine is in her garden at Malmaison outside Paris surrounded
WebDescription:
The satire originally accompanied a text in the form of an imaginery letter from the ex-Empress Josephine 'to the Marchioness of H?.' (both ladies had been disappointed by their paramours). Josephine is in her garden at Malmaison outside Paris surrounded by English plants, including a Wellington laurel. Pride of place goes to the Royal Sunflower with the face of the Prince of Wales, but twining round its stem is another plant 'Love in Idleness' A lady beside her says 'If you will allow me to give my opinion Madam I should prefer this to any other in your garden !!!.' Josephine answers 'Ah you rogue ! Why that is a favourite with the English ladies - I must cut away that love in idleness or it will ruin my plant'.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Description: Lady Hertford Satire
WebDescription:
The poem and caricature refer to the Regent's failure to appoint the Whigs to power in 1812.  Lady Hertford is prominent behind the throne where the Regent is opening the cloak of royal favour over the Tories.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

20 x 10 in. (50.8 x 25.4 cm)

Description: Yellow linen with a block printed resist design of  figures and Castles, depicting the story of the grape gatherers, chapter 13 of the Book of Numbers (Old Testament).
WebDescription: To make the design on this textile, a starch paste was spread onto the printing blocks to form the pattern then the whole cloth was dipped in dye. When washed the starch paste pattern is left.

Title Sort: Block printed Linen Textile With Chinoiserie figures
Dimensions:
object width: 10 1/2 in. (26.7 cm)
object length: 17 1/2 in. (44.5 cm)
Pattern unit: 15 3/4 in. (40 cm)
Description: Block printed cotton with stipple ground.  In madder and indigo colours with chinoiseriere pattern of men eating duck surmounted by feathered and floral cornucopia
WebDescription: This fragment is printed using a carved wooden block. Making the block took immense skill, especially in making the pins for the fine dotted background. When it was made Europeans were trying to imitate Indian cottons which dominated the market. This makes it very difficult to tell where the cotton came from.

Dimensions:
22 x 8 in. (55.9 x 20.3 cm)
Pattern unit: 16 1/2 in. (41.9 cm)
Description: Roller printed cotton with scenes of children playing
WebDescription: This textile shows children playing games. Images such as these were taken from popular prints. Such prints were known as "sentimental".

Dimensions:
object width: 15 in. (38.1 cm)
object width: 10 in. (25.4 cm)
Description: Block printed indigo dyed textile fragment.
WebDescription:
At first glance this is a deceptively simple textile to make.
Howver, stripes were one of the most difficult things to print by hand.  It would take a steady hand to line up a large heavy wooden block without spilling ink everywhere.
Floral patterns obscured many mistakes but witha simple stripe errors are easy to spot.

Description: Exquisitely woven dress silk in deep red. Pattern is formed by cartouches of flowers, bordered in trails of lace riccons, formed in white brocade, silver brocade
WebDescription:
A piece of silk of this complexity and this size would have taken over a day to make. A multitude of different weaving techniques and types of thread have been used.  
The technical achievements of draw loom weaving reached their peak by the end of the 1700s, before more mechanised weaving took over the industry.

Title Sort: A Ridicule or a new Aera, New Manners; alias the Age of Wonders
Description: Lady Hertford and the Regent at Hertford House, with Col. McMahon (the Prince's Secretary) in a bag (reticule) under the Prince's arm.  A skit on the recent appointment of McMahon as Keeper of Prince's Purse.
WebDescription:
Lady Hertford and the Regent at Hertford House, with Col. McMahon (the Prince's Secretary) in a bag (reticule) under the Prince's arm.  A skit on the recent appointment of McMahon as Keeper of Prince's Purse.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Description: The setting is the new Regent's Park in north London, with figures arranged as in a tapestry with heads of identifiable personalities. The Prince is seen as a stag to the left of centre, opposite Lady Hertford as a smaller stag who looks at him amorously.
WebDescription:
The setting is the new Regent's Park in north London, with figures arranged as in a tapestry with heads of identifiable personalities. The satire is a general skit on the Prince and his circle. He is seen as a stag to the left of centre, opposite Lady Hertford as a smaller stag who looks at him amorously. At the top in the centre is a decanter with the face of the prince and to the extreme left appear the faces of the Princess of Wales and Princess Charlotte.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Title Sort: The Bill Thrown Out but the Pains and Penalties Inflicted
Description: In the satire the King reclines 'a la chinois' attended by lady friends, with Lady Hertford seen from the rear on the right.
WebDescription:
The Bill of Pains and Penalties was in effect the Divorce Bill put together by George, now King, and his government in order to finally dispose of Queen Caroline on the grounds of her adultery. The Opposition rallied to the Queen's defence: the eventual vote was lost because of the opposition of the bishops who could not countenance the clause enabling divorce with the possibility of subsequent remarriage. The passage of the bill was the most talked about event in the first year of the king's reign, with the general public entirely on the side of the Queen. In the satire the King reclines, attended by lady friends, with Lady Hertford seen from the rear on the right.

For more information please see Mary Dorothy George 'Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires.  Preserved in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum', vol. IX 1811-1819, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1949) and vol. X 1820-1827, published by The Trustees of the British Museum (1952).

Description: The lobed hexagonal foot is raised and has short vertical flutings.  It supports a tall hexagonal stem with a knop of pierced Gothic tracery and masks, and a raised near hemispherical bowl.  The whole ensemble is very similar in style to standard late 15t
WebDescription:
The design is related in a general way to the drawings made by Frank Theodore (fl.c. 1910-1960) copying Bodley's designs for church plate (V&A E 1005-1010 1963), especially to a chalice apparently designed for Church Stretton in 1888.  Other similar chalices designed by Bodley and made by Jes Barkentin include those made  for the Hon Mrs Meynall Ingram's church of the Holy Angels at Hoar Cross, Staffordshire in 1873, and another made for the chapel at Clumber Park, Nottinghamshire in 1889.

For more information please see James Lomax 'British Silver at Temple Newsam and Lotherton Hall' (1992), Leeds Art Collections Fund

Description: Pratt ware. Moulded and painted in black, two shades of blue green and brown with images of three soldiers and a flag and the legend "LL VOL TEERS" believed to be Liverpool Volunteers.  Faint impressed mark on base "LEEDS POTTERY".
WebDescription:
Jug decorated with pictures of three soldiers and the legend 'L L volunteers'. On one side the soldiers are carrying their muskets in front of a Union Jack and on the other side they are firing them. 

The 'L L' seems to be short for Liverpool. The 79th Regiment of Foot, known as the Liverpool Volunteers was raised by the port of Liverpool in January 1778 for service in the American War of Independence. It was disbanded six years later following Britain's defeat in the war.

Medium/Materials: red earthenware, the upper side covered with white slip and trailed with light and dark red slip under a yellowish glaze
Description: Dish. Circular.  In the centre the Tree of Knowledge entwined with the Serpent between the figures of Adam and Eve surrounded by various birds, reptiles, fishes and animals; to the right of Adam a guardian angel and to the left of Eve a wyvern; on the rim
WebDescription:
There are three known dishes signed and dated by Thomas Toft.  This one, a similar decorated one in the Fitwilliam Museum, Cambridge and one in Chester Museum.

For more information please see Peter Walton 'Creamware and other English Pottery at Temple Newsam House, Leeds: A Catalogue of the Leeds Collection' 1976 Leeds Art Collections Fund.

Title Sort: Punch bowl painted with warehouses or Hongs.
Description: Large circular bowl with grisaille decoration heightened with gilt, most of which is worn. Outside: a view of the hongs (European and American workshops or warehouses) at Canton, on the Pearl River.  Canton is now known as Guangzhou, and is the largest ci
WebDescription: Punch bowl from Canton (Guangzhou), celebrating the trade with Europe. The bowl itself was made at Jhingdezhen, and the grey or grisaille decoration heightened with gilt, applied in Guangzhou.  Inside, in the centre, is a view of the East India Company ship 'Pitt'.  On the outside are the Hongs or warehouses of the English, French and others at Canton. These European hongs were burnt down in 1856. Bequeathed by Dorothy Ratcliffe, 1967.

object height: 23 cm (9 1/16 in.)
object diameter: 13 cm (5 1/8 in.)
Description: Solid body formed from two blocks of amethyst-tinted Derbyshire fluorspar, resting in a cast leaf-cut raised on a rosette stem, set on a plinth with concave corners; the vases, mounted with a pair of satyr masks linked by vine swags, are encircled by pear
WebDescription:
One of a pair. Solid body formed from two blocks of amethyst-tinted Derbyshire fluorspar, resting in a cast leaf-cut raised on a rosette stem, set on a plinth with concave corners; the vases, mounted with a pair of satyr masks linked by vine swags, are encircled by pearl-beading and a water leaf collar headed by a pineapple finial. One satyr head and one finial re-cast.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: The hollow pink fluorspar body is richly mounted with handles in the form of leafy female terminal busts, linked by fringed drapery swags festooned with foliage; the vase rests in an acanthus cup with berried sprays standing on a circular foot bordered by
WebDescription:
The hollow pink fluorspar body is richly mounted with handles in the form of leafy female terminal busts, linked by fringed drapery swags festooned with foliage; the vase rests in an acanthus cup with berried sprays standing on a circular foot bordered by a bay leaf wreath supported on a square black marble plinth; the loose cover (replaced) is surmounted by a pineapple finial.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: The upright frame, with a serpentine crest rail and cross stretcher, is fitted with a sliding panel held in position by steel springs set into grooved posts. the stand and slender splayed legs ending in spade toes are of solid mahogany outlined in rosewoo
WebDescription:
The panel of this fire screen is covered on both sides with a brocaded silk dress fabric dating from c. 1765-70.  The pattern of floral bouquets and blue meanders suggests that it may be French.

The upright frame, with a serpentine crest rail and cross stretcher, is fitted with a sliding panel held in position by steel springs set into grooved posts. The stand and slender splayed legs ending in spade toes are of solid mahogany outlined in rosewood; the legs are reinforced underneath with their original brass spines.

Title Sort: chair, one of set of twenty
Description:
Suite of twenty chairs, four settees and a day-bed by James Pascall, London.

The entire suite is covered with wool needlework executed in tent-stitch, stuffed over the rails and fastened down by round-headed brass nails cast in one piece; the many-colo
WebDescription:
Suite of twenty chairs, four settees and a day-bed by James Pascall, London.

The entire suite is covered with wool needlework executed in tent-stitch, stuffed over the rails and fastened down by round-headed brass nails.   The multicoloured design of garden flowers, all depicted larger than life and shaded to give the appearance of relief, is worked in the opposite direction to the greenish-gold ground.  Some flower centres are enhanced with French knots and the double-headed day bed has two bolsters. 

The settees are raised on six- and the bed eight-hipped cabriole legs bordered by C-scrolls and ornamented with a hatched flame cartouche; the leafy pad feet conceal castors with leather rollers; the settees have curved flattened arms enriched with flame-work and fronds terminating in shaggy monster heads, the supports are carved with beaded acanthus and scrolls. The frames of the settees are made from beech, with walnut arms.  They have their original webbing and hair stuffing.

This set formed part of a larger suite commissioned by Henry 7th Viscount Irwin of Temple Newsam for the Picture Gallery which he completely redesigned from the original Long Gallery between 1738 and 1745. It comprised in addition, a pair of console tables, a pair of side tables and eight torchres which almost certainly relate to a payment dated 7th August 1746 'to James Pascall, London, 4 tables, 2 Settees, etc 364.16.0'. Very little is known about his activities other than scattered references in Sir Richard Hoare's Private Accounts recording various payments to 'Mr Pascall the carver and gilder' or 'framemaker' and his wife Ann between 1733 and 1751. A pair of matching stools is now at Garrowby, Yorkshire.

Description: Of rectangular design with inner and outer leaf mouldings on which are super-imposed serpentine borders centring on frond clusters, the rounded corners feature shells and foliage. The ornament is in cast composition. The frame, which contains the text of
WebDescription:
The frame, which contains the text of a speech delivered by the Duke of York to the House of Lords on 25 April 1825, is surmounted by a carved ducal coronet and cushion. 

The historic Temple Newsam collection also includes a portrait of the Duke of York painted by Henry Wyatt in 1825 and two other Royal portraits in frames of closely similar design and date.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund

Description: The circular folding ropes are lined with green baize, both rear legs swing out on beech fly-rails to support the flaps; the top, frieze and square tapered legs are veneered with mahogany panels having satinwood borders, tulipwood crossbanding, and box an
WebDescription:
The circular folding ropes are lined with green baize, both rear legs swing out on beech fly-rails to support the flaps; the top, frieze and square tapered legs are veneered with mahogany panels having satinwood borders, tulipwood crossbanding, and box and ebony corner strings. The pine top, medial brace and laminated frieze are stained red.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: The H-pattern bases support broad uprights headed by crossbars mounted with pairs of hinged trelliswork flaps, which can be raised or lowered through 90 degrees, by operating an adjustable horse on each side engaging ratchets; turned horizontal guide bars
WebDescription:
The H-pattern bases support broad uprights headed by crossbars mounted with pairs of hinged trelliswork flaps, which can be raised or lowered through 90 degrees, by operating an adjustable horse on each side engaging ratchets; turned horizontal guide bars; the runners are set on bun feet concealing brass swivel castors. Large flush plate hinges and countersunk brass sockets to receive pins. One stand is impressed: 'GILLOWS . LANCASTER'.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: The tripod legs are vigorously carved with acanthus fronds headed by anthemion motifs and terminate in rosette whorls; the turned shaft is raised on a bulbous base pierced in the gothic taste and ornamented with husks, leaf-tongues and foliate collars, th
WebDescription:
The panel of petit-point wool needlework portrays lovers in a pastoral landscape, set in a rococo style cartouche. 

The tripod legs are carved with acanthus fronds headed by anthemion motifs and terminate in rosette whorls; the turned shaft is raised on a bulbous base pierced in the gothic taste and ornamented with husks, leaf-tongues and foliate collars, the pole is capped by a wrythen finial. 

The finial and pole are replacements, one whorl foot has been renewed and the screen may not belong to the stand.

Description: Tablet, carved in high relief with a quiver of arrows and a horn amid crossed oak boughs. Painted white and gold.
WebDescription:
From the architrave of a door case rescued from Methley Hall, 24 x 56 (10 x 22). Two companion door cases were re-erected in the Prince's Room at Temple Newsam. The green and gold leaf-blocked cornice survives in a damaged state.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: The gilt chairs are designed with oval, slightly curved backs supported on acanthus stays, swept arms and square tapered legs enriched with overlapping coin rosettes; the padded arm rests carved with husks, are united to the back frames by leafy scrolls w
WebDescription:
The Gobelins tapestry covers are woven in wool with a high proportion of silk on a 'damas cramoisy ground; the backs display colourful bunches of garden flowers tied with ribbons, the seats are strewn with floral sprays and the arm pads portray various blossoms; the panels are all different. 

The gilt chairs are designed with oval, slightly curved backs supported on acanthus stays, swept arms and square tapered legs enriched with overlapping coin rosettes; the padded arm rests carved with husks, are united to the back frames by leafy scrolls while the serpentine-fronted seat rails are ornamented with fluting between pearl-beaded and twisted ribbon mouldings, The legs, headed by patera blocks end in turned leaf-cup feet. The sofa is basically of identical design except for the absence of an open gap between seat and back and the existence of eight legs; the original tie-rods have been replaced by three iron tie-rods, the back is reinforced behind two struts. 

These pieces are from a suite commissioned by Sir Lawrence Dundas for his tapestry drawing room at Moor Park, Hertfordshire. In 1784 the wall tapestries and furnishings were installed by his son at 19 Arlington Street, London and remained together until 1934 when a majority of the wall hangings were taken to Aske Hall, Yorkshire, where they remain; the other tapestry furnishings were sold. One sofa, six armchairs, two window stools and two fire screens passed to the Philadelphia Museum of Art (1941.6.1-11), the four remaining armchairs and a sofa with two cushions are now at Temple Newsam House. Fell and Turtons' account for this suite is dated 1771.

Description: The gilt chairs are designed with oval, slightly curved backs supported on acanthus stays, swept arms and square tapered legs enriched with overlapping coin rosettes; the padded arm rests carved with husks, are united to the back frames by leafy scrolls w
WebDescription: This set of matching furniture consists of four arnchairs and a sofa.  They were specially made for the owner of Moor Park in Hertfordshire in 1771.  The chairs are made of beech wood and the covers are of Gobelins tapestry woven using a mixture of wool and silk.
