Description: The cabinet, of architectural design, is raised on a richly carved stand supported by cabriole legs. The central door and sides are mounted with glazed panels of chenille needlepoint executed in cotton and silk against a tent stitched ground worked in bla
WebDescription:
The cabinet, of architectural design, is raised slightly on a richly carved stand supported by cabriole legs. The central door and sides are mounted with glazed panels of chenille needlepoint executed in cotton and silk against a tent stitched ground worked in black wool. The front panel depicts a basket of garden flowers on a grassy hillock; those at each end portray similar floral compositions. The cabinet is headed by a broken pediment cantering on a finely carved fronded cartouche ending in a mask; the frieze is enriched with a continuous design of scrolling leaves and flower heads, while the front corners are ornamented with free-standing Corinthian columns. The side panels are surmounted by shells between paired leaves and the needlework on the front is set beneath a tinctured armorial cartouche suspending floral festoons. 

The interior contains twenty-two small ogee-shaped drawers arranged in two tiers flanking two graduated long drawers faced with panels of silk embroidery on a satin ground, concealing six pairs of secret drawers; the upper part is designed as a mirror-lined niche incorporating twelve Ionic columns, the floor decorated with parquetry and the ceiling with inlaid star motifs. 

The stand, banded with a key-pattern fret and lavishly carved with shells, rococo foliage and floral sprays is raised on massive cabriole legs connected to the apron by fronded spurs; the claw and ball feet are carved in full relief. Oak carcase veneered in mahogany with some pine inner structures.

Medium/Materials: partridge wood(?); satinwood, tulipwood, pine etc.
Dimensions:
object height: 25 cm (9 13/16 in.)
object diameter: 11.5 cm (4 1/2 in.)
Description: In the form of an octagonal vase set on a square foot; each section is veneered in a chocolate-coloured wood with tulipwood divisions, the hinged lid and base are banded with 'Van Dyke' pattern borders in green-stained and pale inlays between chequered st
WebDescription:
In the form of an octagonal vase set on a square foot; each section is veneered in a chocolate-coloured wood with tulipwood divisions, the hinged lid and base are banded with 'Van Dyke' pattern borders in green-stained and pale inlays between chequered strings. The body is raised on a turned satinwood stem and capped by an acorn finial; dummy keyhole; internal lid with ivory knob; foil lining.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Medium/Materials: pine headboard, tester and cornices, silk velvet and damask furnishing fabrics, gold, cotton, jue, oak, lime.
Dimensions:
object height: 142 in. (360.7 cm)
object length: 90 in. (228.6 cm)
object width: 85 in. (215.9 cm)
Description:
New Parts under LEEAG. 2011.343* More records under 1981.17.
This descripiton was made in 2012 just after the restoration was made. Bed, with canoby or tester suspender from the ceiling by an iron hook and rods. This form of bed is known as a flying or A
WebDescription:
The bed was commissioned by The 1st Earl of Poulett for the state bedchamber at Hinton House, Hinton St. George, Somerset. The Earl was Lord Steward of the Royal Household 1711-14 and according to family tradition the bed was made for Queen Anne's visit to Hinton House at the time of the christening of one of the Earl's children to whom she was a godmother, but owing to ill health the visit never took place.

For more information please see C.Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall. A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes. Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in associated with the National Art Collections Fund

Title Sort: Gothic chair, one of a pair
Dimensions:
object height: 52 in. (132.1 cm)
object width: 23 in. (58.4 cm)
object depth: 19 1/2 in. (49.5 cm)
Description: Of picturesque Gothic design, the tall open backs composed of twin pointed arches surmounted by crocketed spires and filled with quatrefoil tracery. The corner posts and the central uprights are ornamented with a relief system of applied Perp. panels encl
WebDescription:
Of picturesque Gothic design, the tall open backs composed of twin pointed arches surmounted by crocketed spires and filled with quatrefoil tracery. The corner posts and the central uprights are ornamented with a relief system of applied Perp. panels enclosing lozenges and foliate rosettes; they too are capped by crocketed finials. The seat rails are edged with pendant Gothic arcading, while the outer faces of the chamfered front legs bear Perp. panels alternating with quatrefoils - an identical system of blind fretwork once ornamented the sides of the rear legs, but this is now entirely missing. 

The seat is worked in early 20th century gros-point needlework depicting stylised botanical motifs in red, yellow and brown on a green ground. The beech seat rails are faced with a delicate three-ply mahogany arcade, the open tracery is also of three-ply construction; all the surface ornament is applied and much is now lost. Beech corner bars, four angle irons on one chair, the other has a single brace.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: The veneered hoop back is composed of paired scrolls enclosing a shaped splat joined to the uprights by two sets of spurs, the lower ones carved with clasps; the splat centres on a 'verre eglomise' heraldic devise (a peacock's tail surmounted by a coronet
WebDescription:
The armorials belong to Nicholas, 4th and last Earl of Scarsdale, who started rebuilding Sutton Scarsdale, Derbyshire in 1724 and died in 1736, Stylistically the chairs cannot predate 1720. The attribution of authorship is based on the discovery, reported in Country Life, 15 Feb. 1919, p.171 of a lead plaque inscribed with the name of the architect Francis Smith of Warwick and thirteen of the principal tradesmen involved in building and equipping the house, the only furniture maker mentioned is 'Thomas How of Westminster, gentleman, upholsterer'. 

Thomas How was in business at Jarman Street, corner of Duke Street, Westminster 1710-33; he provided luxurious furnishings, including a State Bed to the 5th Earl of Salisbury at Hatfield House, Hertfordshire. 'Verre eglomise' (a peacock's tail surmounted by a coronet) panels on chairs are unprecedented - they may have been conceived as part of a unified room scheme which included matching pier glasses and tables. Gilt-lead applied ornament is also rare on furniture of this date. 

The Sutton Scarsdale papers have not survived and the house in now a roofless ruin; Pevsner stated that it was 'easily the grandest mansion of its date in the county'. To see some of the sumptuous interior decoration one must visit the Philadelphia Museum of Art which acquired the Oak Room. The suite of twelve chairs are described in The Reminiscences of Lady Dorothy Nevill (ed. Ralph Nevill), 1906, pp.228-30, as having passed into the hands of an American collector.

This now famous suite is next heard of when it was partly destroyed in a fire at the Brussels International Exhibition, 1910. They were in a period room re-created by White, Allom & Co. of 15 George Street, London who specialised in both reproductions and antiques. White, Allom & Co. commissioned copies to make good their loss and for general sale. The suite, or what remained of it, is next heard of when it was again damaged in a fire at the 5th Avenue, New York, apartment of Mrs Annie C. Kane in August 1921.

The suite seems originally to have consisted of twelve chairs (four of which were lost in the Brussels fire), two settees and a pair of pedestals. The surviving examples appear to be: a pair of chairs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (incised X & I); a pair of chairs in the Frick collection, New York (VIII & XII); a chair at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum (IV); a pair of chairs at Temple Newsam (VII & IX); one pedestal at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. 

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Medium/Materials: beech, wool, linen, horse hair, brass
Dimensions:
object height: 42 in.
object width: 20 3/4 in.
object depth: 17 1/4 in.
Description: Of rectangular design, the frame constructed of blocked spiraltwist members with plain rear and side stretchers; the seat and back are upholstered in wool Turkeywork edged by a tasselled fringe secured with dome-headed brass nails, the braid of the back u
WebDescription:
This backstool is upholstered in wool Turkeywork, a type of knotted embroidery which was widely practiced in England from the sixteenth to the eighteenth centuries.  It is stitched in rows with looped threads which are often cut so that the surface of the fabric resembles the pile of a rug.  Designs of stylised flowers were very popular. 

The upholstery is edged by a tasselled fringe secured by dome-headed brass nails.  Braid attached to the back uprights has a matching fringe but no tassels.  The original widely spaced webbing, canvas back panel and stuffing are still in place.

Medium/Materials: mahogany with padouk crossbanding; pine, oak
Description: Of serpentine-fronted design; the lower stage contains four long drawers, the top one, which pulls out on divided corner trusses, is partitioned and fitted with a baize covered writing-slide having a flap over the central well and sliding pen trays with d
WebDescription:
This spectacular cabinet relates to a family of high quality rococo furniture embellished with brass-inlay and a distinctive repertoire of gilt brass mounts christened the 'nymph and satyr' group. In terms of overall design the closed analogy is a mahogany writing cabinet which also incorporates storage space in the thickness of the doors and is profusely enriched with brass-inlay but displays carved corner ornaments rather than luxurious mounts. 

The inlaid decoration reflects a slightly old-fashioned, Continental baroque style characteristic of Jean Berain, although no engraved source for the ornament has yet been identified. The gilt brass mounts seem to be related to rococo modelling on silver of the late 1730s and early 40s, and early designs by Cuvilles or the work of Kandler could have inspired certain elements. Dr. Charles Avery has established that the brass Bacchus figure on the cabinet was cast from a bronze which the Florentine sculptor, Massimiliano Soldani supplied to the Prince of Liechtenstein in 1702; he believes that both statuettes are based on Soldani bronzes after antique and 'old master' models.

Old Ochtertyre House, Perthshire, was demolished and rebuilt in the neo-classical taste by Sir William Murray, 1784-90. Household inventories of 1763, 1800 and 1861 survive (N. L. S. Murray of Ochtertyre papers) but contain no record of this writing cabinet, so the Murray's may have inherited rather than commissioned it.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall. A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III, (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund

Medium/Materials: walnut and beech, Yorkshire broadcloth (a woollen twill) embroidered with wool
Dimensions:
object height: 40 in. (101.6 cm)
object width: 20 1/2 in. (52.1 cm)
object depth: 19 in. (48.3 cm)
Description: Beech inner frame, corner braces and back legs stained to match the walnut front legs which are of cabriole form designed with a lappet behind the knees and raised edges; pad front and plain club rear feet.  The solid rectangular back and the seat are cov
WebDescription:
This chair is in a remarkably untouched condition all the basic and primary upholstery materials surviving.  The back is much better preserved than the extensively repaired seat.  The 21 in. wide broadcloth has a blue stripe in the selvedge and the webbing is stitched with a square outline.  One of four, the others having been stripped of their original upholstery.  The late Nancy Lancaster owned an identical chair and there is another privately owned example.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Made in the manner of a traditional beehive from coiled ropes of straw bound with bramble peelings; the circular seat is supported on a slightly splayed hollow skirt built-up of thick straw bands; the rounded back is similarly fashioned and has internal a
WebDescription:
This chair is made from coiled ropes of straw.  This method was traditionally used to make straw beehives!   The straw base was lined with a layer of fur, and then covered with striped cotton ticking fabric.  
Chairs of this type are particularly associated with East Anglia.  They were used in many country houses in the early nineteenth century.  Mrs Webster's Family Encyclopaedia, c.1836, stated "The beehive chair made of straw, has long been used in Wales and Scotland, as well as some places in the north of England; but it is only of late that they have appeared among our fashionable furniture.  They are, however, warm and cheap, and are admired by some persons for their simple, homely and snug appearance".

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund

Description: Rectangular with tower corners and straight rounded legs on pad feet, ornamented at the knees with lappets; a fifth leg swings out on an oak fly-rail. The first flap, supported when open on a hinged prop, provides a plain table top; the second flap, which
WebDescription:
This is an interesting 'three decker' games table in that it combines so many functions, being designed for taking tea, playing cards, chess or backgammon and even serving as a desk. The survival of the loose frame or fixing on top when playing backgammon is a bonus, but the 'men' have disappeared. A certain clumsiness, and a lack of technical sophistication, choice of secondary timbers and the history of this table suggest a provincial origin.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Of break-sided design, the rectangular leather-lined top enriched with a tooled and gilt border; the frieze is fitted on each side, with one long and two short drawers, the central ones formerly partitioned; the front contains three drawers in each pedest
WebDescription:
This table is recorded in the Library at Temple Newsam in an inventory of 1808 (Y.A.S. DD54) 'a large mahogany library table with carved mouldings and doors and shelves on one side and drawers on the other and covered with green cloth'. About thirty years later an amateur watercolourist depicted the interior of the Library, in which this table is clearly recognisable. The Library is a richly styled architectural room created by York craftsmen in 1744-5, probably to designs by Daniel Garrett. The rhythm and detailing of the table are so closely allied to decorative features in this interior that Garrett may even have designed the table himself. Both on historical and stylistic grounds there are good reasons to attribute the library table to William Hallett; Arthur, 6th Viscount Irwin of Temple Newsam, is his earliest recorded patron having commissioned a number of pieces from the firm in 1735 for his London house ('Connoisseur', Dec. 1964, pp.224-5), the table also bears interesting affinities with the only known piece of cabinet furniture signed by Hallett, including identical lifting handles of a ribbed swag pattern (Gilbert, 'Pictorial Dictionary, fig.463). 

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Dimensions:
object height: 92 in. (233.7 cm)
object length: 75 in. (190.5 cm)
object depth: 42 in. (106.7 cm)
Description: The arched canopy is supported on four posts with a bare pine headboard housed in a groove between squared uprights; the upper parts of the footposts are decorated with a carved acanthus frond, cable twist and ring-turning; the bed bolts are concealed by
WebDescription:
This single bed still has its original summer hangings and quilt of printed cotton.  The canopy above the bed is known as a "tester".  Often the curtains and canopy were made all in one piece, but this bed might have had separate curtains which have since gone.  It has recently been hung with cotton muslin curtains.
The bed came from North Shields, Northumberland, and was described in a will of 1848 as a "four post Bedstead, Straw and Hair mattress with blue hangings, large feather bed bolster and six pillows".  This type of bed was quite common at the time. Often the curtains and canopy were made all in one piece, but it is possible that this bed had separate curtains which have since been lost.

Households in the North East clearly regarded beds as an important status symbol, so this example is a valuable social document which also reflects a strong local quilting tradition.

C. Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall. A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes. Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collection Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Of rectangular form fronted by double doors raised on a low stand; veneered with coromandel lacquer featuring incised painted and gilt designs on a black ground. The top, faded to a nut brown, displays an exotic landscape with water, rocks, boats, buildin
WebDescription:
Oak carcase, faced with coromandel lacquer cut from a screen and walnut veneers. The top displays an exotic landscape with water, rocks, boats, buildings and traveller, framed by a moulded pine edge; the door panels are in-cut with coloured vases of flowers, a bowl of fruit, a sun and moon, etc. between upper and lower borders of incised stylised dragons, seals, flowers and tendrils; one end panel depicts fashionable (headless) ladies walking in a garden, the other, clouds against a green tiled roof.

Stalker & Parker in their 'Treatise on Japanning and Varnishing', 1688, in the section on Bantam work had this to say: '... tis now almost obsolete, and out of fashion, out of use and neglected... I think no person is fond of it, or gives it house-room, except some who have made new Cabinets out of old Skreens. And from that large old piece, by the help of a Joyner, make little ones, such as Stands or Table, but never consider the situation of their figures; so that in these things so torm and hacked to joint a new fancie, you may observe the finest hodgpodg and medly of Men and Trees turned topsie turvie, and instead of marching by Land you shall see them taking journeys through the Air... Such irregular pieces as these can never certainly be acceptable.'

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Of rectangular design with a plain frieze, cabriole legs ending in pad feet and brass castors. The central section of the top is divided into two hinged slides which open to reveal a well fitted with a loose tray which, by means of brass catches, can be e
WebDescription:
This table corresponds to one of 15 diminutive designs for ingenious mechanical furniture featured on an advertisement sheet signed 'Potter/London' (V&A E.2320-1889). This may well be Thomas Potter, recorded as a cabinet maker in High Holborn in 1737, who, as the partner of John Kelsey supplied furniture to Sir Richard Colt Hoare for Barn Elms in 1738. When breakfast was finished the tray, holding china and leftovers could, by the release of the two catches, be conveniently lowered into the framing and the two flaps slid across so that the table top was available for reading, writing or work. This functional arrangement neatly avoided the alternative practice of clearing the table top by placing leftover food etc. in a lattice cupboard below.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Designed as two-handled classical vases which split above friezes depicting a Triumph cast in low-relief; the circular bases are set on low tripods with anthemion ornament and paw feet; elaborately scrolled handles featuring obelisks and free-hanging pend
WebDescription:
This type of lamp was described in the 1845 'Supplement' to the 'Penny Cyclodaedia', p.204 '... in this reservoir is a kind of piston or plunger, worked up and down by a nut and screw from the outside; the rising of this piston occasions the pressure or tightening of a coiled central tube towards the flame. The admission and regulation of the oil to the lamp, the adjustment of the wick, the arrangement of the air holes for admitting draught are all of an intricate kind, and, whatever may be their efficiency while in good order would render the repair, in case of damage a serious matter.'

The 1867 Paris Exhibition, 'Art Journal' volume, illustrates this lamp on p.42 with the comment: 'M. M. Schlossmacher & Co., Paris, manufacturers of Lamps, Chandeliers, Candelabra, &c., mainly, however, they exert their resources to obtain superiority in the production of LAMPS for the table. They are designed both as to form and ornamentation, by accomplished artists of France. Those we engrave have been selected from a large and varied collection - all of great merit.'

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Title Sort: The Finding of Moses (one of pair)
Dimensions:
object height: 3556.01mm (140 in.)
object width: 3810.01mm (150 in.)
Description: The tapestries are said to have been the gift of the Prince of Wales, later George IV, to the elderly Viscountess Irwin and her daughter Lady Hertford on his visit to Temple Newsam in 1806.  It was around this time that the Prince began his friendship wit
WebDescription:
The tapestries are said to have been the gift of the Prince of Wales, later George IV, to the elderly Viscountess Irwin and her daughter Lady Hertford on his visit to Temple Newsam in 1806.  It was around this time that the Prince began his friendship with Lady Hertford which was to be the (unjustified) subject of much popular satire and scandal.

The subjects are taken from the Life of Moses; up to eight or nine different scenes could be ordered, either separately or as a complete series, from the workshops of the weavers, the van der Borchts in Brussels.  The cartoons were probably designed by Jan van Orley (1665-1735) (figures) and Augustin Coppens (1668-1740) (landscapes).  Van Orley perhaps worked from his brother Richard's book illustrations for the 1701 Brussels edition of Josephus' "L'Histoire des Juifs", themselves probably influenced by a set of Moses tapestries woven at the Gobelins factory after designs by Poussin and Le Brun.

So far the earliest recorded tapestries from the van Orley cartoons are the five woven by Frans and Pieter van der Borcht for the Stadhuys in Maastricht in 1737-38 (two years after van Orley's death).  The most complete set appears to be the six in the Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna.

The cartoons were passed down through various members of the van der Borcht family to Jacob the Younger who died in 1794.  It is unclear when the Temple Newsam pair were woven but the unusual border design suggests an early date during the life of the cartoons.  Another tapestry with the same border is known with a scene derived from Teniers.

The Battle of the Israelites and the Amalekites took place during the Exodus from Egypt when:
"...it came to pass, when Moses held up his hand, that Israel prevailed.  But Moses' hands were heavy; and they took a stone, and put it under him, and he sat thereon; and Aaron and Hur stayed up his hands, the one on the side, and the other on the other side; and his hands were steady until the going down of the sun.  And Joshua discomfited Amalek and his people with the edge of the sword."

The tapestries have hung in the Terrace Room probably since 1806, but certainly since 1827 when the room was re-decorated.  Originally they had heavy oak and gilt frames (later re-used as picture frames elsewhere in the house) which probably also surrounded panels of pink silk moire in the chimney alcoves and above the doors.  In 1922 they were removed by Lord Halifax who hung them at the Foreign Office and later at the Embassy in Washington.  He sold them to the antique dealers Frank Partridge & Sons in New York in 1945 who subsequently attempted to sell them at Sotheby's in 1961.  After vanishing without trace they re-appeared at the sale of Stackallan House, Co Meath, in October 1992, from where they were bought for Temple Newsam.

object width: 76 cm (29 15/16 in.)
object depth (closed): 38 cm (14 15/16 in.)
Description: Rectangular triple-flap top with moulded edges, rounded corners and a wide crossbanded border; one leg swings out to support the open flaps, the first serving as a tea or card table, the second providing a leather-covered writing surface with an oblong ri
WebDescription:
The design for this table features amongst an anthology of ingenious mechanical furniture depicted on an advertisement sheet signed 'Potter/London' (V&A E.2320-1889). The engraving is in the style of M. Darly. In 1738 Thomas Potter and his partner, John Kelsey of Holborn, invoiced Sir Richard Colt Hoare for a bed table which is likely to have been hinged and ratcheted in a manner akin to the items illustrated in Potter's advertisement. The name 'Harlequin; derives from the 'Comedia del Arte's' master of disguises.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Long spiral-twist handle, plain stock with turnover bristles.
WebDescription:
Signs of wear on the stock suggest this broom is old and not an example of fanciful Victorian design. There is a similar example at Cotehele, Cornwall.

For more information please see 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Christopher Gilbert, Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Long flat handle, the stock set with a single row of black bristles. The shaft is impressed: MADE BY (?) DURAS & CO LONDON PATENT.'
WebDescription:
Wall brush with a long flat handle and a single row of bristles. This type of brush was used for dusting behind furniture, pictures, radiators, etc. 

For more information please see 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Christopher Gilbert, Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Of rectangular design with an arched top and rope border; the panel centres on a high-relief figure of a bushy-tailed fox with a halo seated on a bible, to his left is a fir tree lettered 'SILVA'. Incised in the casting 'C of A' and dated 'MCMXCIII'. Two
WebDescription:
Specially designed for the spectacular heraldic chimney piece in the Victorian dining room at Temple Newsam. The design commemorates Edward Frederick Lindley Wood, 3rd Viscount Halifax (1881-1959) the last private owner of Temple Newsam, a prominent Anglo-Catholic, nicknamed by churchmen the 'Holy Fox'.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the Public Art Collections Fund.

Medium/Materials: cast metal, plated with brass and gilded
Description: The campana-shaped cisterns, each ornamented with three Bacchic masks and 'thyrsi', are set on cylindrical bodies ornamented with satyr masks and lotus, supporting twin arms terminating in frosted glass shades etched and wheel-cut with flowers and grapes.
WebDescription:
The campana-shaped cisterns, each ornamented with three Bacchic masks and 'thyrsi', and set on cylindrical bodies ornamented with satyr masks and lotus, supporting twin arms terminating in frosted glass shades etched and wheel-cut with flowers and grapes. The lamps are raised on three leopard monopodia standing on circular stepped plinths. Original oil feed tubes, sleeve regulators, wick adjustment rings and overflow cups survive.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Dimensions:
40 9/16 x 50 13/16 x 22 7/16 in. (103 x 129 x 57 cm)
object height (Splash back): 43 cm (16 15/16 in.)
object length (Splash back): 114 cm (44 7/8 in.)
Description: Rectangular, with a high back supporting a shelf and profiled returns, two frieze drawers with finger-grips cut into the front rail, tapering octagonal legs headed by ring-turning and ending in brass socket castors; towel-rail on brackets at the left side
WebDescription:
Rectangular, with a high back supporting a shelf and profiled returns, two frieze drawers with finger-grips cut into the front rail, tapering octagonal legs headed by ring-turning and ending in brass socket castors; towel-rail on brackets at the left side. The backboard of one drawer inscribed 'Back' in pencil.

Acquired with a wicker SPLASH BACK (c.1900) of rectangular design with an arched top, the field woven in horizontal bands with a wide border and decorative edging. A lifting loop and pair of metal brackets missing.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Of rectangular design, in the form of a commode cabinet with a base plinth, low gallery round three sides of the top and pilasters. Fitted with a cupboard, the door fronted as a panelled drawer with turned oak knobs, above a matching commode drawer, which
WebDescription:
Of rectangular design, in the form of a commode cabinet with a base plinth, low gallery round three sides of the top and pilasters. Fitted with a cupboard, the door fronted as a panelled drawer with turned oak knobs, above a matching commode drawer, which pulls forward on castors, housing a creamware vase beneath a baize-lined seat and circular cover.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Medium/Materials: Beech with rosewood graining, worsted furnishing cloth with looped braid
Description: Rectangular frame with gabled head and footboards set between block-turned posts bridged by crossbars which support single head and footposts carrying a canopy with rounded corners.  The fronded two-tone yellow striped worsted furniture, trimmed with loop
WebDescription:
This bed is noted in the Princess Dressing Room in Raby Castle in an inventory of 1842. It is an unusual design with the canopy supported by single head and footposts fixed to the crossbars of a rectangular frame. 

For more information please see C. Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton. A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes. Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Sons Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Plain headboards between square uprights, blocked footposts with ring-turning, ball finials and stump feet; corded canvas bottoms woven with blue and orange stripes, tensioning bar at the head, the rails and posts united by bed bolts; lignum vitae castors
WebDescription:
These examples from Raby Castle are thought to come from the footmen's bedroom. They belong to virtually the last generation of wood and sacking servant beds' before cheap iron frames became widely popular. 

For more information please see C. Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall. A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes. Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collection Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: Plain headboards between square uprights, blocked footposts with ring-turning, ball finials and stump feet; corded canvas bottoms woven with blue and orange stripes, tensioning bar at the head, the rails and posts united by bed bolts; lignum vitae castors
WebDescription:
These examples from Raby Castle are thought to come from the footmen's bedroom. They belong to virtually the last generation of wood and sacking servant beds' before cheap iron frames became widely popular.

Description: The campana-shaped reservoirs have domed covers, floral and foliate ornament around the bodies and are set on tubular supports with single arms terminating in burners with pendant drip cups, spiral-grooved wick carriages and cast-leaf shade supports; the
WebDescription:
These handsome Regency lamps are in remarkably intact condition retaining all the oil-burning mechanisms, together with the original lacquered finish simulating bronze.

For more informaiton please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Medium/Materials: Mainly oak; cotton, gilt carving on a white ground
Dimensions:
object height: 310 cm (122 1/16 in.)
object width: 183 cm (72 1/16 in.)
object length: 214 cm (84 1/4 in.)
Description: Of rectangular design; the canopy frames an oval panel of chintz and radiating ribs backed by crimson silk; guilloche cornices, centring on crossed ribbon-tied laurel-spray tablets, with flower head corners; the square panelled posts, carved with pendant
WebDescription:
This richly styled bed, together with an en suite white and gold wardrobe, chest of drawers, pedestal cupboard and matching chintz case covers, was installed very soon after the Prince of Wales stayed at Temple Newsam in 1868. It can be seen as an upgrading of facilities, at a strategically placed country house just outside Leeds, specifically to cater for rail borne Royal visitors. For a visit of the Duke and Duchess of York in 1894 the bed was moved into the South Bedroom where it is shown in a contemporary photograph. The counterpane may be part of the original bed-furniture.

For more information please see Christopher Gilbert, 'Furniture at Temple Newsam House and Lotherton Hall, A catalogue of the Leeds collection in three volumes, Volume III', (1998), Published by the Leeds Art Collections Fund and W. S. Maney and Son Ltd in association with the National Art Collections Fund.

Description: The inscribed square base supports a raised circular foot with chased flutes and a short stem with a knop of further chased flutes, leaves and beading.  The amphora shaped cup has a raised body and neck.  The lower part has embossed and chased stiff leave
WebDescription:
The cup is an exact but reduced replica of the celebrated 'Buckingham Vase', the famous 46 inch high antique marble vase excavated from Hadrian's Villa near Rome by Gavin Hamilton in 1769.  The taste for exact replicas or adaptations of famous antique for modern uses is one of the most characteristic features of Regency silver.  Barnards produced a large number of wine coolers based on the Buckingham Vase and their working drawings show alternative designs for the handles-vine tendrils, or serpents (as here).

The mark on this cup represents the partnership of Rebeccah Emes and Edward Barnard Senior.  The former was the widow of John Emes who died in 1808 whereupon she went into partnership with her husband's former manager Edward Barnard senior until 1829.  Barnard had been apprenticed to Charles Wright and Thomas Chawner before working for Emes.  The firm supplied all the Doncaster Gold Cups between 1821 and 1829, and their Day Book for 10 February 1830 records that they sold '9 Fin'd drawings of Doncaster Cups 1821 to 1829, inclusive to Philip Bright, the retailer in Doncaster High Street, for 4-10s.'

For more information please see James Lomax 'British Silver at Temple Newsam and Lotherton Hall' (1992), Leeds Art Collections Fund

Description: Half-lenght portrait of Arthur, 3rd Earl of Halifax.
WebDescription: This portrait of Arthur, third Viscount Irwin (ticket no. 267) can be seen in the Crimson Bedroom at Temple Newsam House. There are also portraits of his wife Isabella, Viscountess Irwin (nee Machel) (ticket no. 133) and another portrait of Arthur, third Viscount (ticket no. 118) in the Crimson Bedroom and Picture Gallery respectively.  The portrait of Arthur in the Picture Gallery by Leonard Knyff was painted in 1700 at a cost of 30 guineas and gives an indication of the pleasure Arthur took in sports.  However, in addition to sporting and gambling Arthur also under took public duties as an MP twice for Scarborough and as Vice- Admiral for Yorkshire with responsibility for press gangs.  Isabella was the intelligent, sophisticated and accomplished heiress of John Machel of Hills, Sussex.  She also brought two parliamentary seats for Horsham to the marriage thus establishing the political power base for the family that lasted until 1832.  Letters from Arthur to Isabella indicate that theirs was a marriage of affection and during their 16 years together they produced nine sons.   Seven sons survived infancy five of whom succeeded each other as Viscounts.  In order these were; Edward of which there are two portraits  (ticket nos 263 and 269) in the Crimson Bedroom, Rich who married Lady Anne Howard of which there are portraits (ticket nos 265 and 110) in the Crimson Bedroom and Picture Gallery respectively, Arthur of which there is a portrait in the Great Hall, Henry who married Anne Scarborough of whom there is a joint portrait (ticket no. 126) in the Picture Gallery, and George of whom there can also be found a portrait (ticket no. 268) in the Crimson Bedroom.  However, a male heir was provided by a younger son, Charles who like his brother John was never a Viscount.  A portrait of Charles (ticket no. 196) can be found in the State Dressing Room.  All the portraits can be seen at Temple Newsam House.

Title Sort: Portrait of Thomas Oliver Gascoigne R.H.G.
Description: Half length, wearing uniform of the Royal Horse Guards; head turned to the spectator's right.
WebDescription:
This portrait currently hangs in the Dining Room at Lotherton. A label on the frame reads ?THOMAS OLIVER GASCOIGNE/R.H.G/1827?, and although this could have been added later, the picture is thought to date to 1826-1827. The oil on canvas painting (British school) shows Thomas Oliver Gascoigne (1806-1842) at half-length wearing the swagger uniform of the Royal Horse Guards. The Prince Regent (later George IV) had put them into this uniform after the Battle of Waterloo (1815), which he imagined he had won himself.
 
Thomas was the eldest son of Richard Oliver Gascoigne (d.1843) of Parlington Hall, who bought Lotherton in 1825. Richard was very wealthy and gave his son the best possible start to a career in army by purchasing him an officer?s commission in the Royal Horse Guard. However, Thomas never saw active service and predeceased his father in 1842. The following year Lotherton passed to his sisters Mary Isabella (1810-1891) and Elizabeth (1812-1893).
